Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: This Skipper is found on the eastern side of the country, from Port St. Johns, north-eastwards, while it spreads, in Rhodesia, as far as the Victoria Falls, and, on this account, Dr. Pinhey thinks it would be found in the Kasane area of Botswana. In Durban and its neighbourhood it is still of frequent occurrence. Two seasonal forms are found in Durban and its neighborhood, form mackenii and form denia. From aurifrons and nyassicola are found in Rhodesia and Mocambique.
Abundance: This Skipper is a very common insect in the coastal bush and rain forests of the eastern side of the country, from Port St. Johns, north-eastwards. In Durban and its neighbourhood it is still of frequent occurrence.
Habitat: This Skipper inhabits coastal bush and rain forests.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Different forms of this Skipper fly in the wet-season and dry-season.
Adult.forms: Two seasonal forms of this Skipper are found in Durban and its neighbourhood- form mackenii, the dry-season form, and form denia Evans (1937), the wet-season form. In Rhodesia and Mocambique the forms differ slightly- form aurifrons Strand (1920), being the dry-season form, and form nyassicola Strand (1920) the wet-season form. The difference between mackenii and ploetzi, lies in the underside of the forewing, which in ploetzi is broadly whitish along the inner margin.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Distribution.Range: Ssp. olaus  flies from Senegal to Nigeria, Cameroun, Central African Republic, the DRC, southern Sudan, Rwanda, and Burundi.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Field Guide: Butterflies of Southern Africa
Common.name: Marsh Skipper, Macken's Skipper
Distribution.Range: This species is found in the Eastern Cape, Natal, Transvaal, Mashonaland, and Moҫambique, and ranges to equatorial Africa.
Habitat: This species inhabits swampy spots in forest or thick bush, or undergrowth near forest streams.
Adult.forms: This species is dark brown with white fringe on the hindwing, with, sometimes, or without a few white spots on the middle of the forewing, which are duller or fainter in the male than in the female. There are numerous varieties.
Author: anne.lott
Full.Species.Account: Acleros mackenii (Trimen, 1868) Marsh Skipper, Macken’s Skipper (plate 42) Dark brown with white fringe on hindwing; with, sometimes, or without a few white spots on middle of forewing, which are duller or fainter in male than in female. Underside of hindwing brown in outer half, this area sharply demarcated from a white basal half which is speckled with brown. There are numerous varieties. Forewing 0.5—0.55". Named after M. J. M’Ken. Swampy spots in forest or thick bush or on undergrowth near forest streams. Eastern Cape, Natal, Transvaal, Mashonaland, Moҫambique; to equatorial Africa.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Macken's Dusky Dart
Distribution.Range: Macken’s Dusky Dart has been found in Senegal, Guinea, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Volta, Togo, southern Nigeria, and the Cross River loop. I found it in Korup as well. This butterfly was seen at Wli Falls in Volta. Ssp. olaus as used here flies from Senegal to Nigeria, Cameroun, Central African Republic, the DRC, southern Sudan, Rwanda, and Burundi. Ssp. instabilis flies from parts of the DRC to Uganda, Kenya, and Ethiopia, with the nominate subspecies in southern Africa.
Abundance: Though not always common, I have on a couple of occasions seen amazing numbers of this butterfly, especially at Wli Falls in Volta in January 1996.
Habitat: Macken's Dusky Dart is a forest butterfly that pushes to the frontier of its habitat and is able to adapt to a fair amount of habitat degradation.
Hostplant.larval.food: There are records of the larva of this species from an unidentified Fabaceae (Larsen 1991), Rhus (Anacardiaceae), and Acridocarpus (Malpighiaceae).
Adult.food: Males are fond of bird-droppings and both sexes come to flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Though not always common, I have on a couple of occasions seen amazing numbers of this butterfly, especially at Wli Falls in Volta in January 1996.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: Eggs and larvae were recorded from Durban.
Oviposition: The egg is laid singly on the underside of a leaf.
Hostplant.larval.food: The egg shell is not eaten after the larva emerges, but the larva bites away much of the upper surface of the egg before it emerges. The larvae feed on the edges of leaves.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Eggs hatch after 9 to 11 days. In the 1st instar the larva grows from 2 to 4 mm in 8 days. In the 2nd instar the larva grows from 4 to 7 mm in 8 days. In the 3rd instar the larva grows from 7 to 11.5 mm in 8 days. In the 4th instar the larva grows from 11.5 to 18 mm in 13 days. Instars may be of shorter or longer duration than is recorded above. Emergence of the adult from the pupa after 21 or 22 days. The species is multi-brooded. This insect appears throughout the year.
Defense.strategies: Larvae construct a cache by joining a leaf or leaves together but young larvae partly bite away and turn down a portion of a leaf, attaching it to the under-side of the same leaf (as observed in the field, in the case of the 1st and 2nd instar larvae). They crawl out at intervals to feed on the edge of a leaf. Moulting and pupation take place within a cache. The pupa resembles a crumpled leaf, and is difficult to detect.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Distribution.Range: Port Moresby area (CeP)...Australia
Ant.associations: Labels on some specimens of Arhopala madytus in the KONE collection state that they were collected in the Port Moresby area (CeP) whilst perching in the company of Arhopala arta and Arhopala micale on nests of the ant Oecophylla smaragdina.
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus ARHOPALA Boisduval, 1932 This very large genus ranges throughout the Indo-Australian Region, from Afghanistan, Sri Lanka and India to China, Korea and Japan, and through South-east Asia and Indonesia to NG, northern Australia and the Solomons. Evans (1957) recorded that 187 species were classified under the Arhopala group. However, the number of species is now probably more accurately stated as being over 200 because, as predicted by Corbet (1946), new Arhopala species have since been discovered and various taxa are now considered to be distinct, not merely races of certain species (e.g. see below). Large numbers of species exist, especially in India, Burma, Malaya and NG. For example, Corbet and Pendlebury (1978) recorded over 108 species in Malaya, and about 40 species are, to date, known from PNG, many of which also occur in Irian Jaya. A further 2 species present in Irian Jaya are not yet known from PNG. Only 4 species occur in Australia, all of which also occur in NG. The type species for Arhopala is phryxus Boisduval, 1832, designated by Butler, 1875. Hemming (1967: 58) discussed, in detail, the nomenclature relating to this species. Arhopala is predominantly a lowland genus. Corbet (1946) found that, of the 82 Malayan species known at the time, only 8 (10%) did not exist below 820 m, whilst 63 (77%) were not found above this altitude. In PNG, nearly all species occur at, or down to, elevations little above sea level. However, only arta has been recorded as high as about 1,600 m. Five species apparently range up to 50 m elevation, 8 to 200 m, 9 to 500 m, 9 to 800 m, 2 to 1,000 m, and 6 to 1,200 m. Thus, as in Malaya, 77% of Arhopala in PNG do not occur above about 800 m. Corbet noted that Malayan Arhopala are practically confined to primary forest, although he also observed that, in northern Malaya and Burma, some species frequent secondary vegetation. The latter is the prevailing habitat type for Arhopala in NG. Corbet pointed out that all Arhopala species, except A. centaurus, are rare in Malaya, especially in the north. In PNG, most Arhopala species can be classed as rare generally, but occasional to common locally. Bethune-Baker (1903a) published the first comprehensive revision of Arhopala and this contains useful text, figures and colour plates. The most recent revision of Arhopala is still that of Evans (1957), who treated the genus as 5 separate genera and listed Iois Doherty, 1889, as a synonym of Arhopala (sensu Evans, 1957). However, recent authors, such as Corbet and Pendlebury (1978), D’Abrera (1978) and Common and Waterhouse (1981), have all preferred to follow Corbet (1946) who treated all species listed by Evans as belonging to the single genus Arhopala. This arrangement is also employed here. Therefore, the following must all be regarded as being synonyms of Arhopala: Mahathala Moore, 1878; Narathura and Thaduka Moore, 1879; Nilasera Moore, 1881; Panchaia Moore, 1882; Apporasa, Satadra, Darasana and Acesina Moore, 1884; Flos Doherty, 1889; Aurea Evans, 1957. Nevertheless, these taxa were retained at the genus level by Eliot (1973), who treated Arhopala under the tribe Arhopalini Bingham, 1907. The use of the generic name Amblypodia Horsfield, 1929 (which is currently applied to a separate group of butterflies, e.g. A. annetta: see Genus Amblypodia), instead of Arhopala, was clarified in detail by Evans (1957: 133). Arhopala range from fairly small to medium-sized species (lycaenids that are, therefore, large, considering the family as a whole). Throughout their range their undersides are predominantly cryptically mottled with brown, but a few NG species are obviously mimetic of unrelated, more brightly patterned lycaenids (see Chapter 8). The adults are robustbodied, strong-winged lycaenids which usually bear a short, curved HW tail at the end of vein CuA2, although this is completely absent in some species. Some species also possess a hindwing tornal lobe which usually bears a black eye-spot. A weaker black eye-spot may also be present above the base of the tail. The area between these is often iridescent pale blue, the extent of this usually being very individually variable. The Arhopala male lacks sex-brands, but species are usually fairly sexually dimorphic. The male upperside is usually extensively mauve or iridescent blue, with narrow dark brown margins. The female is duller, with less extensive, duller blue upperside scaling and much broader dark brown margins, and the underside is usually paler than that of the male. Most Arhopala tend to resemble one another. However, their underside patterns are generally a good guide to identifying taxa as these vary from species to species, but are usually almost identical in both sexes. As pointed out by Corbet (1946), Evans (1957) and Corbet and Pendlebury (1978), Arhopala male genitalia are all very similar and so are not very helpful in making species determinations (a condition analogous to that of Delias of the Pieridae). The genitalia of some Arhopala species are also somewhat variable. Corbet and Pendlebury suggested that frequent natural hybridisations might occur in Malaysian Arhopala, which would add to the confusion regarding their taxonomy. However, this has not been observed in PNG species. Another problem in the identification of species in ‘difficult’ species groups (such as the centaurus species group covered in this work) is that they are also phenotypically variable, often to quite a degree, so that some forms of each species tend to resemble each other. This variability is often manifested at both the regional and local level. For example, the hue of the upperside blue or mauve ground colour in males, and the width of their dark brown wing margins, often varies in this way, as do the widths of the underside markings in both sexes. Where species exhibit such variability then an attempt has been made to illustrate the main forms. The Arhopala eye is naked and the antenna has a gradual cylindrical club with more than 40 segments. The labial palpus is clothed with appressed scales and bears a short apical segment. The male foreleg tarsus is fused into a single segment, which is more or less stubby-tipped, but which is often slightly recurved, and briefly, but bluntly, pointed. The forewing bears 11 veins. Veins Mj and R5 are separate, and M2 arises much closer to M1 than M4. Adult Arhopala are all very similar in their habits. They rest for much of the time, wings folded, on the uppersides of the leaves of marginal vegetation from 2-8 m above ground. They are, therefore, very difficult to see because of their cryptic brown undersides. Only when disturbed are the brilliant blue uppersides of the adults seen. The flashing coloration and very rapid flight makes them difficult to follow with the eye. If disturbed, they usually quickly take flight and settle out of reach on higher perches, facing head downwards in order to survey the area below them. Corbet and Pendlebury (1978) noted that, when the sun disappears, adults often leave their lower perches and fly up into the forest canopy. However, they also pointed out that, as evening approaches, some species become more active and take up favoured positions on the forest margin or in clearings, from where they dart at great speed on repeated excursions which always follow the same route. It is notable in PNG (and possibly, therefore, elsewhere), that Arhopala adults exhibit interspecific gregarious behaviour which may be protective in function (on the basis of ‘safety in numbers’: see Chapter 8). For example, in the Bulolo area (MoP) often up to 3 Arhopala species (e.g. chamaeleona, leander and philander), numbering several adults of each species, may be observed in certain areas using the same perching trees. The trees are apparently not utilised as larval foodplants, although the foodplants doubtless occur nearby. Labels on some specimens of Arhopala madytus in the KONE collection state that they were collected in the Port Moresby area (CeP) whilst perching in the company of Arhopala arta and Arhopala micale on nests of the ant Oecophylla smaragdina. Common and Waterhouse (1981) pointed out that madytus is found in the “same situations” as A. micale and A. eupolis in Australia. The early stages of a number of Arhopala species in the centaurus species group have been well documented and illustrated by various authors (e.g. Bell, 1919). They are all very similar to each other in PNG. Good colour plates of Arhopala early stages from Japan are included in Shirozu and Hara (1973). The larvae and pupae of many Arhopala species are known to be attended by Oecophylla smaragdina, the kurukum, tailor, or green tree ant (e.g. PI. 122). These and other ants ‘milk’ nectarlike secretions from the prominent dorsal organ of Arhopala larvae (e.g. PI. 123.3154). Arhopala larvae are extremely slow- moving. Mature larvae constaict loose shelters by silking together portions of the leaves of their foodplants, inside which they rest concealed. They feed on young leaves of trees in several different families, especially the oaks (Fagaceae). Evans (1957) divided the ‘Arhopala group’ into 16 natural groups. These are convenient species-group divisions and so are employed here. However, Eliot (1972) demonstrated that, on the basis of its external facies and male genitalia, Arhopala ate Hewitson, 1863, does not belong in the hercules species group as Evans had treated it, but in the democritus species group under the cleander subgroup. For similar reasons Arhopala antharita is here removed from Evans’ eumolphus species group to his anthelus species group, alongside its nearest relative Arhopala auxesia salvia. 8 species groups occur in PNG: anthelus, hercules, democritus, eumolphus, centaurus, fulla, thamyras and critala. The thamyras group was treated under the genus Arhopala (sensu Evans, 1957) and is here termed thamyras, from the oldest-named species in the group. Evans (1957) did not mention the 2 species of the critala group as they were not recognised as belonging to Arhopala at the time because of their very accurate mimicry of species in the lycaenid genus Danis (see Chapter 8). Only the fulla group in PNG contains species which all lack hindwing tails.

Book: Butterflies of Australia: their identification, biology and distribution
Hostplant.larval.food: feed on species in a wide range of plant genera from many families, including the Anacardiaceae, Boraginaceae, Chrysobalanaceae, Clusiaceae, Combretaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Lauraceae, Loranthaceae,  Lythraceae, Malvaceae, Meliaceae, Myrtaceae, Sapindaceae, Sterculiaceae and Verbenaceae
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Genus Arhopala Boisduval, 1832 This genus comprises many species distributed from India, Sri Lanka, China, Korea and Japan, through South-east Asia to New Guinea, northern Australia and the Solomon Islands. It is very species rich in India, Burma, Malaysia and New Guinea. In the Australian faunal subregion, there are four species, all of which occur in the tropical zone. Larvae of three of these species are phytophagous, feeding on the foliage of many different dicotyledonous plants, and are attended by Oecophylla (Formicinae) ants. The fourth species (A. wildei) is myrmecophagous, its larvae feeding exclusively on immature stages of its attendant ant, Polyrhachis (Formicinae). Two species (A. micale, A. centaurus) in Australia feed on species in a wide range of plant genera from many families, including the Anacardiaceae, Boraginaceae, Chrysobalanaceae, Clusiaceae, Combretaceae, Euphorbiaceae, Lauraceae, Loranthaceae, Lythraceae, Malvaceae, Meliaceae, Myrtaceae, Sapindaceae, Sterculiaceae and Verbenaceae. An unidentified larva has been found on Scolopia (Flacourtiaceae) (P.S. Valentine). It is likely that female oviposition behaviour and larval diet in these species is more dependant on the presence of the attendant ant than on food plant chemistry. Adults are robust, medium sized, usually with a shining blue upperside with black margins and a dull brown underside. In Arhopala, the antenna is relatively short, being less than half the length of the costa of the fore wing; the eye is smooth; the fore wing has 11 veins, with the radial branches R4 and Rs fused into a single vein R4+5; the hind wing has a short curved tail at the end of vein CuA2, and a weakly developed tornal lobe; the male lacks sex-scales.

Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Great Southern White Ascia monuste r Family/Subfamily: Whites and Sulphurs (Pieridae)/ Whites (Pierinae) Wingspan: 1.5-2.5" (3.8-6.4 cm) Above: male is immaculate white with narrow, black scalloped forewing border; female is seasonally vari able; dirty white to gray with more pronounced black forewing border and black forewing cell spot Below: males white with pale yellow hindwings; females dirty white to gray Sexes: similar, although female has more gray scaling and a single black dorsal forewing spot Egg: yellow, laid singly or in small groups on host leaves Larva: yellow with grayish purple longitudinal stripes, black dots and numerous small hairs Larval Host Plants: Virginia Peppergrass, Saltwort, Sea Rocket and others Habitat: open sites including roadsides, coastal dunes, salt marshes, vacant fields, agricultural land Broods: multiple generations Abundance: rare to uncommon Compare: Cabbage White (pg. 379) is smaller and lacks black scalloped forewing border. Comments: The Great Southern White's antennae have a distinctive blue tip. While males are always white, females may be white, gray or an intermediate color. Adults have a low, generally casual flight, but can move swiftly if disturbed. The butterfly occasionally experiences tremendous population outbreaks. Extensive northward movements of adults along the coast often follow such explosions in number.

Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: ASCIA MONUSTE Linnaeus 1764 Great Southern White Pl. 13 Description. Fw [male] and [female] 28-32 mm. Male upperside white, the outer margins with distinctive black wedge-shaped markings centred on the veins. Female upperside white, very pale yellowish or even pale grey, the marginal markings often larger than in the males. Underside white, or with ground colour of hindwing and apex of forewing pale yellow, with or without streaky grey-brown markings on and between the veins and in the cell, and cloudy markings towards the base of spaces 2 and 4. In life the tip of the antenna is turquoise blue. Distribution. A. monuste monuste, described above, only reaches the West Indies in the Lesser Antilles, especially in the Grenadines, Grenada and Barbados. There are, however, two truly indigenous Caribbean subspecies. From the Bahamas through Cuba, Hispaniola and Jamaica to Porto Rico the northern subspecies, A. m. evonima Boisduval 1836 (TL: Cuba) prevails. It is as large as A. m. monuste or even at times larger. On the forewing upperside the marginal wedges are smaller especially towards the apex, particularly in the males, in which the underside is only very rarely pure white, generally pale yellow, especially in specimens with striate grey-brown markings. The females tend to be more heavily striate on the underside; and in the grey migratory form, f. phileta Fabricius, which sometimes spreads to the Antilles from the southern United States, both surfaces may be almost uniformly grey and the striate markings hardly visible. The area between the Virgin Islands and St Vincent is occupied by the much smaller subspecies A. m. virginia Godart 1819, forewing 22-28 mm (TL: not given, taken as St Vincent). It differs markedly in having the marginal black wedges greatly reduced in size or even absent, and the apex of the forewing and the whole of the hindwing on the underside bright ochreous with no trace of striate markings. RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: 'Exteris terris', recte Surinam. [images]Fig. 13. Ascia monuste. a, [male], b, [female] A. m. phileta, migratory form, Nassau, Bahamas, April; c, [male] A. m. virginia, Montserrat, February, d, [female] St Lucia, x 2/3. Early stages. Caterpillar light yellow, with a dark greenish to blackish wide lateral stripe and numerous very small black dots many of which are grouped in subsidiary longitudinal or transverse bands. Food plants Cruciferae, especially Brassica and Cleome, also Tropaeolum.

Phenology.and.voltinism: All year in peninsular Fla., Gulf Coast, and s. Texas.
Adult.forms: Female dimorphic. One form (dry season) similar to male with upperside forewing black more extensive on outer margin, also \with small black spot in cell. Wet-season female almost completely clouded above and below with black scaling.

Full.Species.Account: Baeotis zonata zonata Felder, 1869 FW length: 12.5-13 mm Plate 10 Range: Mexico to Venezuela, Trinidad. Subspecies: Mexico to Venezuela, Ecuador Hostplant: Unknown Early stages: Unknown • Adult: Sexes similar. Upperside pale yellow with broad black wing margins, two yellow sub marginal spots in the black FW margin (one at the tomus), a black medial line that runs from FW costa almost to HW inner margin, a black postmedial spot on HW costa, and another black spot in HW tomus at inner margin that bears a yellow spot. Note: Some specimens may have a slight orange cast, a characteristic that becomes more prominent as this species en ters South America. Compare with nesaea. Habits: In our area this butterfly has been recorded from 400 to 1700 m in association with all forest areas, although it is apparently absent in the Guanacaste dry forest. Encountered on brilliantly sunny days as rare, solitary individuals along forest edges, roadcuts, and rivers. This butterfly has a fast zigzag flight that is reminiscent of many lycaenids. Both sexes are active between 09:30 and 14:00 hrs. Localities: [A]: Atenas (December), San Mateo (December), Guacima (September), Alajuela. [C]: Turrialba (May, August), Cachi. [H]: Chilamate (March, August). [SJ]: San Jose (July), San Pedro (July), Patarra (September), Santa Ana (July), Paso Ancho (March), Desamparados (March). [P]: San Vito (April), Las Alturas (April).

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: Pipevine Swallowtail
Distribution.Range: wide distribution. Our populations are geographically isolated from the main body of the range, which extends from the desert Southwest to the mid-Atlantic states and south through tropical Mexico. DISTRIBUTION: All counties, but breeding only where the h
Abundance: It is abundant in ri parian forest in the Sacramento Valley and locally, mostly in canyons but also in coastal scrub (as in the Marin Headlands), in the Bay Area. seemingly robust populations, there are grounds for concern about its future; it has shown a
Hostplant.larval.food: is also one of our most specialized butterflies, feeding on only one plant species—California pipevine (Aristolochia californica),
Adult.food: Adults nectar eagerly at California buckeye (Aesciilus cnlifornica), yerba santas (Eriodictyon), dogbanes (Apocynum), milk weeds (Asclepias)y thistles (Cirsium, CardiiuSy and Silybuni), and many garden plants. In late summer the sole nectar source in many
Phenology.and.voltinism: large emergence in early spring. When the larvae pupate, some will lay over until next spring; some will hatch without diapause in a couple of weeks; and a few will hatch some time late in summer or in fall. Thus, the spring flight contains individuals fr
Diapause: It overwinters only as a pupa, When the larvae pupate, some will lay over until next spring; some will hatch without diapause in a couple of weeks; and a few will hatch some time late in summer or in fall.
Mimicry: The eggs (brick red), larvae, and adults display warning coloration,
Defense.strategies: All species of pipevines produce to.xic alkaloids called aristolochic acids. These are sequestered by the larva, passed on to the adult, and then transferred by the female to the eggs! The en tire life history is thus protected from vertebrate predators (
Adult.forms: The spring brood averages a little smaller than later ones, with slightly shorter tails and (allegedly) more \hair\" on the body. Otherwise there is almost no variation"

Defense.strategies: . The velvety black lar vae sequester various toxins from their host. These chemicals render the larvae and resulting adults highly distasteful to many predators.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Pipevine Swallowtail Battus philenor Family/Subfamily: Swallowtails (Papilionidae)/ Swallowtails (Papilionlnae) Wingspan: 2.75-4.00" (7.0-10.2 cm) Above: overall black; male has iridescent greenish blue hindwings; female is duller black with a more promi nent row of white spots near the wing margins Below: hindwings are iridescent blue with a row of prominent orange spots Sexes: dissimilar; female is dull black with a more promi nent row of white spots Egg: brownish orange, laid singly or in small clusters Larva: velvety black with orange spots and numerous long, fleshy tubercles Larval Host Plants: various pipevine species, including Dutchman's Pipe, Virginia Snakeroot and Wooly Pipevine Habitat: fields, rich woodlands, stream corridors, gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional to common Compare: Spicebush Swallowtail (pg. 73) is larger with prominent crescent-shaped marginal spots. RedSpotted Purple (pg. 61) lacks hindwing tails. Female Black Swallowtail (pg. 65) is larger with an orange hindwing eyespot. Comments: A relatively small member of the family, the Pipevine Swallowtail nevertheless has a strong, rapid flight. It is particularly abundant throughout the Appalachians. Adults frequently visit flowers but rarely linger at any one blossom for long. They continuously flutter their wings while feeding. The velvety black lar vae sequester various toxins from their host. These chemicals render the larvae and resulting adults highly distasteful to many predators. As a result, several other butterfly species mimic the color pattern of the Pipevine Swallowtail in order to gain protection.

Book: A Field Guide to Eastern Butterflies (Peterson Field Guide Series)
Common.name: Pipevine Swallowtail
Distribution.Range: [image]Davis Mts., Texas S. Canada (Ont.), s. Mich., and New England (rare) west to desert Southwest and south through much of our area to s. Mexico.
Abundance: rare in New England
Flight.characteristics: Flight rapid, wings flutter shallowly. Adults flutter wings rapidly when visiting flowers.
Habitat: Freshly emerged males of patrolling butterflies often taken moisture at sandy or muddy spots near streams or trails. Glades in woods in east, open fields and thorn scrub in west. Sea level to 5000 ft.(1500 m).
Hostplant.larval.food: Various pipe vines (Aristolochia spp.).
Adult.food: [image] male imbibing moisture at wet spot… Freshly emerged males of patrolling butterflies often taken moisture at sandy or muddy spots near streams or trails. Adults flutter wings rapidly when visiting flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Feb.-Nov. in Deep South and s. Texas (possibly 3-4 flights), April-Sept. in north (2 flights)
Mimicry: The adult is the "model" for several mimics — Spicebush Swallowtail, Black and Ozark Swallowtails, Eastern Tiger Swallowtail (black female). Red-spotted Purple, and  female Diana.
Defense.strategies: The larvae and adults of this common butterfly are distasteful and emetic to birds, their would-be predators.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: PIPEVINE SWALLOWTAIL
Distribution.Range: Resident from southern portion of our area and in n. Calif, south to s. Mex.; wanders north to s. Ore., n. Colo., e. S.D., and Man.
Flight.characteristics: Flight rapid, wings flutter shallowly. Adults flutter wings when visiting flowers.
Habitat: Open fields, desert, thorn forest, stream valleys, and foothills.
Hostplant.larval.food: Pipevines.
Adult.food: Adults flutter wings when visiting flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Jan.-Nov. (3-4 flights), late March-Oct. in  n. Calif, (most fly in spring with stragglers later).
Mimicry: Larvae and adults of this common butterfly are distasteful and, when eaten, cause birds to regurgitate. Adult is "model" for several mimics: Black Swallowtail, Old World Swallowtail (black form of subspecies bairdii), Indra Swallowtail (possibly subspecies kaibabensis), Spicebush Swallowtail (rare stray in our area), female Diana Fritillary (not in our area), and Red-spotted Purple.
Defense.strategies: Larvae and adults of this common butterfly are distasteful and, when eaten, cause birds to regurgitate.
Adult.forms: All isolated breeding population in n. Calif, and extreme s. Ore. (subspecies hirsuta) is smaller, has denser hairlike scales, and has short tails,
Author: andra.doherty

Common.name: The Red Rim
Distribution.Range: Not uncommon on Porto Rico and the Lesser Antilles, e.g. St Croix, St Thomas, Dominica, St Kilts, Guadeloupe, Montserrat, St Lucia, Tortola and St Eustachc. Rare in Hispaniola. Not reported from Cuba, Jamaica or Martinique...  RANGE: Mexico to Paraguay. TL: St Thomas.
Abundance: Not uncommon on Porto Rico and the Lesser Antilles; Rare in Hispaniola. Not reported from Cuba, Jamaica or Martinique.
Flight.characteristics: A lazy slow-flying rather sedentary butterfly, easily caught
Habitat: preferring moist but fairly open ground
Hostplant.larval.food: The food plant is Pine Nettle, Tragia volubilis.
Adult.food: preferring moist but fairly open ground and much attracted to rotting fruit.
Phenology.and.voltinism: On the wing throughout the year in most places.
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: BIBLIS HYPERIA Cramer 1782 The Red Rim Pl. 7 syn. Didonis biblis auctorum Description. Fw [male] and [female] 28—36 mm. Upperside velvety dark brown, outer margin of forewing broadly paler, of hindwing bordered by a broad red band cut into sections by narrow black lines along the veins. Underside the same but colours all much paler and hindwing with three red basal spots. Distribution. Not uncommon on Porto Rico and the Lesser Antilles, e.g. St Croix, St Thomas, Dominica, St Kilts, Guadeloupe, Montserrat, St Lucia, Tortola and St Eustachc. Rare in Hispaniola. Not reported from Cuba, Jamaica or Martinique. A lazy slow-flying rather sedentary butterfly, easily caught and preferring moist but fairly open ground and much attracted to rotting fruit. On the wing throughout the year in most places. RANGE: Mexico to Paraguay. TL: St Thomas. Early stages. The caterpillar is spiny and grey-brown, with pale oblique lateral stripes, small green warts and a light coloured band on the seventh segment. When at rest it raises head and tail above its support to form an inverted arch. The food plant is Pine Nettle, Tragia volubilis.

Common.name: White-barred Charaxes
Distribution.Range: Common  and  widespread, often  seen  flying  in  forest,  woodland  and gardens.
Abundance: Common  and  widespread, often  seen  flying  in  forest,  woodland  and gardens.
Flight.characteristics: Flies  very  fast  and  generally quite  high
Habitat: Common  and  widespread, often  seen  flying  in  forest,  woodland  and gardens.   Flies  very  fast  and  generally quite  high,  but  settles  to  feed  on  fruit, carrion  and  fermenting  tree  sap.

Author: walker.darling
Full.Species.Account: White-barred  Charaxes Charaxes  brutus 75-85 mm Large  and  robust;  one  of the  most  powerfully  built butterflies.  The  sleek,  sharply pointed  black  wings  have a  single,  broad  white  band running  along  their  length,  which  breaks into  spots  on  the  forewing.  The  undersides are  exquisite,  with  the  intricate  patterning typical  of  many  Charaxes  species.  Sexes are  similar. HABITS  &  HABITAT:  Common  and  widespread, often  seen  flying  in  forest,  woodland  and gardens.  Flies  very  fast  and  generally quite  high,  but  settles  to  feed  on  fruit, carrion  and  fermenting  tree  sap.  Males  are territorial.  Caterpillars  feed  on  many  plants, including  Trichelia  and  Ekbergia.

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of Seychelles: Their Natural History and Conservation
Common.name: Striped Policeman
Distribution.Range: This butterfly is found in the Malagasy subregion. Its distribution includes Madagascar and Seychelles, where it has been recorded on Cosmoledo Atoll. It was incorrectly listed as occurring on the granitic islands in previously published works (Lawrence 2010). This butterfly appears to have a sporadic distribution within Seychelles, most likely represented by vagrants from Madagascar. This taxon has been erroneously listed as occurring on Reunion (Legrand 1965) and Mauritius (Williams 2007). Although unconfirmed, arbogastes may also occur on Mayotte in the Comoros (Turlin 1995). Despite the sporadic occurrence of this butterfly in Seychelles, it is widespread on Madagascar.
Abundance: This butterfly appears to have a sporadic distribution within Seychelles. Despite the sporadic occurrence of this butterfly in Seychelles, it is widespread on Madagascar. Its conservation status is \Not threatened\"."
Flight.characteristics: The Striped Policeman is a strong flier.
Habitat: The Striped Policeman is usually found along forest edges and clearings. On Madagascar, it occurs in unnatural grasslands, forest margins and the littoral zone (Lees et al. 2003).
Hostplant.larval.food: Nothing is known about the early stages of this subspecies.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Adults have been recorded between July and February on Madagascar.
Mobility: This butterfly appears to have a sporadic distribution within Seychelles, most likely represented by vagrants from Madagascar.
Author: anne.lott
Full.Species.Account: Coeliades forestan arbogastes (Guenée, 1863) Striped Policeman Malagasy subregion Not threatened Description Sexes similar. LFW: 47- 53 mm. UPF light brown in ground colour with green overlay in basal area. UPH brown with green to white overlay covering most of basal area. UNF light-brown in ground colour with white scales between 1A+2A and trailing edge of wing. UNH light-brown with characteristic well-developed white band in post-median region. The thorax is covered with green scales.  Distribution Madagascar and Seychelles, where it has been recorded on Cosmoledo Atoll. Incorrectly listed as occurring on the granitic islands in previous published works (Lawrence 2010).  Biology and conservation The Striped Policeman is a strong flyer usually found along forest edges and clearings. On Madagascar, it occurs in unnatural grasslands, forest margins and the littoral zone (Lees et al. 2003), with adults recorded between July and February. Nothing is known about its early stages. This butterfly appears to have a sporadic distribution within Seychelles, most likely represented by vagrants from Madagascar. This taxon has been erroneously listed as occurring on Reunion (Legrand 1965) and Mauritius (Williams 2007). Although unconfirmed, arbogastes may also occur on Mayotte in the Comoros (Turlin 1995). Despite the sporadic occurrence of this butterfly in Seychelles, it is widespread on Madagascar. This taxon is not threatened at present.

Book: Butterflies of Mauritius
Distribution.Range: Mauritius
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Coeliades forestan (Stoll, 1782) Plate I Papilio forestan Stoll, 1782, De uitlandsche Kapellen 4: 210, pI. 391, figs. E, F (Cote de Bengale [patria falsaD. Common name: Striped Policeman. Distribution: Mauritius, Rodrigues, Agalega, Reunion, Madagascar, Comoros, Seychelles and Africa. Larval foodplants: In Mauritius, Terminalia catappa (badamier), Canavalia gladiata (pois sabre). Eggs and larvae have been recorded recently on Terminalia sp. on the south-east coast (Atkins, 1999). Remarks: First recorded from Mauritius by Trimen in 1866. Common in some localities from the coast to the upland plateau during the summer months. Its flight is quick and evasive. The subspecies found in Mauritius is C. forestan arbogastes (Guenee, 1863).

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of Seychelles: Their Natural History and Conservation
Common.name: Striped Policeman
Distribution.Range: The distribution of this butterfly is the entire Afrotropical region including the islands of Mauritius, Comoros, Réunion and Rodrigues. In Seychelles it has been recorded on the islands of Mahe, La Digue, Aride, and Cousine. This subspecies is widespread and common across most of the Afrotropical region.
Abundance: This subspecies is widespread and common across most of the Afrotropical region. It is more commonly encountered during the wet NW Monsoon period. Its conservation status is \Not threatened\"."
Flight.characteristics: The behaviour of this subspecies is similar to the subspecies arbogastes, where the subspecies arbogastes is a strong flier.
Hostplant.larval.food: The larvae are polyphagous and feed on a wide range of food plants which include Canavalia species, Terminalia catappa and Parinari curatellifolia. Vinson (1938) considered this butterfly to be a minor pest of Canavalia species in Mauritius.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Adults have been recorded throughout the year, but Coeliades forestan forestan is more commonly encountered during the wet NW Monsoon period.
Author: anne.lott
Full.Species.Account: Coeliades forestan forestan (Stoll, 1784) Striped Policeman Afrotropical region Not threatened Description Similar to Coeliades forestan arbogastes, except the green scales are replaced by beige-coloured scales. Sexes similar. LFW: Male 40-50 mm. Female 50-58 mm. Distribution  The entire Afrotropical region including the islands of Mauritius, Comoros, Réunion and Rodrigues. In Seychelles it has been recorded on the islands of Mahe, La Digue, Aride and Cousine.  Biology and conservation Behaviour and biotype preferences similar to the subspecies arbogastes. Adults have been recorded throughout the year, but it is more commonly encountered during the wet NW Monsoon period. This butterfly occasionally migrates. The larvae are polyphagous and feed on a wide range of food plants which include Canavalia species, Terminalia catappa and Parinari curatellifolia. Vinson (1938) considered this butterfly to be a minor pest on Canavalia species in Mauritius. The subspecies is widespread and common across most of the Afrotropical region. The Striped Policeman is not threatened.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Striped Policeman
Distribution.Range: The Striped Policeman is one of the select few butterflies that have been positively recorded from all of West Africa covered by this book.  The nominate subspecies (TL ‘Bengal’ [!]) is found throughout Africa, though rarely in undisturbed forest or extreme pre-desert.
Abundance: Though the Striped Policeman may be numerous in a given locality, more often than not single specimens turn up practically anywhere. The nominate subspecies (TL ‘Bengal’ [!]) is found throughout Africa, though rarely in undisturbed forest or extreme pre-desert.
Flight.characteristics: Some migratory capacity seems indicated (as in C. libeon); it has been seen five km off the coast of Senegal coming to lights at a ship (R. de Jong pers. obs.). The flight is fast and powerful.
Habitat: The Striped Policeman has a great degree of ecological adaptability and may be found inside the densest rainforests as well as on the fringes of the Sahel savannah (I have taken it at 300mm annual rainfall in the Kalahari and at 6,000mm in the Oban Hills). When camping in open country it is often an early morning visitor to the camp rubbbish-tip. They can also be found hilltopping.  The nominate subspecies (TL ‘Bengal’ [!]) is found throughout Africa, though rarely in undisturbed forest or extreme pre-desert.
Hostplant.larval.food: The species is strongly polyphagous, and the following list of host-plants is probably incomplete: Canavalia, Cassia, Crotalaria, Indigofera, Lonchocarpus sericeus, Millettia, Phaseolus, Robinia, Sesamus, Dioclea reflexa (Fabaceae); occasionally on cocoa (Theobroma cacao (Sterculiaceae)) (Smith 1965); Dregea, Marsdenia (Asclepiadaceae), Combretum, Quiscalis, Terminalia (Combretaceae); Conchocarpus (Rutaceae); Gossypium (Malvaceae); Sphedamnocarpus (Malpighiaceae); Geranium (Geraniaceae); Solanum (Solanaceae); finally Pterocarpus santalinoides (Fabaceae), Triaspis odorata (Malpighiaceae), and Cassipourea congoensis (Rhizophoraceae) were recorded from Lamto, Côte d’Ivoire by Vuattoux (1999).
Adult.food: When camping in open country the Striped Policeman is often an early morning visitor to the camp rubbbish-tip; it also comes to mudpuddles and urine patches. Flowers are visited as well.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: New data on Hesperioidea and Papilionoidea (Lepidoptera) from the Cape Verde Islands, with a review of previous records
Distribution.Range: C. f. forestan occurs throughout sub-Saharan Africa, except the Cape Province, and also in Madagascar, Mauritius, Reunion, and the Seychelles. Riley (1968) suggested that its presence in Cape Verde must be due to the accidental introduction by man. It was reported by Nystrom from Santo Antao and Sao Nicolau. In Cape Verde, caterpillars were assigned to this species.
Hostplant.larval.food: Terminalia catappa (Combretacaea)

Flight.characteristics: They are easily disturbed and fly away rapidly upon being approached, returning to the perch a short time later.
Habitat: found in many different habitat types
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on a variety of different plants.
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: Striped policeman Coeliades.forestan fares tan Stoll, 1782 ( 1207) Wingspan 53 mm, found in many different habitat types. It is most likely to be seen perched on a leaf during a forest walk. They are easily disturbed and fly away rapidly upon being approached, returning to the perch a short time later. Sexes similar. C. pisistratus is a similar West African species, but it has a black bar and two distinct black spots in the white band (not currently recorded from The Gambia, but possibly occurs there). Larvae feed on a variety of different plants.

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: This Skipper flies along the edges of the rain forests and coastal bush as far south as or beyond, East London, and through much of the savannah areas. Occasional captures have been made at Port Elizabeth, and the species has been recorded from Grahamstown. Although absent from a very large area in the south-western portion of our zone, it extends from Rhodesia westwards into various parts of Botswana, etc.
Abundance: Occasional captures have been made at Port Elizabeth.
Flight.characteristics: This butterfly has the usual rapid flight of its group.
Habitat: This Skipper flies along the edges of the rain forests and coastal bush, and through much of the savannah areas. It visits koppies or forest-fringes.
Hostplant.larval.food: Combretum bracteosum and C. apiculatum, Solanum auriculatum (= S. mauritianum), Millettia sutherlandii, Sphedamnocarpus rhamni (= S. rehmannii), Robinia pseudacacia.
Adult.food: From early dawn to dusk this species seeks nectar.
Phenology.and.voltinism: This Skipper flies through most months of the year.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: Eggs and larvae were recorded from Durban.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid singly on a leaf of young shoot-stem.
Phenology.and.voltinism: The larva emerges from the egg after 9 days. In the 1st intar the larva grows from 1.75 to 3.5 mm in 4 days. In the 2nd intsar the larva grows from 3.5 to 6 mm in 3 days. In the 3rd instar the larva grows from 6 to 10 mm in 3 days. In the 4th instar the larva grows from 10 to 16 mm in 4 days. In the 5th instar the larva grows from 16 6o 35 mm in 7 days. Instars are of variable duration. Sometimes an extra instar occurs between the 4th and final instars. The adult emerges from the pupa after 17 days. The species is multi-brooded. It appears from September to April in cold parts, but all the year in warm parts.
Defense.strategies: The larva bends over the side of a leaf and secures it with silk to form a cache in which it lives, crawling out at intervals to feed. Pupation takes place within a cache formed by binding leaves together. The pupa is usually covered with a white powdery substance.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Flight.characteristics: Low, exceedingly swift flight. Will settle momentarily.
Habitat: Forested areas.
Adult.food: Has a great fondness for flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: C. forestan is widespread and common in forested areas throughout the year. It is on the wing for most of the daylight hours.

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: California ringlet
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses; field preferences are unknown. This spe cies can be reared on many grasses, including some weedy Mediterranean annuals, which it almost certainly does not use in nature. It can breed in the wild as well as in the lab on Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon)^ but that ability has not allowed it to enter the urban fauna
Adult.food: e not very avid flower either—though they seem broad in their floral tastes (fiddlenecks [Atnsinckia], yellow star-thistle [Centaurea solstitialis) milk thistle [Silybum marianum]y yerba santas [Eriodictyonjy asters [Asterjy goldenrods [Solidago
Phenology.and.voltinism: Recorded from January (unusual) to November; usu ally a break between the two generations, in late spring. They undergo estivation wi^ re productive diapause for as long as 2 to 3 months and do not begin laying eggs until August or even early September Late-summer eggs hatch quickly, but the larvae usually have nothing to eat and re main inactive until new growth begins. They flien feed, reacluhe third instar, and again become quiescent until early spring
Diapause: ovenvintered (third-instar) larva
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: The California Ringlet is our representative of a species or species complex that reaches completely around the Northern Hemi sphere, mostly in higher latitudes. Our subspecies is very differ ent in appearance and life history from most others, including the one directly across the Sierra Nevada, but molecular genetics suggests all are a single biological species. In North America, the only other subspecies approaching ours in coloration is the Siskiyou Ringlet (C. t. cryngii) of western Oregon and northwest ern California. There arc populations of the C. tullia complex in Eurasia with somewhat similar coloring, but these are almost cer tainly convergent, not closely related. The California Ringlet is still abundant in many areas of the Coast Ranges and Bay Area in oak woodland and grassland but has been in decline in the Sacramento Valley for years for reasons that we do not understand. i • j • First-brood adults—produced from ovenvintered (third-instar) larvae—are pearly or even silvery gray above and heavily infuscated with blackish brown on the ventral hindwing (this is probably thermoregulatory melanism). They emerge in ear y spring and breed immediately. Second-brood adults are very p e reddish buff (exactly the color of dry grass) with little or no dark ening of the ventral hindwing. The actual factors controUing the seasonal polyphenism are unknown. Summer adults are p ysio logically quite different, as weU. They undergo estivation wi^ re productive diapause for as long as 2 to 3 months and do not begin laying eggs until August or even early September. e esUva ing they remain quiescent, preferably in shade, but can e c e up; they may fly around on cool afternoons. Late-summer eggs hatch quickly, but the larvae usually have nothing to eat and re main inactive until new growth begins. They flien feed, reacluhe third instar, and again become quiescent until early spring, ei ther generation lays its eggs preferentially on grasses; the larvae are left to forage for themselves. The adults don't seem to do very much. They don t pu e, are not territorial (though male-male chases can be seen, gener ally rather desultory ones!), and are not very avid flower either—though they seem broad in their floral tastes (fiddlenecks [Atnsinckia], yellow star-thistle [Centaurea solstitialis) milk thistle [Silybum marianum]y yerba santas [Eriodictyonjy asters [Asterjy goldenrods [Solidago Mostly, they either sit still or fly with an odd undulating motion among tall grasses. DISTRIBUTION: All counties, but declining in the Sacramento Val ley and around urban and suburban areas generally. HOST PLANTS: Grasses; field preferences are unknown. This spe cies can be reared on many grasses, including some weedy Mediterranean annuals, which it almost certainly does not use in nature. It can breed in the wild as well as in the lab on Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon)^ but that ability has not allowed it to enter the urban fauna. Seemingly associated with both perennial bunchgrasses and stoloniferous or rhizomatous species. SEASONS: Recorded from January (unusual) to November; usu ally a break between the two generations, in late spring. SIMILAR SPECIES: None in our fauna. The pale coloration of the spring brood may lead to it being mistaken for a pierid, but the flight is very different.

Book: A Field Guide to Eastern Butterflies (Peterson Field Guide Series)
Common.name: Common Ringlet
Distribution.Range: The Inornate Ringlet (C. t. inornata) occurs in  most of our area. Holarctic. In North America from Alaska and w. N.W. Terr. south through w. mountains to Baja Calif. Norte, se. Ariz., and cen. N.M., ranges across s. Canada to Que. and New England south to Long I. and n. N.J.; range is still expanding, also isolated populations in N.B. (C. t. nipisquit) and Nfld. (and adjacent mainland).
Habitat: Open grassy areas In wide variety of settings.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses and rushes.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Mid-June to mid-Sept. (1 -2 broods).
Adult.forms: Highly variable geographically. Different geographic forms blend over narrow areas. Some experts consider these forms to be separate species.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: COMMON RINGLET
Distribution.Range: Calif. …Rocky Mts. …prairies lowland Calif. ...Pacific Northwest and w. Nev. Holarctic. In N. Amer. from n. Alaska and n. Canada south to n. Baja Calif., e. Ariz., cen. N.M., east across s. Canada and n. U.S. to Maritimes and New England. Extcnding range southward along Atlantic Coast (s. N.Y. and N.J.). Not found in deserts, s. Ariz., s.N.M., Tex., or prairies south of S.D.
Flight.characteristics: Adults are most often seen flying low through sunny grassy areas
Habitat: prairies Open grassy areas in an incredibly wide array of habitats and biomes. Not found in deserts… or prairies south of S.D. Adults are most often seen flying low through sunny grassy areas, but  they periodically stop to nectar at flowers, especially in hot, arid habitats.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses.
Adult.food: they periodically stop to nectar at flowers, especially in hot, arid habitats.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Feb.-Nov. in lowland Calif. (3 flights). May-Sept. in Pacific Northwest and w. Nev. (2 flights), mid-May-Aug. (1 flight elsewhere in West).
Adult.forms: Highly variable geographically. Ranges from cream white (Calif.) through yellow-cream and yellow-orange (Rocky Mts.) to orange-brown (prairies). often has darker cast, especially where spring flights occur. demonstrated to   gradually change appearance across broad geographic areas.
Author: andra.doherty

Abundance: The Orange Sulphur can be found in virtu ally any open landscape and is particularly abundant in and around cultivated alfalfa fields, where it occasion ally can become a serious pest; occasional to abundant;
Flight.characteristics: Adults have a rapid, erratic flight
Habitat: The Orange Sulphur can be found in virtu ally any open landscape and is particularly abundant in and around cultivated alfalfa fields, where it occasion ally can become a serious pest; open, sunny sites including roadsides, old fields, alfalfa fields, pastures and home gardens

Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Orange Sulphur Colias eurytheme Family/Subfamily: Whites and Sulphurs (Pieridae)/ -Sulphurs (Coliadinae) Wingspan: 1.6-2.4" (4.1-6.1 cm) Above: bright yellow orange with black wing borders and black forewing ceil spot; hindwing has central orange spot Below: yellow with row of dark submarginal spots; hindwing has one or two central red-rimmed silvery spots Sexes: similar, although female has yellow spots in broader black wing borders and are less vibrantfemale is occasionally white Egg: white, laid singly on host leaves Larva: green with thin, cream lateral stripe and numer ous short hairs Larval Host Plants; Alfalfa, White Sweet Clover, White Clover and vetches Habitat: open, sunny sites including roadsides, old fields, alfalfa fields, pastures and home gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional to abundant Compare: Southern Dogface (pg. 393) is larger, has pointed forewings and wide, scalloped forewing bor ders. Clouded Sulphur (pg, 395) lacks dorsal orange scaling. Comments: The Orange Sulphur can be found in virtu ally any open landscape and is particularly abundant in and around cultivated alfalfa fields, where it occasion ally can become a serious pest. Because of this strong preference, it is often called the Alfalfa Butterfly, It is a prolific colonizer. Adults have a rapid, erratic flight. Butterflies produced very early or late in the season are generally smaller and darker. This butterfly typically rests and feeds with its wings closed, so its orange color IS seen primarily in flight or when the butterfly is basking in the sun.

Hostplant.larval.food: Various legumes, especially alfalfa, white sweet closer, white clover, and vetches. Others used less frequently.

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Alfalfa Butterfly
Distribution.Range: The Alfalfa Butterfly ranges throughout North America from the southern edge of Canada to Mexico. It is found less frequently in boreal regions north to Newfoundland and north-central Alberta. Alberta records are mainly from the southern agricultural regions. Most Alberta specimens probably dispersed from more southerly parts of the species' range.
Abundance: Their abundance varies greatly from year to year, but they are usually sparse.
Habitat: open areas, especially alfalfa and clover fields.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae of the Alfalfa Butterfly feed on numerous legumes, including Alfalfa (Medicago sativa), but have not yet been reported for Alberta.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Adults have been collected from June 1 to September 20 in Alberta, mainly in late summer. There are two overlapping broods per year.
Diapause: The species is not believed to overwinter in Alberta.
Author: elise.larsen

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Abundance: occasionally reaches high enough densities to damage alfalfa
Author: elise.larsen

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: Orange sulphur or Alfalfa butterfly
Distribution.Range: One of the most abundant and generally distributed butterflies in California and indeed in most of North America,
Elevation: sea level to tree line and above
Abundance: One of the most abundant and generally distributed butterflies in California and indeed in most of North America, In the Central Valley, where alfalfa (Medicago sativa) is grown, it sometimes swarms by the millions in the sec ond half of the season. Every
Habitat: Orange Sulphur occurs in all open habitats but almost never in forest.
Hostplant.larval.food: Orange Sulphur overwinters poorly in alfalfa fields in the Sacramento Valley. Most breeding in late winter and early spring is on annual vetches (Vicia). Papilionaceous legumes (Fabaceae), both native an in ro uced, including alfalfa (Medicago sativa), ot
Phenology.and.voltinism: January to December, usually with a 4 to 8 week winter hiatus, but m severe drought years flying all winter
Diapause: The larvae do not enter true diapause but are merely torpid in winter.
Adult.forms: Up to half the females are white, due to an autosomal dominant gene caUed "alba, Cold-season animals are very small; they have relatively narrow wings with less pronounced apices, narrow black borders above—which may disappear altogether!—and very heavy g
Author: elise.larsen

Phenology.and.voltinism: fly 44 weeks of the year, but in dry years may be nearly continuous

Book: The Butterflies of Hong Kong
Distribution.Range: North America
Hostplant.larval.food: in North America Colias eurytheme Boisduval is a pest of Alfalfa.
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Chapter 7 Family PIERIDAE Whites, Yellows and Sulphurs Size small to large. Eyes naked or with a sparse covering of very short hairs. Antennae of variable length; club gradual, slim or occasionally broad. Maxillary palpi absent. Labial palpi variable. Tarsal claws of all legs bifid. Forelegs normally developed and functional in both sexes; foretibia without an epiphysis. Mid and hindtibiae with terminal pair of spurs. Cell of both wings closed. Forewing Rs with two, three or four (most frequently three) branches; origin of M3 at or near posterior angle of cell, the cubitus appearing three-branched; one anal vein (1A+2A), with 2A usually separate at base. Hindwing humeral vein variable, sometimes absent; two anal veins (1A+2A and 3A). Male secondary sexual characters (brands, hair tufts or scattered androconia) usually present (fig. 7.2). Male eighth tergite often produced posteriorly, either as paired dorsolateral flaps or as a middorsal depressed sac (a pseuduncus). Male genitalia: tegumen often with an uncus anticus; a diffusely sclerotized subscaphium sometimes present; valvae not well sclerotized, often w ith an ampullary process arising from central part of medial wall, sometimes with distal processes, costa attached to tegumen by a distinct and usually well sclerotized band; aedeagus usually with a trochanter; vesica nearly always w ithout cornuti. Larvae do not form shelters. Pupae exposed, with a girdle. Most are of m edium size though a few, such as Leptosia, are small and fragile while members of the Oriental genus Hebomoia are larger than many Papilionidae. Unique among butterflies is the universal occurrence of bifid tarsal claws (fig. 7.1), otherwise found in only a few Papilionidae, Satyrinae, Acraeinae and Lycaenidae. The characteristic white and sulphurous yellows, and the reds of the more colourful tropical species, are produced by pteridine pigments that are found in few other Lepidoptera. Though pterins are now known to be derived from guanine nucleotides and not uric acid. Ford's modified murexide test (Ford, 1947), in which specimens are exposed to chlorine gas, is still a simple means of demonstrating these pigments. The test is conveniently done by placing the set specimen in a wet box with a small amount of household chlorine bleach for about 20 minutes. The bleached insect is then removed, allowed to dry and stored in the dark. A strong purplish pink tinge develops during the following few days (fig. 7.3). A singular feature of the male genitalia, possessed by many members throughout the family, is a sclerotized plate on the ventral surface of the aedeagus posterior to the caecum. Since it appears to be an area of muscle insertions Higgins (1975: 69) has named it the trochanter penis. The family contains about 1000 species distributed in all habitable regions. Of the four subfamilies the Dismorphiinae are mainly confined to the New World tropics and the Pseudopontiinae comprise a single aberrant west African species. Only the widely distributed and closely related Pierinae (about 700 species) and [Fig 7.1 Bifid claws on right hindleg of Cepora nerissa (SEM Scale bar indicates magnification)] [Fig. 7.2 Brush-tipped androconiumm at Pieris canidia (SEM Scale bar indicates magnification.)] [Fig. 7.3 Underside of Eurema hecabe before (A) and after (B) Ford's test.] Coliadinae (about 250 species) occur in the IndoAustralian Region. In most areas, including Hong Kong, one or two species associated with secondary growth or crops are the most common of all butterflies and at times attain epidemic proportions. The larvae of Pieris are important pests of cultivated Cruciferae, and in North America Colias eurytheme Boisduval is a pest of Alfalfa. Until the widespread use of insecticides Aporia crataegi Linnaeus was a pest of fruit trees in Europe. The family includes many migrants, among which the Catopsilia and Appias species are the best known and sometimes occur in huge swarms. Many Dismorphiinae are associated with the Heliconiini and other groups in mimicry rings, and Delias species are aposematic and known to be distasteful to captive birds. Larvae of Catopsilia and Pieris have been shown to sequester distasteful compounds from their foodplants and it is possible that these and other predominantly white Pieridae are aposematic or warningly coloured, form ing Batesian or Mullerian mimetic associations within the family and with other Lepidoptera. The eggs are white, yellow or orange and laid singly in the ma|ority of species. They are two or three times as tall as broad, rarely less, taper towards the micropylar area and [Fig. 7.4 Egg of Eurema hecabe, diameter 0.4 mm, height 1.2 mm.] [Fig. 7.5 Last instar larva of Catopsilia pomona on Cassia siamea, length 39 mm.] [Fig. 7.6 Pupa o f Pieris canidia on Tropaeolum majus, length 19 mm.] have variably developed vertical ridges and transverse striations. The larvae are slim and cylindrical and mostly procryptic green or green and yellow. Typically each segment is rugose and bears several bands of short conical tubercles, each ending in a simple small seta (e.g. Hebomota) or stout seta that ends in a thin-w alled spherical expansion (e.g. Eurema, fig. 3.15 B) These cuticular outgrowths extend over most of the head, which usually appears little different from the rest of the dorsal and lateral cuticle and is not concealed at rest. In a few, such as Cepora and Appias, the integum ent is partly unpigmented and the larger tracheae are visible. All pupae have a single cephalic horn and long tapering abdomen and are supported by a girdle. Many are suspended beneath an angled or horizontal surface like those of the Papilioninae; others are less particular about their posture and may be found at any angle, head upwards or downwards, or on top of or beneath a horizontal surface. Those of many species show great variation in colour, from bright green to shades of brow n or grey. Immature stages of the two subfamilies in Hong Kong show few consistent differences. Key to the Hong Kong subfamilies: Hindwing humeral vein long and curved outwards. Eggs with vertical ridges ending in low projections surrounding the micropylar area. Larval foodplants predominantly Capparaceae and Cruciferae. Pierinae Hindwing humeral vein short and curved inwards, or absent. Eggs with vertical ridges tapering oft before the micropylar area. Larval foodplants predominantly Leguminosae. Coliadinae.

Common.name: Coast Purple Tip
Distribution.Range: A fairly common butterfly in East Africa, found in a wide range of habitats, including dryland bush, savanna and woodland.
Abundance: A fairly common butterfly in East Africa, found in a wide range of habitats, including dryland bush, savanna and woodland. Flies fast, but also visits flowers; can be very common after good rains.

Full.Species.Account: Coast Purple Tip Colotis hetaera 45-60 mm Males have bright reddish-purple tips to the wings and veins outlined in fine black lines. Females are larger, with reddish dots and black tipped forewings. HABITS & HABITAT: A fairly common butterfly in East Africa, found in a wide range of habitats, including dryland bush, savanna and woodland. Flies fast, but also visits flowers; can be very common after good rains. Caterpillars feed on different species of Capparaceae.

Author: walker.darling
Full.Species.Account: Lurid Glider Cymothoe lurida 55-85 mm A large, elegant, golden yellow butterfly. Males are bright, almost shining golden yellow to yellow ochre. Females are larger, with brown wings covered with white spots. HABITS & HABITAT: Occurs in the forested western regions of Kenya, Tanzania, Rwanda and Uganda. Typically encountered in more moist forests, where it flies along trails and paths, stopping to bask on foliage, with wings spread. Feeds on rotting fruit dropped by monkeys. Caterpillars feed on Rinorea (Violacae).

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 3: Danainae, Amathusiinae

Adult.forms: Our studies confirm that in Vietnam the local populations include all variations typical to ssp. hegesippus though in Vietnam the proportion of melanic morphs is higher
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Danaus melanippus (Cramer, [1777]) Plate 1,figs. 3a-b Uitlandsche Kapellen, 2: 44, pi. 127. (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY. According to Fruhstorfer (1910) and Bryk (1937) the nominate ssp. was described from Java (Ackery & Vane-Wright, 1984; Morishita, 1985); ssp. hegesippus - Sumatra. Papilio hegesippus Cramer: Uitlandsche Kapellen, 2:128, pi. 180, fig. A. Salatura indicus Fruhstorfer, 1899. Berl. Ent. Zeitschr. 44(1/2): 75 (Jul). Danaida melanippus Indicus: Fruhstorfer in Seitz, 1910: 196. Saigon. Danaida melanippus f. Indicus: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 23. Indochina. Danaus melanippus Indicus: Metaye, 1957a: 100. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Danaus melanippus Indicus: Metaye, 1958: 153, pl.1, fig. 3. C. Vietnam (Blao); s. Vietnam (Saigon). Salatura melanippus Indicus: Morishita, 1970: 63-64. S. Vietnam (Ba Diem, Thu Due, Dinh Quan, Trang Bom, Lai Thieu etc.). Danaus (Salatura) melanippus hegesippus: Ackery & Vane-Wright, 1984: 122. Indochina (Vietnam). Anosia melanippus hegesippus: Morishita in Tsukada, 1985: 455-6. C. & S. Vietnam (-indicus). Danaus (Salatura) melanippus Indicus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 15. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Danaus melanippus indlcus: Miyazaki et al., 2006: 15. Fig. D-2 [female] Up C. Vietnam (Lam Dong: Bao Loc). SYNONYMS. The taxon indicus Fruhstorfer, 1899 (TL: Tenasserim) is a synonym of ssp. hegesippus Cramer, 1777 (TL: w. Sumatra). RANGE. The species is distributed from N.E. India to Indochina and Taiwan, and southwards to the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, and further to the Philippines, Sulawesi and Lesser Sunda Islands. The ssp. hegesippus (= indicus Fruhstorfer, 1899) occurs on the  Southeast Asian mainland, including Vietnam. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM, C. Vietnam: Bao Loc (SM); S. Vietnam: Cat Tien N.P., I-IV; Binh Chau N.R., V-VL, Lo Go Sa Mat N.R., XI-XII; Saigon, I, VI, X; Phu Quoc Is., XL It has not been discovered in other parts of N. & C. Vietnam to date. Specimens of Vietnamese populations are slightly variable in size and wing pattern. Length of FW: both sexes 38-44 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. Fruhstorfer (1910) considered that the continental populations, distributed from Myanmar to Indochina, belong to ssp. indicus, which scarcely varies and differs from taxon hegesippus which is distributed in Sumatra, Malaya and adjacent Islands. In comparison with the Burmese and Malayan populations the Vietnamese specimens are characterised by higher melanism (Morishita, 1970). Later Morishita (1985) and Ackery & Vane-Wright (1984) extended the range of hegesippus to all mainland territories where the species had been recorded. Our studies confirm that in Vietnam the local populations include all variations typical to ssp. hegesippus though in Vietnam the proportion of melanic morphs is higher. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is not frequent and can be seen occasionally at the same lowland open habitats typical for D. genutia. Larval foodplants belong to the genera Gxmnema and Tylophora (Asclepiadaceae). Imagos are attracted by the flowers of Ageratum conxzoides (Asteraceae) and Lantana camara (Verbenaceae) (Ackery & Vane-Wright, 1984). SIMILAR SPECIES. Danaus affinis is smaller and can be distinguished by a wide white area on the HW extended from the tornus to the discal cell; D. genutia (see  description above)

Vietnam: Cat Tien N.P., I-IV; Binh Chau N.R., V-VL, Lo Go Sa Mat N.R., XI-XII; Saigon, I, VI, X; Phu Quoc Is., XI. It has not been discovered in other parts of N. & C. Vietnam to date. Specimens of Vietnamese populations are slightly variable in size and wing pattern. Length of FW: both sexes 38-44 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. Fruhstorfer (1910) considered that the continental populations, distributed from Myanmar to Indochina, belong to ssp. indicus, which scarcely varies and differs from taxon hegesippus which is distributed in Sumatra, Malaya and adjacent Islands. In comparison with the Burmese and Malayan populations the Vietnamese specimens are characterised by higher melanism (Morishita, 1970). Later Morishita (1985) and Ackery & Vane-Wright (1984) extended the range of hegesippus to all mainland territories where the species had been recorded. Our studies confirm that in Vietnam the local populations include all variations typical to ssp. hegesippus though in Vietnam the proportion of melanic morphs is higher. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is not frequent and can be seen occasionally at the same lowland open habitats typical for D. genutia. Larval foodplants belong to the genera Gxmnema and Tylophora (Asclepiadaceae). Imagos are attracted by the flowers of Ageratum conxzoides (Asteraceae) and Lantana camara (Verbenaceae) (Ackery & Vane-Wright, 1984). SIMILAR SPECIES. Danaus affinis is smaller and can be distinguished by a wide white area on the HW extended from the tornus to the discal cell; D. genutia (see  description above)

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Distribution.Range: Australian Subregion...Sogeri to Kokoda Trail area of the Central Province in PNG... Queensland, Australia... Indo-Australian Region from India as far eastwards as Samoa
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: The epijarbas Species Group The following group contains about 14 species, 7 of which occur in PNG (3 of these undescribed). Of this group D’Abrera (1978) followed Seitz (1926) and recognised only D. epijarbas as occurring within the Australian Subregion. He treated several similar, but nevertheless distinct, species from the region as races of epijarbas. However, this is untenable and many of the supposed races have overlapping distributions. For example, the taxa epijarbas, diovis, littoralis and woodfordi are all sympatric in the Sogeri to Kokoda Trail area of the Central Province in PNG. The taxa epijarbas and diovis are also sympatric in northern Queensland, Australia (Cooper et al., 1993). Members of the group are characterised by their pale grey or pale brown undersides marked with fine white lines which delineate bands that are only slightly darker than the ground colour. The group ranges throughout the Indo-Australian Region from India as far eastwards as Samoa, and is typified by its most widespread species, epijarbas. Deudorix viridens Druce, 1891, which flies with D. woodfordi on Guadalcanal Island in the Solomons, and which has distinctive male genitalia, may eventually be located on Bougainville Island (NSP, PNG). The species in this group are all very similar. However, they are usually easily separable by comparison of the subtle differences in the patterns of their undersides. Other useful external features include the colour of the frons, the colour and maculation of the hindwing upperside tomal lobe, and the size and shape of the hindwing underside subtomal eye-spot. In combination, all of these characters are a good guide to species in this group. However, the epijarbas species group male genitalia (PI. XIV) provide the most certain means of species identification for that sex. These exhibit 4 important diagnostic characters: the frontal profile of the uncus (including the sinus), the size and distribution of the cornuti of the aedeagus, the size and shape of the pair of lateral cornutal blades below the aedeagus distal aperture, and the morphology of the valval apices. (The pair of lateral cornutal blades fold inwards if the vesica of the aedeagus is not distally everted to some extent, and this is obvious from some of the Figures.) The specific identities of the NG members of the epijarbas species group have been ascertained on the basis of the above-mentioned characters and, as far as possible, the correct names are applied to the taxa discussed below.

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Hostplant.larval.food: Meliosma rigida
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus DICHORRAGIA Butler, 1869 Dichorragia contains only 2 species, 1 of which, the type species nesimachus (Boisduval, 1846), designated by author, ranges from Sikkim and Bhutan to South-east Asia, western China, Taiwan and southern Japan, through the Philippines, Sumatra, Nais, Java, Borneo, Sulawesi and Sula. D. ninus continues the range of the genus eastwards through the Moluccas to mainland NG and Fergusson Island (MBP) in PNG. However, Corbet and Pendlebury (1978) considered that ninus is merely a race of nesimachus. This may be correct as the early stages of both taxa are similar (pers. obs.), although the adults are phenotypically rather distinct, which suggests that they are best maintained as separate species. Corbet and Pendlebury (1978: 205) treated Dichorragia as belonging to the subfamily Pseudergolinae (containing: Pseudergolis C. & R. Felder, 1867; Stibochiona Butler, 1868; Amnosia Doubleday, 1849; and Dichorragia), following the genus Lexias, and preceding the subfamily Apaturinae. They stated that: “The females of the included genera, except Amnosia, have the foretarsi clawed, a feature not found in other Nymphalid groups and, apparently previously unrecorded in the case of Dichorragia. The group appears to be more nearly related to Apaturinae than to any other subfamily, and should perhaps rank as one of its tribes.” Earlier, Bingham (1905) had noted that the main structural difference between Stibochiona and Dichorragia are the much shorter forewing and hindwing cells in Stibochiona. Otherwise the venation, shape and length of antennae and labial palpi, and hirsute eyes, are all like Dichorragia. Fruhstorfer (1912-15, in Seitz), had also included Dichorragia in his tribe Apaturidi, stating that the genus “represents a transition from the Euthaliidi to the Apaturidi”. He proposed that a relationship between Dichorragia and Apaturina is suggested by the closed cells of their wings and the distinct scaphium (sociuncus) of the tegumen of the male genitalia. Corbet and Pendlebury pointed out that the Dichorragia thorax is very robust, and that they are much more powerful fliers than other species of the Pseudergolis group of genera. The form of the Dichorragia larvae is clearly suggestive of the Apaturinae (see further discussion under Subfamilies Apaturinae and Nymphalinae). Ackery (1988), however, treated Dichorragia under the subfamily Limenitinae and tribe Pseudergolini. He maintained that records of Dichorragia feeding on the Meliosmaceae and Anacardiaceae, both members of the Sapindales, indicate some affinity with the true limenitines. The larval feeding behaviour of Dichorragia documented by Shirozu and Hara (1960-62) does bear out this possibility. The first instar larva moves to the apex of a leaf of its foodplant after eating away the top of the eggshell and leaving the base as a ring. In limenitine fashion, it then proceeds to eat back both sides of the leaf, leaving the mid-vein intact and affixing pieces of the leaf with silk to a 2-3 mm long section of the mid-vein on which it rests cryptically among the brown leaf fragments. The larva then progressively eats the leaf lamina backwards either side of the mid-vein, returning after each meal to rest at the apex. Shirozu and Hara noted that the young larval instars of Cyrestis thyodamas in Japan similarly affix faeces to the mid-vein which they leave intact and on which they rest cryptically, so this camouflage behaviour is obviously common to Apaturinae and limenitines. Dichorragia exhibits little sexual dimorphism. The cells of both wings are closed. The antennae are long, being over half the length of the forewing costa, the club long and cylindrical. The labial palpi are obliquely porrect and the eye is sparsely hirsute. Until now, only the early stages of Oriental D. nesimachus were known. They were photographically illustrated from Japan with colour plates by Shirozu and Hara (1960-62), the larval foodplants being various species of Meliosma (Meliosmaceae). Lee and Chang (1992) also provided a good photographic plate of the mature larva of D. nesimachus formosanus (Fruhstorfer, 1908) and of its primary foodplant Meliosma rigida.
