Full.Species.Account: Elodina eg natia Godart (Original Description) *egnatia Godart, Ene. Meth. , 9, p.138 ( 1819) S.Moluccas boisduvali Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p.187 ( 1911 ) N.Celebes fruhstorferi Rober, Ent, Runds., 36, p.7 ( 1919) Timor tenimberensis Joicey & Talbot, Bull, Hill Mus. , 1(2) , P.346 (1922) Tanimbar [Notes] Rare species widely distributed in Wallacea. Certain authors include Australian angulipennis In this species. But, here, I follow Talbot (1932-35) and Common & Waterhouse (1972), and separate them as two distinct species. Characters: Butterfly is similar to Australian angulipennis, but is smaller and has forewing apex somewhat acute. Black marking on the upperside forewing is obtuse on vein 4, and not produced. Female is slightly larger than male. Benneath side is somewhat brownish. Underside hindwing with a narrow submarginal band. Book: Butterflies of Australia: their identification, biology and distribution
Distribution.Range: A number of Victorian localities listed by Anderson and Spry (1893-94) for E. angulipennis, including Springvale, Balaclava, Coburg and Mt Buninyong near Ballarat during March and April, are probably erroneous
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Elodina padusa (Hewitson, 1853) (Plate 26, fig. 2) Narrow-winged Pearl-white ■ Other common names. None. ■ Description. Wingspan: male 38 mm; female 40 mm. Upperside: cream-white; fore wing with a broad black apical patch which extends narrowly along costa and along termen to dorsum; hind wing often with a series of small black terminal streaks at end of veins. Underside: fore wing cream-white, with cell lemon-yellow, and a black subapical patch superimposed on a silvery-grey apical patch; hind wing pearly-white faintly suffused with cream or pale yellowish-orange. The female can be distinguished from the male by the presence of an obscure brown spot at the end of the cell on the underside of the hind wing, followed by a series of one to three faint brown postmedian spots; these spots are generally absent in the male. Also in the female the black apical patch on the upperside of the fore wing is usually slightly broader along the termen between veins CuAl and 1A+2A. ■ Variation. Seasonal variation is weak in this species, although wet- and dry-season forms are apparent. The above description refers to the ‘wet-season form’ (Plate 26, fig. 2a). The ‘dry-season form’ (Plate 26, fig. 2b) has the underside ground colour of the fore wing more extensively suffused with yellow, and the underside ground colour of the hind wing is pale brown or darker yellow-orange, the variation being more pronounced in the female than in the male. Both sexes of the cdry season form’ often have a small brown spot at the end of the cell on the underside of the fore wing, and in the male a similar spot is usually present on the underside of the hind wing. The ‘dry-season form’ is usually found only during the cooler months, from May to September at Millmerran, QLD (J. Macqueen). The seasonal variation possibly has thermoregulatory significance, but the factors inducing the phenotypic shift have not been established experimentally. In addition to seasonal differences in the underside ground colour, both sexes show variation in the shape of the apex of the fore wing, which may be distinctly pointed or slightly rounded. The extent of the black terminal streaks at the end of the veins on the upperside of the hind wing also varies. ■ Similar species. Elodina parthia (p. 311), E. angulipennis (p. 314), E. queenslandica (p. 315), E. walkeri (p. 316), E. perdita (p. 318), E. claudia (p. 319). E. padusa ‘wet-season form’ is similar to that of E. parthia in that the inner edge of the black apical patch on the upperside of the fore wing is strongly produced and angled, however, it is distinguished from that species by the narrower and more elongate fore wing with, on its underside, the lemon-yellow cell and a black subapical patch. The ‘dry-season form’ is readily distinguished from most other species of Elodina by the creamish-white upperside, and the pale brown or yellow- orange underside ground colour of the hind wing which, in freshly emerged specimens, has a pearly or glistening sheen. A similar underside ground colour is sometimes found in E. perdita females, but E. padusa can be easily distinguished by) the presence of a black subapical patch on the underside of the fore wing. ■ Immature stages. Egg: 1.0 mm high, 0.5 mm wide; white when laid, later changing to pink; elongate and spindle-shaped, with 16 fine longitudinal lines. Larva (Plate 68, fig. 10): 20 mm long; body pale green, with a faint yellow or white dorsal line; abdominal segments 2 and 8 with prominent reddish-brown dorsal tubercles; anal segment bifid; head green or reddish- brown. The larva completes only four instars (Fisher 1984b). Pupa (Plate 68, fig. 11): 18 mm long; pale green, with variable reddish-brown spots near head; head produced to a long prominent point; thorax with a raised dorsal ridge; abdomen slightly flattened, with three pairs of brown dorsal spots and a series of white lateral lines. The pupa is longer and narrower than that of other species of Elodina. ■ Larval food plants. Capparis canescens, C. mitchellii (Capparaceae). Larvae have been reported to feed on several species of Capparis (Waterhouse 1932b, 1937c; E.O. Edwards 1948; Manski 1960), but the only species documented in the literature are C. mitchellii (Waterhouse 1932b; Fisher 1978, 1984b) and C. canescens (De Baar and Flancock 1993a). ■ Life cycle and behaviour. Eggs are laid singly on the larval food plant, usually on a leaf or sometimes a stem (E.O. Edwards 1948; Fisher 1978, 1984b). The very inconspicuous larva feeds and rests along the edges of the leaves. Pupation occurs amongst the leaves and stems of the food plant, the pupa, also very inconspicuous, attached by the cremaster and a central silken girdle. When attached to a leaf the pupa is aligned along the central midrib of the leaf (Fisher 1984b) or attached to the underside (Waterhouse 1937c). Adults fly close to the ground, like those of E. parthia, but their flight is usually stronger. In flight they may be easily confused with Pieris rapae, although E. padusa tends to fly faster, more directly and less erratically. Adults occur during all months of the year in QLD, probably with several generations annually. The life cycle from egg to adult was completed in 33 days near Mitchell, QLD with the egg stage lasting six days (E.O. Edwards 1948). A life cycle of 29 days was reported when reared in captivity during March at Adelaide (Fisher 1984b). ■ Distribution and habitat. This species is endemic to Australia, where it is widespread over much of the mainland, except for the northern parts of the NT and Cape York Peninsula, the far south-east and in TAS and the south-western quarter of WA. In WA, it has been recorded as far south as Exmouth (Common and Waterhouse 1981), in NT as far north as Cullen River 28 km south-east of Pine Creek (C.E. Meyer), and in QLD as far north as Musgrave (Monteith and Hancock 1977). E. padusa is common in dry inland areas where the larval food plants grow (Waterhouse 1932b; Fisher 1978), and in SA it is relatively common in the Flinders Ranges. Although the species is not known to migrate, adults are clearly capable of dispersing great distances as they have been captured many hundreds of kilometres outside the natural range of the larval food plants. In the south-east, where it is a rare vagrant and breeding populations are not established, single specimens were collected from as far south as Jervis Bay in 1919 (L.M. Mosse-Robinson), nine kilometres east of Hoskinstown in 1980 (D.J. Ferguson), seven kilometres north-west of Bungendore in 1988 (J. Armstrong), NSW, suburban Canberra (Kitching et al. 1978), Mt Majura in 1993 (M.S. Roesler and A. Polak), Camels Back in the Tidbinbilla Range (1420 m) in 1998 (M.F. Braby), ACT, Dimboola, VIC (Waterhouse and Lyell 1914), and the Coorong in 1946, SA (Fisher 1978 and pers. comm.). Near Melbourne, it has been recorded very occasionally, with records from East St. Kilda, Wandin in 1914, Malvern in 1944 (Dunn and Dunn 1991), Croydon in 1944 (W.N.B. Quick) and Research in 1979 (T. Brain). Most specimens from these southern localities have been collected between October and January. A number of Victorian localities listed by Anderson and Spry (1893-94) for E. angulipennis, including Springvale, Balaclava, Coburg and Mt Buninyong near Ballarat during March and April, are probably erroneous. This species is not known to occur further south than Sydney, so these early records are likely to be of E. padusa. ■ Major reference. Fisher (1984b).

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Elymnias hypermnestra (Linnaeus, 1763) Plate 4, figs.1a-i (In Johansson, B.) Amoenit. Acad. 6 (121): 407 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - Java; ssp. tonkiniana - C. Tonkin (N. Vietnam), Chiem Hoa (Tuyen Quang province); Elymnias nigrescens tonkiniana, Fruhstorfer, [1902a]: 271-273. Syntypes [Male] and [Female], xi 1899, Tonkin: Haiphong; viii-ix.1900, Chiern Hoa. Elymnias nigrescens tonkiniana [Female] f- typica: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 188. Tonkin: Haiphong; C. Annam: Phuc Son. Elymnias nigrescens tonkiniana [Female] f. typica: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 188. Syntypes 11 [Male], 7 [Female]. Tonkin: Chiem-Hoa. Elymnias nigrescens tonkiniana: Fruhstorfer, 1911: 377. Tonkin: Haiphong; C. Annam: Phuc Son. Elymnias migrescens (sic.) f. tonkiniana: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Tonkin, C. Annam. Elymnias migrescens (sic.) f. depicta: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Tonkin. Elymnias hypermnestra tonkiniana: Ikeda et al. 1999: 53, figs 4/5, 6 - [Male] (Up & Un), 9/18 - [Male] (genitalia). N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). ssp. meridionalis - C. Vietnam, (Xom-Gom), Elymnias undularis meridionalis Fruhstorfer, 1902b: 169. Syntypes [Male] and [Female], S. Annam: Xom-Gom; Cochinchina: Saigon. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 178-179. S. Annam; Cochinchina. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis [Female] f. orphina: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 179. Syntype [Female], S. Annam: Xom-Gom. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Fruhstorfer, 1911: 375. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis [Female] f. orphina Fruhstorfer, 1911: 375. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra f. meridionalis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra f. undularis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Cochinchina: Saigon. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 17. C. & S. Vietnam. ssp. robinsona - S. Vietnam, Con Dao Island (=Con Son) Elymnias hypermnestra robinsona Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 81-82. Holotype cT; paratypes 10 [Male], 12 [Female]. S. Vietnam , Con Dao Island (=Con Son) SYNONYMS, nigrescens Butler, 1871 (TL: Borneo); undularis Drury, 1773 (TL: N. India). RANGE. From Sri Lanka and India, east through S. China to Taiwan; south through Indochina and the Malay Peninsula to the Sunda Islands. Ssp. tonkiniana is restricted to N. and C. Vietnam, while the ssp. meridionalis is distributed in Cambodia, C. (southern part) and S. Vietnam. According to Aoki et al., (1982) in the west of the range, E. h. tonkiniana and E. h. meridionalis border upon E. h. violetta (Thailand and Laos). E. h. robinsona is an endemic of Con Dao Island. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. E. h. tonkiniana: N. Vietnam: Hanoi, Tam Dao N.P., Cat Ba N.P, Cue Phuong N.P; C. Vietnam: Ben En N.P, Pu Hoat N.R., Vu Quang N.R., Ke Bang N.R., Phong Dien N.R., Bach Ma N.P, Ba Na N.R., Ngoc Linh N.R. E. h. meridionalis: C. and S. Vietnam: Dac Lac Province, Lam Dong Province, Hon Ba P.N.R., Nui Chua N.R., Tan Phu N.R., Cat Tien N.P, Lo Go Sa Mat N.R. E. h. robinsona: S. Vietnam: Con Dao Island: 11 [Male] 12 [Female] VII, IX, XII, 1967 (ABR). Length of FW: [Female] 33-37mm, [Male] 35-40mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. Both sexes of ssp. tonkiniana from the north are rather similar. The females of this subspecies have a dark ground colour on the UpF with a bluish tinged ground colour and a series of blue submarginal spots. The female of ssp. meridionalis from the south differs from the male, which resembles the male from northern populations. It has a wide orange yellowish basal and discal area on the UpF with a series of whitish submarginal spots on both wings. In ssp. robinsona the female differs from the continental female populations in C. and S. Vietnam in having a very dull brown border and lacking any whitish spots on either wings. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. Tam Dao: palm vegetation at low elevation; Cat Ba: scrub, lowland forest; Cue Phuong: forest edge; Ben En: lowland secondary forest; Vu Quang: palm lowland forest, 200m; Phong Dien: mixed lowland forest, 200m; Bach Ma: secondary vegetation, palm plantation at 50-100m; Ngoc Linh: forest, 1,000 - 1,100m; Nui Chua: evergreen forest at 700-1,000m; Tan Phu: forest edge; Cat Tien: secondary vegetation and palm forest. Larval food plants comprise different species of palms, in particular Calamus spp., Areca catechu, A. saccharifera, Arenga engleri, Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, Cocos nucifera, Livistona spp., Metwxylon sagus, Phoenix humilis, P. roebelinii, Archontophoenix alexandrae (Aoki et al., 1982; Chou, 1994; Bascombe et al., 1999). SIMILAR SPECIES. Ssp. tonkiniana in flight resembles Elymnias patna and Euploea mulciber (Danainae); the flying female of ssp. meridionalis can be confused with Danaus genutia, D. melanippus and D. affinis.

Elymnias migrescens (sic.) f. depicta: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Tonkin. Elymnias hypermnestra tonkiniana: Ikeda et al. 1999: 53, figs 4/5, 6 - [Male] (Up & Un), 9/18 - [Male] (genitalia). N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). ssp. meridionalis - C. Vietnam, (Xom-Gom), Elymnias undularis meridionalis Fruhstorfer, 1902b: 169. Syntypes [Male] and [Female], S. Annam: Xom-Gom; Cochinchina: Saigon. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 178-179. S. Annam; Cochinchina. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis [Female] f. orphina: Fruhstorfer, 1907a: 179. Syntype [Female], S. Annam: Xom-Gom. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Fruhstorfer, 1911: 375. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis [Female] f. orphina Fruhstorfer, 1911: 375. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra f. meridionalis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. S. Annam. Elymnias hypermnestra f. undularis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Cochinchina: Saigon. Elymnias hypermnestra meridionalis: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 17. C. & S. Vietnam. ssp. robinsona - S. Vietnam, Con Dao Island (=Con Son) Elymnias hypermnestra robinsona Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 81-82. Holotype cT; paratypes 10 [Male], 12 [Female]. S. Vietnam , Con Dao Island (=Con Son) SYNONYMS, nigrescens Butler, 1871 (TL: Borneo); undularis Drury, 1773 (TL: N. India). RANGE. From Sri Lanka and India, east through S. China to Taiwan; south through Indochina and the Malay Peninsula to the Sunda Islands. Ssp. tonkiniana is restricted to N. and C. Vietnam, while the ssp. meridionalis is distributed in Cambodia, C. (southern part) and S. Vietnam. According to Aoki et al., (1982) in the west of the range, E. h. tonkiniana and E. h. meridionalis border upon E. h. violetta (Thailand and Laos). E. h. robinsona is an endemic of Con Dao Island. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. E. h. tonkiniana: N. Vietnam: Hanoi, Tam Dao N.P., Cat Ba N.P, Cue Phuong N.P; C. Vietnam: Ben En N.P, Pu Hoat N.R., Vu Quang N.R., Ke Bang N.R., Phong Dien N.R., Bach Ma N.P, Ba Na N.R., Ngoc Linh N.R. E. h. meridionalis: C. and S. Vietnam: Dac Lac Province, Lam Dong Province, Hon Ba P.N.R., Nui Chua N.R., Tan Phu N.R., Cat Tien N.P, Lo Go Sa Mat N.R. E. h. robinsona: S. Vietnam: Con Dao Island: 11 [Male] 12 [Female] VII, IX, XII, 1967 (ABR). Length of FW: [Female] 33-37mm, [Male] 35-40mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. Both sexes of ssp. tonkiniana from the north are rather similar. The females of this subspecies have a dark ground colour on the UpF with a bluish tinged ground colour and a series of blue submarginal spots. The female of ssp. meridionalis from the south differs from the male, which resembles the male from northern populations. It has a wide orange yellowish basal and discal area on the UpF with a series of whitish submarginal spots on both wings. In ssp. robinsona the female differs from the continental female populations in C. and S. Vietnam in having a very dull brown border and lacking any whitish spots on either wings. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. Tam Dao: palm vegetation at low elevation; Cat Ba: scrub, lowland forest; Cue Phuong: forest edge; Ben En: lowland secondary forest; Vu Quang: palm lowland forest, 200m; Phong Dien: mixed lowland forest, 200m; Bach Ma: secondary vegetation, palm plantation at 50-100m; Ngoc Linh: forest, 1,000 - 1,100m; Nui Chua: evergreen forest at 700-1,000m; Tan Phu: forest edge; Cat Tien: secondary vegetation and palm forest. Larval food plants comprise different species of palms, in particular Calamus spp., Areca catechu, A. saccharifera, Arenga engleri, Chrysalidocarpus lutescens, Cocos nucifera, Livistona spp., Metwxylon sagus, Phoenix humilis, P. roebelinii, Archontophoenix alexandrae (Aoki et al., 1982; Chou, 1994; Bascombe et al., 1999). SIMILAR SPECIES. Ssp. tonkiniana in flight resembles Elymnias patna and Euploea mulciber (Danainae); the flying female of ssp. meridionalis can be confused with Danaus genutia, D. melanippus and D. affinis.

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 1: Satyrinae
Habitat: can usually be found in secondary growth, countryside and urban gardens and parks
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: HABITATS Species of this subfamily can be found in any vegetative habitats of Vietnam from the shoreline to the highest peaks of montane areas. Basically all Satyrinae can be divided into lowland and montane species. For example, the majority of Mycalesini are lowland species while most Lethini are high montane inhabitants. Many tropical species, as with species of temperate zones, prefer open areas, while many other species prefer shady undergrowth within forested habitats. A great number of Satyrinae species may be recorded in the tropical forest sub-canopy. Butterflies fly very close to the ground, often sitting either on the ground surface or on the leaves of herbs and shrubs. They often visit sunlit forest paths and trails. Many have a swift, short-lived flight when disturbed during the day and settle quickly with wings closed in near-by foliage. The majority of satyrids can be recorded in the vicinity of their foodplants which belong to monocotyledonous families such as Poaceae (grasses) and Arecaceae (palms). More information concerning habitats is in the relevant text for individual taxa. Such species as Melanitis leda, Elymnias hypermnestra, Ypthima baldus and some Mycalesis species can usually be found in secondary growth, countryside and urban gardens and parks. The males are distinctly territorial and patrol an area for mating.

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Silver-spotted Skipper
Distribution.Range: Resident [to the Carolinas];
Abundance: It is a common garden visitor.; occasional to common
Flight.characteristics: The Silver-spotted Skipper is a large, robust butterfly with a rapid, darting flight.
Habitat: forest edges, open woodlands, roadsides, utility easements, old fields and gardens;  It is a common garden visitor.
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: wide variety of legumes including Black Locust, wisteria, bush clover. False Indigo, Kudzu, Groundnut, Butterfly Pea and beggarweeds
Adult.food: They have a long proboscis and can eas ily gain access to nectar from a variety of flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Late April - October; multiple generations
Defense.strategies: The colorful larvae construct individual shelters on the host by tying one or more leaves together with silk.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Silver-spotted Skipper Epargyreus clarus I: Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Spread-wing Skippers (Pyrginae) Wingspan: 1.75-2.40" (4.4-6.1 cm) Above: brown with median row of gold spots on forewing and checkered wing fringe; hindwing is tapered into small, rounded, lobe-like tail Below: brown; forewing as above; hindwing has distinct, elongated clear silver-white patch in center Sexes: similar Egg: green, laid singly on host leaves Larva: yellow-green with dark bands and reddish brown head Larval Host Plants: wide variety of legumes including Black Locust, wisteria, bush clover. False Indigo, Kudzu, Groundnut, Butterfly Pea and beggarweeds Habitat: forest edges, open woodlands, roadsides, utility easements, old fields and gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional to common Compare: Hoary Edge (pg. 205) is smaller and has mar ginal white ventral hindwing patch. Comments: The Silver-spotted Skipper is a large, robust butterfly with a rapid, darting flight. It is a common garden visitor. They have a long proboscis and can eas ily gain access to nectar from a variety of flowers. Males perch on shrubs or overhanging branches and aggressively investigate passers-by. The colorful larvae construct individual shelters on the host by tying one or more leaves together with silk.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Silver-spotted Skipper
Distribution.Range: A yearlong resident, it does not migrate.  Southern Canada, all of the continental U.S. and into northern Mexico. [images]Cook County, IL; Champaign County, IL; Vermilion County, IL
Abundance: Common statewide.
Flight.characteristics: . Males perch, actively darting at passing butterflies in their search for receptive conspecific females.
Habitat: Roadsides, gardens, open woods, brushy areas, disturbed areas. Likely to be found almost anywhere.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid singly on the larval host plants.
Hostplant.larval.food: a large variety of woody perennials, as well as a few herbaceous species. Favorite hosts are black locusts (Rohinia spp.), honey locusts (Gleditsia spp.), false indigo (Amorpha fruticosa), and many others.
Adult.food: Adults take nectar from a great variety of plants, preferring white, red, pink, or purple flowers. [images]on animal dung; feeding on butterfly bush
Phenology.and.voltinism: Multivoltine, two or three generations per year, with adults present from April to October  A yearlong resident, it does not migrate.
Defense.strategies: Larvae make shelters by fastening a cluster of leaflets together with silk.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Silverspotted Skippe
Distribution.Range: This is one of the most widely distributed North .American skippers. This species ranges from British Columbia to Quebec, south to Florida and Mexico. In .Alberta, the Silverspotted Skipper is found from the southeast corner of the pro\ ince north to Edmon ton and west to Nanton. Virtually all records are from river valley and hill systems in the prairie and aspen parkland regions. Adults can be found in small clearings in aspen woods, edges of poplar groves, along prairie streams, in badlands and in ravines.
Flight.characteristics: Males are aggressive fliers and often have aerial encounters with other males.
Habitat: Adults can be found in small clearings in aspen woods, edges of poplar groves, along prairie streams, in badlands and in ravines
Hostplant.larval.food: Numerous woody legumes have been reported as larval hosts; Wild Licorice {Glycyrrhiza lepidota) is the reported host in Alberta, North Dakota and Colorado. Peavine {Lathyrus spp.) and milk vetch {Astragalus spp.) are also used
Phenology.and.voltinism: There is one brood per year.  Adults fly from May 6 to August 1. The peak flight period is late June and early July.
Diapause: The brown pupae have light and dark markings and are protected by a loose co coon in the ground litter where they overwinter
Defense.strategies: The brown pupae have light and dark markings and are protected by a loose co coon in the ground litter where they overwinter

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: Silver-spotted skipper
Distribution.Range: North Bay counties, mainly inland. Formerly found with urban locust trees (Robinia) in Sacramento and Yolo Counties, but no recent records.
Abundance: Unlike the eastern subspecies, ours is seldom very common
Habitat: , The Silver-spotted Skipper is found in riparian canyon habitat, often along roadsides where males perch on foliage well off the ground
Hostplant.larval.food: it has benefited from the introduction of the ornamental tree black locust (Robinia pseudacacia) in the nineteenth century. This is the usual host plant of the eastern subspecies (typical E. c. clarus)y and our sub species quickly adopted it as a host as weU. As a result, it is regu larly seen in towns such as Downieville, Jackson, or WeaverviUe, where no native hosts occur.   All pea family (Fabaceae) plants including false in digo or lead plant (Amorpha); Lotus crassifolius; black locust (Robinia pseudoacacia) but apparendy not honey or moraine lo cust (Gleditsia triacanthos); perennial vetches (Lathyrus) sus pected. The rapidly spreading weedy riparian shrub Argentine flame pea (Sesbania punicea) is very likely to be adopted as a host plant in the next decade, potentially increasing the range and abundance of this species into the Sacramento Valley and Delta
Adult.food: it is easily approached when feed ing at flowers, especially California buckeye (Aesculus califomica) and dogbanes (Apocynum),
Phenology.and.voltinism: One brood. May to early July depending on locality. A very few late-summer records may indicate a rudimentary sec ond brood. The eastern subspecies is multiple brooded.
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: This is the largest skipper in our fauna. Its flight is extremely fast, and the silver blotch on the underside of the hindwing flashes as the insect moves through dappled light and shade. It is difficult to follow in flight, but fortunately it is easily approached when feed ing at flowers, especially California buckeye (Aesculus califomica) and dogbanes (Apocynum), The Silver-spotted Skipper is found in riparian canyon habitat, often along roadsides where males perch on foliage well off the ground. In the Gold Country, and to a lesser extent in the North Coast Ranges, it has benefited from the introduction of the ornamental tree black locust (Robinia pseudacacia) in the nineteenth century. This is the usual host plant of the eastern subspecies (typical E. c. clarus)y and our sub species quickly adopted it as a host as weU. As a result, it is regu larly seen in towns such as Downieville, Jackson, or WeaverviUe, where no native hosts occur. Unlike the eastern subspecies, ours is seldom very common. DISTRIBUTION: North Bay counties, mainly inland. Formerly found with urban locust trees (Robinia) in Sacramento and Yolo Counties, but no recent records. HOST PLANTS: All pea family (Fabaceae) plants including false in digo or lead plant (Amorpha); Lotus crassifolius; black locust (Robinia pseudoacacia) but apparendy not honey or moraine lo cust (Gleditsia triacanthos); perennial vetches (Lathyrus) sus pected. The rapidly spreading weedy riparian shrub Argentine flame pea (Sesbania punicea) is very likely to be adopted as a host plant in the next decade, potentially increasing the range and abundance of this species into the Sacramento Valley and Delta. Larvae tie several leaflets together to form solitary nests. The large larva has a brown head capsule with two bright orange eye like spots; many people find its appearance clownish. Since the larva rarely leaves its nest in daylight, the function of these spots is unknown. If disturbed, the larva throws fecal pellets through the air, adding to the comical effect. SEASONS: One brood. May to early July depending on locality. A very few late-summer records may indicate a rudimentary sec ond brood. The eastern subspecies is multiple brooded. SIMILAR SPECIES: None in our area.

Common.name: Arran Brown
Distribution.Range: The Arran brown can be found anywhere in Finland: it is common in the south and casual in Lapland.
Abundance: Annual numbers fluctuate biennially due to the fact that the larvae need two years to develop. The species is most abundant in oddly-numbered years.
Habitat: Habitat: Forests, forest margins, logging clearings and also shores.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larval foodplant: Different grasses (Poaceae) and sedges (Carex).
Phenology.and.voltinism: Flying time: Mid-July–mid-August.; Overwintering form: First winter as egg and second as caterpillar.
Diapause: Overwintering form: First winter as egg and second as caterpillar.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Arran Brown Erebia ligea Family: Brushfooted Butterflies – Nymphalidae Subfamily: Browns – Satyrinae Wing span: Medium-sized, 36–46 mm (1.41–1.8 in.). Wing upper side: Dark brown, forewing and hind wing with red strip along edge with black spots and eyespots with white centres. Wing underside: Forewing dark brown. Outer part with red strip with black, white-centred eyespots. Hind wing brown, edge with row of clear or unclear eyespots. Basal side of eyespots close to centre of wing with one or two white patches. Basal part of females’ hind wing darker than outer margin area around eyespots. Habitat: Forests, forest margins, logging clearings and also shores. Flying time: Mid-July–mid-August. Overwintering form: First winter as egg and second as caterpillar. Larval foodplant: Different grasses (Poaceae) and sedges (Carex). The Arran brown can be found anywhere in Finland: it is common in the south and casual in Lapland. Annual numbers fluctuate biennially due to the fact that the larvae need two years to develop. The species is most abundant in oddly-numbered years.  Like all the ringlets it has eyespots surrounded by a red or reddish yellow area. The Arran brown’s flying time is usually later than the Arctic or Lapland ringlet’s. These and the dewy ringlet lack the Arran brown’s continuous red strip along the underside of the forewings and hind wings. The Arctic woodland ringlet’s can be continuous, but it lacks the white blotches on the underside of the wing that are typical of the Arran brown.

Oviposition: often oviposits on young trees and saplings
Hostplant.larval.food: Oaks (Quercus); in summer utilizes tender young growth,  Recorded in our area from both evergreen species (coast live oak [Q. agrifoliajy interior live oak [Q. wisUzenii]) and decid uous ones (valley oak [Q. lobataj) and on introduced species in cluding cork oak (Q. suber) from the Mediterranean and eastern black oak (Q. velutina) from the eastern United States.

Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: This is the only duskywing routinely observed in cities and sub urbs in both the Bay Area and the Sacramento Valley. In wild lands it occurs with oaks (Quercus)y often in riparian situations but also in chaparral. Males hilltop in midafternoon. This species is less of a puddler than most duskywings. It visits tall flowers such as tall blue verbena (Verbena bonariensc)^ milkweeds (Asclepias)y dogbanes (Apocynum)y yerba santas (Eriodictyon)y mints (Mentha)y and California buckeye (Aesculus californica)^ and in gardens it is partial to butterfly bush (Buddleia). There is little variation except between the sexes. DISTRIBUTION: All counties. HOST PLANTS: Oaks (Quercus); in summer utilizes tender young growth, mainly at shoot tips; often oviposits on young trees and saplings. Recorded in our area from both evergreen species (coast live oak [Q. agrifoliajy interior live oak [Q. wisUzenii]) and decid uous ones (valley oak [Q. lobataj) and on introduced species in cluding cork oak (Q. suber) from the Mediterranean and eastern black oak (Q. velutina) from the eastern United States. SEASONS: Three to four broods, January (rare) to October. SIMILAR SPECIES: The Propertius Duskywing (E. propertius), with which the Mournful Duskywing often occurs, has dark fringes and the two diagnostic white spots on the ventral hindwing below. The Funereal Duskywing (E. fnneralis) has white fringes but the forewing is longer and narrower, with a some what frosted, sometimes vaguely bronzed or reddish appear ance, and occurs mostly in a different sort of habitat and is rare in our area.

Common.name: Atala Hairstreak
Distribution.Range: Only the typical subspecies, E. atala atala, occurs in the Antilles, in Cuba, the Isle of Pines and on Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas. Specimens from the last locality should be carefully compared with the Florida subspecies, E. atala florida Roeber 1926... The Central American Eumaeus minijas Huebner... RANGE: Florida, Cuba and Bahamas. TL: Cuba.
Abundance: local but sometimes abundant.
Habitat: A lowland butterfly
Hostplant.larval.food: It feeds openly on the leaves of the Cycad, Zamia integrifoliat 'Coontie' and is known as the Coontie Worm in Florida. In Cuba the food plant is known as 'Yuquilla'.
Defense.strategies: The red coloration suggests that the caterpillar is distasteful.
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: EUMAEUS ATALA Poey 1832 Atala Hairstreak Pl. 11 Description. Fw [male] 20-22 mm, [female] 21-24 mm. A large black round-winged tailless Hairstreak with metallic blue-green suffusion and marginal spots, and a red abdomen. The metallic blue on the upperside extends to near the margin of the forewing and fills the cell of the hindwing in the male, but is less extensive in the female. Beneath, the forewing is essentially dull black, but the hindwing is decorated with three concentric rows of blue-green or blue spots. Quite unmistakable. Distribution. Only the typical subspecies, E. atala atala, occurs in the Antilles, in Cuba, the Isle of Pines and on Great Abaco Island in the Bahamas. Specimens from the last locality should be carefully compared with the Florida subspecies, E. atala florida Roeber 1926, which has more extensive blue-green on the upperside and larger spots of that colour on the underside of the hindwing. The Central American Eumaeus minijas Huebner is smaller, has black fringes and a black body with only the tip red beneath. A lowland butterfly, local but sometimes abundant. RANGE: Florida, Cuba and Bahamas. TL: Cuba. Early stages. The full-grown caterpillar is brilliant red, the body segments rather humped-up and each with a transverse row of four tubercles bearing tufts of short hair. In shape it is much less slug-like than usual for a Lycaenid caterpillar. It feeds openly on the leaves of the Cycad, Zamia integrifoliat 'Coontie' and is known as the Coontie Worm in Florida. In Cuba the food plant is known as 'Yuquilla'. The red coloration suggests that the caterpillar is distasteful.

Abundance: most common in early summer. Considered endangered by the State of Florida, where populations are thought to have gone extinct from time to time. Possibly the butterflies reeolonize from Bahamian populations, as  in  the late  1970s and 1980s when, after a long absence, the butterflies became locally abundant and a minor pest of ornamental cycads

Phenology.and.voltinism: All year, most common in early summer.

Author: andra.doherty

Book: Butterflies through Binoculars: The East- A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Eastern North America
Common.name: Atala
Distribution.Range: Also, West Indies. South Florida
Abundance: LC. Not too long ago, this species was thought to be gone from the U.S., a victim of the rapid development of South Florida. But since 1970, landscape gardeners and butterfly gardeners have planted increasing numbers of coontie and other cycads and the population of this butterfly, one of the more sensationally colored, is now booming.
Habitat: Anyplace its foodplants want to be, including urban and suburban plantings. Occasionally even found in natural habitats!
Hostplant.larval.food: Coontie (Zamia pumila) and other introduced ornamental cycads.
Phenology.and.voltinism: All year.

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Zebra Swallowtail
Distribution.Range: Resident [to the Carolinas]
Abundance: occasional to common; Resident [to the Carolinas]
Flight.characteristics: Adults have a low, rapid flight and adeptly maneuver among understory vegetation.
Habitat: rich woodlands, stream corridors, swamp mar gins, forest edges and old fields
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves or budding branches
Hostplant.larval.food: Pawpaw
Adult.food: This swal lowtail has a proportionately short proboscis and is thus unable to nectar at many long, tubular flowers. It instead prefers composites and is regularly attracted to white flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: March - Late October  multiple generations
Author: vaughn.shirey
Additional.Data: Males regularly patrol territories for females.
Full.Species.Account: Zebra Swallowtail Eurytides marcellus Family/Subfamily: Swallowtails (Papliionidae)/ Swallowtails (Papilioninae) Wingspan: 2.5-4.0" (6.4-10.2 cm) Above; white with black stripes and long, slender tailshindwings bear a bright red patch above the eyespor spring-forms are smaller, lighter and have shorter tails Below: as above, but with a red stripe through hindwing Sexes: similar Egg: light green, laid singly on host leaves or budding branches Larva: several color forms; may be green, green with light blue and yellow stripes or charcoal with white and yellow stripes Larval Host Plants: Pawpaw Habitat: rich woodlands, stream corridors, swamp mar gins, forest edges and old fields Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional to common Compare: unique  Comments: The black and white striped Zebra Swallowtail can be confused with no other resident Eastern butterfly. Adults have a low, rapid flight and adeptly maneuver among understory vegetation. Males regularly patrol territories for females. This swal lowtail has a proportionately short proboscis and is thus unable to nectar at many long, tubular flowers. It instead prefers composites and is regularly attracted to white flowers.

Book: The complete field guide to butterflies of Australia
Common.name: Regent Skipper
Distribution.Range: Montane areas of northeast Queensland. Local. Larval food plants found in northeast and southeast Queensland as well as northeast New South Wales.
Abundance: Generally common but local.
Flight.characteristics: Males fly rapidly and often gather on hilltops and ridges, especially in the more open areas towards dusk. They frequently settle on foliage of trees in the mid-canopy.
Habitat: Usually tropical and subtropical rainforest in both lowland and upland areas, where the larval food plants grow; also ecotone beteen rainforest and eucalypt tall open-forest in montane areas of northeast Queensland. They frequently settle on foliage of trees in the mid-canopy. They feed from flowers, such as Lantana on roadsides. Males often gather on hilltops and ridges, especially in the more open areas towards dusk.
Hostplant.larval.food: Usually Tetrasynandra pubescens in northeast Queensland, Wilkiea huegeliana in southeast Queensland and northeast New South Wales; also T. laxiflora, Wilkiea macrophylla, W. austroqueenslandica.
Adult.food: They feed from flowers, such as Lantana on roadsides.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Number of generations completed annually not recorded. Adults are active mainly during the late afternoon, but may also be observed flying during the early morning and at dusk. Males fly rapidly and often gather on hilltops and ridges, especially in the more open areas towards dusk.
Author: minji.ku
Full.Species.Account: Wingspan: male: 54 mm, female: 61 mm. Similar species: none. The Regent Skipper has the upperside colour black with bright lemon-yellow bands. Variation: two subspecies, both of which have the lemon-yellow spots and bands occasionally cream or while. Behaviour: adults are active mainly during the late afternoon, but may also be observed flying during the early morning and at dusk; they frequently settle, with wings outspread, on foliage of trees in the mid canopy, they also feed from flowers, such as Lantana on roadsides. Males fly rapidly and often gather on hilltops and ridges, especially in the more open areas towards dusk. Number of generations completed annually not recorded. Habitat: usually tropical and subtropical rainforest in both lowland and upland areas, where the larval food plants grow; also ecotone between rainforest and tall open-forest in montane areas of ne. QLD. Status: generally common but local. Larval food plants: usually Tetrasynandra pubescens in ne. QLD, Wilkea huegeliana in se. QLD and ne. NSW, T. laxiflora, Wilkea macrophylla, W austroqueenslandica.

Distribution.Range: Brasil; PA; Peru (Loreto)
Author: minji.ku
Full.Species.Account: Euselasia euromus (Hewitson, 1856) 25 mm Brasil; PA; Peru (Loreto)

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon Linne (Original Description) agmemnon Linne, Syst. Nat. , ed. 10, p.462, n. 21 (1758) exilis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.451 452 (1895) decoratum Rothschild, Nov . Zool., 2, p.452 (1895) baweanum Hagen, Jahrd . Ver. Nass. Nat., p.180, 181 (1896) ( Leiden Mus. ) atropictus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p.218 (1902)  comodus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p. 218 (1903) meton Fruhstorfer, Ins.-Bors. 21, p.180 (1904) andamanum Lathy, Trans. Ent. Soc. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive. Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: “Asia” [China, Canton (=Guangdong) | (Honey & Scouble, 2001)
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon (Linnaeus, 1758) Plate 27, figs.la-b Syst. Nat. (ed.10)1: 462 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - “Asia” [China, Canton (=Guangdong) | (Honey & Scouble, 2001). Papilio agamemnon f. agamemrton (=dorylas; rufescens): Dubois & Vitalis de  Salvaza, 1921:16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon ab. aegisthus (-anoura): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon f. menides: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Annam,  Cochinchine. Papilio agamemnon agamemnon ab. aegisthus: Metaye, 1957:84. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Papilio agamemnon menides: Metaye, 1957: 84. C. & S. Vietnam. Graphium agamemnon agamemnon: Ikeda et al., 1998: 17. Fig. 5/4-6: [male] Up & [female] Un,  9Up. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Graphium (Graphium) agamemnon agamemnon: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 12. N. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. dorylas Sulzer, 1776 (TL: ?China); rufescens Oberthur, 1879 (TL: ? China); aegisthus Linnaeus, 1763 (TL: China); and anoura Oberthiir, 1879 (TL: China) are all synonyms of the nominate subspecies G. agamemnon Linnaeus. RANG E. The species ranges from N. India to S. China and through the Archipelago to New Guinea, Queensland (Australia) and the Solomon Islands. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. G. agamemnon is common throughout Vietnam all year round. The sexes are alike, but the female is slightly larger and has more prominent tails. Length of FW: [male] [female] 45-47 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The long tail form menides Fruhstorfer, 1904 (TL: S. India) is distributed in Sri Lanka and s. India. Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) showed the form menides from C. & S. Vietnam. The same long tail form has been also recorded in N. Vietnam (Tam Dao N.p.) HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. This species is common in gardens, parks and other open areas. Eggs are pale yellow and smooth and generally laid singly on the under surface of the leaves. In S.E. Asia the larval foodplants are trees as follows: Polyalthia longifolia,  Annona squamosa and A. reticulata (Annonaceae) and various Magnoliaceae: e.g. Michelia doltospa (d'Abrera, 1998). The population in the Malay Peninsula feeds on  Saccopetalum sp. and Friesodielsia sp. (Annonaceae) and Michelia spp.(Magnoliaceae). Chinese populations are known to feed on Magnolia grandiflora, Artabotrys uncinatus, Desmos cochinchinensis and Uvaria microcarpa. SIMILAR SPECIES. Unmistakable in wing pattern, and a tailed species.

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Philippines generally
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 046) Graphium agamemnon (Linnaeus, 1758) TAILED JAY/GREEN SPOTTED TRIANGLE  Plate 8 Subspecies and distribution: (i) agamemnon (Linnaeus, 1758) - Philippines generally. Recorded hostplants: Annonaceae: Anaxagorea luzonensis, Annona cherimola, A. glabra, A. muricata (Soursop/Guyabano), A. reticulata (Custard Apple/Atis), Artabotrys hexapetalus, A. siamensis, A. speciosus, Desmos chinensis (Dwarf Ylang- ylang), D. cochinchinensis, Friesodielsia sp., Goniothalamus amuyon, G. macranthus, Guatteria sp., Melodorum fruticosum (White Cheesewood), M. siamense, M. uhrii, Polyalthia longifolia (Indian Tree), Pseuduvaria froggattii, Saccopetalum sp., Uvaria microcarpa, Xylopia maccreai.Dioscoreaceae: Dioscorea hispida. Fabaceae: Cassia bakeriana (Pink Cassia, Wishing Tree), C. fistula (Tropical Golden Shower). Lauraceae: Cinnamomum sp.. Magnoliaceae: Magnolia alba (White Champaca), M. champaca (Champak/ Tsampaka), M. compressa, M. fuscata, M. grandiflora, M. siamensis. Malvaceae:Durio zibethinus (Durian). Piperaceae: Piper betle (Betel). Rutaceae: Citrus maxima (Pomelo). Very common. Occurs in Metro Manila. Can be seen in most habitats including  urban areas.

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Engano
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon Linne (Original Description) agmemnon Linne, Syst. Nat. , ed. 10, p.462, n. 21 (1758) exilis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.451 452 (1895) decoratum Rothschild, Nov . Zool., 2, p.452 (1895) baweanum Hagen, Jahrd . Ver. Nass. Nat., p.180, 181 (1896) ( Leiden Mus. ) atropictus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p.218 (1902)  comodus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p. 218 (1903) meton Fruhstorfer, Ins.-Bors. 21, p.180 (1904) andamanum Lathy, Trans. Ent. Soc. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive.  (Range) agamemnon : China , Formosa, Thailand, Burma, N.India, Philippines, Malaya, Sumatra, Borneo, Java , Bali, Palawan (=dorylas, rufescens, anoura ) menides : Sri Lanka S.India andamanum : Andaman (=andamana, andamanica) decoratum : Nikobar (=decoratus, pulo) lasius : Simaulue rufoplenus : Nias atropictus : Engano baweanum : Bawean meton : Lombok, Sumbawa, Sumba, Alor, Flores exilis : Wetar, Damar, Babar, Timor, Kisar, Tanimbar (=pedius, perecopus) comodus : Celebes, Sula, Kalao, Tanajampea, Selayar, Talaud, Sangir (=celebensis) enoplos : Palau guttatus : Morotai, Halmahera, Ternate, Bachan, Obi (=kineas, appius) plisthenes : Buru, Ambon, Seram argynnus : Kai mynion : Queensland obliteratus : Louisiades ligatus : New Guinea, Irian, Aru, Misol, Waigeu, Jobi, Mefor (=ligathus, atreus, aegistus) neopommeranius : Bismarck, New Ireland, New Hanover ugiensis : Ugi salomonis : Shortland, Choiseul, Gizo, Bougainville, Rendova, Florida, Guadalcanar, Santa Isabel  PLATE 148 1 [male] agamemnon 1977-May Kalo Hill N .SUMATRA 2 [male] agamemnon 1979-Nov.-21 Keningau N.BORNEO 3 [male] V agamemnon 1979- May Surabaya E. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive. Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Simaulue
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon Linne (Original Description) agmemnon Linne, Syst. Nat. , ed. 10, p.462, n. 21 (1758) exilis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.451 452 (1895) decoratum Rothschild, Nov . Zool., 2, p.452 (1895) baweanum Hagen, Jahrd . Ver. Nass. Nat., p.180, 181 (1896) ( Leiden Mus. ) atropictus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p.218 (1902)  comodus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p. 218 (1903) meton Fruhstorfer, Ins.-Bors. 21, p.180 (1904) andamanum Lathy, Trans. Ent. Soc. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive.  (Range) agamemnon : China , Formosa, Thailand, Burma, N.India, Philippines, Malaya, Sumatra, Borneo, Java , Bali, Palawan (=dorylas, rufescens, anoura ) menides : Sri Lanka S.India andamanum : Andaman (=andamana, andamanica) decoratum : Nikobar (=decoratus, pulo) lasius : Simaulue rufoplenus : Nias atropictus : Engano baweanum : Bawean meton : Lombok, Sumbawa, Sumba, Alor, Flores exilis : Wetar, Damar, Babar, Timor, Kisar, Tanimbar (=pedius, perecopus) comodus : Celebes, Sula, Kalao, Tanajampea, Selayar, Talaud, Sangir (=celebensis) enoplos : Palau guttatus : Morotai, Halmahera, Ternate, Bachan, Obi (=kineas, appius) plisthenes : Buru, Ambon, Seram argynnus : Kai mynion : Queensland obliteratus : Louisiades ligatus : New Guinea, Irian, Aru, Misol, Waigeu, Jobi, Mefor (=ligathus, atreus, aegistus) neopommeranius : Bismarck, New Ireland, New Hanover ugiensis : Ugi salomonis : Shortland, Choiseul, Gizo, Bougainville, Rendova, Florida, Guadalcanar, Santa Isabel  PLATE 148 1 [male] agamemnon 1977-May Kalo Hill N .SUMATRA 2 [male] agamemnon 1979-Nov.-21 Keningau N.BORNEO 3 [male] V agamemnon 1979- May Surabaya E. Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: S. India... distributed in Sri Lanka and s. India
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon (Linnaeus, 1758) Plate 27, figs.la-b Syst. Nat. (ed.10)1: 462 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - “Asia” [China, Canton (=Guangdong) | (Honey & Scouble, 2001). Papilio agamemnon f. agamemrton (=dorylas; rufescens): Dubois & Vitalis de  Salvaza, 1921:16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon ab. aegisthus (-anoura): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon f. menides: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Annam,  Cochinchine. Papilio agamemnon agamemnon ab. aegisthus: Metaye, 1957:84. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Papilio agamemnon menides: Metaye, 1957: 84. C. & S. Vietnam. Graphium agamemnon agamemnon: Ikeda et al., 1998: 17. Fig. 5/4-6: [male] Up & [female] Un,  9Up. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Graphium (Graphium) agamemnon agamemnon: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 12. N. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. dorylas Sulzer, 1776 (TL: ?China); rufescens Oberthur, 1879 (TL: ? China); aegisthus Linnaeus, 1763 (TL: China); and anoura Oberthiir, 1879 (TL: China) are all synonyms of the nominate subspecies G. agamemnon Linnaeus. RANG E. The species ranges from N. India to S. China and through the Archipelago to New Guinea, Queensland (Australia) and the Solomon Islands. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. G. agamemnon is common throughout Vietnam all year round. The sexes are alike, but the female is slightly larger and has more prominent tails. Length of FW: [male] [female] 45-47 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The long tail form menides Fruhstorfer, 1904 (TL: S. India) is distributed in Sri Lanka and s. India. Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) showed the form menides from C. & S. Vietnam. The same long tail form has been also recorded in N. Vietnam (Tam Dao N.p.) HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. This species is common in gardens, parks and other open areas. Eggs are pale yellow and smooth and generally laid singly on the under surface of the leaves. In S.E. Asia the larval foodplants are trees as follows: Polyalthia longifolia,  Annona squamosa and A. reticulata (Annonaceae) and various Magnoliaceae: e.g. Michelia doltospa (d'Abrera, 1998). The population in the Malay Peninsula feeds on  Saccopetalum sp. and Friesodielsia sp. (Annonaceae) and Michelia spp.(Magnoliaceae). Chinese populations are known to feed on Magnolia grandiflora, Artabotrys uncinatus, Desmos cochinchinensis and Uvaria microcarpa. SIMILAR SPECIES. Unmistakable in wing pattern, and a tailed species.

Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon Linne (Original Description) agmemnon Linne, Syst. Nat. , ed. 10, p.462, n. 21 (1758) exilis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.451 452 (1895) decoratum Rothschild, Nov . Zool., 2, p.452 (1895) baweanum Hagen, Jahrd . Ver. Nass. Nat., p.180, 181 (1896) ( Leiden Mus. ) atropictus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p.218 (1902)  comodus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p. 218 (1903) meton Fruhstorfer, Ins.-Bors. 21, p.180 (1904) andamanum Lathy, Trans. Ent. Soc. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive.  (Range) agamemnon : China , Formosa, Thailand, Burma, N.India, Philippines, Malaya, Sumatra, Borneo, Java , Bali, Palawan (=dorylas, rufescens, anoura ) menides : Sri Lanka S.India andamanum : Andaman (=andamana, andamanica) decoratum : Nikobar (=decoratus, pulo) lasius : Simaulue rufoplenus : Nias atropictus : Engano baweanum : Bawean meton : Lombok, Sumbawa, Sumba, Alor, Flores exilis : Wetar, Damar, Babar, Timor, Kisar, Tanimbar (=pedius, perecopus) comodus : Celebes, Sula, Kalao, Tanajampea, Selayar, Talaud, Sangir (=celebensis) enoplos : Palau guttatus : Morotai, Halmahera, Ternate, Bachan, Obi (=kineas, appius) plisthenes : Buru, Ambon, Seram argynnus : Kai mynion : Queensland obliteratus : Louisiades ligatus : New Guinea, Irian, Aru, Misol, Waigeu, Jobi, Mefor (=ligathus, atreus, aegistus) neopommeranius : Bismarck, New Ireland, New Hanover ugiensis : Ugi salomonis : Shortland, Choiseul, Gizo, Bougainville, Rendova, Florida, Guadalcanar, Santa Isabel  PLATE 148 1 [male] agamemnon 1977-May Kalo Hill N .SUMATRA 2 [male] agamemnon 1979-Nov.-21 Keningau N.BORNEO 3 [male] V agamemnon 1979- May Surabaya E. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour.
