Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Ugi
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon Linne (Original Description) agmemnon Linne, Syst. Nat. , ed. 10, p.462, n. 21 (1758) exilis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.451 452 (1895) decoratum Rothschild, Nov . Zool., 2, p.452 (1895) baweanum Hagen, Jahrd . Ver. Nass. Nat., p.180, 181 (1896) ( Leiden Mus. ) atropictus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p.218 (1902)  comodus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 47, p. 218 (1903) meton Fruhstorfer, Ins.-Bors. 21, p.180 (1904) andamanum Lathy, Trans. Ent. Soc. Lona., p.5 (1907) rufoplenus Fruhstorfer, Berl. Ent. Zeitschr., 42, p.310 (1917) lasius Eecke, Zool. Med., 4, p.73 (1918) [Notes] This species belongs to the Agamemnon group of the subgenus Graphium. Besides the typical one the Macfarlanei and Wallacei subgroups are included in the Agamemnon group. The two are well-developed in the Papuan sub-region. This species is a widely distributed species ranging from S. India through the Archipelago eastwards to the Solomons, and is separated into 21 subspecies. Its sister species G. meeki on Santa Isabel Island is a exceedingly rare species, of only few females have so far been collected. On the contrary agamemnon is everywhere common, both the sexes being frequently collected. Within the area here dealt with ten subspecies are distributed, but these western agamemnon forms are not so attractive for they vary but little. Besides, the forms occurring in the vast area ranging from N. India through Sundaland to the Philippines and Formosa, are included in the nominate subspecies except those from the Andamans and a chain of islands off west coast of Sumatra. Futhermore, the subspecies from the latter islands also differ but little from the nominate subspecies. However, its eastern subspecies occurring from Papua to the Solomons vary dynamically, and several good subspecies are found among them, the example of which is the conspicuously darkened subspecies neopommeranius from the Bismarcks. Seven subspecies are figured in this book, other three, namely, decoratum of the Nicobars, lasius of Simeulue and atropictus of Engano being unavailable. The above three islands are all remotely located and difficult to enter. The butterflies visit various blossoms such as Lantana and Bougainvillea and frequently suck water. They fly off rapidly with their beautiful green markings glittering in thesun. They are found abundantly in submontane areas, but are equally found near seasides and villages. Rarely they are in evidence on the mountain, which suggest their strong flying powers. This species, with its wings spotted with bright green, was quite impressive when we first observed it in S. Formosa. It is not abundant in Formosa, but is widely distributed and very common from the Philippines to southwards. The female of this species are more frequently captured than the sex of other Graphium species, probably because this species is mainly collected on flowers. The female is larger than the male and has the longer tail though it varies in length within the same nominate subspecies. The female is paler, but it is more correctly identified by checking the scent hairs within the fold on the inner margin of the hindwing. The example figured in PLATE 148-5 is an aberrant form from W. Malaysia, such an aberration being rarely found in this species, though melanic forms are known to occur among other several species of Graphium such as sarpedon. The recorded larval food plants include Annona reticulata, A. squamosa and A. discolor (Annonaceae); Michelia fuscata, M. alba and M. figo (Magnoliaceae). The Graphium forms of Nias, for example, the subspecies of doson, evemon and sarpedon, have the beautifully developed red spots on the hindwing beneath in common, but rufoplenus, the Niasese subspecies of this species, has the only slightly enlarged red spots as compared with other subspecies, and lacks the brilliancy of the red spots unlike doson and evemon. In Nias it is found throughout the year but not so abundant. The Andaman subspecies andamanum is quite beautiful with its small green spots tinged with blue. The Celebesian comodus is differently looking in having the considerably large size and the darker ground colour. We obtained this species in some numbers from Lombok, where collecting should have been made in proper season. Ssp. exilis ranging from Timor to Tanimbar is difficult to obtain probably due to its scarcity. The subspecies, with its weakly spotted, dark hindwing, somewhat indicates the character of the Papuan subspecies. A typical tropical butterfly. Its soaring flight in the strong sunshine, as well as its swift flitting from flower to flower with the wing vibrated rapidly, is really impressive.  (Range) agamemnon : China , Formosa, Thailand, Burma, N.India, Philippines, Malaya, Sumatra, Borneo, Java , Bali, Palawan (=dorylas, rufescens, anoura ) menides : Sri Lanka S.India andamanum : Andaman (=andamana, andamanica) decoratum : Nikobar (=decoratus, pulo) lasius : Simaulue rufoplenus : Nias atropictus : Engano baweanum : Bawean meton : Lombok, Sumbawa, Sumba, Alor, Flores exilis : Wetar, Damar, Babar, Timor, Kisar, Tanimbar (=pedius, perecopus) comodus : Celebes, Sula, Kalao, Tanajampea, Selayar, Talaud, Sangir (=celebensis) enoplos : Palau guttatus : Morotai, Halmahera, Ternate, Bachan, Obi (=kineas, appius) plisthenes : Buru, Ambon, Seram argynnus : Kai mynion : Queensland obliteratus : Louisiades ligatus : New Guinea, Irian, Aru, Misol, Waigeu, Jobi, Mefor (=ligathus, atreus, aegistus) neopommeranius : Bismarck, New Ireland, New Hanover ugiensis : Ugi salomonis : Shortland, Choiseul, Gizo, Bougainville, Rendova, Florida, Guadalcanar, Santa Isabel  PLATE 148 1 [male] agamemnon 1977-May Kalo Hill N .SUMATRA 2 [male] agamemnon 1979-Nov.-21 Keningau N.BORNEO 3 [male] V agamemnon 1979- May Surabaya E. Book: The complete field guide to butterflies of Australia
Common.name: Green-spotted Triangle
Distribution.Range: Local.
Abundance: Common but local.
Flight.characteristics: Adults fly very rapidly in sunny openings such as clearings or along edges of the forest, occasionally descending from the canopy to feed from flowers, pausing momentarily at each flower with wings constantly vibrating.
Habitat: Tropical rain forest and monsoon forest (semi-evergreen vine thicket), where the larval food plants grow. Adults fly very rapidly in sunny openings such as clearings or along edges of the forest.
Hostplant.larval.food: Cyathostemma, Desmos, Fitzalania, Gniothalamus, Haplostichanthus, Meiogyne, Melodorum, Miliusa, Polyalthia, Pseuduvaria, Uvaria, Xylopia, *Annona, *Rollinia.  [* = introduced]
Adult.food: Feeds from flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Several generations completed annually.
Author: minji.ku
Full.Species.Account: Wingspan: male: 62 mm, female: 65 mm.  Similar species; Green Triangle. The Green-spotted Triangle has a short tail on the HW tornus, and the central spots on the FW upperside discrete. Behaviour: adults fly very rapidly in sunny openings such as clearings or along edges of the forest, occasionally descending from the canopy to feed from flowers, pausing momentarily at each flower with wings constantly vibrating. Several generations completed annually.  Habitat: tropical rainforest and monsoon forest (semi-evergreen vine thicket), where the larval food plants grow. Status: common but local. Larval food plants: Cyathostemma, Desmos, Fitzalania, Goniothalamus, Haplostichanthus, Meigyne, Melodorum, Miliusa, Polyalthia, Pseuduvaria, Uvaria, Xylopia, *Annona, *Rollinia

Book: The Butterflies of Thailand Vol. 1: Hesperiidae, Papilionidae, Pieridae
Distribution.Range: Doi Suthep, Chiang Mai Prov.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Doi Suthep, Chiang Mai Prov. May 1977

Book: Butterflies of Micronesia
Common.name: Tailed jay, green spotted triangle.
Distribution.Range: Palau. North India to the Solomons. In Palau we observed it primarily around Koror.
Flight.characteristics: Males appeared to set up territories around certain trees, and were observed flying rapidly about but returning to the same spots.
Habitat: we observed it primarily around Koror, probably feeding on Annonaceae in gardens. Males appeared to set up territories around certain trees
Hostplant.larval.food: Food plants of the larvae in Asia include Annona. Saccopetalum, Friesodielsia, Polyalthia, Mitrephora frogatti (all Annonaceae) and Michelia.
Adult.food: probably feeding on Annonaceae
Author: Sam.Lopez
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon (L.) Plate 2 Palau Tailed jay or the green spotted triangle. Range: North India to the Solomons. A number of subspecies are known from various islands. Mature larvae are ocher yellow to dark green. Each segment bears a brown spine, which on segment three arises from an orange spot. The pupa is a watery blue-green with yellow markings on the thorax. In Palau we observed it primarily around Koror, probably feeding on Annonaceae in gardens. Males appeared to set up territories around certain trees, and were observed flying rapidly about but returning to the same spots. Food plants of the larvae in Asia include Annona. Saccopetalum, Friesodielsia, Polyalthia, Mitrephora frogatti (all Annonaceae) and Michelia.

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: The species ranges from N. India to s. China and through the Archipelago to New Guinea, Queensland (Australia) and the Solomon Islands
Abundance: common throughout Vietnam
Habitat: This species is common in gardens, parks and other open  areas
Oviposition: Eggs... generally laid singly on the under surface of  the leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: In S.E. Asia the larval foodplants are trees as follows: Polyalthia longifolia, Annona squamosa and A. reticulata (Annonaceae) and various Magnoliaceae: e.g. Michelia doltospa (d'Abrera, 1998). The population in the Malay Peninsula feeds on Saccopetalum sp. and Friesodielsia sp. (Annonaceae) and Michelia spp.(Magnoliaceae).  Chinese populations are known to feed on Magnolia grandiflora, Artabotrys uncinatus, Desmos cochinchinensis and Uvaria microcarpa
Phenology.and.voltinism: common throughout Vietnam all year round
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Graphium agamemnon (Linnaeus, 1758) Plate 27, figs.la-b Syst. Nat. (ed.10)1: 462 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - “Asia” [China, Canton (=Guangdong) | (Honey & Scouble, 2001). Papilio agamemnon f. agamemrton (=dorylas; rufescens): Dubois & Vitalis de  Salvaza, 1921:16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon ab. aegisthus (-anoura): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Indochina. Papilio agamemnon f. menides: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 16. Annam,  Cochinchine. Papilio agamemnon agamemnon ab. aegisthus: Metaye, 1957:84. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Papilio agamemnon menides: Metaye, 1957: 84. C. & S. Vietnam. Graphium agamemnon agamemnon: Ikeda et al., 1998: 17. Fig. 5/4-6: [male] Up & [female] Un,  9Up. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Graphium (Graphium) agamemnon agamemnon: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 12. N. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. dorylas Sulzer, 1776 (TL: ?China); rufescens Oberthur, 1879 (TL: ? China); aegisthus Linnaeus, 1763 (TL: China); and anoura Oberthiir, 1879 (TL: China) are all synonyms of the nominate subspecies G. agamemnon Linnaeus. RANG E. The species ranges from N. India to S. China and through the Archipelago to New Guinea, Queensland (Australia) and the Solomon Islands. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. G. agamemnon is common throughout Vietnam all year round. The sexes are alike, but the female is slightly larger and has more prominent tails. Length of FW: [male] [female] 45-47 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The long tail form menides Fruhstorfer, 1904 (TL: S. India) is distributed in Sri Lanka and s. India. Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) showed the form menides from C. & S. Vietnam. The same long tail form has been also recorded in N. Vietnam (Tam Dao N.p.) HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. This species is common in gardens, parks and other open areas. Eggs are pale yellow and smooth and generally laid singly on the under surface of the leaves. In S.E. Asia the larval foodplants are trees as follows: Polyalthia longifolia,  Annona squamosa and A. reticulata (Annonaceae) and various Magnoliaceae: e.g. Michelia doltospa (d'Abrera, 1998). The population in the Malay Peninsula feeds on  Saccopetalum sp. and Friesodielsia sp. (Annonaceae) and Michelia spp.(Magnoliaceae). Chinese populations are known to feed on Magnolia grandiflora, Artabotrys uncinatus, Desmos cochinchinensis and Uvaria microcarpa. SIMILAR SPECIES. Unmistakable in wing pattern, and a tailed species.

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Common.name: TAILED JAY, GREEN SPOTTED TRIANGLE
Distribution.Range: Occurs in Metro Manila
Abundance: Very common
Habitat: Can be seen in most habitats including urban areas
Hostplant.larval.food: Annonaceae: Anaxagorea luzonensis, Annona cherimola, A. glabra, A. muricata (Soursop/Guyabano), A. reticulata (Custard Apple/Atis), Artabotrys hexapetalus, A. siamensis, A. speciosus, Desmos chinensis (Dwarf Ylang- ylang), D. cochinchinensis, Friesodielsia sp., Goniothalamus amuyon, G. macranthus, Guatteria sp., Melodorum fruticosum (White Cheesewood), M. siamense, M. uhrii, Polyalthia longifolia (Indian Tree), Pseuduvaria froggattii, Saccopetalum sp., Uvaria microcarpa, Xylopia maccreai.Dioscoreaceae: Dioscorea hispida. Fabaceae: Cassia bakeriana (Pink Cassia, Wishing Tree), C. fistula (Tropical Golden Shower). Lauraceae: Cinnamomum sp.. Distribution.Range: TYPE LOCALITY. England (Verity, 1943). RANGE. Europe; Turkey. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION. Occurring locally in the W. and S. European parts, and the Caucasus Major.
Habitat: Open landscapes in deciduous forest, in the mountains
Hostplant.larval.food: Host plants in Turkey (Hesselbarth et al., 1995): Primula vulgaris, P. auriculata
Phenology.and.voltinism: Flight period: May to June, sometimes in August to September as a second generation.
Diapause: Hibernation pupal.
Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Hamearis lucina (Linnaeus, 1758)  Pl. 49, figs. 10-12. Syst. Nat. (ed. 10), 1: 480.  TYPE LOCALITY. England (Verity, 1943). RANGE. Europe; Turkey. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION. Occurring locally in the W. and S. European parts, and the Caucasus Major. HABITATS AND BIOLOGY. Open landscapes in deciduous forest, in the mountains up to 1,300 m a.s.l. Flight period: May to June, sometimes in August to September as a second generation. Host plants in Turkey (Hesselbarth et al., 1995): Primula vulgaris, P. auriculata . Hibernation pupal.

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Ent., 2, p. 25 (1859) Nias borneensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Borneo javanensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Java timorensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Timor celebensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Celebes philippensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Luzon roepstorffi : Wood-Mason, Journ. As. Soc. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Cuyo
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon, Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Mindoro
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Balabac, Calamian, Palawan
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.
