Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Polillo
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Distribution.Range: Bachan
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Ent., 2, p. 25 (1859) Nias borneensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Borneo javanensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Java timorensis : Wallace, Journ. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Ent., 2, p. 25 (1859) Nias borneensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Borneo javanensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Java timorensis : Wallace, Journ. Nat. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. II. Pieridae and Danaidae
Distribution.Range: Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is.
Abundance: commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Eormosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands.
Flight.characteristics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground...
Habitat: Males delight in sunny place... females are found in the forest... tropical monsoon zone...
Oviposition: The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant
Hostplant.larval.food: Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition
Adult.food: often visit certain flowers... Males... visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow
Phenology.and.voltinism: They brood four times a year in Kyushu
Diapause: may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva... Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C... Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive.
Defense.strategies: Final instar larva... surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus... When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings.
Adult.forms: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Hebomoia glaucippe Linnaeus (Original Description) *glaucippe Linnaeus, Syst. Nat., 1, p. 469 (1758) Asia [India~S.ChinaJ vossi : Maitland, Tijd. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Timor celebensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Celebes philippensis : Wallace, Journ. Ent., 2, p. 3 (1863) Luzon roepstorffi : Wood-Mason, Journ. As. Soc. Beng., 64 (2), pp. 134, 150, 235 (1880) Andamans sumatrensis : Hagen, Iris, 7, p. 36 (1894) Sumatra flavomarginata Pagenstecher, Jahrb. Nass. Ver., p. 126 (1896) Sumba lombokiana : Butler, Ann. Mag. Nat. Hist., 7 (1), p. 290 (1898) Lombok cuyonicola : Fruhstorfer, Iris, ·20, p. 98 (1907) Cuyo palawanensis Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 98 (1907) Palawan reducta : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 100 (1997) Polillo sulaensis : Fruhstorfer, Iris, 20, p. 101 (1907) Sula aturia : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Malay Peninsula anaxandra : Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) Kalao erinna : Fruhstorfer, Seitz Macrolep., 9, p. 176 (1910) N.W.Luzon sangirica : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Sangir mindorensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 186 (1911) Mindoro domoranensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Domaran boholensis : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Bohol iliaca : Fruhstorfer, Ent. Runds., 28, p. 188 (1911) Mindanao anomala : Pendlebury,J. F. M. S. Mus., 18, p. 383~4 (1939) Aur  [Notes] Large sized butterflies distributed throughout the Oriental Region and N. Moluccas. In Japan they are found in Southern Kyushu and Yaeyama Is. Leucippe from S. Moluccas is often considered as a subspecies of glaucippe. But, here, I separate them because they are constantly different in appearance and in male and female genitalia. I.e. in leucippe, 1) forewing entirely yellow, 2) distal process of valva not fairly long; harpal process from the inner valva ill-developed and 3) cervix bursae of the female genitalia much longer than glaucippe. Characters: Glaucippe has 1) wing above usually white, 2) orange markings not extend toward the base, 3) male genitalia harpal process well-developed and 4) cervix bursae shorter than leucippe. Varieties: Seasonal forms in the high latitudes are slightly different. Spring (dry-season) form is smaller than summer (wetseason) form, and has the forewing apex curved and strongly acute. Island forms are very variable. Ryukyu Island (Kurosawa & Omoto, 1955) and Oriental (Morishita, 1973) forms are revised. Morishita (1973) recognized following seven subspecies group: 1) India. Malay Peninsula, 2) Andamans-Paramalaya, 3) Ryukyu, 4) Lesser Sundas, 5) Celebes, 6) Philippines and 7) N. Moluccas. In Andaman-Paramalayan subspecies-group, wing above is yellow. Niasan vossi has the wings in both sexes entirely bright yellow. Roepstorffi from Andamans has outer half of wing yellown. In Indo-Malayan subspecies-group, male wing is white. while female is pale yellowish-green with well developed marginal and submarginal black markings. Bornean borneensis has the black oblique band just below the orange markings conspicuously broad. Oran'ge markings in the female are covered by black scales. In Lesser Sundanian subspeciesgroup. butterflies are smaller. Male above ground color tinged with yellow and the orange markings are larger. Javanese javaensis is small-sized. Inner ridge of the orange markings and hindwing costa in the male are more or less covered with yellow. Flavomarginata from Sumba and Sumbawa has black markings obsolete. In Celebesian subspecies-group. butterflies are largesized with strongly acute apex. Orange markings extend into the cell. Celebesian celebensis has wing ground color white with well-developed orange markings. In Philippine subspecies-group. butterflies are smaller. Black edge under the orange markings is vestigial or entirely absent. Male above with some yellow. Female is entirely covered with pale-yellow. In iliaca from Mindanao. black marking is declining, and apex less pointed than N.C. Philippine form. The form from Palawan has the black marking much more reduced. Some abnormal forms have hitherto been described. In ab. dorolheae, black markings in the male become off-white. Male orange markings become bright-yellow in ab. pallens. Early stages: Well known for a long time. Piepers & Snellen (1909) Uava], Bell (1912-14) [India], Ng (1935) [China] and Shir6zu & Hara (1960) [Japan] have described them in detail. Egg; 1.6mm high by 1.0mm wide; color creamy-white or yellow-white when laid, turning orange later; shape of a dumpy shell; 11-14 ridges; no lateral stripe. The egg is laid, always singly, on the sprout or stalk of food plant. Final instar larva; 47-55mm long by 8mm wide; color glaucous-green with white spiracular line; surface covered with transparent, conical, bluish tubercles, each bearing a fine, short seta; this marking suggests a snake when the larva leans backward by stimulus. The larva lies along the midrib of leaf surface with a good carpet of white silk, with its head toward the point. And it moves to the edge of leaf to eat. Pupa; 35-40mm long; shape of Catopsilia and Gonepteryx; dorsal line nearly straight; wing sheath strongly expanded; cephalic snout short and thick, not pointed at the tip; color green or yellow. Larval food plants belong to the Capparidaceae and the larva has been found on Crataeva religiosa in India. Capparis moonii [India], C. pumila [Hong Kong] and C. formosana (?) are also reported. They have also Rorippa indica under the breeding condition, but the adults are smaller than wiled butterflies. Bionomics: Butterflies are quick and stout in flight. They fly so far from the ground and often visit certain flowers. Males delight in sunny place and visit moist spot, while females are found in the forest where the food plants grow. When at rest on the ground the insect is almost invisible, the reverse side pattern blending so well with the surroundings. The species are commonly found in the tropical monsoon zone such as Formosa, Indo-China Peninsula and India, while they are not so common in the island as in Sundalands. They brood four times a year in Kyushu and may hibernate in pupa or non-diapause larva (Fukuda et aI., 1972). Diapause larva occurs in Kagoshima and the critical day light is 12hr. and a half in 20°C. Diapause and non-diapause larva are indistinctive. (Range) glaucippe : S.China, Indo-China, Himalaya australis : S.India ceylonica : Sri Lanka formosana : Formosa ( = subgrisea)  liukiuensis : Amami, Okinawa ( = conspergata ) cincia : Yaeyama shirozui : S.Kyushu, Yakushima aturia : S.Burma~Malay Peninsula sumatrensis : Sumatra borneensis : Borneo anomala : Aur roepstorffi : Andamans vossi : Nias javanensis : Java, Bali, Kangean lombokiana : Lombok timorensis : Flores, Alor, Timor .......... Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Common.name: GREAT ORANGE TIP
Abundance: Common
Flight.characteristics: A strong-flying, very active butterfly
Hostplant.larval.food: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa
Adult.food: sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 116) Hebomoia glaucippe (Linnaeus, 1758) GREAT ORANGE TIP Plate 20 and 143 Subspecies and distribution: (i) philippensis Wallace, 1863 - central & southern Luzon, Marinduque. (ii) boholensis M. & T. Okano, 1994 - Bohol, Masbate, Negros, Panay. (iii) cuyonicola Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Cuyo. (iv) domoranensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Dumaran. (v) erinna Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Babuyan, Batanes, northern Luzon. (vi) iliaca Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Bongao, Dinagat, Jolo, Leyte, Mindanao, Panaon,  Samar, Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. (vii) mindorensis Fruhstorfer, 1911 - Mindoro. (viii) palawensis Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Balabac, Calamian, Palawan. (ix) reducta Fruhstorfer, 1907 - Polillo. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparidastrum sola, Capparis cantoniensis, C. lanceolaris, C. micracantha, C. moottii, C. pubiflora, C. sepiaria, C. sikkirnensis, Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog) [PH]. Cleomaceae: Cleome spinosa. Common. A strong-flying, very active butterfly, sometimes briefly pausing to take nectar but not usually very approachable. It is very conspicuous and unmistakable.

Book: Butterflies of Trinidad and Tobago
Common.name: The Postman
Distribution.Range: Tropical America. Tobago.
Abundance: Common in forested areas and shaded tracks all over Trinidad.  Particularly large specimens develop in southern districts during the rainy season. It is not, however, as common as H. erato, its close and similarly coloured relative
Flight.characteristics: Flight is slow and settling is frequent
Habitat: forested areas and shaded tracks
Adult.food: Passiflora laurifolia (L) “Belle Apple” or “Pomme dc Liane”.
Adult.forms: Very dark brown to black with a wide red central forewing band. Sexes are identical in colour but the female’s wings are just slightly more rounded at the margins. There are three small red mating dots placed at the base on the underside of the lower wing.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: A Field Guide to the Butterflies of the West Indies
Common.name: Hanno Blue
Distribution.Range: throughout the Antilles, in three subspecies... In the Bahamas, Cuba and the Isle of Pines subspecies filenus Poey occurs... continental H. hanno hanno, H. hanno watsoni Comstock and Huntington 1943 flies, from Porto Rico (TL) southwards throughout the Lesser Antilles. The intermediate islands, Jamaica and Hispanola are occupied by subspecies H. h. ceraunus Fabricius 1793 (TL: Jamaica). RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: Surinam.
Abundance: H. hanno occurs commonly all year round throughout the Antilles
Oviposition: Other plants, on which eggs have been laid, in Florida, are Chamaecrista brachiata, C. aspera and Abrus precatorius
Hostplant.larval.food: In Jamaica the caterpillar has been reared on the leaves of Mimosa and on the buds and young fruits of Crotalaria. Other plants, on which eggs have been laid, in Florida, are Chamaecrista brachiata, C. aspera and Abrus precatorius... In Porto Rico it has been found feeding on Macroptilium lathyroides (poison pea).
Phenology.and.voltinism: H. hanno occurs commonly all year round throughout the Antilles
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: HEMIARGUS HANNO Stoll 1790 Hanno Blue Pl. 12 Description. Fw [male] and [female] 9-10.5 mm. Upperside shining violaceous blue in male, black margins at most 1 mm wide; female brownish black above, shot with shining blue at the wing bases; both sexes with single black marginal spot in space 2 of hindwing. Underside in both sexes light grey with a macular pattern of squarish darker white-edged markings; forewing with dark bar at cell-end, the postdiscal line succeeded by two submarginal rows ofdarker spots many of which are sagittate, and wing base free of markings; on the hindwing this general pattern is repeated, with a rather crowded effect, and there are in addition the following quite black spots, viz. two small ones close to the wing base, two larger ones against the costa, and a fifth very much larger spot (the eye-spot) at the margin in space 2; the last, like the two dusky anal spots, bears a few metallic scales. Distribution. H. hanno occurs commonly all year round throughout the Antilles, in three subspecies. The distinguishing characters of these are by no means sharply defined and depend largely upon the relative sizes of the anal eye-spot and the extent of the white areas beyond the postdiscal band. In the Bahamas, Cuba and the Isle of Pines subspecies filenus Poey occurs; it has relatively large and bold underside markings. At the other end, and approaching the pale and somewhat insipid continental H. hanno hanno, H. hanno watsoni Comstock and Huntington 1943 flies, from Porto Rico (TL) southwards throughout the Lesser Antilles. The intermediate islands, Jamaica and Hispanola are occupied by subspecies H. h. ceraunus Fabricius 1793 (TL: Jamaica). RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: Surinam. Early stages. In Jamaica the caterpillar has been reared on the leaves of Mimosa and on the buds and young fruits of Crotalaria. Other plants, on which eggs have been laid, in Florida, are Chamaecrista brachiata, C. aspera and Abrus precatorius. The caterpillar when full grown is yellowish green with dorsal and lateral stripes that may be darker green, pink or pale yellow. In Porto Rico it has been found feeding on Macroptilium lathyroides (poison pea).

Distribution.Range: Central America to Brazil and the West Indies. Tobago

Flight.characteristics: quick  getaway  if  attacked.

Defense.strategies: The  tails  and  eyespots  on  the hind  wings  create  a  false  head,  drawing attention  away  from  the  real  head  and allowing  for  a  quick  getaway  if  attacked.
Author: walker.darling
Full.Species.Account: Azure  Hairstreak Hemiolaus  caeculus 30-40 mm Males  are  a  pure  intense blue  on  the  upper  side  of  the wings,  with  blackish  wing  tips and  spots.  The  females  have pale  whitish-blue  patches  on the  wings  and  orange  spots  at  the  base of  their  tails.  The  undersides  of  the  wings (shown  here)  are  beautifully  striped  with red  lines  on  a  soft  grey-white  background. HABITS  &  HABITAT:  Found  in  coastal  woodland and  forest.  Spends  long  periods  basking  on foliage,  where  it  can  often  be  approached closely.  The  tails  and  eyespots  on  the hind  wings  create  a  false  head,  drawing attention  away  from  the  real  head  and allowing  for  a  quick  getaway  if  attacked. Caterpillars  feed  on  Olax  (Olacacae).

Book: The millennium atlas of butterflies in Britain and Ireland
Common.name: Silver-spotted Skipper
Distribution.Range: This rare skipper is restricted to chalk downs in southern England. Its range has declined substantially during the twentieth century and it has become extinct in many areas including Yorkshire, the Cotswolds, the northern part of the Chilterns [?], and much of the North Downs. Its decline began early in the twentieth century but was particularly severe during the 1960s and 1970s. It has since re-expanded a little in the late 1980s and 1990s, mainly in south-east England.; There are currently eight main centres of distribution: north Dorset, south Wiltshire, east and west Hampshire, Surrey, east Sussex, east Kent, and the southern part of the Chilterns.; The range...appears to be stable in many European countries but has declined seriously in Belgium, Latvia, and Luxembourg (>50% decrease in 25 years), and also in Denmark, Germany, the Netherlands, Romania and Sweden (25-50% decline in 25 years).; Resident, decline and recent partial re-expansion of its range.; Across Europe from central Spain to Scandinavia and throughout temperate Asia. Also in North Africa and North America. Attempts have been made to re-establish the butterfly at two nature preserves in Kent. ;The data for 1995-9 show that the butterfly has continued to expand and has been recorded in 48% more 10 km grid squares than in 1970-82. However, sites further than about 10 km from any refuge sites have not been colonized and the butterfly is still absent from much of its former distribution.; The Silver-spotted Skipper is at the north-west limit of its European range in Britain… [restricted] to the warmer climate of southern England; The re-expansion has been accompanied by, and probably assisted by, a steady increase in population sizes on many extant sites over the last 20 years.
Abundance: The Silver-spotted Skipper is a rare butterfly, found only on chalk downland in southern England.; Its range has declined substantially during the twentieth century and it has become extinct in many areas including Yorkshire, the Cotswolds, the northern part of the Chilterns and much of the North Downs. Its decline began early in the twentieth century but was particularly severe during the 1960s and 1970s. It has since re-expanded a little in the late 1980s and 1990s, mainly in south-east England.; This rare skipper is restricted to chalk downs in southern England.; Resident; Conservation status UK BAP status: Priority Species. Butterfly Conservation priority: high. European status: not threatened. Protected in Great Britain for sale only.; declined rapidly over the last 50 years but has re-expanded partially since 1980.; adults tend to concentrate on suitable breeding habitat… large areas of habitat are more likely to be colonized than small ones and the rate of colonization tails off rapidly with distance. Small populations have also been shown to have particularly high emigration and often immigration rates and cannot be regarded as self-sustaining colonies. The butterfly is thus thought to form metapopulations covering relatively large areas of countryside within which it breeds in numerous discrete habitat patches. Some of these are larger and more permanently occupied core sites while other are occupied more temporarily.; An intensive national survey of the species, conducted in 1982, found that it had been reduced to 49 more or less distinct sites. Over half of these contained very small colonies 3500 at peak. A subsequent survey of the North and South Downs in 1991 found that the number of occupied habitat patches in this region of south-east England had increased by about 30%. The data for 1995-9 show that the butterfly has continued to expand and has been recorded in 48% more 10 km grid squares than in 1970-82. However, sites further than about 10 km from any refuge sites have not been colonized and the butterfly is still absent from much of its former distribution.; The introduction of myxomatosis in the early 1950s severely reduced rabbit populations and led to a sudden decline of the butterfly, which reached a low point in the 1970s.; The re-expansion has been accompanied by, and probably assisted by, a steady increase in population sizes on many extant sites over the last 20 years.
Flight.characteristics: ...seen darting low over short turf, stopping frequently to bask on bare ground
Habitat: The butterfly breeds in open chalk grassland which contains patches of short, sparse turf typically on thin soils. It also occurred formerly on limestone grassland in central and northern England. Warm, south facing slopes are prefered, but a few colonies occur on slopes with other aspects, including some gently north-facing ones.; The Silver-spotted Skipper is a rare butterfly, found only on chalk downland in southern England.; This rare skipper is restricted to chalk downs in southern England.; requires some of the hottest and driest grasslands available [in Britain], laying its eggs on foodplants growing in the warmest positions. This restricts it to the warmer climate of southern England and to shorter swards where it usually relies on grazing by livestock or rabbits.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid singly on leaf blades of Sheep's-fescue or occasionally on adjacent plants, where they pass the winter. Females are highly selective a lay most of their eggs on small tufts of foodplant growing in short turf (1-4cm tall) and often next to small patches of bare ground. Most eggs are laid next to animal tracks, old rabbit scrapes, or where there is some erosion on steep slopes or due to grazing animals. However, in hot conditions, some eggs are laid on short tufts of Sheep's-fescue growing in more closed turf.; laying its eggs on foodplants growing in the warmest positions; rarely lays on heavily nibbled tufts of foodplant
Hostplant.larval.food: Sheep's-fescue (Fesutca ovina) is the sole foodplant and the butterfly breeds only where this grows as small tufts in short or broken turf.
Adult.food: ...seen darting low over short turf, stopping frequently to bask on bare ground or feed on flowers such as Dwarf Thistle.; flower heads needed as nectar sources
Phenology.and.voltinism: The butterfly in single brooded with adults flying from late July to early September.; Eggs are laid singly on leaf blades of Sheep's-fescue or occasionally on adjacent plants, where they pass the winter.; The larvae hatch in early spring and feed in small silken webs around the foodplant.;
Diapause: Eggs are laid singly on leaf blades of Sheep's-fescue or occasionally on adjacent plants, where they pass the winter.
Defense.strategies: The larvae hatch in early spring and feed in small silken webs around the foodplant.; They pupate at ground level, deep within small grass tussocks and surrounded by loose silken cocoons.
Mobility: Recent detailed studies have shown that although adults tend to concentrate on suitable breeding habitat, the butterfly has reasonable powers of colonization. Since 1980, it has colonized several new sites within 1km of existing populations, and occasionally sites up to 8.5km away. However, large areas of habitat are more likely to be colonized than small ones and the rate of colonization tails off rapidly with distance. Small populations have also been shown to have particularly high emigration and often immigration rates and cannot be regarded as self-sustaining colonies. The butterfly is thus thought to form metapopulations covering relatively large areas of countryside within which it breeds in numerous discrete habitat patches. Some of these are larger and more permanently occupied core sites while other are occupied more temporarily.; The data for 1995-9 show that the butterfly has continued to expand and has been recorded in 48% more 10 km grid squares than in 1970-82. However, sites further than about 10 km from any refuge sites have not been colonized and the butterfly is still absent from much of its former distribution.

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Common Branded Skipper
Distribution.Range: Subspecies names were defived from geographic districts of western Canada. Subspecies Hesperia comma assiniboia recoginizes the district of Assiniboia, formerly a part of the Northwest territories, while subspecies manitoba refers to the province of Manitoba. There are fourteen named subspecies in the Hesperia comma complex in North America. In Alberta there are phenotypes of both subspecies represented.
Abundance: There are fourteen named subspecies in the Hesperia comma complex in North America. Common Branded Skipper is found from Labrador to Alaska and south to New England states, western Texas, and Baja California. In Alberta, H.c manitoba is essentially a mountain creature, with an isolated record from Fort Chipewyan. Isolated populations of assiniboia occur in the Peace River region, mostly along the Peace River.
Habitat: Assiniboia is found throughout the prairie grasslands and more locally in the aspen parklands north to the boreal forest near Redwater. Isolated populations occur in the Peace River region, mostly along the Peace River. Adults occur in prairies, grassy valley sides, aspen parkland and sand dune areas in the boreal forest. Adults of H. c. manitoba are found in mountain meadows, along roads and other clearings at elevations below treeline.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on a wide variety of grasses primarily spear grass, porcupine grass, needle grass (Stipa spp.), fescue (Festuca spp.), brome grass (Bromus spp.), and grama grass (Bouteloua spp.).
Adult.food: Adults nectar on a variety of flowers with Dotted Blazing-star (Liatris punctata) and Aster canescens serving as frequent nectar sources in prairie regions, with Senecio and Aster are visited in the mountains.
Phenology.and.voltinism: One brood per year. Flight period of H.c manitoba is June 4 to September 19, but peaks in July and early August. H. c. assiniboia adults have been observed from July 29 through September 30, with peak flights during August and early September. Mountain populations fly only in even-numbered years.
Diapause: Eggs overwinter.
Adult.forms: Comma-shaped marking on the fore wing of the male. Males have a prominent black stigma.

Distribution.Range: Across Europe from central Spain to Scandinavia and throughout temperate Asia. Also in North Africa and North America. Found only omn chalk downlands in southern England.

Also occurs on warm, south facing slopes with other aspects, including some gently north-facing ones. Formerly occurred on limestone grassland in central and northern England. Requires hottest and driest grasslands available.
Oviposition: Eggs laid singly on leaf blades of Sheep's-fescue. Lay eggs on small tufts of foodplants growing in short turf and often next to small patches of bare ground. Highly selective on their egg-laying. Typically lay eggs next to signs of animals, such as tracks and scrapes.
Hostplant.larval.food: Sheep's-fescue (Festuca ovina) is the sole foodplant.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Single brood with adults flying from late July to early September.

Book: The Butterflies of Cascadia
Common.name: Common Branded Skipper
Distribution.Range: Great Britain
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Silver-spotted Skipper Epargyreus clarus (Cramer) 1775 Recognition .2". Chocolate-brown, long DFW crossed by brassy-gold patches, bluntly tailed VHW with large, jagged, bright silver marks across their discs. No other Northwest skipper approaches its size or dramatic markings. Variation  E. c. "clarus" (TI, Dayton, VA), occupies the eastern section of the territory. These are actually smaller, with reduced spots and a darker ventrum than true eastern E. c. clarus, and may represent an unnamed subspecies. In and west of the Cascades flies E. c. californicus MacNeil, 1975 (TI. China Flat. El Dorado Co., CA), which has the upper half of the silver spot narrowed, and the posterior portion of the golden spot on the DFW reduced and nearly separated from the band. Life History The red-capped, ribbed green eggs are laid singly atop leaves of many kinds of legumes, including ornamental locusts (Robinia spp.) and wisteria. Pelham has reared E. c. californicus on Lotus crassifolius, the only host known for the ssp. here. A favorite hostplant for E. c. clarus in the West is wild licorice (Glycyrrhiza lepidota), a common riparian shrub in the eastern Columbia Gorge. Black locust trees introduced by pioneers are also used in the dry side. The greenish larvae have red and yellow legs, and black bands and shiny head. When small they fold a leaf into a tent, when larger, two leaves bound by silk. Dark brown chrysalides overwinter. A single generation. On the Wing E. April - L. August, peak in June. Habitat and Range Watercourses, parks, gardens, afforesting cuts, heath-like Christmas tree farms, and other open, flowery places at lower to middle elevations. Most of the U.S. and southern Canada; irregular in the West, omitting the Great Basin. Much of the east side of Cascadia, far less common on the west side: barely in SW coastal BC and S Vancouver Is,; Puget Trough in WA, more abundant southward in Coast Range of OR. Our largest skipper, this is also the most dramatically colored. From the glassy golden spots on the forewings and the big silver patches on the ventral hindwings, its rapid, herky-jerky flight alloys a brilliant metallic streak. In Great Britain, the name Silver-spotted Skipper applies to what we call the Common Branded Skipper [Hesperia comma)-, ours has the greater claim, with much larger silver spots. In boyhood. I pretended that these common neighborhood habitues of honeysuckle bushes were giant skippers of the desert Southwest. Unlike the yucca- and agave-burrowing megathymines. which do not make it north to Cascadia, f. clarus is a generalist on many legumes. Even so, the species is far more restricted on the westside than is the population east of the Cascades, For example, it occurs regularly among Lotus crassifolius stands in unsprayed Christmas tree plantations above Hood Canal, but unpredictably elsewhere in western Washington. Silver-spotted Skippers like hot and sunny country as well as moisture, so they become more common in eastern and southwestern Cascadia, In Benton County. Oregon, Andy Warren observed males perching from late morning through early afternoon, alert for interloping males and passing females. The perches ranged from twelve to fifteen feet above the ground. In July. 1999. I found a live, egg-heavy female trapped in the hot sunny foyer of a grocery store in Old Town, Idaho, fifty yards east of the Washington state line. I released her across the street, on sweet clover in Newport. Washington, The next day, T. L, Pyle found one just below the Canadian border along the Columbia, a little way into Stevens County. So, although Rend Orelile County was bracketed by Silver-spotted Skippers, it remained without a record of its own.

Habitat: Swallowtails, Whites and Sulphurs (Pieridae) and some kinds of Nymphalidae, are especially conspicuous around gardens where there is a profusion of flowers. It seems almost as if they have formed an association with man-made habitats, both his flowers and his crops. It is on this type of habitat, especially in the lowlands that wideranging species such as... Historis odius... are to be found.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: A Field Guide to the Butterflies of the West Indies
Common.name: Orion
Distribution.Range: Two subspecies occur in the islands. Cuba, Hispaniola, Porto Rico and Jamaica are inhabited by typical odius, the Leeward and Windward Isles (Guadaloupe, Dominica, Martinique, St Lucia and Grenada) by subspecies orion, which has no doubt reached them from the American mainland via Trinidad and Tobago... RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: West Indies.
Abundance: moderately common
Flight.characteristics: Orion is a very strong flyer
Hostplant.larval.food: Food plant Cecropia peltata.
Adult.food: much attracted to rotting fruit
Phenology.and.voltinism: On the wing all the year round
Defense.strategies: Underside cryptically patterned; fond of resting on tree trunks where its cryptic underside markings make it very difficult to see.
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: HISTORIS ODIUS Fabricius 1775 Orion Pl. 5 Description. Fw [male] 53-56 mm, [female] 60-65 mm. Forewing markedly falcate. Upperside velvety dark brown; forewing base and disc (almost to outer margin) rich bright ochreous brown, a single small white costal spot towards the apex; hindwing basal area slightly suffused ochreous brown, outer margin narrowly white or cream. Underside cryptically patterned in narrow bold black lines on a silky green-tinted purplish brown background. Distribution. Two subspecies occur in the islands. Cuba, Hispaniola, Porto Rico and Jamaica are inhabited by typical odius, the Leeward and Windward Isles (Guadaloupe, Dominica, Martinique, St Lucia and Grenada) by subspecies orion, which has no doubt reached them from the American mainland via Trinidad and Tobago. In the male of the latter subspecies the light brown area on the forewing juts out narrowly from the disc towards the outer margin like two fingers: in H. o. odius this light brown area is much wider from back to front and fills a large part of space 5 and some of space 6, areas which in H. o. orion are almost wholly black. In the females, both of which have more extensive light brown areas, the differences are comparable. Orion is a very strong flyer, much attracted to rotting fruit and fond of resting on tree trunks where its cryptic underside markings make it very difficult to see. On the wing all the year round and moderately common. RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: West Indies. Early stages.The fully grown caterpillar is about three inches long, light green with light brown transverse markings. The row of spines along the middle of the back black, lateral spines white, not all spines branched but, if branched, the branches arise very low down; three rows of spines on each side, but the rows not all complete. Head whitish marked with bold black cross and bearing a pair of short black spiky horns. Food plant Cecropia peltata.

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Fiery Skipper
Distribution.Range: Visitor [to the Carolinas]
Abundance: Adults are exceedingly fond of flowers and readily con gregate at available blossoms.; common to abundant
Flight.characteristics: The Fiery Skipper has a rapid, darting flight but frequently stops to perch on low vegetation.
Habitat: open, grassy areas including old fields, road sides, vacant lots, open woodlands, forest edges, parks, lawns and gardens;
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: a variety of grasses including Bermuda Grass, crabgrass, bentgrass and St. Augustine Grass;  The larvae utilize a variety of grasses including many commonly planted for lawns. As a result, the butterfly is often mentioned as a minor turf pest.
Adult.food: Adults are exceedingly fond of flowers and readily con gregate at available blossoms. They have a strong preference for colorful composites
Phenology.and.voltinism: May - November; multiple generations
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Fiery Skipper Hylepnila phyleus Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Banded Skippers (Hesperiinae) Wingspan: 1.00-1.25" (2.5-3.2 cm) Above; elongated wings; male is golden orange with jagged black border and black stigma; female is tawny orange with dark brown bands Below: hlndwing golden orange in male or orange brown in female with tiny dark brown spots Sexes: dissimilar; female darker with reduced orange markings and larger hindwing spots Egg: whitish green, laid singly on host leaves Larva: greenish brown with thin, dark brown dorsal stripe and black head Larval Host Plants: a variety of grasses including Bermuda Grass, crabgrass, bentgrass and St. Augustine Grass Habitat: open, grassy areas including old fields, road sides, vacant lots, open woodlands, forest edges, parks, lawns and gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: common to abundant Compare: Whirlabout (pg. 281) has two rows of large dark spots on the ventral hindwing. Sachem (pg, 293) lacks dark spots on ventral hindwing. Comments: The Fiery Skipper has a rapid, darting flight but frequently stops to perch on low vegetation. Adults are exceedingly fond of flowers and readily con gregate at available blossoms. They have a strong preference for colorful composites. The larvae utilize a variety of grasses including many commonly planted for lawns. As a result, the butterfly is often mentioned as a minor turf pest. It is often found alongside the similar-looking and equally abundant Sachem and Whirlabout.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Fiery Skipper
Distribution.Range: Connecticut to California, south to Brazil and Argentina. [images]Williamson County, IL; Union County, IL; Alexander County, IL; Champaign County, IL; Lee County, IL
Abundance: It is most common in September. Summer resident only, populations increasing in late summer. Abundance varies from year to year, occasionally common in late summer locally, but in some years scarce to absent in the north and uncommon in the south. Cannot survive an Illinois winter.
Habitat: Open areas, fields, roadsides, gardens, parks, lawns.  Males perch on low vegetation
Oviposition: Eggs are laid on the larval hosts, which include finger-grass (Digitaria spp.), Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), and in the tropics sugarcane and other grasses
Hostplant.larval.food: Eggs are laid on the larval hosts, which include finger-grass (Digitaria spp.), Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), and in the tropics sugarcane and other grasses
Adult.food: Adults nectar at thistles (Cirsium spp.), ironweed (Vernonia spp.), asters (Aster spp.), and many others. [images]nectaring
Phenology.and.voltinism: Multivoltine in the southern states and Neotropics where the species is a permanent resident. One or two generations during the summer in Illinois. It is most common in September. Summer resident only, populations increasing in late summer. Abundance varies from year to year, occasionally common in late summer locally, but in some years scarce to absent in the north and uncommon in the south. Cannot survive an Illinois winter.
Diapause: Cannot survive an Illinois winter.
Defense.strategies: Larvae make shelters by fastening grass blades together with silk; the nest is positioned horizontally on the soil.  This habit allows the larvae to survive mowing and favors survival in lawns.
Author: andra.doherty

Common.name: Fiery Skipper
Distribution.Range: It tends to overwinter in the same places every year; these locations presumably serve as foci from which succes sive broods spread out to blanket the region. the Fiery Skipper itself has a huge range, from northern California to central Ar gentina and Chile. . It is not known whether it is native to Califor nia or was introduced from the tropics or subtropics. It may not have been in our area before the 1930s  All counties, almost never in wildlands.
Abundance: Records exist for all months, but mostly March to early December; rarely common before July.
Flight.characteristics: Adults are very ac tive and agile;
Habitat: This is our most urban butterfly, rarely found far from mowed lawns.
Hostplant.larval.food: Mostly Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), occa sionally on other lawn grasses such as Dallis grass (Paspalum) native host may be alkali grass (Distichlis spicata), which occurs naturally nearly throughout its hemispheric range.
Adult.food: visiting zinnias (Zinnia )y marigolds (Tagetes)y\antana (Lantana)y and other flowers
Phenology.and.voltinism: After suffering apparently heavy mortality over winter, it is usually rare and spotty early in the season but becomes abundant by late July.  By September and October it is abundant in gardens.  Records exist for all months, but mostly March to early December; rarely common before July.
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: This is our most urban butterfly, rarely found far from mowed lawns. After suffering apparently heavy mortality over winter, it is usually rare and spotty early in the season but becomes abundant by late July. By September and October it is abundant in gardens, visiting zinnias (Zinnia )y marigolds (Tagetes)y\antana (Lantana)y and other flowers. It tends to overwinter in the same places every year; these locations presumably serve as foci from which succes sive broods spread out to blanket the region. Adults are very ac tive and agile; male-male chases can be marvelously aerobatic. This species belongs to a mostly Andean genus; the Fiery Skipper itself has a huge range, from northern California to central Ar gentina and Chile. It is not known whether it is native to Califor nia or was introduced from the tropics or subtropics. It may not have been in our area before the 1930s. Specimens collected in cool weather tend to have heavier spot-patterns beneath, and the female ground color beneath is sootier. Otherwise, there is little variation. DISTRIBUTION: All counties, almost never in wildlands. HOST PLANTS: Mostly Bermuda grass (Cynodon dactylon), occa sionally on other lawn grasses such as Dallis grass (Paspalum); its native host may be alkali grass (Distichlis spicata), which occurs naturally nearly throughout its hemispheric range. SEASONS: Records exist for all months, but mostly March to early December; rarely common before July. SIMILAR SPECIES: The Fiery Skipper has a sharply pointed forewing and short antennae; the ventral hindwing pattern has dis crete spots not forming connected bands; the stigma is slender, the gray in center scarcely noticeable; the male has triangular dark spots along the margins. This set of traits should distinguish the Fiery Skipper from all the other similarly colored skippers.

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. II. Pieridae and Danaidae
Distribution.Range: S.Celebes; [plates] Butung South of CELEBES; Bantimurung S.CELEBES
Phenology.and.voltinism: [plates] [Male] arachosia 1980. Butung South of CELEBES; [Male] arachosia 1975. Bantimurung S.CELEBES; [Female] arachosia 1976.Jul.1 Bantimurung S.CELEBES
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Ideopsis vitrea Blanchard (Original Description) *vitrea Blanchard, Voy. Pole Sud, 4, p.385, t.2, f.2 (1853) Arfak, West Irian oenopia C. Felder, Wien. Ent. Monatsschr., 3, p.182, t.4, f.2 (1859) N.Celebes ribbei Rober, Corr. blatt Deutsche Ent. Ver. Iris, 1(n.4), p.186, t.8, f.4 (1887) Banggai iza Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitg. Stettin, 59, p.258~259, 262 n.13 (1898) Mangole (B.M.) arachosia Fruhstorfer in Seitz, Gross·schmett. Erde, 9, p.217 (1910) S.Celebes [Notes] This species replaces gaura, the preceding species in the N. Moluccas, New Guinea and its neighbouring islands. The forewing length 37-53 mm. It has important characters in common with gaura, but partly differs from gaura in the scheme of markings as mentioned below. 1. Hindwing without the series of postdical round black spots in spaces 1,2,3 and 4, the black markings in these spaces being limited to the marginal and basal areas. In gaura the series of postdiscal spots almost complete. 2. Hindwing with a prominent postdiscal black patch or band in spaces 4, 5 and 6. The patch extends toward the inner margin and enters space 2 in Celebesian subspecies. This species also exhibits marked geographical variation as in gaura, often producing strikingly different subspecies within a limited area. The ground colour varies geographically from almost white to bicoloured one (white and yellow) or rich yellow. In Celebes a peculiar Satyrid species surprisingly similar to this species in wing pattern sometimes flies together with it. An excellent example of mimicry. The early stages are unknown. (Range) oenopia : N.Celebes arachosia : S.Celebes ribbei : Banggai iza : Mangole (Sula ) chloris : Halmahera, Ternate, Morotai, Bachan, Buru ?
