Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Distribution.Range: occurs only as far eastwards as the Arfak and Wandammen Mountains of Irian Jaya.
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus IDEOPSIS Horsfield, 1858 According to Ackery and Vane-Wright (1984), this small Indo- Australian genus contains only 8 species, 3 of which occur in NG. One of these species, and 2 others from elsewhere, are insular taxa, being restricted to small islands. Only 1 of the NG species, I. juventa, occurs in PNG and it enjoys the largest distribution of the 8 species. I. hewitsonii Kirsch, 1877, is restricted to Biak Island in Geelvink Bay, Irian Jaya, and the Moluccan /. vitrea (Blanchard, 1853) occurs only as far eastwards as the Arfak and Wandammen Mountains of Irian Jaya. Ideopsis ranges from Sri Lanka (as an isolated portion of the distribution of /. similis (Linnaeus, 1758)), throughout South-east Asia, as far northwards as southernmost Japan, and throughout the Indonesian archipelago, to NG, the Bismarcks and Solomons. However, the genus does not reach Australia. The type species for Ideopsis is gaura (Horsfield, 1829), designated by Scudder, 1875. Ackery and Vane-Wright listed the following synonyms of Ideopsis: Radena Moore, 1880; Gamana Moore, 1883; Aianthis Fruhstorfer, 1910. Ideopsis exhibits little sexual dimorphism. However, all of the males possess a characteristic, but somewhat indistinct, dark, linear sex-brand on the hindwing which borders the entire length of vein 1A+2A. Neither this vein, nor adjacent veins, are swollen as they are in Parantica. Veins and Sc of the forewing are anastomosed but separate before they meet the costal margin. However, Ackery and Vane-Wright pointed out that this feature also occurs in some Parantica, Euploea and other danaine genera. They noted that the inner lamina of the male valva is folded and produced into a downwardly directed, pointed process. As in Parantica (and some other members of the Danainae) the corpus bursae of the female is double-chambered. Vane-Wright and Boppre (1990) stated that, amongst the 6 currently recognised genera of the Danaini, only Ideopsis is known not to include species which produce pheromone transfer particles (see Tribe Danaini). Some members of Ideopsis were included in Danaus by Talbot (1943b). Ackery and Vane-Wright found that there was a paucity of good characters by which Ideopsis species could be recognised, but that the division of the genus into 2 equal groups {Radena and Ideopsis) was warranted. They suggested that many aspects of the biology of all Ideopsis species will have to be studied before a meaningful classification of the genus can be made. In their habits, Ideopsis are generally similar to Parantica. Members of the genus frequent marginal forest and small open areas of low-growing shrubs, but Ideopsis is less distinctly montane than Parantica, most of its species ranging up to about an elevation of about 1,000 m. However, I. klassika Martin, 1909, endemic to the island of Seram in the Moluccas, is known to occur as high as 2,500 m (Rothschild, 1915b; as stresemanni).

Book: Afrotropical Butterflies Website - Lycaenidae
Common.name: Red-line Sapphire
Distribution.Range: [South Africa]: “Kaffraria and Natal” [type specimen];  Democratic Republic of Congo [Semuliki Valley; Mt Mitumba]; Uganda; Kenya [Mount Elgon; Shimoni; Watamu; Ol Jogi Ranch, near Nanyuki]; Tanzania [Widespread]; Malawi [Mt Mulanje]; Zambia [Chisamba; Chalimbana; Lusaka; Choma; Kanona; Ndola; Luanshya; Mufulira; Mkushi; Shiwa Ngandu; Mbala; Mafinga Mountains]; Mozambique [Mt Namuli; Mt Mabu]; Zimbabwe (east) [Great Dyke Pass, 50 km north of Harare]; South Africa: Mpumalanga [Nelspruit]; KwaZulu-Natal [Umkomaas; Durban; Amahlongwa; Balcomb’s Hill; Impenza; Eshowe; Muden; St Lucia; False Bay; Ndumo Nature Reserve]; Eastern Cape Province [Bathurst district; East London; Amabele; Bashee River; Port St Johns; Port Alfred; Great Fish Point; Bedford]; Swaziland
Elevation: In Tanzania at altitudes from 900 to 2 000 m
Abundance: Tanzania – Widespread
Flight.characteristics: Males hilltop
Habitat: Coastal and secondary forest and savanna. Also in Brachystegia woodland; Males hilltop... choosing the highest leaves and twigs of trees as perches. Females are most often encountered around bunches of loranthus, the larval host-plants
Oviposition: The eggs are laid on the upper- or undersides of the leaves, on the buds, stems, etc., without any apparent effort at concealment; [eggs] Laid singly, normally, but sometimes in pairs
Hostplant.larval.food: The larvae feed on the leaves or young flower-buds (of Loranthus woodfordioides), but not ‘as a rule’ on the flowers after they have opened; The discarded shell is not eaten... The discarded larval skin is eaten; Larval food: Actinanthella wyliei (Sprague) Wiens (Loranthaceae) [as Loranthus wyliei]; Agelanthus atrocoronatus Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Agelanthus bipartitus Balle ex Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Agelanthus brunneus (Engl.) Balle & N.Hallé (Loranthaceae) [as Tapinanthus brunneus (Engl.) Danser]; Agelanthus fuellebornii (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Agelanthus kraussianus (Meisn.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [as Tapinanthus kraussianus]; Agelanthus sambesiacus (Engl. & Schinz) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Agelanthus sansibarensis (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Agelanthus subulatus (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [as Tapinathus subulatus]; Agelanthus zizyphifolius (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens subspecies vittatus (Loranthaceae) [as Tapinanthus vittatus]; Englerina inaequilatera (Engl.) Gilli (Loranthaceae); Englerina schubotziana (Engl. & K.Krause) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae); Englerina woodfordioides (Schweinf.) Balle (Loranthaceae) [as Loranthus woodfordioides Schweinf.]; Englerina woodfordioides (Schweinf.) Balle (Loranthaceae) [as Loranthus woodfordioides]; Moquiniella rubra (Spreng.) Balle (syn. Loranthus elegans) (Loranthaceae); Oliverella hildebrandtii (Engl.) Tiegh. (Loranthaceae); Oncocalyx bolusii (Sprague) Wiens & Polhill (Loranthaceae); Oncocalyx quinquenervius (Hochst.) Wiens & Polhill (Loranthaceae) [as Tieghemia quinquenervia]; Tapinanthus oleifolius (J.C.Wendl.) Danser (Loranthaceae)
Phenology.and.voltinism: Flight period: All year; Early stages recorded in Mt. Elgon, 18 miles S.W. of Kitale, Jan., 1932, and April, 1931; [Eggs] Hatching occurs after some 8 days... Larva:  1st instar 1.25 mm, growing to 2.5 mm in 5-10 days; 2nd instar growing to 3.5 mm in 4-9 days; 3rd instar growing to 5.7 mm in 5-7 days; 4th instar growing to 13-15 mm in 13-19 days... There is a rotation of broods... Normally the pupal state lasts for 13-14 days but, at times, up to 30 days are not uncommon; [images] Male specimen collected in Umtamvuna River, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa on 30 December 2011; Female specimen collected in Cwebe Nature Reserve, Eastern Cape Province, South Africa on 8 May 2014
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Males hilltop from midday onwards
Diapause: the pupa may overwinter
Defense.strategies: [pupa] Resembles a seed capsule of the plant... Some eggs are covered with a yellow glutinous substance which gives the white egg a yellow appearance and is a partial protection against parasitical attack... Larvae in the 3rd and 4th instars resemble droppings of birds... Larvae can alter their appearance by pinching in the 8th segment and expanding the 3rd to 5th segments laterally... The main part of the pupa is generally well away from the twig and the pupa resembles a young, immature gall both in shape and colour.  If close to the twig, it taps on this when disturbed
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: *Iolaus (Epamera) sidus Trimen, 1864# Red-line Sapphire Iolaus sidus Trimen, 1864.  Transactions of the Entomological Society of London (3) 2: 176 (175-180). Iolaus sidus Trimen.  Trimen, 1866a. Iolaus sidus Trimen, 1864.  Trimen & Bowker, 1887b. Iolaus sidus Trimen.  Swanepoel, 1953a. Iolaus sidus Trimen, 1864.  Dickson & Kroon, 1978. Iolaus (Epamera) sidus Trimen, 1864.  Pringle et al., 1994: 155. Epamera sidus Trimen, 1864.  d’Abrera, 2009: 741. Iolaus (Epamera) sidus Trimen, 1864. Collins et al., 2014. Type locality: [South Africa]: “Kaffraria and Natal”. Distribution: Democratic Republic of Congo, Uganda, Kenya, Tanzania, Malawi, Zambia, Mozambique, Zimbabwe (east), South Africa (Mpumalanga, KwaZulu-Natal, Eastern Cape Province), Swaziland. Specific localities: Democratic Republic of Congo – Semuliki Valley (Ducarme, 2018); Mt Mitumba (Ducarme, 2018). Kenya – Mount Elgon (Jackson, 1937); Shimoni (Larsen, 1991c); Watamu (Larsen, 1991c); Ol Jogi Ranch, near Nanyuki (Williams, unpublished). Tanzania – Widespread (Kielland, 1990d). Malawi – Mt Mulanje (Congdon et al., 2010). Zambia – Chisamba (Heath et al., 2002); Chalimbana (Heath et al., 2002); Lusaka (Heath et al., 2002); Choma (Heath et al., 2002); Kanona (Heath et al., 2002); Ndola (Heath et al., 2002); Luanshya (Heath et al., 2002); Mufulira (Heath et al., 2002); Mkushi (Heath et al., 2002); Shiwa Ngandu (Heath et al., 2002); Mbala (Heath et al., 2002); Mafinga Mountains (Heath et al., 2002). Mozambique – Mt Namuli (Congdon et al., 2010); Mt Mabu (Congdon et al., 2010). Zimbabwe – Great Dyke Pass, 50 km north of Harare (Pringle et al., 1994). Mpumalanga – Nelspruit (Pringle et al., 1994). KwaZulu-Natal – Umkomaas (Swanepoel, 1953); Durban (Swanepoel, 1953); Amahlongwa (Swanepoel, 1953); Balcomb’s Hill (Swanepoel, 1953); Impenza (Swanepoel, 1953); Eshowe (Swanepoel, 1953); Muden (Swanepoel, 1953); St Lucia (Swanepoel, 1953); False Bay (Swanepoel, 1953); Ndumo Nature Reserve (Pringle & Kyle, 2002). Eastern Cape Province – Bathurst district (Swanepoel, 1953); East London (Swanepoel, 1953); Amabele (Swanepoel, 1953); Bashee River (Swanepoel, 1953); Port St Johns (Swanepoel, 1953; male illustrated above); Port Alfred (Clark & Dickson, 1971); Great Fish Point (Pringle et al., 1994); Bedford (Pringle et al., 1994). Habitat: Coastal and secondary forest and savanna.  Also in Brachystegia woodland (Heath et al., 2002).  In Tanzania at altitudes from 900 to 2 000 m (Kielland, 1990d). Habits: Males hilltop from midday onwards, choosing the highest leaves and twigs of trees as perches.  Females are most often encountered around bunches of loranthus, the larval host-plants (Pringle et al., 1994). Flight period: All year. Early stages: Jackson, 1937: 215  [as Epamera sidus; Mount Elgon, Kenya]. “The larvae feed on the leaves or young flower-buds (of Loranthus woodfordioides), but not ‘as a rule’ on the flowers after they have opened.”  “Egg.  The eggs are laid on the upper- or undersides of the leaves, on the buds, stems, etc., without any apparent effort at concealment.  They are yellow, circular and domed, with a complicated embossed pattern covering the surface.  Diameter, about 0.5 mm.  Larva.  The larva is very strangely formed.  Green or greyish-green with a large whitish triangular spot filling up the central depression.  Beginning at the anal extremity and arising from the last four segments there is a large tent-like process ending in in a curved and sharply pointed spike; following this is a deep valley, the bottom of which is only 3 mm. in total thickness.  Finally the dorsum rises again to a curved knife-edged ridge extending over three quarters of the total length, and from this falling almost vertically to the head.  At the highest point of this anterior dorsal ridge, the depth is 6 mm.  There are apparently neither tubercles nor gland, although the carapace is more than adequate for protection against ants.  Length, 15 mm.  Pupa.  Resembles a seed capsule of the plant.  The posterior segments are contracted into a thin stalk which is fixed to a twig, and are articulated so that the head-case can be hammered against the surface of the twig when an enemy comes too close.  The whole pupa is so contracted that the overall length is only 6-7 mm.  The dorsum is rounded, the thorax slightly ridged, and in general the shape is semispherical and strongly reminiscent of a berry.  It is green with the exception of a large sepia brown patch on the thorax.  Locality.  Mt. Elgon, 18 miles S.W. of Kitale, Jan., 1932, and April, 1931.” Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138, plate 67  [as Epamera sidus; Port Alfred, Eastern Cape]. “Egg:  0.8 mm x 0.4 mm high.  Laid singly, normally, but sometimes in pairs.  Some eggs are covered with a yellow glutinous substance which gives the white egg a yellow appearance and is a partial protection against parasitical attack; some such eggs have, however, been found to have been parasitized.  Hatching occurs after some 8 days.  The discarded shell is not eaten.  Larva:  1st instar 1.25 mm, growing to 2.5 mm in 5-10 days; 2nd instar growing to 3.5 mm in 4-9 days; 3rd instar growing to 5.7 mm in 5-7 days; 4th instar growing to 13-15 mm in 13-19 days.  The discarded larval skin is eaten.  The honey-gland and tubercles are present in the 2nd to 4th instars.  Larvae in the 3rd and 4th instars resemble droppings of birds.  The colour of the final-instar larva varies from pale olive-green to green, some larvae of the latter colour having dark purple blotches round the spiracles.  Sometimes there are five instars, the extra instar being intermediate between the 3rd and 4th instars.  There is a rotation of broods.  Larvae can alter their appearance by pinching in the 8th segment and expanding the 3rd to 5th segments laterally.  The skin of the final-instar larva is fluted, somewhat like that of E. aemulus (as depicted round the illustration of the tubercle) and the setae are sunken in circular depressions.  Pupa:  10 mm.  Attached firmly to a twig by the cremastral hooks.  The main part of the pupa is generally well away from the twig and the pupa resembles a young, immature gall both in shape and colour.  If close to the twig, it taps on this when disturbed.  Normally the pupal state lasts for 13-14 days but, at times, up to 30 days are not uncommon; or the pupa may overwinter.  Parasites:  Egg.  Destroyed by small Chalcids (Trichogramma sp.?), despite the glutinous coating on the egg.  Larva.  Killed by Braconids.  Pupa.  Killed by various Ichneumonids; especially by a Pimpla sp.”  “Recorded from eggs and larvae from Port Alfred, eastern Cape Province.” Congdon et al., 2017 [final instar larva]. Larval food: Actinanthella wyliei (Sprague) Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Edge, 1985: 4; Dukaneni siding, near Eshowe, KwaZulu-Natal; as Loranthus wyliei]. Agelanthus atrocoronatus Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Congdon et al., 2017; Mufindi, Tanzania]. Agelanthus bipartitus Balle ex Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Congdon & Bampton, 2000: 35]. Agelanthus brunneus (Engl.) Balle & N.Hallé (Loranthaceae) [Pringle et al., 1994: 155; as Tapinanthus brunneus (Engl.) Danser]. Agelanthus fuellebornii (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Congdon & Bampton, 2000: 35]. Agelanthus kraussianus (Meisn.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Platt (1921), in Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138; as Tapinanthus kraussianus]. Agelanthus sambesiacus (Engl. & Schinz) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Congdon & Bampton, 2000: 35]. Agelanthus sansibarensis (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Kielland, 1990d: 189]. Agelanthus subulatus (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Pringle et al., 1994: 155; as Tapinathus subulatus]. Agelanthus zizyphifolius (Engl.) Polhill & Wiens subspecies vittatus (Loranthaceae) [Kielland, 1990d: 189; as Tapinanthus vittatus]. Englerina inaequilatera (Engl.) Gilli (Loranthaceae) [Kielland, 1990d: 189]. Englerina schubotziana (Engl. & K.Krause) Polhill & Wiens (Loranthaceae) [Congdon & Bampton, 2000: 35]. Englerina woodfordioides (Schweinf.) Balle (Loranthaceae) [Jackson, 1937: 215; as Loranthus woodfordioides Schweinf.]. Englerina woodfordioides (Schweinf.) Balle (Loranthaceae) [Platt (1921), in Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138; as Loranthus woodfordioides]. Moquiniella rubra (Spreng.) Balle (syn. Loranthus elegans) (Loranthaceae) [Platt (1921), in Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138]. Oliverella hildebrandtii (Engl.) Tiegh. (Loranthaceae) [Congdon & Bampton, 2000: 35]. Oncocalyx bolusii (Sprague) Wiens & Polhill (Loranthaceae) [Rossouw, 2005; False Bay Park, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa]. Oncocalyx quinquenervius (Hochst.) Wiens & Polhill (Loranthaceae) [Platt (1921), in Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138; as Tieghemia quinquenervia]. Tapinanthus oleifolius (J.C.Wendl.) Danser (Loranthaceae) [Platt (1921), in Clark & Dickson, 1971: 138]. [images] Red-line Sapphire (Iolaus sidus) male. Image courtesy Steve Woodhall; Iolaus sidus.  Male (Wingspan 30 mm).  Left – upperside; right – underside. Umtamvuna River, KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa.  30 December 2011.  J. Dobson. Images M.C. Williams ex Dobson Collection; Iolaus sidus.  Female (Wingspan 27 mm).  Left – upperside; right – underside. Cwebe Nature Reserve, Eastern Cape Province, South Africa.  8 May 2014.  M. Williams. Images M.C. Williams ex Williams Collection.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Pale Ranger
Distribution.Range: The Pale Ranger is found in open areas along the Nigeria/Cameroun border, with certain records from Nigeria only from Gashaka-Gumpti National Park. It can be common in the Bamenda Highlands of western Cameroun. The range covers all of southern (TL Namibia) and eastern Africa to Kenya and Uganda, parts of central Africa, Zambia, Angola, Cameroun and eastern Nigeria. Carcasson (1981) mistakenly states that the range is pan African.
Abundance: The Pale Ranger can be common in the Bamenda Highlands of western Cameroun.
Flight.characteristics: The Pale Ranger flies about rather leisurely in the shade of thickets, often resting on green leaves, then occasionally darting at great speed from one thicket to another.
Habitat: The Pale Ranger normally inhabits a mixture of grassland and bushland, but is on the wing only when the grass is green. It flies about rather leisurely in the shade of thickets, often resting on green leaves, then occasionally darting at great speed from one thicket to another.
Hostplant.larval.food: The larva has been recorded on Imperata cylindrica (Poaceae).
Adult.food: Both sexes are frequently seen on flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: This butterfly in on the wing only when the grass is green.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: This Skipper can be found from the Tugela in Natal, northwards through Swaziland, the Transvaal, Mocambique and Rhodesia. Further localities include the Okavango delta (besides other localities) in Botswana, and Guchab, South West Africa.
Abundance: This shade-lover is common in the bushveld, from the Tugela in Natal, northwards through Swaziland, the Transvaal, Mocambique and Rhodesia.
Habitat: This shade-lover is common in the bushveld. It can be seen resting on grass in the shade, and has been found in a delta.
Phenology.and.voltinism: This species emerges in December and remains out till April.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Luehder's Recluse
Distribution.Range: Luehder’s Recluse is known from Sierra Leone, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana (TL Aburi), and the Cross River loop in Nigeria. It was recorded also from the Korup area. It must also be in Guinea, Liberia, and southern Nigeria. During research for this book I caught just one in the Oban Hills. It was, however, recently caught in the Guma Valley near Freetown by C. Belcastro. The range stretches from Sierra Leone to Nigeria, Cameroun, and parts of the DRC, with ssp. laura Evans, 1937 in Uganda, northwestern Tanzania, and western Kenya.
Abundance: Luehder's Recluse must be very scarce in West Africa.
Habitat: Luehder's Recluse must be only found in wetter forests.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Full.Species.Account: Closely allied is Lepella lepeletier (Latreille, 1824) of Eastern Mashonaland, with broader white stripes on underside.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Lepeletier's Sylph
Distribution.Range: Lepeletier’s Sylph flies in grasslands on the Obudu and Mambilla Plateaux in Nigeria. It also occurs in the Rumpi Hills, where collected by T. Helps. It seems to be somewhat submontane in Nigeria. The range stretches from eastern Nigeria along the northern fringes of the main forest zone to southern Sudan, western Kenya, western Tanzania, Zambia, and Angola, wholly avoiding the main rainforest zone except in submontane habitats. Geographical variation is negligible. The type locality was wrongly given as \Cap de Bonne-Esperance\"."
Abundance: I have only ever seen a single male flying along the verge of the main road leading down from the Obudu Plateau.
Flight.characteristics: The flight of the Lepeletier's Sylph is a bounding one.
Habitat: Lepeletier’s Sylph flies in grasslands. It seems to be somewhat submontane in Nigeria. I have only ever seen a single male flying along the verge of the main road leading down from the Obudu Plateau.
Hostplant.larval.food: The species has been bred on an unidentified grass (Poaceae).

Distribution.Range: Distribution in Altai, Sayans and Tuva. Widespread, excluding south-eastren parts.
Habitat: Woodland clearings and glades, meadows and meadow steppes, grassy river valley up to 2000 m.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Univoltine (end May - August) in north and mountains; bivoltine (May - June and July - August) southern and central lowlands.

Krasnoyarsky kray, Khakassia, Kemerovo region, Altaisky krai, Altai Rep., Tyva Rep.). | Lep tid ea sinapis. - Ivonin 8c Nikolaev, 2008b: 119 (Tuva: Kaa-Khem distr., mid flow of Koptu river; Ulug-Knem distr., mid flow of Elegest river; Mongun-Tayga distr., 15 km W Mugur-Aksy settl., Khayyrakan river). New records for Altai, Sayans and Tuva ZMALJ: Turochak distr. | ISEA: Altaysky kray, Egor’evskii distr., Gor’koe-Peresheechnoe lake. | Coll. R. Yakovlev (Barnaul): Barnaul vie.; Altaiskiy kray, Pervomaiskiy distr., Ob’ river valley, ‘Obskie plesy’ camp. | O. Kosterin (Novosibirsk): Ulus-Cherga; 28 km WWS Ust’-Byur, 53°46’ N 89°50’ E. | P. Y. Maikov (Gorno-Altaisk): Nizhneneninka, Saydyp, Kebezen’, Chiri. Distribution in Altai, Sayans and Tuva. Widespread, excluding south-eastren parts. Flight. Univoltine (end May - August) in north and mountains; bivoltine (May - June and July - August) southern and central lowlands. Habitat. Woodland clearings and glades, meadows and meadow steppes, grassy river valley up to 2000 m.

Author: vaughn.shirey

Book: The millennium atlas of butterflies in Britain and Ireland
Common.name: Wood White
Distribution.Range: The butterfly expanded northwards during the fine summers of 1970s and 1980s, spreading particularly along railway lines, both used and disused. These habitats are believed to have acted as linear corridors enabling the butterfly to colonize many kilometres in just a few decades. However, this period of expansion now seems to be over and there were signs of a slight contraction in the 1990s.; Resident [to Britain and Ireland], range declining in Britain, stable in Ireland. Widespread in Europe as far as 66-degrees N in Scandinavia and eastwards to the Caucasus Mountains and Siberia.
Abundance: The Wood White has a very localized distribution in England and Wales and declined substantially during the twentieth century. It is absent from Scotland and may now be extinct in Wales, although there are occasional sightings. In contrast, the butterfly is widespread and locally abundant in Ireland, where it has expanded northwards over the last 30 years. The Wood White was formerly quite widely distributed in England and Wales. Its decline began earlier than many other species and by the 1900s, the butterfly was extinct in several counties, including some where it has been abundant. The Wood White continued to decline during the twentieth century and, by the late 1970s, only 87 colonies were estimated to remain. During the 1980s, it declined substantially in Warwickshire and in the woodlands on the Surrey/Sussex borders from 20 sites to fewer than 1. The current survey indicates a major recent decline in Britain where it has been lost from 62% of the 10 km squares recording in 1970-82. Since the 1960s the Wood White has been introduced to a number of sites. Many...failed but at least two have resulted in sizeable colonies in north Bedfordshire and on the Buckinghamshire/Oxfordshire border. The recent records for Cumbria and Derbyshire are also suspected to be of released individuals. The butterfly's British strongholds are now in three main regions: Herefordshire and Worcestershire; Northamptonshire and Buckinghamshire; and east Devon and south Somerset. In Ireland, the Wood White is far more widespread than in Britain, but becomes sparser in the far south (for example in Co. Cork; where there is less Meadow Vetchling in road verges, and in intensively farmed areas such as Co. Carlow.) It is under-recorded in some regions and is probably more widely distributed than shown. The butterfly expanded northwards during the fine summers of 1970s and 1980s, spreading particularly along railway lines, both used and disused. These habitats are believed to have acted as linear corridors enabling the butterfly to colonize many kilometres in just a few decades. However, this period of expansion now seems to be over and there were signs of a slight contraction in the 1990s. The Wood White is thought to be stable over much of its European range but has declined severely in Denmark (>75% decrease in 25 years) and to a lesser extent in Luxembourg (25-50%), Germany, Latvia, and European Turkey (15-25%). In woodland and scrub habitats, Wood White populations are known to fluctuate in response to the growth of surrounding trees and shading of its scrub-edge breeding habitats.; The butterfly has declined seriously in England and Wales. UK BAP Status: Species of Conservation Concern; Butterfly Conservation priority: medium; European Status: not threatened; Protected in Great Britain for sale only.; It has declined in a few European countries.
Flight.characteristics: The Wood White is a delicate, slow-flying butterfly...; Males fly almost continuously in fine weather, patrolling to find a mate, whereas females spend much of their time feeding on flowers or resting.
Habitat: The Wood White breeds in tall grassland or light scrub in partially shaded or edge habitats. In Britain, most colonies breed in woodland rides and clearings, though a few large colonies occur on coastal undercliffs. A few smaller colonies occur on disused railway lines and around rough, overgrown field edges (for example in north Devon). In Ireland, more open habitats are used, often far from woodland, including rough grassland with scrub, road verges, hedges, and disused railway lines.; By the 1970s, almost 50% of colonies occurred in ride alongside young conifer plantations.; usually encountered in sheltered situations such as woodland rides or scrub edges.
Oviposition: The eggs are laid singly on upper parts of foodplants, usually where they protrude above surrounding vegetation. In Britain, females prefer to lay eggs in light scrub or in the edges of sunny woodland rides. They rarely lay in very open areas and never fly into dense shade.
Hostplant.larval.food: Various legumes are used, commonly Meadow Vetchling (Lathyrus pratensis), Bittervetch (L. linifolius), Tufted Vetch (Vicia cracea), Common Bird's-foot-trefoil (Lotus corniculatus), and Greater Bird's-foot-trefoil (L. pedunculatus). (Note that some vetches are not used, notably Bush Vetch (V. sepium), and Common Vetch (V. sativa).; [The larvae] tend to feed on younger, more nutritious growth at the top of foodplants.
Adult.food: females spend much of their time feeding on flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: There is one generation per year through most of its range, with adults flying from the end of May to the end of July. In the far south of England, and elsewhere in hot years, adults fly a few weeks earlier and there is a partial second brood in late July and August.; The butterfly overwinters as pupa.
Diapause: The butterfly overwinters as pupa.
Mobility: At most woodland sites, the Wood White occurs in discrete colonies, although there may be considerable movement between suitable rides and glades. In Ireland, it appears to have a looser colony structure as it does in continental Europe, often occurring at low densities over wide areas with concentrations only in the best breeding areas. Adults, usually males, are recorded sporadically many kilometres from known colonies and presumably represent dispersing individuals. There is little precise information on colonization range, but this must be considerable judging by its spread in Ireland over recent decades.; The butterfly expanded northwards during the fine summers of 1970s and 1980s, spreading particularly along railway lines, both used and disused. These habitats are believed to have acted as linear corridors enabling the butterfly to colonize many kilometres in just a few decades.
Author: vaughn.shirey

Book: The millennium atlas of butterflies in Britain and Ireland
Common.name: Wood White
Distribution.Range: Widespread in Europe as far as 66 degrees-North in Scandinavia and eastwards to the Caucasus Mountains and Siberia. Very localized distribution in England and Wales, and widespread in Ireland.
Abundance: Declined seriously in England and Wales, and is much more widespread in Ireland.
Flight.characteristics: Delicate, and slow-flying
Habitat: Breeds in tall grasslands or light scrub in partially shaded or edge habitats. In Britain, most colonies breed in woodlands rides and clearings, and a few on coastal undercliffs. Some smaller colonies use disowned railway lines and around rough, overgrowrn field edges. In Ireland, more open habitats are used, often far from woodland, including rough grassland with scrub, road verges, hedges, and disused railway lines.
Oviposition: Eggs laid singly on upper parts of foodplants. In Britain, they prefer to lay eggs in slightly shaded and shelterd situations, either in light srcub or in the edges of sunny woodland rides.
Hostplant.larval.food: Various legumes used, commonly Meadow Vetchling (Lathyrus pratensis) Bittervetch (L. linifolius), Tufted Vetch (Vicia cracca), Common Bird's-foot-trefoil (Lotus corniculatus), and Greater Bird's-foot-trefoil (L. pedunculatus).
Phenology.and.voltinism: One main generation per year, with adults flying from the end of May to the end of July. In hot years and southern England, adults fly a few weeks earlier and there is a partial second brood in late July and August.
Diapause: Overwinters as a pupa.
Defense.strategies: Green and well camouflaged with plants.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. II. Pieridae and Danaidae
Distribution.Range: Tanajampea, Kalao
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Leptosia nina Fabricius (Original Description) nina Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3 (1), p.194 (1793) India chlorographa Hubner, Zutr., Exot., Schm., figs. 47, 48 (1818) Java dione Wallace, Trans. Ent. Soc., 3(4), p.317 (1867) S.Celebes nicobarica Doherty, Journ. As. Soc. Beng., p.262 (1886) Nicobars fumigata Fruhstorfer, Iris, 15, p.269 (1902) Lombok~Flores comma Fruhstorfer, Iris, is, p.269 (1902) Timor malayana Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p.121 (1910) Malay Peninsula aurisparsa Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Sawu aebutia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) terentia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) georgi Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Tanajampea, Kalao Bazilan Luzon nani Morishita, Memoirs, Tsukada Collection, (3), p.8, f.1 (1981) Nias (Tsukada coll.) [Notes] Oriental representative of Leptosia widely distributed from India to Lesser Sundas, Timor and Formosa. Nina has male genitaria quite different from African species, and may stand alone. Characters: Butterfly differs from African species as follows, 1) forewing above apical marking abruptly narrowed in space 5, 2) hindwing above marginal black border absent and 3) two conspicuous stripes on the underside hindwing. Male and female genitalia differ in the following points, 1) uncus longer, 2) tip of valva wider, 3) basal prong of phillus fairly developed and 4) signum of slender stick. Varieties: Sexes are alike. Female wings are much rounded. Various local forms occur. In malayana from Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo, subapical dot is smaller than that of typical nina, and has rather conspicuous two greyish-green stripes on the underside hindwing. Fumigata from Lombok to Flores has subapical black dot fairly developed, and the beneath side is entirely stained. S. Celebesian dione is larger and has no apical marking. In comma from Timor to Tanimbar, subapical black dot elongates along the vein 3 and joins the apical marking. Early Stages: Bell (1912-14) described them in detail. Egg; 1.2mm high by O.5mm wide; 13 longitudinal ridges; color whiteblue. The egg is laid on the underside of a young leaf. In Luzon, larvae have Capparis rutidosperma as Appias oflerna. However the former eggs are found keeping in the shade, while the latter in the sun (Fukuda, 1974). Final instar larva; 17mm long by 2.5mm wide; grayish-green with a whitish spiracular line, above which is a dark border. Pupa; 13.6mm long; very transpalent green, often suffused with pink; cephalic projection shorter and thicker than African L. alcesta. Capparis heyeana and Cratatia relgicsa are known as larval food plants. We found larvae on Capparis zeylanica in the grounds of University of the Philippines. (Yata et al., 1978). Chromosome number: Formosan materials are examined by Maeki & Ae (1968); n=19. Bionomics: Butterfly is feeble in flight, never rises more than a foot or so from the ground. I think the flight may rather take effect to free from the attackers. It is a conspicuous insect when flying, however, when at rest it closes the wings and becomes nearly invisible by the protective marking of greenish striae and lines. They are delight in plain forests but are also found anywhere the food-plants grow. For instance, I found the eggs were laid on weeds, Capparis rutidosperma, in the shade on the flower beds of University of the Philippines. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Jolo
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 094) Leptosia nina (Fabricius, 1793)  PSYCHE Plate 14 and 15 Subspecies and distribution: (i) terentia Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Basilan, Calamian, Cebu, Cuyo, Mindoro, Mindanao,  Palawan, Panay. (ii) georgi Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Luzon. (iii) asukae Nihira & Kawamura, 1986 - Jolo. (iv) malayana Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparis baducca, C. heydeana C. lanceolaris, C. sicula, C. sikkimensis, C. spinosa (Caper), C. tomentosa (Woolly Caper Bush), C.  zeylanica [ph], Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog). Cleomaceae: Cleome gynandra, C. rutidosperma (Purple Cleome/Fringed Spiderflower) [PH], C. viscosa (Asian Spiderflower). Rhamnaceae: Rhamnus Very common. Occurs in Metro Manila.This species flies slowly low down amongst vegetation; it is tolerant of a wide range of habitats and can be seen almost anywhere in suburban as well as rural areas.

Full.Species.Account: Leptosia nina Fabricius (Original Description) nina Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3 (1), p.194 (1793) India chlorographa Hubner, Zutr., Exot., Schm., figs. 47, 48 (1818) Java dione Wallace, Trans. Ent. Soc., 3(4), p.317 (1867) S.Celebes nicobarica Doherty, Journ. As. Soc. Beng., p.262 (1886) Nicobars fumigata Fruhstorfer, Iris, 15, p.269 (1902) Lombok~Flores comma Fruhstorfer, Iris, is, p.269 (1902) Timor malayana Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p.121 (1910) Malay Peninsula aurisparsa Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Sawu aebutia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) terentia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) georgi Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Tanajampea, Kalao Bazilan Luzon nani Morishita, Memoirs, Tsukada Collection, (3), p.8, f.1 (1981) Nias (Tsukada coll.) [Notes] Oriental representative of Leptosia widely distributed from India to Lesser Sundas, Timor and Formosa. Nina has male genitaria quite different from African species, and may stand alone. Characters: Butterfly differs from African species as follows, 1) forewing above apical marking abruptly narrowed in space 5, 2) hindwing above marginal black border absent and 3) two conspicuous stripes on the underside hindwing. Male and female genitalia differ in the following points, 1) uncus longer, 2) tip of valva wider, 3) basal prong of phillus fairly developed and 4) signum of slender stick. Varieties: Sexes are alike. Female wings are much rounded. Various local forms occur. In malayana from Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo, subapical dot is smaller than that of typical nina, and has rather conspicuous two greyish-green stripes on the underside hindwing. Fumigata from Lombok to Flores has subapical black dot fairly developed, and the beneath side is entirely stained. S. Celebesian dione is larger and has no apical marking. In comma from Timor to Tanimbar, subapical black dot elongates along the vein 3 and joins the apical marking. Early Stages: Bell (1912-14) described them in detail. Egg; 1.2mm high by O.5mm wide; 13 longitudinal ridges; color whiteblue. The egg is laid on the underside of a young leaf. In Luzon, larvae have Capparis rutidosperma as Appias oflerna. However the former eggs are found keeping in the shade, while the latter in the sun (Fukuda, 1974). Final instar larva; 17mm long by 2.5mm wide; grayish-green with a whitish spiracular line, above which is a dark border. Pupa; 13.6mm long; very transpalent green, often suffused with pink; cephalic projection shorter and thicker than African L. alcesta. Capparis heyeana and Cratatia relgicsa are known as larval food plants. We found larvae on Capparis zeylanica in the grounds of University of the Philippines. (Yata et al., 1978). Chromosome number: Formosan materials are examined by Maeki & Ae (1968); n=19. Bionomics: Butterfly is feeble in flight, never rises more than a foot or so from the ground. I think the flight may rather take effect to free from the attackers. It is a conspicuous insect when flying, however, when at rest it closes the wings and becomes nearly invisible by the protective marking of greenish striae and lines. They are delight in plain forests but are also found anywhere the food-plants grow. For instance, I found the eggs were laid on weeds, Capparis rutidosperma, in the shade on the flower beds of University of the Philippines. (ii) georgi Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Luzon. (iii) asukae Nihira & Kawamura, 1986 - Jolo. (iv) malayana Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparis baducca, C. heydeana C. lanceolaris, C. sicula, C. sikkimensis, C. spinosa (Caper), C. tomentosa (Woolly Caper Bush), C.  zeylanica [ph], Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog). Full.Species.Account: Leptosia nina Fabricius (Original Description) nina Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3 (1), p.194 (1793) India chlorographa Hubner, Zutr., Exot., Schm., figs. 47, 48 (1818) Java dione Wallace, Trans. Ent. Soc., 3(4), p.317 (1867) S.Celebes nicobarica Doherty, Journ. As. Soc. Beng., p.262 (1886) Nicobars fumigata Fruhstorfer, Iris, 15, p.269 (1902) Lombok~Flores comma Fruhstorfer, Iris, is, p.269 (1902) Timor malayana Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p.121 (1910) Malay Peninsula aurisparsa Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Sawu aebutia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) terentia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) georgi Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Tanajampea, Kalao Bazilan Luzon nani Morishita, Memoirs, Tsukada Collection, (3), p.8, f.1 (1981) Nias (Tsukada coll.) [Notes] Oriental representative of Leptosia widely distributed from India to Lesser Sundas, Timor and Formosa. Nina has male genitaria quite different from African species, and may stand alone. Characters: Butterfly differs from African species as follows, 1) forewing above apical marking abruptly narrowed in space 5, 2) hindwing above marginal black border absent and 3) two conspicuous stripes on the underside hindwing. Male and female genitalia differ in the following points, 1) uncus longer, 2) tip of valva wider, 3) basal prong of phillus fairly developed and 4) signum of slender stick. Varieties: Sexes are alike. Female wings are much rounded. Various local forms occur. In malayana from Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo, subapical dot is smaller than that of typical nina, and has rather conspicuous two greyish-green stripes on the underside hindwing. Fumigata from Lombok to Flores has subapical black dot fairly developed, and the beneath side is entirely stained. S. Celebesian dione is larger and has no apical marking. In comma from Timor to Tanimbar, subapical black dot elongates along the vein 3 and joins the apical marking. Early Stages: Bell (1912-14) described them in detail. Egg; 1.2mm high by O.5mm wide; 13 longitudinal ridges; color whiteblue. The egg is laid on the underside of a young leaf. In Luzon, larvae have Capparis rutidosperma as Appias oflerna. However the former eggs are found keeping in the shade, while the latter in the sun (Fukuda, 1974). Final instar larva; 17mm long by 2.5mm wide; grayish-green with a whitish spiracular line, above which is a dark border. Pupa; 13.6mm long; very transpalent green, often suffused with pink; cephalic projection shorter and thicker than African L. alcesta. Capparis heyeana and Cratatia relgicsa are known as larval food plants. We found larvae on Capparis zeylanica in the grounds of University of the Philippines. (Yata et al., 1978). Chromosome number: Formosan materials are examined by Maeki & Ae (1968); n=19. Bionomics: Butterfly is feeble in flight, never rises more than a foot or so from the ground. I think the flight may rather take effect to free from the attackers. It is a conspicuous insect when flying, however, when at rest it closes the wings and becomes nearly invisible by the protective marking of greenish striae and lines. They are delight in plain forests but are also found anywhere the food-plants grow. For instance, I found the eggs were laid on weeds, Capparis rutidosperma, in the shade on the flower beds of University of the Philippines. Beng., p.262 (1886) Nicobars fumigata Fruhstorfer, Iris, 15, p.269 (1902) Lombok~Flores comma Fruhstorfer, Iris, is, p.269 (1902) Timor malayana Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9, p.121 (1910) Malay Peninsula aurisparsa Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Sawu aebutia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) terentia Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) georgi Fruhstorfer, Seitz' Macrolep., 9. p.121 (1910) Tanajampea, Kalao Bazilan Luzon nani Morishita, Memoirs, Tsukada Collection, (3), p.8, f.1 (1981) Nias (Tsukada coll.) [Notes] Oriental representative of Leptosia widely distributed from India to Lesser Sundas, Timor and Formosa. Nina has male genitaria quite different from African species, and may stand alone. Characters: Butterfly differs from African species as follows, 1) forewing above apical marking abruptly narrowed in space 5, 2) hindwing above marginal black border absent and 3) two conspicuous stripes on the underside hindwing. Male and female genitalia differ in the following points, 1) uncus longer, 2) tip of valva wider, 3) basal prong of phillus fairly developed and 4) signum of slender stick. Varieties: Sexes are alike. Female wings are much rounded. Various local forms occur. In malayana from Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo, subapical dot is smaller than that of typical nina, and has rather conspicuous two greyish-green stripes on the underside hindwing. Fumigata from Lombok to Flores has subapical black dot fairly developed, and the beneath side is entirely stained. S. Celebesian dione is larger and has no apical marking. In comma from Timor to Tanimbar, subapical black dot elongates along the vein 3 and joins the apical marking. Early Stages: Bell (1912-14) described them in detail. Egg; 1.2mm high by O.5mm wide; 13 longitudinal ridges; color whiteblue. The egg is laid on the underside of a young leaf. In Luzon, larvae have Capparis rutidosperma as Appias oflerna. However the former eggs are found keeping in the shade, while the latter in the sun (Fukuda, 1974). Final instar larva; 17mm long by 2.5mm wide; grayish-green with a whitish spiracular line, above which is a dark border. Pupa; 13.6mm long; very transpalent green, often suffused with pink; cephalic projection shorter and thicker than African L. alcesta. Capparis heyeana and Cratatia relgicsa are known as larval food plants. We found larvae on Capparis zeylanica in the grounds of University of the Philippines. (Yata et al., 1978). Chromosome number: Formosan materials are examined by Maeki & Ae (1968); n=19. Bionomics: Butterfly is feeble in flight, never rises more than a foot or so from the ground. I think the flight may rather take effect to free from the attackers. It is a conspicuous insect when flying, however, when at rest it closes the wings and becomes nearly invisible by the protective marking of greenish striae and lines. They are delight in plain forests but are also found anywhere the food-plants grow. For instance, I found the eggs were laid on weeds, Capparis rutidosperma, in the shade on the flower beds of University of the Philippines. Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of The Philippines
Distribution.Range: Basilan, Calamian, Cebu, Cuyo, Mindoro, Mindanao, Palawan, Panay
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: 094) Leptosia nina (Fabricius, 1793)  PSYCHE Plate 14 and 15 Subspecies and distribution: (i) terentia Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Basilan, Calamian, Cebu, Cuyo, Mindoro, Mindanao,  Palawan, Panay. (ii) georgi Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Luzon. (iii) asukae Nihira & Kawamura, 1986 - Jolo. (iv) malayana Fruhstorfer, 1910 - Sanga Sanga, Sibutu, Tawi-Tawi. Recorded hostplants: Capparaceae: Capparis baducca, C. heydeana C. lanceolaris, C. sicula, C. sikkimensis, C. spinosa (Caper), C. tomentosa (Woolly Caper Bush), C.  zeylanica [ph], Crateva adansonii, C. religiosa (Sacred Garlic Pear/Salingbobog). Cleomaceae: Cleome gynandra, C. rutidosperma (Purple Cleome/Fringed Spiderflower) [PH], C. viscosa (Asian Spiderflower). Rhamnaceae: Rhamnus Very common. Occurs in Metro Manila.This species flies slowly low down amongst vegetation; it is tolerant of a wide range of habitats and can be seen almost anywhere in suburban as well as rural areas.

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Clouded Skipper
Distribution.Range: Resident Visitor [to the Carolinas]
Abundance: occasional;  It regularly explores the surrounding landscape and may show up occasionally in suburban yards or gardens.; Resident Visitor [to the Carolinas]
Flight.characteristics: Adults have a quick, nervous flight but readily alight on low vegetation or leaf litter.
Habitat: open woodlands, forest edges, roadsides, wet land edges, swamps, stream corridors and old fields;  It regularly explores the surrounding landscape and may show up occasionally in suburban yards or gardens.
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: various grasses including St. Augustine Grass, Plumegrass and Rustyseed Paspalum
Phenology.and.voltinism: April - Early November; multiple generations
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Clouded Skipper Lerema accius Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Banded Skippers (Hesperlinae) Wingspan: 1.0-1.5" (2.5-3.8 cm) Above: dark chocolate brown; forewing has several small semitransparent spots Below: dark brown; forewing has row of small semitransparent spots near apex; both wings have lavender scaling in center and toward margin Sexes: similar, female has larger forewing spots Egg: laid singly on host leaves Larva: green with a dark dorsal stripe and white lateral stripes; head is white with a black margin and three black stripes; body is covered with fine white spots Larval Host Plants: various grasses including St. Augustine Grass, Plumegrass and Rustyseed Paspalum Habitat: open woodlands, forest edges, roadsides, wet land edges, swamps, stream corridors and old fields Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional Compare: Zabulon Skipper (pg. 147) female has larger forewing spots and a white bar along leading edge of ventral hindwing. Dusted Skipper (pg. 201) has small white spot near base of ventral hindwing.  Comments: The Clouded Skipper is our only member of this primarily tropical genus. Although superficially appearing drab, closer inspection is needed to appreci ate the delicate lavender scaling on the hindwings below. It regularly explores the surrounding landscape and may show up occasionally in suburban yards or gardens. Adults have a quick, nervous flight but readily alight on low vegetation or leaf litter. It is an easy but terfly to approach.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Clouded Skipper
Distribution.Range: southern Illinois Permanent resident southeast U.S. south to Colombia and Venezuela. Summer stray to Connecticut and southern Illinois. [images]Hardin County, IL; Alexander County, IL; Hamilton County, IL
Abundance: The species occurs in southern Illinois, sometimes locally common Scarce to occasional but can be locally common in southern Illinois. Summer and fall resident only. Not found every year. Summer stray to Connecticut and southern Illinois.
Habitat: Forest edges, clearings, along streams and swamps. Prairie openings in forests. Males perch near ground… along wood edges or in clearings.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on grasses including barnyard grass (Echinochloa crus-galli) and plume grass (Erianthus alopecuroides).
Adult.food: Adults nectar on various plants, often white, pink, or purple, including buttonbush (CephaIanthus occidentalis), blue vervain (Verbena hastata), sell-heal (Prunella vulgaris), ironweed (Vernonia spp.), mist flower (Conoclinium coelestinum), and others.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Multivoltine in the southern U.S. Summer and fall resident only. Not found every year. Summer stray to Connecticut and southern Illinois.
Author: andra.doherty

Common.name: Clouded Skipper
Phenology.and.voltinism: [late summer and fall.]

Abundance: Strays north as far as s. New England, s. Ill., se. Kans., and s. Ariz.
Habitat: Woods edges and clearings near swamps and rivers.

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: CLOUDED SKIPPER
Author: andra.doherty

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: CLOUDED SKIPPER
Distribution.Range: Resident in se. Ariz. near Mexican border, also in se. U.S. south through s. Tex. and mainland tropical Amer. to Venezuela and Colombia. In West strays north as far e. Colo., s. N.M., and w. Tex.; in East strays to s. New England, s. Ill., and se. Kans.
Abundance: In West strays north as far e. Colo., s. N.M., and w. Tex.; in East strays to s. New England, s. Ill., and se. Kans.
Habitat: Woods edges and clearings near swamps and rivers, suburban gardens.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses.
Adult.food: Adults in search of nectar will disappear inside the corolla of large flowers. They also favor lantana and a wide variety of other flowers.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Mid-April-early Dec. in se. Ariz., all year in Fla. and s. Tex. (several flights).
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Butterflies through Binoculars: The East- A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Eastern North America
Common.name: Clouded Skipper
Distribution.Range: Southern Florida and Houston TX areas- all year. Decreasing immigrant northward, mainly April-Oct. Common along the coast north to North Carolina, late summer - early fall. Irregular immigrant or RS north to New York, Massachusetts,Indiana, Missouri, and southeastern Kansas.
Abundance: C-A. Southern Florida and Houston TX areas- all year. Decreasing immigrant northward, mainly April-Oct. Common along the coast north to North Carolina, late summer - early fall. Irregular immigrant or RS north to New York, Massachusetts,Indiana, Missouri, and southeastern Kansas. From phenogram NC: rare from very end of April to end of May, uncommon beginning and early June, rare in mid June and early July, uncommon mid July to mid August, common mid August to early October, uncommon mid to end of October.
Habitat: Can be found in almost any open habitat, including open wood-land, but prefers moist grassy areas in or near woods.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Southern Florida and Houston TX areas- all year. Decreasing immigrant northward, mainly April-Oct. Common along the coast north to North Carolina, late summer - early fall. One of our earliest rising skippers, Clouded Skippers will be seen perching and courting early in the morning before their relatives have woken. From phenogram NC: rare from very end of April to end of May, uncommon beginning and early June, rare in mid June and early July, uncommon mid July to mid August, common mid August to early October, uncommon mid to end of October.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Butterflies through Binoculars: The East- A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Eastern North America

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 1: Satyrinae
Distribution.Range: Tonkin, Chiem Hoa... N., C. & S. Vietnam...  Ssp. crijnana occurs in Vietnam, Laos, ?Cambodia... The Vietnamese populations belong to ssp. crijnana Fruhstorfer, 1911.
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Lethe mekara (Moore, [1858]) Plate 15, figs. 4a-b Catal. Lep. Mus. East Ind. Co. 1 (1857): 219 (Debis) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - Sikkim Darjiling. Debis mekara Moore; Cat Lep. Mus. 1857: 219. Oxford University Museum, Type Lep. 3167, [Male] Darjiling. ssp. crijnona - N. Vietnam (Tonkin). Lethe mekara crijnana Fruhstorfer: l. c., 1911: 319, t. 98c. Syntype, [Male] , VIII-IX, C. Tonkin, Chiem Hoa. Lethe mekara crijnana: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 29. Lethe mekara crijnana: Meteye, 1957:103. N. Vietnam. Lethe mekara crijnana: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 18. N., C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. The nominate ssp. is also known as taxon vajra Fruhstorfer, 1911 (TL: Darjiling) RANGE. It is distributed from India, Sikkim and Burma to Indochina and the Malay Peninsula and south to Borneo and Sumatra. Ssp. crijnana occurs in Vietnam, Laos, ?Cambodia. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. N. Vietnam: Na Hang N.R., Ba Be N.P, Tam Dao N.P. C. Vietnam: Pu Hoat N.R., Vu Quang N.R., Ben En N.P., Pu Mat N.R., Xuan Lien N.R., Ngoc Linh N.R. S. Vietnam: Cat Tien N.P. (Cat Loc sector), Nghia Trung SFE. Length of FW: [Male] 30-34mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The Vietnamese populations belong to ssp. crijnana Fruhstorfer, 1911. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. Tam Dao: secondary forest, 200m; Vu Quang: secondary forest, 100m; Ben En: scrubland; Pu Mat: secondary forests, 200-1,300m; Xuan Lien: bamboo, 300m; Cat Tien (Cat Loc): forest at 500m; Nghia Trung: secondary evergreen forest with bamboo. Chou (1994) mentions Phyllostachys pubescens (Poaceae) as a food plant for the Chinese population. SIMILAR SPECIES. L. chandica has an irregular subbasal line on the UnH; the subbasal line on the UnF is split into two lines within the cell; the male UpH is fully black.

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Red-Spotted Purple
Distribution.Range: Resident [to the Carolinas]
Abundance: occasional; It is a common butterfly of immature woodlands but is rarely encountered in large numbers.; Resident [to the Carolinas]
Flight.characteristics: Adults have a strong, gliding flight and are often quite wary.
Habitat: open woodlands, forest edges and adjacent open areas; It is a common butterfly of immature woodlands but is rarely encountered in large numbers.  Males perch on sunlit branches along trails or forest borders and make periodic exploratory flights.
Oviposition: laid singly on the tips of host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: Black Cherry, Wild Cherry and wil low; Larvae eat the tip of the leaf to mid-vein
Adult.food: Adults occasionally visit flowers but often prefer rotting fruit, dung, carrion or tree sap.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Mid April - Late October; multiple generations
Mimicry: The Red-Spotted Purple is one of several Carolina butterflies that mimic the toxic Pipevine Swallowtail to gain protection from predators such as birds.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Red-Spotted Purple Limenitis arthemis astyanax Family/Subfamily: Brush-foots (Nymphalidae)/ Admirals and Relatives (Limenitidinae) Wingspan: 3.0-3.5" (7.6-8.9 cm) Above: dark velvety bluish black with iridescent blue scaling on hindwing and small orange and white soots near forewing apex Below: brownish black with an iridescent blue sheen and basal red-orange spots; hindwings have a row of redorange spots toward the outer margin Sexes: similar Egg: gray-green, laid singly on the tips of host leaves Larva: mottled green, brown and cream with two long, knobby horns on thorax; resembles a bird dropping Larval Host Plants: Black Cherry, Wild Cherry and wil low Habitat: open woodlands, forest edges and adjacent open areas Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional Compare: Pipevine Swallowtail (pg. 67) has hindwing tail and a low, rapid flight; continually flutters wings when nectaring.  Comments: The Red-Spotted Purple is one of several Carolina butterflies that mimic the toxic Pipevine Swallowtail to gain protection from predators such as birds. It is a common butterfly of immature woodlands but is rarely encountered in large numbers. Adults have a strong, gliding flight and are often quite wary. Males perch on sunlit branches along trails or forest borders and make periodic exploratory flights. Adults occasionally visit flowers but often prefer rotting fruit, dung, carrion or tree sap. Larvae eat the tip of the leaf to mid-vein and rest on the end of the vein when not actively feeding.

Common.name: White Admiral, Red-Spotted Purple, Banded Purple
Distribution.Range: The more northern White Admiral (L. arthemis arthemis) freely hybridizes with the more southern Red-spotted Purple (L. arthemis astynax) in a belt across New England, s. Ontario, and the Great Lakes states. Rarely, individuals looking like White Admirals show up far to the south amid Red-spotted Purple populations. Boreal and temperate North America from Alaska and subarctic Canada southeast of continental divide ad high plains to peninsular Fla. and the Gulf states. Isolated populations (L. a. arizonensis) from Ariz., N.M., and w. Texas south into n. Mexico.
Abundance: Rarely, individuals looking like White Admirals show up far to the south amid Red-spotted Purple populations.
Habitat: Deciduous broad-leaf forest or mixed evergreen forest, associated edges, and clearings.
Hostplant.larval.food: Leaves of trees and shrubs: Wild Cherry, poplar, aspens, black oaks, and others.
Phenology.and.voltinism: April or May to Oct. (2 broods).
Adult.forms: Our two very different forms were once considered separate species. WHITE ADMIRAL: Upperside of both wings black. Forewing with outwardly curved broad white band and a few white spots on apex. Hindwing has a postmedian white band, submarginal series of red spots, and a marginal row of blue dashes. Underside: White bands are repeated. Hindwing has reddish brown background. RED-SPOTTED PURPLE: Upperside is blue to blue-green with outer part of hindwing more iridescent. Underside: forewlng has two costal red-orange bars, and hindwing has 3 basal red-orange spots and a submarginal row of red-orange spots. The Banded Purple, form \proserpina\" which is like White Admiral with a submarginal blue band"

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: WHITE ADMIRAL
Distribution.Range: [image]White Admiral (subspecies arthemis)… Goreham, N.H. The more northern White Admiral (L. arthemis arthemis) freely hybridizes with the more southern Red-spotted Purple (L. arthemis astyanax) in a broad belt across New England, s. Ontario, the Great Lakes states, and northern plains. Rarely, individual butterflies appearing to be White Admirals are found far to the south amid Red-spotted Purple populations. Boreal and temperate N. Amer. from Alaska and subarctic Canada south and east to most of e. U.S. Isolated populations of Red-spotted Purple (subspecies arizonensis) occur in Ariz., N.M., and w. Tex. south into n. Mex. The Red-spotted Purple form is a mimic of the distasteful Pipevine Swallowtail and occurs within the permanent or temporary range of that species. The White Admiral form is found to the north of the Pipevine Swallowtail.

Adult.food: Adults rarely visit white flowers such as viburnum, privet, sweet pepperbush, and Hercules' club.

Mimicry: The Red-spotted Purple form is a mimic of the distasteful Pipevine Swallowtail and occurs within the permanent or temporary range of that species.

Underside: Forewing has 2 costal red-orange bars, and hindwing has 3 basal red-orange spots and submarginal row of red-orange spots. White Admiral: Upperside: Both wings black. Forewing has outwardly curved broad white and and a few white spots on apex. Hindwing with postmedian white band, submarginal series of red spots, and a marginal row of blue dashes. Underside: White band sare  repeated. Hindwing has reddish brown background. The Banded Purple, form proserpina, is like the White Admiral with a submarginal blue band above. [image]White Admiral (subspecies arthemis)… Goreham, N.H. …This butterfly shows some features of form prosepina. The Red-spotted Purple form is a mimic of the distasteful Pipevine Swallowtail and occurs within the permanent or temporary range of that species. The White Admiral form is found to the north of the Pipevine Swallowtail.

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: White Admiral
Distribution.Range: These butterflies range across Canada from the treeline south to Michigan, Manitoba and North Dakota. Most Alberta material is referred to L. a. rubrofasciata. Hybrids of L. arthemis and L. lorquini are found in the mountain passes and valleys of the Crowsnest and Castle river drainages in southwestern Alberta. Hybridization also occurs with L. weidemeyerii in other localities.
Habitat: Males patrol forest edges and coulees.
Oviposition: The round, pale green eggs are laid singly on leaves of the host.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larval food plants include birch {Betula spp.), Trembling Aspen {Populus tremuloides), poplar [Populus spp.) and willow {Salix spp.).
Adult.food: Both sexes puddle actively.
Phenology.and.voltinism: In Alberta, adults have been collected from May 23 to September 9. Peak flight occurs in late June and July.There is one brood per year.
Diapause: The partly grown larvae overwinter in a leaf shelter
Author: elise.larsen

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Adult.food: In Liphyra, the proboscis is wholly atrophied so that adults apparently cannot feed during this stage of their life and so rely entirely on their fat reserves for sustenance. For example, Dodd (1902) pointed out that L. brassolis adults are: “very oily; in some instances grease came through abdomen in less than a week after setting. A thick layer of almost liquid grease lines the abdomen”. This partly explains why the Liphyra abdomen is so abnormally large and rounded
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus LIPHYRA Westwood, 1864 This lowland genus is remarkable for the specialised life histories of its members and the related structural features of the adults. It contains only 2 species. The type species, brassolis Westwood, 1864, designated by author, ranges throughout the Indo- Australian Region from northern India, through South-east Asia to the Moluccas, mainland NG, the Solomons and northern Australia. The other, grandis Weymer, 1902, is endemic to mainland PNG. Strand (1911a) discussed the genus in the Australian Subregion and newly described castnia from PNG as a species distinct from brassolis, for which he recognised 4 subspecies. However, he was unaware that his castnia was a synonym of L grandis described earlier by Weymer (1902). Eliot (1973) listed Sterosis C. & R. Felder, 1865, as a synonym of Liphyra. In the past, 5 African genera, including Liphyra, have been treated by some authors as a subfamily, Liphyrinae (e.g. Eliot, 1973), or even as a separate family, Liphyridae (e.g. Clench, 1955). However, Ehrlich (1960) showed that Liphyra is a typical member of the Lycaeninae, to which subfamily it is now correctly assigned. The most recent review of Liphyra is that of Samson and Smart (1980). The African genus Euliphyra Holland, 1890, is the nearest relative of Liphyra and both genera possess very similar genitalia, venation and early stages (Bethune-Baker, 1924). In both the males bear 5-segmented foretarsi and a pair of terminal claws, whereas in most other lycaenids the male tarsi are reduced to a single elongate segment without claws. Liphyra is also the only genus in the Indo-Australian Region with all veins present in the fore wings of both sexes. Eliot (in Corbet and Pendlebury, 1978) stated that ‘Liphyrinae’ is rather closely related to ‘Miletinae’. Liphyra adults are medium-sized butterflies which, for their family, is very large. In fact, they are the largest of all lycaenids. This appearance is enhanced by their stout, robust, very moth-like bodies. They are very cryptically coloured with dark brown wings and pale brown and orange markings. The genus exhibits little sexual dimorphism and the males lack secondary sexual characters such as sex-brands. The eye is smooth and the labial palpus is porrect and gradually tapered, being very small and shorter than the head. The Liphyra antenna is short, stout, and tapers gradually into a cylindrical club. The hindwing and forewing cells are about one-half the lengths of their respective wings. The hindwing termen is well-rounded, but the tomus is produced into a broad lobe at vein 1A+2A. The male genitalia are typically lycaenine, but the tegumen is strongly dorsally recurved so that it usually projects proximally almost as much as the saccus. In Liphyra, the proboscis is wholly atrophied so that adults apparently cannot feed during this stage of their life and so rely entirely on their fat reserves for sustenance. For example, Dodd (1902) pointed out that L. brassolis adults are: “very oily; in some instances grease came through abdomen in less than a week after setting. A thick layer of almost liquid grease lines the abdomen”. This partly explains why the Liphyra abdomen is so abnormally large and rounded. Additionally, it is probable that L. brassolis females have ovarian development similar to that described by Sands (1979b) in that their ovaries are well-developed (containing many mature ova) at eclosion from the pupa. Adult Liphyra are diurnal but also exhibit markedly crepuscular behaviour and, in PNG, of the few records of Liphyra adults known, most have been recorded as being attracted to lights in the evening twilight, when they have been captured. Due to their extremely moth-like and rather dull appearance they may be overlooked at such times and this may partly explain the paucity of records. However, Rothschild (1915b) suggested that the “extreme rarity” of specimens is probably due to their particularly specialised ant associated life histories. This is fully described below. The larvae, pupae and adults are remarkable for their specialised features of protection from Oecophylla smaragdina (the tailor, or green tree ant) in whose nests they occur and upon whose larvae they feed. Liphyra larvae do not produce glandular secretions of interest to their ant hosts as do the larvae of many other lycaenids. They are predacious on the ant larvae, and are thus ‘parasitic’ on the colony as a whole, hence their need for special armour-like protection from the O. smaragdina ants, which would otherwise not tolerate their presence within their nests. These are a tough, leathery, rather smooth skin and dome-shaped puparium. Interestingly, analogous protection has been evolved for apparently much the same reason by larvae of the syrphid fly genus, Microdon, in the USA and Mexico. The tough-skinned, dome-shaped syrphid larvae occur inside the nests of Formica species ants and possibly prey on the ant larvae (R. Snelling, pers. comm., 1995).

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Purplish Copper
Distribution.Range: The Purplish Copper ranges from Ontario west to British Columbia and south to Baja California and New Mexico. In Alberta, it occurs as far north as the Peace River region.
Habitat: The Purplish Copper is found in prairies and aspen parklands, often along water courses and around pond margins. Males perch on flowers and prominent stems and investigate passing butterflies. Asters and yellow composites are often chosen for perches.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on dock {Rumex spp.), knotweed {Polygonum spp.), Oxytheca spp. and Low Willowherb {Gayophytum racemosum). They are rare on cinquefoil {Potentilla spp.).
Adult.food: Adults nectar readily
Phenology.and.voltinism: Several generations may occur over the summer. The flight period in Alberta is from May 17 to October 5 with the butterflies most abundant in June and again in late August.
Diapause: The Purplish Copper overwinters as a pupa.
Author: elise.larsen

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: Purplish copper
Distribution.Range: counties,
Abundance: Since the mid- to late 1990s this usually abundant and even weedy species has declined precipitously in abundance and dis tribution throughout our area. Many populations have simply disappeared, while others are seldom observed except in fall. but increas
Habitat: Now it seems increas ingly confined to marshlands.
Hostplant.larval.food: Knot weeds and smart\veeds (Polygonum), includ ing the common prostrate knotweeds of the P. aviculare complex; docks (Rumex); in the Suisun Marsh (formerly) Potetuilla anse rina subsp. pacifica.
Adult.food: This species visits low flowers with shallow corollas, especially heliotropes (Heliotropium) and lippias (Lippia), but in fall it often visits tall asters (Aster) and coyote brush (Baccharis pilularis).
Phenology.and.voltinism: Its increasingly dominant pattern of greatest abundance in September and October. Multiple broods, March to December, but in recent years in most areas seldom seen before July or August, and com mon (if at all) only in fall.
Diapause: Overwinters as egg.
Author: elise.larsen

Book: Field Guide to Butterflies of the San Francisco Bay and Sacramento Valley Regions
Common.name: purplish copper
Abundance: Especially since 1999, even once-common and once-widespread species have suffered dramatic declines.
Author: elise.larsen

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Yucca Giant-Skipper
Distribution.Range: Resident [of the Carolinas]
Abundance: occasional
Flight.characteristics: Adults have a rapid, powerful flight that produces a noticeable buzz.
Habitat: dry woodlands, pinelands and scrub; Males perch on vegetation along trails or clearings and actively defend their territory.
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: yuccas including Spanish Dagger and Stiff-leaved Bear Grass;  The larvae feed on host leaves when young but soon bur row into stem and large taproot, forming a long tunnel.
Phenology.and.voltinism: March - Early May; single generation;  The butterfly is particu larly active in late afternoon or early evening.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Yucca Giant-Skipper Megathymus yuccae Comments: The Yucca Giant-Skipper is a beautifully marked butterfly with elongated wings. Adults have a rapid, powerful flight that produces a noticeable buzz. Males perch on vegetation along trails or clearings and actively defend their territory. The butterfly is particu larly active in late afternoon or early evening. The larvae feed on host leaves when young but soon bur row into stem and large taproot, forming a long tunnel. Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Giant-Skippers (Megathyminae) tA/ingspan: 2.0-2.8" (5.1-7.1 cm) Above: blackish brown with yellow hindwing border and straight band of yellow spots on forewing; small white spots near the forewing apex; female has small postmedian band of tiny orange spots on hindwing Below: chocolate brown with marginal frosting and dis tinct white patch along upper margin of hindwing Sexes: similar, although female is significantly larger with broader wings and an additional row of yellow spots on hindwing Egg: pinkish brown, laid singly on host leaves Larva: light tan with reddish brown head Larval Host Plants: yuccas including Spanish Dagger and Stiff-leaved Bear Grass Habitat: dry woodlands, pinelands and scrub Broods: single generation Abundance: occasional Compare: Cofaqui Giant-Skipper (pg. 237) has a broad, curved yellow forewing band and is duller gray-brown below with less prominent scattered small white hind wing spots.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Yucca Giant Skipper
Distribution.Range: This species has recently been found breeding in western Kentucky (Calloway County) at a number of sites where Yucca smalliana has become established. The sites are a range extension of the yucca species as well as the skipper. possibility of the skipper eventually reaching Illinois is high The species has not been recorded trom Illinois. Its recent discovery in Kentucky is a range extension to the north for the species. Very likely, the species will eventually reach Illinois. It should be looked for in the southern counties of the state.  Coastal Virginia south into Florida, through the southern stales, westto California. [images]Onslo County, NC
Abundance: possibility of the skipper eventually reaching Illinois is high The species has not been recorded trom Illinois. Very likely, the species will eventually reach Illinois. It should be looked for in the southern counties of the state.
Habitat: a number of sites where Yucca smalliana has become established. Yuccas are often found established or persisting on abandoned farmyard sites, in cemeteries, and other places in southern Illinois, providing suitable habitat for the Yucca Skipper. Because of this, the possibility of the skipper eventually reaching Illinois is high Disturbed areas and roadsides, old homesteads and cemeteries where the larval host Yucca filamentosa and smalliana have become established.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid on the leaves of yucca in the east, other species further south and west).
Hostplant.larval.food: Upon hatching the first, and even the second, instar larvae may feed externally on the leaves before boring into a leaf caudex (growing point), and then feeding internally within the plant as a borer… tunnels through the root or stem… where it lives and feeds Yucca smalliana, the known larval host in Kentucky, is common in southern Illinois
Adult.food: the adults do not reportedly visit flowers. They do take moisture from damp soil.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Univoltine. Adults emerge in April in Kentucky. Upon hatching the first, and even the second, instar larvae may feed externally on the leaves before boring into a leaf caudex (growing point), and then feeding internally within the plant as a borer. The mature larva overwinters within the silken-lined tube, and without further feeding pupates in late winter or early spring, sheltered within the tunnel.
Diapause: The mature larva overwinters within the silken-lined tube, and without further feeding pupates in late winter or early spring, sheltered within the tunnel.
Defense.strategies: Upon hatching the first, and even the second, instar larvae may feed externally on the leaves before boring into a leaf caudex (growing point), and then feeding internally within the plant as a borer. As each larva tunnels through the root or stem, it puts down a silken lining in the tunnel where it lives and feeds. The mature larva overwinters within the silken-lined tube, and without further feeding pupates in late winter or early spring, sheltered within the tunnel.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Collins Butterfly Guide: The most complete guide to the butterflies of Britain and Europe
Common.name: Marbled White
Distribution.Range: NW Africa, Europe, Turkey, Transcaucasus; TL: Germany; N Spain (Cantabrian Mts. to W and C Pyrenees), eastwards through most of Europe, including S England and Sicily to Lithuania, C Greece and European Turkey. Absent from N Holland, N Germany, and Peloponnesos. Last reported from Latvia in 1950.
Abundance: Absent from N Holland, N Germany, and Peloponnesos. Last reported from Latvia in 1950. Generally widespread and common, but absent from substantial areas within main region of distribution.
Habitat: Diverse. Grassy, flowery, bushy places.
Oviposition: Ova are ejected amongst grasses during flight.
Hostplant.larval.food: Brachypodium pinnatum; B. sylvaticum; Bromus erectus; Poa trvialis; Phleum pratense; Agrostis capillaris; Dactylis glomarata; Molinia caerulea; Avena pubsecens; Festuca rubra.
Adult.food: found of the nectar of Centaurea, Scabiosa, Cirsium, and Carduus spp.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Univoltine. Generally June/July, exceptionally late May/early September
Author: vaughn.shirey

Book: The Butterflies of Mauritius
Common.name: L. 1758 Westwood.
Distribution.Range: This species is widely distributed throughout the old world tropics, being represented in Mauritius by the African subspecies helena
Abundance: Common throughout the island
Hostplant.larval.food: sugar cane and other gramineae, particularly Thysanoloena maxima
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Particularly active at dawn and dusk
Author: erin.leeds
Full.Species.Account: Melanitis leda L. 1758 (CC No. 2894; DA p. 162) ssp. helena Westwood. This species is widely distributed throughout the old world tropics， being represented in Mauritius by the African subspecies helen α. It is common throughout the island， and particularly active at dawn and dusk. Manders collected a series of 155 specimens of this species from Mauritius between March 10 and December 31， 1905， exhibiting seasonal variation. The wet season forms (Dec.-June) have more prominent ocelli and lighter basal areas beneath than do the dry season 岛口ns (June-Nov小 The series is deposited in the Hope Collec

The species is abundant in high forest on the granitic islands where it is commonly attracted to fallen jak fruit (Artocarpus heterophyllus). Least Concern. Elsewhere feeds on Gramineae (Brachiaria, Coix lacrymajobi, Digitaria, Eleusine indica, Panicum maximum, Panicum repens, Paspalum, Pennisetum purpureum, Saccharum officinarum, Setaria, Stenotaphrum) and Palmae.
