Melanitis leda ismene Fruhstorfer, 1911: 362. S. and E. Asia. Melanitis leda f. ismene: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Indochina. Melanitis leda f. palliata: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Indochina. Melanitis leda f. determinata: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924: 31. Indochina. Melanitis leda ismene f. hib. ismene: Metyae, 1957: 104. N., C. and S. Vietnam. Melanitis leda ismene f. aest. determinata: Metyae, 1957:104. N., C. and S. Vietnam. Melanitis leda palliata: Metyae, 1957: 104. N., C. and S. Vietnam. Melanitis leda: Anonymous, 1981: 223; ii, iv-vii, x-xii, N. Vietnam (Bac Thai, Ha Bac, Ha Tay, Hai Hung, Quang Ninh, Son La, Tuyen Quang, Vinh Phu, Nghia Lo); C. Vietnam (Nghe An, Quang Tri). Melanitis leda leda: Ikeda et al., 1999: 53, figs. 4/1 - [Female] (Up); 4/2 [Female] (Un), 9/16 ([Male]genitalia). N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Melanitis leda leda: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 16. N., C. and S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. The nominate ssp. has synonyms as follows: mycena, Stoll, 1782; dsf - ismene Cramer, 1775; wsf - determinata Butler, 1885. RANGE. The geographical range extends from Africa to Australia; the nominate subspecies is distributed in Sri Lanka, India, Burma, Andaman and Nicobar Islands, Indochina, S. China, Taiwan, the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra, Borneo, Palawan and the Philippines. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. This is one of the most common species in the whole of Vietnam. The sexes of both seasonal forms are similar. The very variable Un of the dsf resembles leaf litter. Length of FW: [Male][Female] 35-40mm. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. This species flies throughout the year in all suitable habitats, but mainly at low elevations. The butterflies are usually active before and after sunset, flying swiftly and erratically towards bright lights (such as those of houses). During the dry season the adults may be rather frequent in woodland clearings. The larvae feed on different Poaceae (.Apluda mutica, Capillipedium parviflorum, Digitaria cruciata, Microstegium ciliatum, Rottboellia cochinchinesis) (Bascombe et al., 1999). Aoki et al. (1982) mention other authors who have listed such foodplants as Saccharum officinarum, Elephantopus scaber, Imperata sp., Paspalum sp., Stenotaphrum secundatum (all Poaceae) and also rice (Oryza sativa). SIMILAR SPECIES. M. zitenius is larger in size and has reddish brown UpF. M. phedima has unmarked blackish brown Up of both wings; female is much paler.

Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: Evening Brown Melanitis leda solandra Fabricius, 1775 Papilio solandra F a b ric iu s ,1775, Systema Entomologiae, 500, TL: Tahiti Range: M. leda is a w id e sp re a d species, occurring from tropical A frica e a stw ards through India and sou th-e a st A sia to A ustralia, N ew G uinea and the P acific islands, including the S olom ons, N ew C aledonia, V anuatu, Fiji, Tahiti and Sam oa. M. I. solandra is found in N ew C aledonia, the N ew H ebrides A rchipelago, Fiji, Tonga, the C ook and S ociety Islands. A d u lt c h a ra c te ris tic s : A large satyrine butterfly, w ith an a n g ular w ing shape including a stubby hindw ing 'tail'. The m ale has subdued orange subapical m arkings and a large, irregular ocellus enclosing, usually, tw o w hite spots. The underside is cryptic, w ith an arra n g e m e n t o f fine brow n m arkings and postm edian ocelli that resem ble a dead leaf w hen the butterfly is at rest. The fem ale is larger, w ith m ore extensive and pronounced upperside m arkings. E lsew here in its range, the b u tterfly is stron g ly se a sonally dim orphic: da rke r w ith w ell developed ocelli in the dry season, and highly cryptic w ith less pro m in e n t or vestigial ocelli in the w et season. Such variation appears lim ited in V anuatu. Similar species: T he a n g u la r w ing shape and underside m arkings o f M. leda are unlike any o ther V anuatu butterfly. Flight/Habitat: A lthough this is a com m on and w idespread butterfly, its crep u scu la r flight and habit o f resting in thick undergrow th during the heat o f the day results in adults being infrequently seen unless disturbed. T hey seldom fly fa r before resting again, but are very d ifficu lt to approach. A dults becom e active late in the afternoon and at dusk, w hen they fly sw iftly along fo rest tracks. T hey are also active early in the m orning. O ccasionally attracted to house lights, and also to rotting fruit (e.g. overripe bananas). Distribution: R eported from Vanua Lava, M ere Lava, E spiritu Santo, A m bae, M aew o, P entecost, M alakula, A m brym , Paam a, Epi, E fate, E rrom ango, Tanna, Futuna and A neityum . Host-plants: Various grasses have been reported as host-plants fo r this species, including Phragmites karka (P oaceae). In Fiji Brachiaria mutica (P oaceae), Panicum maximum (P oaceae), Saccharum edule (P oaceae), S. officinarum (R obinson, 1975).

Book: Butterflies of Micronesia
Common.name: Evening brown
Distribution.Range: Marianas, Carolines; Range: Tropical Africa to the Bismarck Archipelago
Abundance: sometimes common enough to be considered pests
Flight.characteristics: low flying butterflies
Hostplant.larval.food: The larvae feed on various species of grasses. On Guam we have found them on corn, Guinea grass and Napier grass. They also feed on rice, and are sometimes common enough to be considered pests
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: active primarily at dawn and at dusk
Adult.forms: Marianas specimens have brighter eye spots than those from the Caroline Islands
Author: Sam.Lopez
Full.Species.Account: Satyridae Melanitis leda (L.) Plate 7 Marianas, Carolines Evening brown. Range: Tropical Africa to the Bismarck Archipelago. The larvae feed on various species of grasses. On Guam we have found them on corn, Guinea grass and Napier grass. They also feed on rice, and are sometimes common enough to be considered pests. The larvae are green with two black hair tufts on their head that look like horns. The low flying butterflies are active primarily at dawn and at dusk. Marianas specimens have brighter eye spots than those from the Caroline Islands

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 1: Satyrinae
Habitat: Melanitis leda... is often found near human habitation... they are inhabitants of primary and secondary forest at different elevations
Hostplant.larval.food: Melanitis leda may damage rice crops... monocotyledonous plants
Adult.forms: Species are characterized by seasonal variation
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Genus Melanitis Fabricius, 1807 Mag. f. Insektenk. (Uliger) 6: 282 Type-species: Papilio leda Linnaeus, 1758 This genus is characterized by rather reduced male forelegs and the slightly clubbed female foretarsus (Figure 1C). Bifid claws are characteristic of this genus and serve to distinguish it from all other local satyrids (Figure1F). There are three species in Vietnam. All are of medium size with wings a dark brown and black ground colour. Species are characterized by seasonal variation. They are inhabitants of primary and secondary forest at different elevations feeding on monocotyledonous plants. Melanitis leda may damage rice crops and is often found near human habitation. Key to the species of the genus Melanitis 1(4) Up with reddish tinge; large species. 2(3) Male Up dark reddish brown with FW almost unicolour; female UpF with an oblique, suffused orange subapical band M. zitenius (wsf) 3 Male has a black patch in space 3 and 4 with the white spot in space 3 near the outer edge; female has bear the same black patch as male. M. zitenius (dsf) 4 Up without reddish tinge; size smaller. 5(8) Un of both wings with more or less prominent yellow ringed ocelli 6(7) Male Up is blackish brown and FW is unmarked, female FW with an obscure black spot, as well as bearing a diffuse white dot in space 4. M. phedima (wsf) 7 Up of both sexes is pale brown; FW with blackish patch in space 3 with white spot is only a little off centre; Un has six ocelli on HW. M. leda (wsf) 8 Ocelli on Un of both wings are absent or reduced to dots; butterflies much more caudate, FW more falcate. 9(10) In the male both wings Up ground colour is blackish brown; female FW paler brown and the black patch in space 3 surrounded by orange colour; the white pupil is off centre M. phedima (dsf) 10 Both sexes are of pale brown ground colour; the white pupil is nearly in the centre of the black patch in space 3 and surrounded by an orange area. M. leda (dsf)

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 1: Satyrinae
Habitat: can usually be found in secondary growth, countryside and urban gardens and parks
Hostplant.larval.food: an occasional pest of rice
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: HABITATS Species of this subfamily can be found in any vegetative habitats of Vietnam from the shoreline to the highest peaks of montane areas. Basically all Satyrinae can be divided into lowland and montane species. For example, the majority of Mycalesini are lowland species while most Lethini are high montane inhabitants. Many tropical species, as with species of temperate zones, prefer open areas, while many other species prefer shady undergrowth within forested habitats. A great number of Satyrinae species may be recorded in the tropical forest sub-canopy. Butterflies fly very close to the ground, often sitting either on the ground surface or on the leaves of herbs and shrubs. They often visit sunlit forest paths and trails. Many have a swift, short-lived flight when disturbed during the day and settle quickly with wings closed in near-by foliage. The majority of satyrids can be recorded in the vicinity of their foodplants which belong to monocotyledonous families such as Poaceae (grasses) and Arecaceae (palms). More information concerning habitats is in the relevant text for individual taxa. Such species as Melanitis leda, Elymnias hypermnestra, Ypthima baldus and some Mycalesis species can usually be found in secondary growth, countryside and urban gardens and parks. The males are distinctly territorial and patrol an area for mating. LIFE CYCLE The eggs are rather variable in shape but generally spherical and whitish or greenish in colour. The egg surface is usually smooth or faintly sculptured. Eggs are laid singly or in egg-masses. The majority of satyrid ovipositing activity occurs in the evening. Larvae (caterpillars) of the Satyridae have the head bifid often with a pair of long straight processes or “horns”, and the anal segment has a pair of posteriorly directed processes; the prothorax is constricted. They are usually green, yellow or brown in colour with some linear markings. Larvae of the majority of satyrins feed on monocotyledon plant species belonging to the Poaceae family. A number of species feed on different species of bamboo. Representatives of the genera Elymnias and Coelites feed on palm species (Arecaceae), growing in both forest habitats and cultivated areas. The species belonging to the Ragadia family feed on ferns belonging to the genus Selaginella. Caterpillars usually feed at night and rest lengthwise on the underside of the leaves during the day but some species move down the plant to rest near the ground. Larvae are usually sluggish and often slow-growing and usually remain motionless when disturbed. Some species are agricultural crop pests, for example, Melanitis leda is an occasional pest of rice. The pupae are usually smooth and green with or without yellow, reddish or woody brown markings and with a pair of variable, developed, cephalic horns. Adults of some genera are active throughout the day (e.g. Ypthima, Callerebia, Neope) and can be recorded in grassland, forest trails and mountain tops. However, the majority of Satyrinae are active at dawn and dusk; they are weak flyers and prefer shaded places in different types of forest

Full.Species.Account: Common  Evening  Brown Melanitis leda  58-75 mm A   large,  elegant  butterfly. Wings  are  beautifully  shaped with  points  on   both  the  fore- and  hind  wings.  The  upper sides  are  brown  with  a   large orange  patch  surrounding  a   black  spot  with white  dots.  The  undersides  display  leaf-like camouflage.  Patterns  and  wing  shapes vary  seasonally.  Sexes  are  similar. HABITS  &   HABITAT:  Common  and  widespread in   East  Africa,  including  in   plantations  of maize  or  sugar  cane.  Shy  and  retiring, this  butterfly  remains  hidden  in   the undergrowth  and  leaf  litter,  flying  only when  startled,  otherwise  active  at  dusk. Caterpillars  feed  on  various  grasses, including  Setaria spp.  (Poaceae),  and  on crops  such  as  rice  and  sugar  cane.

Book: Butterflies of the Bulolo-Wau Valley
Distribution.Range: India...PNG
Hostplant.larval.food: M. leda larvae are a recorded pest of rice in India (e.g. Amn Singh, 1979), and Li (1985a, 1985b) similarly recorded M. leda as a pest of rice
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus MELANITIS Fabricius, 1807 This genus contains 13 species and ranges through the Afrotropical Region, including much of Africa, Madagascar and Mauritius, and throughout the Indo-Australian Region. It was the subject of a revision by Fruhstorfer (1908c) who included monochrome photographic plates of the male genitalia of some species. There are 3 species in NG, 2 of which also occur in Australia. The type species for Melanitis is leda (Linnaeus, 1758), designated by Butler, 1868. Miller (1968) listed Cyllo Boisduval, 1832, as a synonym of the genus. Melanitis are large species for their subfamily and are somewhat sexually dimorphic. Their undersides are very cryptically coloured and mottled with dark brown, the butterflies being perfectly camouflaged when resting on leaf litter. The mottling and size of the eye-spots of some species are often very variable. The crypsis of many species is enhanced by their irregular wing shape, some having markedly falcate forewings, and most with hindwing vein M3 produced into a short triangular ‘tail’. Bingham (1905) pointed out that, in India, Melanitis species have wet and dry season forms which are, respectively, well ocellated with numerous short striae underside, or poorly striated with the eye-spots often reduced to mere specks. Nevertheless, he noted that both forms also occur together and that many different hues of the underside ground colours occur. The Melanitis eye is smooth and the antenna is a little over two-fifths the length of the forewing costa. Miller (1968: 35, fig. 34) illustrated the venation of M. leda, and details of the labial palpus and legs (Miller, 1968: figs 35-39). The labial palpus apical segment is short, being only one-fourth the length of the second. The mid-tibia is unspined dorsally, although spines are present laterally. The tarsal claws of the hind leg are each bifid. The forewing cell is three-fifths the length of the costa and the forewing main veins are exceptional as, unlike other Satyrinae in PNG, none of them is basally inflated. The male genitalia are very simple, the uncus being beak-like and lacking a gnathos. The tegumen ring is broad, ending in a large elongate saccus, and the valva is simple and elongate, the inner lamina densely hirsute. The aedeagus is simple, tubular, but slightly tapers towards the apex, and the ductus enters distally so that there is no coecum. De Vries et al. (1985: 17) stated that Melanitis is certainly not closely related to Antirrhea Hubner, 1822, and Caerois, Htibner, 1819, as Miller (1968) had concluded. In fact, the latter 2 genera were shown to belong to the Morphinae, not Satyrinae as was traditionally believed. The authors observed that Melanitis and its allies are devoid of abdominal androconia and suggested that the genus is probably part of an Old World group that could well be related to Elymnias, Charaxes and Agrias. Corbet and Pendlebury (1978) pointed out that Cyllo genes Butler, 1868, an Indo-Burmese and Bornean genus, is closely related to Melanitis. Melanitis are all lowland species of the forest margin. The adults are all extremely crepuscular and become most active towards dusk, avoiding flight in sunlight unless disturbed, when they will dart off but quickly settle only a few metres away. They remain very inactive during the day, usually camouflaged amongst the leaf litter of the forest floor. They are sometimes also found in somewhat moister areas in the shade of steep creek banks. Adults favour rotting fruits as a food source and they also visit sap seepages. At dusk the males apparently occupy territories, or home ranges, and fly to investigate anything that moves within their immediate vicinity (e.g. see M. amabilis. Habits). Melanitis early stages are well recorded. The larvae feed exclusively on various grasses (Poaceae). M. leda larvae are a recorded pest of rice in India (e.g. Amn Singh, 1979), and Li (1985a, 1985b) similarly recorded M. leda as a pest of rice, and M. constantia as a pest of sugar cane, in PNG.

Abundance: common species in various habitats
Flight.characteristics: fly rapidly, mainly at dusk
Habitat: in various habitats

Daily.or.circadian.patterns: fly mainly at dusk, when disturbed during the day they fly off a short distance into nearby vegatation

Author: erin.leeds
Full.Species.Account: Common evening brown Melanitis leda Linne, 1758 (658) Wingspan 73 mm, a large, common species in various habitats. Underside highly variable with season. They fly rapidly, mainly at dusk. When disturbed during the day they fly off a short distance into nearby vegetation. This species is similar to the next and can be best differentiated by the relative postions of the white spots on the forewing . In M. leda the lower spot is immediately below the upper, whereas in M. libya they are offset. They are also surrounded by red, which tends not to be the case in M. libya. Sexes similar, larvae feed on grasses.

Book: Butterflies of Saudi Arabia and its neighbours
Distribution.Range: widely distributed in the Afrotropical, Oriental and even Australasian Regions
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Palaeotropical distribution patterns. The species found in both Africa and Asia fall into two main groups. One consists of species widely distributed in the Afrotropical, Oriental and even Australasian Regions. Typical examples are: Eurema hecabe, E. brigitta, L. boeticus, Z. hylax, D. chrysippus, Junonia orithya, Hypolimnas misippus, P. phalantha, Melanitis leda and Pelopidas mathias. The other group consists of species which are widely distributed in Africa, but which in Asia are basically restricted to the Indian subcontinent and Indochina. Most species are probably of Afrotropical origin, but it cannot be determined for certain. The species are: Anaphaeis aurota, Catopsiha florella, Junonia hierta, Byblia ilithyia, Ypthima asterope, Gomalia elma and Pelopidas thrax. Some species of Colotis found in Asia have been left out since they are obviously Afrotropical elements which have managed to establish themselves in the dry parts of the Indian subcontinent. Many of the species are strongly migratory and widely distributed in Arabia.

Hostplant.larval.food: Various reports—Sepp (1824-48) described a fluffy white caterpillar (as nigrocinctus) on Paullinia pinata (Sapindaceae) from Surinam. This description was repeated by Kaye (1921) from Trinidad (as phareus). In Panama I found a caterpillar feeding on a sapling of Inga sp. (Fabaceae). Together this information suggests at least three interpretations: both Sapindaceae and Fabaceae are used as hostplants, the plants have been misidentified, and/or there are two species of butterflies...The caterpillar grazes the epidermis of old leaves.
Adult.food: Both sexes visit flowers of various Asteraceae.

[P]: Quepos (February, July, September), Sirena (January, March, July), Rio Catarata (September). [L]: Guapiles (June), Tuis (June). [G]: Taboga (September).

Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Mesene phareus rubella Bates, 1865 FW length: 13-14 mm Plate 13 Range: Mexico to Brazil, Peru. Subspecies: Guatemala to Colombia Hostplant: Various reports—Sepp (1824-48) described a fluffy white caterpillar (as nigrocinctus) on Paullinia pinata (Sapindaceae) from Surinam. This description was repeated by Kaye (1921) from Trinidad (as phareus). In Panama I found a caterpillar feeding on a sapling of Inga sp. (Fabaceae). Together this information suggests at least three interpretations: both Sapindaceae and Fabaceae are used as hostplants, the plants have been misidentified, and/or there are two species of butterflies. Early stages (Fig. 48a): Mature caterpillar—pale green, flattened with segments produced in lateral lobes; overall with a sparse covering of white setae, and a conspicuous crest of very long white dorsal setae. The caterpillar grazes the epidermis of old leaves. Pupa—light brown, flattened ventrally; entire body has a marked dorsal ridge that gives the pupa the impression of being almost triangular in cross-section; a dorsal ridge with a row of long dor sal setae, and abdomen with flattened lateral lobes. • Adult: Sexes dimorphic. Male—upperside crimson, FW costa and both margins evenly black, two or three small black bars intrude into the FW cell from the costa, and abdomen crimson; underside with the FW entirely dusty black, HW crimson with dusty-black costa and margins, and abdomen black. Female—upperside entirely crimson with thin black FW costa and wing margins; underside similar, with a small black bar that intrudes into the FW cell from the costa. Compare with mygdon. Habits: This butterfly has been recorded in our area from sea level to 700 m on both slopes in association with rain forest habitats. Typically encountered as uncommon, solitary individuals flying along forest edges, rivers, and in light gaps between 12:30 and 16:00 hrs. Their flight is slow, fluttery, and generally unidirectional. In Panama, G. Small found the males perching between 14:00 and 16:00 hrs. Both sexes visit flowers of various Asteraceae. Localities: [A]: Poco Sol (February), Cariblanco. [SJ]: Carrillo. [H]: La Selva (May), Magsaysay (August), Plastico (July, August). [P]: Quepos (February, July, September), Sirena (January, March, July), Rio Catarata (September). [L]: Guapiles (June), Tuis (June). [G]: Taboga (September).

Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Mesosemia lamachus Hewitson, 1857 FW length: 17.5-18 mm Plate 5 Range: Mexico to Colombia Hostplant: Psychotria sp. (Rubiaceae) Early stages: Egg—white, deposited singly on the underside of leaves or in the axils of new leaves. • Adult: Sexes dimorphic. Male—FW upperside brown with a light brown postmedial band that runs from the costa straight to the inner margin, and with purplish blue along base and basal half of inner margin; HW upperside brown with a purple-blue iridescence across most of wing, a thin brown medial line, a broad brown postmedial line, a thin brown submarginal line, and a brown distal margin set with isolated blue spots; underside brown with the medial area encompassing the eyespots on both wings, and this area is not filled with filigree patterns. Female—upperside simi lar to male, but with paler blue, brown lines on the HW more distinct, and FW7 with a redbrown postmedial band. Compare with telegone, carissima. Habits: This butterfly occurs commonly, but lo cally from sea level to 800 m in association with primary and secondary rain forest on both slopes. Encountered as solitary individ uals flying in shady understory from 09:00 to 12:30 hrs. The same perching areas may be used by successive males through time. Fe males oviposit from 11:30 to 12:30 hrs in shady understory. Localities: [A]: Pando Azúcar 2.5 km N of Rio Grande (August). [C]: Juan Viñas (November), Turrialba (June, August), Colombiana. [H]: La Selva (April, August). [P]: San Vito (May). [L]: Hitoy Cerere (October), Tortuguerro (August), Guapiles.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Round-Winged Vagrant
Distribution.Range: The Round-Winged Vagrant has been found in Sierra Leone (apparently uncommon), coastal and northeastern Guinea (TL), Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Volta, Togo, Bénin, southern Nigeria, and the Cross River loop. I found it in Korup as well. It is a fairly common forest butterfly and may on occasions even penetrate the savannahs through riverine vegetation (e.g. Bui National Park in Ghana). The nominate subspecies occurs from Sierra Leone to Nigeria, and across the equatorial zone to Cameroun, Congo, Angola, Central African Republic, much of the DRC, and Uganda.
Abundance: Apparently uncommon in Sierra Leone. It is a fairly common forest butterfly.
Flight.characteristics: It usually stays low within forests, often looking more like a Leptosia than a Nepheronia, visiting low flowers in their company. The species is rarely seen more than a few metres from the forest floor, in contrast to the two forest species, which regularly stray up into the canopy.
Habitat: It is a fairly common forest butterfly and may on occasions even penetrate the savannahs through riverine vegetation (e.g. Bui National Park in Ghana).
Adult.food: It usually stays low within forests, often looking more like a Leptosia than a Nepheronia, visiting low flowers in their company.

Book: Butterflies of Costa Rica Volume 2: Riodinidae
Distribution.Range: Range: Honduras to Panama However, I collected an ovipositing female from the mountain pass between Volcan Miravalles and Volcan Santa Maria, suggesting that the butterfly crosses to the Pacific slope in appropriately moist habitats. Localities: [A]: San Gabriel Dos Rios (May), Grecia (December), Cariblanco (March-July, September, October). [C]: Tapanti (November), Juan Viñas (January); Cachi (February, March), Moravia de Chirripo (February, April), Turrialba (March, May, June), Rio Chitaria (March). [SJ]: Carrillo (February, May, September). [H]: La Selva (February, March), Tirimbina (September). [L]: Guapiles (March, May, September).
Abundance: Encountered as solitary individuals
Habitat: mainly on the Atlantic slope in association with rain and wet forests...along forest edges, gaps, or deep in the forest...Typically the butterflies fly less than 3 m above the ground, but they may occasionally ascend into the subcanopy along forest edges.
Oviposition: Egg—white, lozenge shaped, laid in small clusters of five to ten on new shoots and stems...An individual female may oviposit many eggs on the same new shoot after resting between oviposition bouts.
Hostplant.larval.food: Hostplant: Inga spp. (Fabaceae), Cassia fruticosa (Fabaceae), Heteropteris sp. (Malpighiaceae)
Adult.food: Both sexes visit flowers of Psychotria, Croton, and herbaceous Asteraceae.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Localities: [A]: San Gabriel Dos Rios (May), Grecia (December), Cariblanco (March-July, September, October). [C]: Tapanti (November), Juan Viñas (January); Cachi (February, March), Moravia de Chirripo (February, April), Turrialba (March, May, June), Rio Chitaria (March). [SJ]: Carrillo (February, May, September). [H]: La Selva (February, March), Tirimbina (September). [L]: Guapiles (March, May, September).
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Encountered as solitary individuals from 10:00 to 13:00 hrs along forest edges, gaps, or deep in the forest. In Panama, G. Small found males perching between 15:30 and 17:00 hrs.
Adult.forms: Sexes similar
Ant.associations: The caterpillars do not produce a call, even though they have vibratory papillae. Associated with Pheidole and Solenopsis ants.
Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Nymphidium onaeum Hewitson, 1869 FW length: 15-20.5 mm Plate 22 Range: Honduras to Panama Hostplant: Inga spp. (Fabaceae), Cassia fruticosa (Fabaceae), Heteropteris sp. (Malpighiaceae) Early stages (Fig. 58b): Egg—white, lozenge shaped, laid in small clusters of five to ten on new shoots and stems. Mature caterpillar—very similar to that of ascolia except often with a brownish green cast to body and indistinct bands on either side of dorsal midline. The caterpillars do not produce a call, even though they have vibratory papillae. Associated with Pheidole and Solenopsis ants. • Adult: Sexes similar. Upperside white area on the FW distinctly triangular, and broadly bor dered with dark brown along costa and distal margin; FW often with two short red bands in cell, and a short, red submarginal band in FW tomus (red may be absent in specimens to the south); HW broadly white with dark brown dis tal margins; HW always with short, red sub marginal band in tomus. Note: This taxon has been referred to in older literature as a sub species of chione Bates, 1867. Compare with azanoides, ascolia, Juditha molpe, Pixus corculum. Habits: In our area this butterfly has been recorded from sea level to 1000 m mainly on the Atlantic slope in association with rain and wet forests. However, I collected an ovipositing female from the mountain pass between Volcan Miravalles and Volcan Santa Maria, suggesting that the butterfly crosses to the Pacific slope in appropriately moist habitats. Encountered as solitary individuals from 10:00 to 13:00 hrs along forest edges, gaps, or deep in the forest. In Panama, G. Small found males perching between 15:30 and 17:00 hrs. Typically the butterflies fly less than 3 m above the ground, but they may occasionally ascend into the subcanopy along forest edges. An individual female may oviposit many eggs on the same new shoot after resting between oviposition bouts. Both sexes visit flowers of Psychotria, Croton, and herbaceous Asteraceae. Localities: [A]: San Gabriel Dos Rios (May), Grecia (December), Cariblanco (March-July, September, October). [C]: Tapanti (November), Juan Viñas (January); Cachi (February, March), Moravia de Chirripo (February, April), Turrialba (March, May, June), Rio Chitaria (March). [SJ]: Carrillo (February, May, September). [H]: La Selva (February, March), Tirimbina (September). [L]: Guapiles (March, May, September).

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 1: Satyrinae
Distribution.Range: N., C. & S. Vietnam
Adult.forms: Mycalesis (Orsotriaena) medus medus f. (dsf) runeka: Fruhstorfer, 1908c: 214. Tonkin, Annam... Orsotriaena medus medus f. hesione: Metaye, 1957: 104. N. Vietnam
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Orsotriaena medus (Fabricius, 1775) Syst. Entomol. 1775: 488, no. 198 (Papilio) Plate 22, figs. 3a-c TYPE LOCALITY. Java Papilio medus Fabricius, 1775: 448. Capite Bonae Spei [recte Java] Mycalesis (Orsotriaena) medus medus f. (dsf) runeka: Fruhstorfer, 1908c: 214. Tonkin, Annam. Orsotriaena medus f. hesione: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1924:31. Annam: Muong Sen. Orsotriaena medus: Lemee, 1950: 8 Tonkin: Lang Son (Dong Dang). Orsotriaena medus medus f. hesione: Metaye, 1957: 104. N. Vietnam. Orsotriaena medus: Anonymous, 1981: 225; ii, x-xii, N. Vietnam (Ha Bac, Nghia Lo, Quang Ninh, Son La, Tuyen Quang, Hoa Binh]. Orsotriaena medus medus: Ikeda et al., 1999: 57, fig. 5: 1, 2- [Male] (Up, Un), 3- [Female] (Up). N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Orsotriaena medus medus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 18. N., C. & S. Vietnam. RANGE. From India through the Indo-Malayan Region to New Guinea and Australia. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. N. Vietnam: Muong Nhe N.R., Ba Be N.P., Na Hang N.R., Cat Ba N.P., Cue Phuong N.P. C. Vietnam: Pu Hoat N.R., Pu Mat N.R., Ba Na N.R., Song Thanh N.R., S. Vietnam: Cat Tien N.P.. Tay Ninh N.R., Nghia Trung SFE. It can be found throughout all lowland areas of Vietnam. It is a dark brown to black butterfly with a flight pattern similar to Mycaiesis. Sexes are alike but the female is slightly paler. It is subject to seasonal polymorphism. The ocelli on the wsf are more prominent and silvery. The ocelli on the dsf are much smaller. The white discal band on the Un of both wings is rather variable. Length of FW: [Male] [Female] 23-26mm. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. Ba Be N.P.: secondary vegetation in the vicinity of cultivated areas; Pu Hoat: scrub; Pu Mat: secondary forest at 200 to 1,000m. The larvae feed on grasses belonging to the Poaceae family, in particular Oryza sativa and Saccharum sp. (Chou, 1994). The species is rather common on the plains amongst grass growing under shade. SIMILAR SPECIES. Species of the genus Mycalesis which have no ocelli on the UpF, for example, M. adamsonii, M. inopia and M. deficiens, are somewhat similar. However, the adults of Orsotriaena have smooth eyes and only the subcostal vein 12 on the FW is swollen at the base.

Book: A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Vanuatu
Common.name: Smooth-eyed Bush-brown
Distribution.Range: Range: 0 . medus occurs from Sri Lanka, India, N epal, Indo-C hina and the P hilippines, through the Indonesian islands to N ew G uinea, northern A ustralia, the B ism arck and S olom ons A rchipelagos and Vanuatu.  Distribution: R eported from M ota, Espiritu Santo,  P entecost, M alakula, A m brym , Epi and Efate.
Abundance: not a com m on butterfly in V anuatu.
Hostplant.larval.food: Various grasses. In N ew G uinea Saccharum species (P oaceae) (P arsons, 1991: 171). In A ustralia fem ales laid eggs in captivity on Imperata species (P oaceae) and w ere su cce ssfully reared on Panicum maximum (P oaceae) (Johnson et a/., 1995).
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: Smooth-eyed Bush-brown Orsotriaena medus mutata Butler, 1875 Mycalesis mutata Butler, 1875, Proceedings of the Zoological Society of London, 1875 : 612, TL: Vanuatu Range: 0 . medus occurs from Sri Lanka, India, N epal, Indo-C hina and the P hilippines, through the Indonesian islands to N ew G uinea, northern A ustralia, the B ism arck and S olom ons A rchipelagos and Vanuatu. 0 . m. mutata flies in Vanuatu. Adult characteristics: S im ilar to Mycalesis perseus, above, w ith a conspicuous, clearly defined, underside m edian band. The underside o f the forew ing has tw o large postm edian ocelli w ith o u t the sm alle r additional ocelli pre se n t in m ost specim ens o f M. perseus in addition to tw o large ocelli w hich are alw ays present, the hindw ing m ay have an additional sm all ocellus but otherw ise lacks the additional ocelli usually found (variable) in M. perseus. Similar species: S up e rficia lly sim ilar to Mycalesis perseus, above. Flight/Habitat: See Mycalesis perseus, above. 0 . medus is not a com m on butterfly in V anuatu. Distribution: R eported from M ota, Espiritu Santo, P entecost, M alakula, A m brym , Epi and Efate. Host-plants: Various grasses. In N ew G uinea Saccharum species (P oaceae) (P arsons, 1991: 171). In A ustralia fem ales laid eggs in captivity on Imperata species (P oaceae) and w ere su cce ssfully reared on Panicum maximum (P oaceae) (Johnson et a/., 1995).

Ba Be N.P.: secondary vegetation in the vicinity of cultivated areas; Pu Hoat: scrub; Pu Mat: secondary forest at 200 to 1,000m. The larvae feed on grasses belonging to the Poaceae family, in particular Oryza sativa and Saccharum sp. (Chou, 1994). The species is rather common on the plains amongst grass growing under shade. SIMILAR SPECIES. Species of the genus Mycalesis which have no ocelli on the UpF, for example, M. adamsonii, M. inopia and M. deficiens, are somewhat similar. However, the adults of Orsotriaena have smooth eyes and only the subcostal vein 12 on the FW is swollen at the base.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Distribution.Range: The range includes Agege, near Lagos.
Abundance: Seen regularly in Agege, near Lagos. Quite common.
Habitat: Can fly in rich secondary growth.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Common White-Spots
Distribution.Range: The Common White-Spots is widespread in West Africa, with records from Sierra Leone, Guinea (TL), Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Volta, Togo, southern Nigeria, and the Cross River loop. It should occur also in Bénin. Lindsey & Miller (1965) comment that in Liberia it seems to be found only on the coast, but I doubt this can be so. It has been found in both the Guinea and the Côte d’Ivoire Nimba area, and I have it from as far north as Boabeng-Fiema in Ghana and Kyabobo in Volta. I caught few in the Oban Hills and never saw it in Korup. The species ranges from Sierra Leone and Guinea through Nigeria, Cameroun, Congo, Angola, Central African Republic, and the DRC, to Uganda, southern Sudan, western Kenya, and western Tanzania.
Abundance: The Common White-Spots is widespread in West Africa. Together with O. laronia, this is by far the most common member of the genus. I would estimate that at least 80% of all Osmodes randomly collected pertain to these two species. O. thora actually seems scarcer in the wettest forests. I caught few in the Oban Hills and never saw it in Korup.
Habitat: This species is better adapted to secondary habitats than most of the genus and actually seems scarcer in the wettest forests. Males perch along forest edges and paths.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Sabang
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.
