Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: N. India
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae (Fabricius, 1775) Plate 7, figs. 2a-c Syst. Ent. : 443, no 3 (Papilio) TY E LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - N. India; ssp. goniopeltis - Siam, Burma, Tenasserim. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis Rothschild, 1908, Nov. Zool. 15:167. Papilio aristolochiae f. aristolochiae (=polydorus Cramer): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Indochina. Papilio aristolochiae I. diphilus: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Indochina. Papilio aristolochiae f. asteris: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. (Than-Moi) Tonkin. Papilio aristolochiae f. goniopeltis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Cochinchine [S. Vietnam]. Papilio aristolochiae aristolochiae f. aristolochiae: Metaye, 1957: 81. N., c. & s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae aristolochiae f. diphilus: Metaye, 1957: 81. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis: Metaye, 1957: 81. s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae asteris: Metaye, 1957: 81. s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N., C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. Papilio ascanius Linnaeus, 1768 (TL: Insula Nieuw Bay; Java); p. polydorus Linnaeus, 1763 (TL: Ambon) are considered as synonyms of aristolochiae Fabricius, 1775. Such taxa as aristolochiae Fabricius, 1775 and diphilus Esper, 1792 are mentioned instead of ssp. goniopeltis Rothschild, 1908. R A N G E . The species ranges from India to c. China and from Ryukyu Is. to the Philippines; however the ssp. goniopeltis is restricted to the Andaman Islands, Burma, Thailand, Indochina, Hainan and Hong Kong. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. N. Vietnam : Hoang Lien N.P., Ba Be N.P., Tam Dao N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.p. c . Vietnam : Pu Hoat N.R., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R., Bach Ma N.P., Ba Na N.R., Kon Cha Rang N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N.R.; Nui Chua N.R., Bao Loc SFE. S.Vietnam : Poulo Condore, Pont Sur le Song Larna, Nui Ong Yem, Dinh Quan forest. Cat Tien N.P. There are no major differences between specimens from northern, central and southern populations. The specimens from N. Vietnam (Lao Cai province) are insignificantly larger in size, and have slightly longer white spots in spaces 2 ,3 ,4 and 5 of the HW. A whitish spot or dot within the cell is rather frequent; the UpH is darker and the submarginal spots redder and more distinct. Both sexes are variable in size, however the female is larger. Length of FW: [female] 47-51 mm; [male] 42-48 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The Vietnamese populations are similar to subspecies goniopeltis Rothschild, mentioned from s. & c. Vietnam (Metaye, 1957) and also noted from N. Vietnam and s. China (Bascombe et al., 1991). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. In the north of the country the species occurs from April to September. The night period in C. Vietnam was observed from January (southern sites) and March to October and November. In the south it was recorded at all times of the year. The species is found in secondary vegetation and is attracted to Bowering bushes and herbs. It nies rather slowly and low, with night conducted by the FW and using the H W for balance. The larvae feed on Aristolochia spp. (Aristolochia tagala, A. indica, A. griffithi and A.fordiana) and adults are toxic to birds. SIMILAR SPECIES. Flying species may be confused with L. coon and some Byasa and with the female of Papilio polytes, though the last species has a black abdomen.

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Malay Peninsula; [plate] C.H W.MALAYSIA
Phenology.and.voltinism: [plates] [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA; [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb. C.H W.MALAYSIA; [male] ab. arteris 1979-Mar. C.H W.MALAYSIA
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.  (Range) aristolochiae : India hostilius : Assam ceylonica : Sri Lanka adaeus : China goniopeltis : Thailand, Burma, Hong Kong, Andaman, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam asteris : Malay Peninsula camorta : Nicobar (=sawi) aphrodite: Sabang antiphus : Sumatra, Borneo, Nias, Natuna (=kameiros) adamas : Java, Engano brevicauda : Palawan, Cuyo interpositus : Formosa, Yaeyama (=rhodopis) probus: Bawean balina : Bali antissa : Kangean lombockensis : Lombok austrosundana : Sumbawa sapientia : Sumba floresiana : Flores agricola : Tanajampea  PLATE 57 1 [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA 2 [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: from Borneo
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: How to separate the Philippine Species of Pachliopta atropos In Palawan similar to aristolochiae brevicauda of the same locality. In other areas res em bles black aristolochiae lacking the white patch in the centre of the hindwing. Atropos can be distinguished by the absence of series of submarginal red spots on the hindwing and the more slender and longer tail. Besides it is unique in lacking the basal dark area of the forewing, which is always present in other Pachliopta. aristolochiae Within the Philippine area distributed only in Palawan. It is separable from kotzebuea by that it has neither red spots nor white ones on the central area of the hindwing beneath. Kotzebuea is a replacing species of aristolochiae. Palawan subspecies brevicauda closely resembles autiphus from Borneo and Sumatra, but it has shorter tail and submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath undeveloped. kotzebuea The nominate subspecies is unique in having the entirely black forewing. It lacks whitespots in the centreof the hindwing above. In some individuals whitish stripes are perceptible in the distal area of space Ion the forewing beneath, which recalls the basal dark area in typical Pachliopta. The red spots in the centre of the hindwing vary individually, some with welldeveloped ones, others obsolescent, and red or pinkish white in colour. In asina from N. Luzon the basal dark area of the forewing is clearly defined. The hindwing is black above, but in individuals with well-developed submarginal red spots, the spots appear above too. The spots in the centre of the hindwing beneath are variable, being red, pink or even white in colour. It is similar to schadenbergi but is easily separable by that kotzebuea has submarginal concolorous red spots in spaces 1-7 on the hindwing, while schadenbergi has white spots in spaces 5,6 and 7. S. Philippine philippus has white spots in the centre of the hindwing, being similar to phegeus, ley tens is and mariae, etc. The above white spots vary individually and are not available as key characters. The spots extend to spaces 5, 6 if welldeveloped, while they are limited to spaces 2-4, just as phegeus, if not developed. From other allied species it can be separated by its submarginal concolorous red spots in spaces 1-7 on the hindwing. Rarely individuals with the white cell spot on the hindwing are found, but usually the cell is unspotted. scchadenbergi It occurs together with kotzebuea asina in various areas of N. Luzon and most similar to the subspecies, but it is easily separable from others by that it lacks spots in the centre of the hindwing beneath, and it has submarginal series of spots on the hindwing well-developed and large, of which the spots in spaces 2, 3 are beautiful red and the ones in spaces 4-7 are partly white. The subspecies from E. Luzon has the submarginal area of the hindwing conspicuously whitened.  phegeus Usually lacks the white ceU spot on the hindwing. Examples from Leyte have it rarely. Separable from mariae, phlegon and leytensis by the absence of the white cell spot. Most brightly coloured among the species with submarginal red spots. Usually it has five red spots in spaces 1-5. The submarginal spots are well-developed and beautiful red. The spots become extinct or very small and white in spaces 6-7. Very similar to leytensis, but easily separable from it by the absence of the white cell spot on the hindwing and the brighter red of submarginal spots on the hindwing above. leytensis Among the three species with the spot in the hindwing cell this species has the smallest and nearly round spot. On the hindwing submarginal red spots are large in spaces 2, 3 and small in spaces 4-7. It is separable from mariae and phlegon by its whitened submarginal spots in spaces 6, 7. It is also similar to Phegeus, but its white central patch on the hindwing always extends to space 5, and submarginal spots on the hindwing are not so clearly defined as in Phegeus. It resembles mariae in having small spots in spaces 6,7, butleytensis usually lacks red spot in space 1. The spots are bright red in phegeus, paler red except the bright red one in space 1 in mariae, and large and black-dusted in spaces 2, 3 in leytensis. phlegon The white spots in the centre of the hindwing are most developed. It has the largest cell spot of the Philippine Pachliopta. The spot is usually larger than half of the cell, sometimes occupying two-thirds, with six white spots around it. The white spot in space 2 extends to the extreme base, while in phegeus, leytensis, kotzebuea and aristolochiae the base of space 2 triangularly blackened. Only two species, phlegon and muriae, have the base of space 2 white. Phlegon has the submarginal spots on the hindwing weakly developed, and is easily separable from other species by the larger white spot in space 1 on the hindwing. It occurs in two forms; one is redspotted, the other yellow-spotted. mariae The white cell spot on the hindwing is smaller than Phegeus, its size being less than one half of the cell. In the subspecies of S. Luzon and Potillo the upper angle of the white cell spot reaches the origin of vein 6, but in the nominate subspecies it usually does not reach discocellular veins. In mariae, as in Phlegon, the white spot in space 2 extends to the base of the space. Usually five white spots encircle the cell. Subspecies from S. Luzon and Polillo have the weakly developed white spot in space 1, and usually four white spots encircle the cell. This species has black hairs on the clypeus of the head, being instantly separable from other species with red or yellow hairs on it.

Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.  (Range) aristolochiae : India hostilius : Assam ceylonica : Sri Lanka adaeus : China goniopeltis : Thailand, Burma, Hong Kong, Andaman, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam asteris : Malay Peninsula camorta : Nicobar (=sawi) aphrodite: Sabang antiphus : Sumatra, Borneo, Nias, Natuna (=kameiros) adamas : Java, Engano brevicauda : Palawan, Cuyo interpositus : Formosa, Yaeyama (=rhodopis) probus: Bawean balina : Bali antissa : Kangean lombockensis : Lombok austrosundana : Sumbawa sapientia : Sumba floresiana : Flores agricola : Tanajampea  PLATE 57 1 [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA 2 [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.  (Range) aristolochiae : India hostilius : Assam ceylonica : Sri Lanka adaeus : China goniopeltis : Thailand, Burma, Hong Kong, Andaman, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam asteris : Malay Peninsula camorta : Nicobar (=sawi) aphrodite: Sabang antiphus : Sumatra, Borneo, Nias, Natuna (=kameiros) adamas : Java, Engano brevicauda : Palawan, Cuyo interpositus : Formosa, Yaeyama (=rhodopis) probus: Bawean balina : Bali antissa : Kangean lombockensis : Lombok austrosundana : Sumbawa sapientia : Sumba floresiana : Flores agricola : Tanajampea  PLATE 57 1 [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA 2 [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.  (Range) aristolochiae : India hostilius : Assam ceylonica : Sri Lanka adaeus : China goniopeltis : Thailand, Burma, Hong Kong, Andaman, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam asteris : Malay Peninsula camorta : Nicobar (=sawi) aphrodite: Sabang antiphus : Sumatra, Borneo, Nias, Natuna (=kameiros) adamas : Java, Engano brevicauda : Palawan, Cuyo interpositus : Formosa, Yaeyama (=rhodopis) probus: Bawean balina : Bali antissa : Kangean lombockensis : Lombok austrosundana : Sumbawa sapientia : Sumba floresiana : Flores agricola : Tanajampea  PLATE 57 1 [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA 2 [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb.
