Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: restricted to the Andaman Islands, Burma, Thailand, Indochina, Hainan and Hong Kong... The Vietnamese populations are similar to subspecies goniopeltis Rothschild, mentioned from S. & C. Vietnam (Metaye, 1957) and also noted from N. Vietnam and s. China (Bascombe et al., 1991).
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae (Fabricius, 1775) Plate 7, figs. 2a-c Syst. Ent. : 443, no 3 (Papilio) TY E LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - N. India; ssp. goniopeltis - Siam, Burma, Tenasserim. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis Rothschild, 1908, Nov. Zool. 15:167. Papilio aristolochiae f. aristolochiae (=polydorus Cramer): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Indochina. Papilio aristolochiae I. diphilus: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Indochina. Papilio aristolochiae f. asteris: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. (Than-Moi) Tonkin. Papilio aristolochiae f. goniopeltis: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 9. Cochinchine [S. Vietnam]. Papilio aristolochiae aristolochiae f. aristolochiae: Metaye, 1957: 81. N., c. & s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae aristolochiae f. diphilus: Metaye, 1957: 81. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis: Metaye, 1957: 81. s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae asteris: Metaye, 1957: 81. s. Vietnam. Papilio aristolochiae goniopeltis: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N., C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. Papilio ascanius Linnaeus, 1768 (TL: Insula Nieuw Bay; Java); p. polydorus Linnaeus, 1763 (TL: Ambon) are considered as synonyms of aristolochiae Fabricius, 1775. Such taxa as aristolochiae Fabricius, 1775 and diphilus Esper, 1792 are mentioned instead of ssp. goniopeltis Rothschild, 1908. R A N G E . The species ranges from India to c. China and from Ryukyu Is. to the Philippines; however the ssp. goniopeltis is restricted to the Andaman Islands, Burma, Thailand, Indochina, Hainan and Hong Kong. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. N. Vietnam : Hoang Lien N.P., Ba Be N.P., Tam Dao N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.p. c . Vietnam : Pu Hoat N.R., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R., Bach Ma N.P., Ba Na N.R., Kon Cha Rang N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N.R.; Nui Chua N.R., Bao Loc SFE. S.Vietnam : Poulo Condore, Pont Sur le Song Larna, Nui Ong Yem, Dinh Quan forest. Cat Tien N.P. There are no major differences between specimens from northern, central and southern populations. The specimens from N. Vietnam (Lao Cai province) are insignificantly larger in size, and have slightly longer white spots in spaces 2 ,3 ,4 and 5 of the HW. A whitish spot or dot within the cell is rather frequent; the UpH is darker and the submarginal spots redder and more distinct. Both sexes are variable in size, however the female is larger. Length of FW: [female] 47-51 mm; [male] 42-48 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES. The Vietnamese populations are similar to subspecies goniopeltis Rothschild, mentioned from s. & c. Vietnam (Metaye, 1957) and also noted from N. Vietnam and s. China (Bascombe et al., 1991). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. In the north of the country the species occurs from April to September. The night period in C. Vietnam was observed from January (southern sites) and March to October and November. In the south it was recorded at all times of the year. The species is found in secondary vegetation and is attracted to Bowering bushes and herbs. It nies rather slowly and low, with night conducted by the FW and using the H W for balance. The larvae feed on Aristolochia spp. (Aristolochia tagala, A. indica, A. griffithi and A.fordiana) and adults are toxic to birds. SIMILAR SPECIES. Flying species may be confused with L. coon and some Byasa and with the female of Papilio polytes, though the last species has a black abdomen.

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Assam
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer.  (Range) aristolochiae : India hostilius : Assam ceylonica : Sri Lanka adaeus : China goniopeltis : Thailand, Burma, Hong Kong, Andaman, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam asteris : Malay Peninsula camorta : Nicobar (=sawi) aphrodite: Sabang antiphus : Sumatra, Borneo, Nias, Natuna (=kameiros) adamas : Java, Engano brevicauda : Palawan, Cuyo interpositus : Formosa, Yaeyama (=rhodopis) probus: Bawean balina : Bali antissa : Kangean lombockensis : Lombok austrosundana : Sumbawa sapientia : Sumba floresiana : Flores agricola : Tanajampea  PLATE 57 1 [male] asteris C.H W.MALAYSIA 2 [male] ab. asteris 1979-Feb. Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands
Flight.characteristics: Butterflies fly slow
Habitat: They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards
Hostplant.larval.food: Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants
Adult.food: Butterflies... visit many kinds of flowers... Rarely they are found to suck water
Adult.forms: The species being favoured with geographic variation
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pachliopta aristolochiae Fabricius (Original Description) antiphus Fabricius, Ent. Syst., 3:1, p.10, n.28 (1793) adamas Zinken, Nov. Act. Ac. Nat. Cur. 15, p.144, n.3 (1831) camorta Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc., p.592 (1877) brevicauda Staudinger, D. E. Z. Iris, 2, p.10 (1889) goniopeltis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249 (1895) austrosundana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.249~250 (1895) lombockensis Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 3, p.322 Septemb. (1896) balina Fruhstorfer, Ent. Zeitschr. Stuttg., 22, p.72 (1908) antissa Jordan in. Seitz, Gross-Shmett. Erde, 9, p.39 (1908) floresiana Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 15, p.167 (1908) asteris Rothschild, Nov. Zool, 15, p.167 (1908) probus Fruhstorfer, Ent. _Rundsch., 28, p.178 (1911) aphrodite Kalis, Tijdschr. Ent. 76, p.74 (1933) sapientia ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) agricola ssp. nov. (Tsukada call.) [Notes] This species is a member of the Aristolochiae group, in which kotzebuea, polyphontes and polydorus are also included. It is widely distributed from India to Formosa and southward to the Lesser Sunda Islands. The species being favoured with geographic variation, twenty subspecies are known up to now. Besides, it shows considerable individual variation, and in some subspecies two forms, namely, the form with red-spotted wing and red body, and the form with yellow-spotted wing and yellow body, occur together. In many localities it serves as a model of the female of P. polytes. We figure twelve subspecies out of the fifteen occurring in the area here dealt with. Camorta from Nicobar, aphrodite from Sabang and antissa from Kangean were not available and not figured in this book. Almost in the center of its range, there lies the range of the black aristolochiae which lacks the central white patch on the hindwing. It occupies considerable area covering Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra, Nias, etc. No white-patched form has been known from the above districts, but in Java and Bali, the black forms are mixed in the white-patched forms. Usually the white-patched group of a ristolochiae is abundant in sunny grassland or open forest in lowland, while the black group is nowhere numerous and hardly considered as prosperous though it selects the same environment in lowland as its habitat. Among the black aristolochiae the one with curious tails is brevicauda of Palawan. Brevicauda is a name of a form meaning 'short tailed', but in this book we adopted it as the subspecific name on the grounds that by this shape of the tail the examples from Palawan could be clearly separable from others. In Palawan, the proportion of the long-tailed form to the short tailed one varies according to season, but short-tailed forms (PLATE 57-8, 9, 10; PLATE61-5) are predominant. Such a form does not occur elsewhere in aristolochiae. Butterflies in flight are sometimes mistaken for black semperi. In Palawan they hardly frequent primeval forest, usually living on grasslands along forest edges. In the Malay Peninsula the white-patched asteris is distributed. It has the longer wings and more slender tail than continental goniopeltis, and usually has the broader black stripes along veins 4, 5 on the hindwing above. It is common in lowlands. Examples figured in PLATE 57-2, 3 are melanic aberrations. 57-2 has only faint spots on the underside; 57-3 is a unique form almost lacking series of submarginal red spots and also white spot in space 1c, while it has clearly defined white spots in spaces 2, 3 and 4. The individuals with the obsolescent submarginal red spots are numerous in brevicauda in Palawan, the melanic form as figured in PLATE 61-5 being not so rare. The extremely darkened examples as may be mistaken for atropos, the one of which is figured in PLATE 61-6, are rare and treated as the aberrant form. In Palawan the species, together with P. a cropos and A. semperi, tends to be darkened, the phenomenon sometimes being called insular melanism. It is of much interest that the black aristolochiae subspecies, such as antiphus and agricola, are widely distributed ranging from Borneo to Tanajampea. In Selayar, the nearest island just north of Tanajampea, there occurs polyphontes, the separate species, and in Flores, south of it, the peculiar white-patched subspecies occurs. The example from Tanajampea is here separated as ssp. agricola as it has differently shaped submarginal red spots on the hindwing beneath. The comparative study of the submarginal red spots of black aristolochiae subspecies reveals that they are large, rectangular but slightly rounded in Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, small and rounded as usual in Lesser Sunda in lombokensis from Lombok and very slender, particularly in the female which has them crescent-shaped, in agricola from Tanajampea. The white-patched aristolochiae similar to the Continental form is distributed in Java, Bawean and Kangean. Examples from Bawean are similar to those from Java though we have few of them. A fine melanic aberration with the white spots obsolescent above is figured in PLATE 58-6. As in this case there seems to remain some melanic factor in Java. In the Lesser Sunda Islands from Bali and eastwards, the species has the red (yellow) spots on the hindwing beneath small and rounded. Balina from Bali is most variable in the indication of white spots probably as the island lies between Java and Lomook, changing from the one similar to Javan adamas to the one nearest to lombokensis from Lombok. It has the outwardly placed black spot in the white area in space Ic, this character being considered to be related to that of Java. Lombokensis is a black form, while austrosundana of the neighbouring Sumbawa is white-patched without exception, but the patch is not developed, only three spots being indicated in spaces 2,3 and 4. It occurs in two forms, namely, the yellowspotted (wing), yellow body form, and the red spotted (wing), red body form, and it has the centrally placed, black spot in the pink or yellowish white area in space 1c of the hindwing, which is regarded as an important feature of the subspecies. It is local in Sumbawa. The subspecies of Flores lacks this black spot in the pink area in space 1c, and has the well-developed central white spots in spaces 2-5, the character being peculiar among the subspecies of the Lesser Sunda Islands. It is not abundant in Flores. It has not been recorded from Sumba. Probably due to the competition with P. oreon it is rare, and curiously enough, only the yellow-spotted, yeBow body form has been collected. It is a black aristolochiae subspecies without the white patch. Various species of Aristolochia are known as the larval food plants. Butterflies fly slow and visit many kinds of flowers. They usually occur in sub-montane zone, being abundant near human habitation, for instance, around villages, wastelands beside farms and graveyards. Rarely they are found to suck water. Description  Pachliopta aristolochiae sapientia ssp. nov. (PLATE 61-1,2,3)  MALE : As illustrated FEMALE : As illustrated Holotype : [male] Lewa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-30 Paratypes : Lawa Sumba Is. 1979-Dec.-14 (1 [male]), 1978-Apr.-3 (1 [female]), 1980-Mar.- 8 (1 [female]), 1980- Mar.-25 (2 [male]), (2 [female]) Upperside forewing, basally black, with discal area streaked by pale whitish vem stripes from vem 2 to costa. Upperside hindwing with subtornal area of space 2 obscurely dusted with yellow scale. The rest of wing entirely black and unmarked. Underside forewing, basally blackish brown, space 1c almost black, with whitish vein stripes from vein 2 to costa, the stripes extend to outer half of cell. Underside hindwing, with submarginal series of seven yellow spots in spaces 1-7. The yellow spots small, and rounded and not clearly defined for they are black-dusted. Abdomen, with lateral and ventral sides dull yellow, dorsal side black. Clypeus covered with black-tipped dull yellow hair. It is a unique subspecies instantly separable from other subspecies by the above features. It is collected only at Lewa, C. Sumba. There also occurs P. oreon. It is noteworthy that P. oreon has the red submarginal spots while this species has them yellow. Very few specimens have been recorded in spite of the several researches. P. oreon, the competitive species is rather common. It represents the most southeastern extension of the a ristolochiae 's range. In Sumbawa, which lies to the north of Sumba, the yellow-spotted, yellow body form is collected, but it has the central white patch on the hindwing without exception. The new subspecific name means wisdom. Description Pachliopta aristolochiae agricola ssp. nov. (PLATE 59-7.8) MALE : A illustrated FEMALE: A illustrated Range : Tanajampea Holotype: [male] Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1978-Mar.-14 Paratypes: Tanajampea South of CELEBES 1979-Mar.- 14 (2 [male] 1 [female]), 1979-Mar.-16 (1 [female]) The form of this species occurrring in Tanajampea has been classified as belonging to antiphus, the subspecies of Borneo and Sumatra, but the black aristolochiae subspecies proved to be two-stemmed, namely, antiphus, brevicauda stem from Palawan, Borneo, Sumatra and Nias, and balina, lombokensis and sapientia stem from Lesser Sunda. The examples from Tanajampea are rather closely allied to Bornean antiphus as Bryk classified them. But such a distribution pattern as occurring limitedly in Borneo and Tanajampea is unexampled and the interpretation of the fact is very difficult. A careful study of the submarginal spots on the hindwing beneath revealed that there were difinite differences between antiphus from Borneo (and Sumatra) and examples from Tanajampea, and here we describe the latter as a separate new subspecies. Forewing similar to antiphus. Underside hindwing, submarginal red spots poorly indicated and narrow. The male has spot in space 5 obsolescent, spots in spaces 3, 4,6,7, very narrow except those in spaces I, 2. The female similar to the male, but with small, obsolescent red spot in space 5. Lunular spots in spaces 3, 4 chervon-shaped and peculiar. It is separable from antiphus which has red spots round or rectangular. The subspecific name means farmer. Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Mimicry: have mimics amongst polymorphic Papilio memnon and P. polytes and monomorphic P. bootes
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Polymorphism and mimicry. Polymorphism is characteristic for some representatives of the genera Chilasa and Papilio, but is seen mainly for Menelaides. The majority of polymorphic swallowtail species are the mimics of inedible taxa belonging to some Troidini: Byasa, Pachliopta and Losaria and some Danainae: Euploea and Parantica. Sometimes a mimic species shows similarity with several taxa belonging not only to different species but also to different genera. For example, seven forms of Chilasa clytia are mimics of some species of Euploea and Parant ica (Nymphalidae: Danai nae). Chilasa paradoxa produces some forms that are mimics of Euploea mulciber and E. radamanthus. The males of Papilio memnon (Plate 16) are known in one form which is a mimic of Troidini: Atrophaneura varuna (Plate 3) and A. a idoneus (Plate 4). The female of p. memnon has several tailed forms that are mimics of other members of the same tribe: Pachliopta aristolochiae and Losaria coon (Plate 7) while some tailless forms are mimics of Atrophaneura zaleucus (Plate 3). Inedible taxa of Troidini: Byasa, Atrophaneura, Pachliopta and Losaria are characterised by a more or less stable wing pattern. They usually have more than one mimic species belonging to different genera or families. For example Pachliopta aristolochiae and Losaria coon have mimics amongst polymorphic Papilio memnon and p. polytes and monomorphic p. bootes. Papilio memnon, p. protenor and p . alcmenor are mimics for the males of Atrophaneura varuna and A. aidoneus. The female of Papilio alcmenor is a mimic for both sexes of Byasa polyeuctes and B. dasarada.

Book: The Butterflies of Hong Kong
Distribution.Range: has the most northerly distribution and is the only species found in Hong Kong.
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus Pachliopta A homogeneous group clearly separated from other Troidini by the male genitalia in which the valvae are much reduced except for the sacculus and clasper, at least a part of their function appearing to be taken over by the large, widely separated and strongly sclerotized socii above them. The male hindw ing fold is weak or absent Fig 6.35 Venation ot Pachliopta aristolochiae female and without scent wool. They range from Sri Lanka to the Ryukyu Islands and south to northern Australia. P. aristolochiae has the most northerly distribution and is the only species found in Hong Kong.

Book: Butterflies of Micronesia
Hostplant.larval.food: feeds on Aristolochia
Mimicry: In Palau, there are occasional specimens of a second morph [of Papilio polytes] that is a mimic of Pachliopta aristolochiae
Defense.strategies: feeds on Aristolochia, a type of plant that is highly poisonous to vertebrates.
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: Papilio polytes L. Plate 2 Palau, Yap, Guam, Saipan, Tinian, Rota Black citrus swallowtail or common mormon. Range: Sri Lanka and India to China and south intoe the Philippines. In Malaysia it is considered to  be a rather urbanized specices that is rarely found in the forest. It is probably a relatively recent arrival in the Marianas, first being recorded on Guam in the 1950s. There are distinct races living on various islands. The ones in the Marianas and Yap have tails, whereas the ones in Palau do not. In Palau, there are occasional specimens of a second morph that is a mimic of Pachliopta aristolochiae, a butterfly that feeds on Aristolochia, a type of plant that is highly poisonous to vertebrates. This morph is gray and white with red markings. The butterflies are attracted to salt and are frequently found at puddles. Food plants include citrus and Other Rutaceae.

Book: Sequel to \The Life Histories of Asian Butterflies Vols. I & II"
Distribution.Range: This butterfly is widespread on plains from the temperate zone to the subtropics. Also in limited highland areas in liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng (2,300m), liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng, liangdong, Yunnan Sheng (2,060m), To Guan Cum (2,960m), etc.; Japan, Guam, Taiwan, China, Myanmar, Amur, Ussuri, Sakhalin, Hawaii
Abundance: ...in some localities in great numbers
Habitat: This butterfly is widespread on plains from the temperate zone to the subtropics. Also in limited highland areas in liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng (2,300m), liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng, liangdong, Yunnan Sheng (2,060m), To Guan Cum (2,960m), etc.; Japan, Guam, Taiwan, China, Myanmar, Amur, Ussuri, Sakhalin, Hawaii; Frequently occurs in human residential areas
Hostplant.larval.food: Known larval foodplants are mostly of the Rutaceae: Zathoxylum nitidum, Z. piperium (Japan pepper), Z. plapinum/alatum, Z. beecheyanum, Z. schinifolium, Z. ailanthoides , Phellodendron amurense (Amur cork-tree), Euodia glauca, E. rutaecarpa (cultivated), Poncirus trifoliata (cultivated), Skimmia japonica, S. j. var. intermedia Frepens, Toddalia asiatica, Citrus natsudaidai (cultivated), C. junos (ichandarin; cultivated), C. unshiu (Satsuma orange; cultivated), C. grandis (grapefruit, pomelo, shaddock; cultivated), C. obovoidea (cultivated), C. aurantium (cultivated), C. tamurana (cultivated), C. limon (cultivated), Boenninghausenia japonica, etc. Also feeding on Asarum sieboldi (Aristolochiaceae) has been observed; Its natural larval foodplants are presumably wild rutaceous trees, although this species secondarily utilizes planted citrous fruit trees as well
Adult.food: Both male and female visit flowers of many plant species, and feed on nectar. The males sometimes descend to wetland and drink water in groups.
Phenology.and.voltinism: In warm regions, it cycles 3-4 generations a year. However, specimens available in highlands...and in such places it may be univoltine.
Author: michael.belitz
Full.Species.Account: 20. Papilio xuthus Linnaeus, 1767 (CHINA) [Plate No. 29] [Foodplants] Known larval foodplants are mostly of the Rutaceae: Zathoxylum nitidum, Z. piperium (Japan pepper), Z. plapinum/alatum, Z. beecheyanum, Z. schinifolium, Z. ailanthoides , Phellodendron amurense (Amur cork-tree), Euodia glauca, E. rutaecarpa (cultivated), Poncirus trifoliata (cultivated), Skimmia japonica, S. j. var. intermedia Frepens, Toddalia asiatica, Citrus natsudaidai (cultivated), C. junos (ichandarin; cultivated), C. unshiu (Satsuma orange; cultivated), C. grandis (grapefruit, pomelo, shaddock; cultivated), C. obovoidea (cultivated), C. aurantium (cultivated), C. tamurana (cultivated), C. limon (cultivated), Boenninghausenia japonica, etc. Also feeding on Asarum sieboldi (Aristolochiaceae) has been observed. [Habits] This butterfly is widespread on plains from the temperate zone to the subtropics. Also in limited highland areas in liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng (2,300m), liuzhaigou, Nanping Xian, Sichuan Sheng, liangdong, Yunnan Sheng (2,060m), To Guan Cum (2,960m), etc. this species has been known to occur; moreover in some localities in great numbers. Its natural larval foodplants are presumably wild rutaceous trees, although this species secondarily utilizes planted citrus fruit trees as well and frequently occurs in human residential areas. Both male and female visit flowers of many plant species, and feed on nectar. The males sometimes descend to wetland and drink water in groups. In warm regions, it cycles 3-4 generations a year. However, specimens available in highlands are sometimes only small ones little different from the spring forms, and in such places it may be univoltine. [Distribution] Japan, Guam, Taiwan, China, Myanmar, Amur, Ussuri, Sakhalin, Hawaii. [Morphological Notes] The adult forewing length is about 42.0mm in the male and about 47.0mm in the female. (Harada)

Book: Butterflies of Micronesia
Common.name: Citrus Swallowtail
Distribution.Range: Guam, Saipan, Kosrae. East Asia, Hawaii, and Luzon... It is now thought to be extinct in the Marianas... it seems possible the butterfly is no longer present anywhere in Micronesia
Abundance: In the 1930s Swezey stated that this butterfly was very abundant on Guam... It is now thought to be extinct in the Marianas, as the last known specimen known to have been caught on Guam was collected in 1968.  No individuals of P. xuthus were observed in Kosrae on recent collecting trips in 1984 and 1986, and it seems possible the butterfly is no longer present anywhere in Micronesia
Habitat: could be seen in large numbers at the edges of puddles along roads
Hostplant.larval.food: The host plants are various species of Rutaceae. On Guam the larvae commonly fed on Triphasia and Citrus species.
Adult.food: could be seen in large numbers at the edges of puddles along roads
Author: Sam.Lopez
Full.Species.Account: Papilio xuthus L. Plate 3 $ ;  Guam, Saipan, Kosrae : Citrus Swallowtail. Range: East Asia, Hawaii, and Luzon. In the 1930s Swezey stated that this butterfly was very abundant on Guam and could be seen in large numbers at the edges of puddles along roads. It is now thought to be extinct in the Marianas, as the last specimen known to have been caught on Guam was collected in 1968. P. polytes has apparently replaced this species in Saipan also. No individuals of P xuthus were observed in Kosrae on recent collecting trips in 1984 and 1986, and it seems possible die butterfly is no longer present anywhere in Micronesia. The host plants are various species of Rutaceae. On Guam the larvae commonly fed on Triphasia and Citrus species.

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: distributed from japan to Korea, E. China and S. China
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Papilio benguetanus Joicey & Talbot (Original Description) benguetanus Joicey & Talbot, Entomologist, 56, p.273-274 (1923) [Notes] This Philippine species belongs to the Xuthus (sub)group of the subgenus Papilio, replacing xuthus which is found around Japan. It is a relict species of the Continental origin, presumably having the common ancestral species with xuthus and specialized with more plesiomorphous characters retained than others. P. xuthus is distributed from japan to Korea, E. China and S. China. From the mating of xuthus from Japan ([female]) x benguetanus ([male]), F, and F2 were obtained, and the examination of the genitalia also proved their similarity in features. On these grounds some authors regard it as a subspecies of xuthus instead of the independent species. Here we treat it as the distinct species on the grounds that its markings differ greatly from those of xuthus in both sexes. It is a relict species remained in the montane district of N. Luzon and unlike xuthus it shows no biological reaction such as seasonal variation. This species has the same distribution as P. chikae in N. Luzon. It has been collected as far north as N. Bontoc, being not found at the northern extremity of N. Luzon and eastwards as well as in the Batan Peninsula. On Mt. St. Tomas and Mt. Paoai, the most famous localities of this species, the butterflies occur in some number from March to June, where many individuals are found hill-topping in the fine morning. They begin to appear from around 7 a.m., being most vigorously on the wing from 9 a.m. to 11 a.m., then decrease in number in the afternoon, when the area is mostly covered by fog. If favoured with fine weather the species is found soaring on the wind together with Parantica phyle, Appias phoebe, ulastrina or Bestina spp. and Argyreus hyperbius. The flight of this species resembles that of the spring brood of xuthus in Japan. The butterflies fly swift on the breeze, prefer hill-tops and usually display territorial behaviour even on the small peak, with their figures in flight perceptible at some distance. Parantica phyle, which is considered to be the model of this species is abundant in St. Tomas, but is it hardly mistaken for this species as its flight is slow. A species of Bestina is rather similar to this species when on the wing. The female is scarcer than the male, but it is also obtainable on hill-tops. The sex is easily separable from the male by its larger size, well-developed submarginal orange-red spots on the hindwing and broader and paler black streaks on both wings. It resembles xuthus but its discrimination is very easy as it has a somewhat box-like wing contour and also has a very broad black streaks in the apical half of the forewing. The larval food plant in the field is unknown. The mother butterfly refused to lay egg on species of Zanthoxylum or Citrus brought from japan for some unknown reason, and nobody succeeded in obtaining eggs. It is only reported that the larva hatched from the eggs obtained artificially from the female body ate Phellodendron amurense. Subspeciation and seasonal or individual variations are not recognized till now. Presumably it is not a mimetic species, its resemblance to P. phyle being a coincidental one. Anyone can collect this species when it does occur abundantly. We have never seen the form similar to the summer brood of xuthus in japan. (Range) benguetanus : N.Luzon PLATE 95 7 [male] benguetanus 197B-Mar. Mt.St.Tomas N.LUZON 8 [male] V benguetanus 197B-Mar. Mt.St.Tomas N.LUZON 9 [female] benguetanus 197B-Mar. Mt.St.Tomas N.LUZON  [images] distribution map of Papilio benguetanus; male genitalia, Papilio benguetanus (LUZON)

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: XUTHUS SWALLOWTAIL
Distribution.Range: Introduced to Hawaii.
Hostplant.larval.food: Citrus family plants
Author: andra.doherty

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: XUTHUS SWALLOWTAIL
Distribution.Range: Asia, introduced to Hawaii where it is the only swallowtail.
Habitat: Gardens, fields, citrus groves.
Hostplant.larval.food: Many plants in Citrus family.
Phenology.and.voltinism: All year (several flights).
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: TYPE LOCALITY. China, Canton (Honey & Scoble, 2001)...  Far East of Russia, Japan, Korea, China, N. Burma, Luzon
Abundance: It may be supposed that the species occasionally enters N. Vietnam from China, where it is rather common
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae of the Chinese populations feed on Poncirus trifoliata, Zanthoxylum ailanthoides, Z. nitidum. Citrus sp., Euodia rutaecarpa and Phellodendron amurensis (all Rutaceae) (Chou, 2000; Tuzov et al., 1997)
Phenology.and.voltinism: Listed specimens collected on September, March, and June
Author: Jomar.Hinolan

Book: Butterflies of Costa Rica Volume 1: Papilionidae, Pieridae, Nymphalidae
Distribution.Range: Mexico to Costa Rica The southern range of this species terminates near the transition to lowland Pacific rainforest near Quepos. Encountered as solitary individuals along forest edges and road cuts, from July to September. Occurs on the Pacific slope
Abundance: This species is moderately common in the remnant patches of forest, especially from 300-800 m.
Habitat: deciduous forest habitats. The southern range of this species terminates near the transition to lowland Pacific rainforest near Quepos. Encountered as solitary individuals along forest edges and road cuts
Oviposition: Egg - laid singly on young leaves Females oviposit from mid day until late afternoon.
Hostplant.larval.food: Aristolochia (Aristolochiaceae)
Adult.food: Both sexes visit flowers of Lantana, Stachytarpheta, and Hamelia.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Encountered as solitary individuals from July to September.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: The Butterflies of Altai, Sayans and Tuva (South Siberia)
Distribution.Range: Distribution in Altai, Sayans and Tuva. Widespread.
Habitat: From steppes to alpine meadows with rocky formations; glades in pine and mixed mountain forests up to 2500 m.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Univoltine; from early June to late August, depending on elevation and locality
Author: vaughn.shirey

Univoltine; from early June to late August, depending on elevation and locality. Habitat. From steppes to alpine meadows with rocky formations; glades in pine and mixed mountain forests up to 2500 m.

Book: Collins Butterfly Guide: The most complete guide to the butterflies of Britain and Europe
Common.name: Apollo
Distribution.Range: Most larger mountainous regions of Europe to Tian Shan and W Siberia. TL: Sweden; Most larger mountain ranges from Spain to S Fennoscandia, Balkans and Greece, including NW Peloponnesos. Absent from British Isles and Mediterranean islands except Sicily. Extinct in C Germany, Denmark, and Czech Republic.
Abundance: Absent from British Isles and Mediterranean islands except Sicily. Extinct in C Germany, Denmark, and Czech Republic.; generally above 1000m in S Europe.; Declined rapidly in Germany, Norway, Sweden and parts of France during the present century: climatic change appears primarily responsible.
Habitat: Breeding-grounds comprise rocky places with areas favouring the establishment of LHP (Sedum) and the general exclusion of plant species requiring a more substantial soil-base - a condition partially met by the relatively high tolerance of LHP to desiccating conditions. Well-drained, often precipitous rocky slopes; limestone pavements with narrow crevices or hollows, or other flat, stony surfaces provide typical habitats where these occur in proximity to deeper soils supporting robust nectar-rich plants such as knapweeds and thistles.
Oviposition: Ova laid on dead or living woody plant stems, and the leaves of evergreen shrubs such as juniper or lichens.
Hostplant.larval.food: LHPs principally Sedum album: less often, S. telephium. Other Sedum spp. and allied genera are often quoted in the literature - S. roseum; S. annuum; S. villosum; Sempervivum tectorum; Rhodiola rosea.; Feeds in full sun on leaves.
Adult.food: supporting robust nectar-rich plants such as knapweeds and thistles.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Univoltine. Early May/September according to locality, altitude, and season; Usually hibernates as a fully formed larvae within ovum-case, less often externally; may remain in diapause for two seasonal cycles.
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Feeds in full sun on leaves.
Diapause: Usually hibernates as a fully formed larvae within ovum-case, less often externally; may remain in diapause for two seasonal cycles.
Defense.strategies: Pupates in a flimsy cocoon under stones or moss.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Apollo Paynassius apollo RANGE Most larger mountainous regions of Europe toTian Shan and W Siberia. P.apollo Linnaeus 1758TL: Sweden. DISTRIBUTION Most larger mountain ranges from Spain to S Fennoscandia, Balkans and Greece, including NW Pelopon nesus. Absent from British Isles and Mediterranean islands except Sicily. Extinct in C Germany, Denmark and Czech Republic. 500-2400m: generally above 1000m in S Europe. DESCRIPTION Male upf without red pd spot in s8; black pd spot in s5 rarely with obscure red centre: equivalent mark ings in female variable but averagely slightly better developed - sometimes conspicuous. Antennal shaft pale grey, narrowly ringed darker grey (cf. P.phnebiis). VARIATION A large accumulation of formal descriptions has resulted from attempts to account for local/regional variation in size, gc and development of markings. Many named forms differ only slightly, falling within an overall range of variation which might he considered normal for other species attracting less attention. An extensive, and therefore disproportionate account of racial differences may serve only to mislead. Amongst the more superficially distinctive forms are colour variants occurring at S\V and SE extremes of European range; in S Spain, iwraclensis Oberthiir (Sierra Nevada), jilaAr/cnv de Sagarra (S. de los Filahres) and ^adoreitsis Rougeot and Capdeville (S. de Gador); all red markings replaced by yellow-orange: in S Greece (Mt. Erimanthos. NW Peloponnesus), alrides van Apollo der Poorten and Oils: similarly coloured. Other races of Spain {liispankiis Oberthiir), Greece and S Balkans {rhmlopensis Markovic) have the more usual red markings. FLIGHT-PERIDD Univoltine. Early May/September according to locality, altitude and .season. HABITAT Breeding-grounds comprise rocky places with areas favouring the establishment of LHP (Sedum) and the gen eral exclusion of plant species requiring a more substantial soil-base - a condition met partly by the relatively high tolerance of LHP to desiccating conditions. Well-drained, often precipitous rocky slopes; limestone pavements with narrow crevices or hollows, or other flat, stony surfaces provide typical habitats where these occur in proximity to deeper soils supporting robust nectar-rich plants such as knapweeds and thistles. LtFE-HtSTDRY LHPs principally Sedum album: less often, S. lelcphium. Other Sedum spp. and allied genera arc often quoted in the literature - S. yoseunp S. aimuum: S. villosum: Sempermum leelorum; Rhodiola rnsea. Ova laid on dead or living woody plant stems, and the leaves of evergreen shrubs such as juniper or lichens. Usually hibernates as a fully formed larva within ovum-case, less often externally: may remain in diapause for two seasonal cycles: feeds in full sun on leaves. Larva, velvety black, lateral spots yellow or brilliant orange-red according to locality. Pupates in a flimsy cocoon under stones or moss. NOTE Declined rapidly in Germany, Norway, Sweden and parts of France during the present century: climatic change appears primarily responsible.

Book: The Butterflies of Scandinavia in Nature
Common.name: Apollo
Distribution.Range: In Norway until 1950 very common along E. coast and nearby mountains. today it is rare in these same areas. It can, however, still appear in large numbers farther inland, in Telemarken, as from 1973-1976, as well as in the areas north-west of Oslo. In Jotunheimen it appears in small numbers and is not found every year, even though in good years in one spot up to 100 apollos can be found in one day. In Sweden it has earlier been quite common along the eastern coast and several inland areas, among others near the large lakes, where Hen. and Rambring caught it south of Kopmannebro in 1959, but since then several searches have ended without result. It appears that apollo is in decline in both Norway and Sweden at the present time. There are several possible reasons for this decline, but perhaps a small change in climate will improve apollo's situation. Apollo has been reported as caught in Denmark, but this is so extraordinary that the species cannot be considered a Danish native.
Elevation: In Jotunheimen, it is only found on the warmest SW - facing slopes and at an altitude of 900-1300 m. where it flies at the base of steep inclines and lower. In S. Norway it flies in areas of 500-900 m altitude, often among flowers along roads with hairpin bends or near high-altitude lakes. In Sweden in mountains by the sea.
Abundance: In Norway until 1950 very common along E. coast and nearby mountains. today it is rare in these same areas. It can, however, still appear in large numbers farther inland, in Telemarken, as from 1973-1976, as well as in the areas north-west of Oslo. In Jotunheimen it appears in small numbers and is not found every year, even though in good years in one spot up to 100 apollos can be found in one day. In Sweden it has earlier been quite common along the eastern coast and several inland areas, among others near the large lakes, where Hen. and Rambring caught it south of Kopmannebro in 1959, but since then several searches have ended without result. It appears that apollo is in decline in both Norway and Sweden at the present time. There are several possible reasons for this decline, but perhaps a small change in climate will improve apollo's situation. Apollo has been reported as caught in Denmark, but this is so extraordinary that the species cannot be considered a Danish native.
Flight.characteristics: Their flight is heavy, sluggish, but powerful and swooping. It flees with quick, vibrating wing strokes, a few meters above the ground or almost vertically to a great height, then gliding down again to feed.
Habitat: Norway: mountainous areas, southern-facing slopes where orpine (Sedum telephium) or rose root (Sedum roseum) grow on steep, sunny, nearly vertical Archaen rock, and among rocks on eroded inclines which are partially overgrown with thistles (Cirsium) and knapweed (Centaurea).; In E. Sweden, apollo flies over slopes and plateaus, preferably those with steep southern-facing inclines, but on Gotland it lives on low-lying and overgrown-slopes. From the two latter biotopes it can reach arable land, edges of woods, and on Gotland, dry juniper stands. In Jotunheimen, it is only found on the warmest SW - facing slopes and at an altitude of 900-1300 m. where it flies at the base of steep inclines and lower. In S. Norway it flies in areas of 500-900 m altitude, often among flowers along roads with hairpin bends or near high-altitude lakes. In Sweden in mountains by the sea.; limestone ledges;
Oviposition: Laid singly on dry leaves and stems near food plant.; Eggs are laid over long periods of time.
Hostplant.larval.food: Sedum telephium, Sedum album, Sedum rosea; they eat only in sunshine.; Like a bumblebee, apollo can squeeze scabious flowers and press out the nectar.
Adult.food: It prefers large flowers such as thistles, knapweed, field scabious, etc. It is always hungry.
Phenology.and.voltinism: During warm summers...it appears from mid-June, otherwise from early July or mid-August and in Jotunheimen from late July - mid-August or later. In E. Sweden, new apollos have been seen as late as early September, 1952.; The egg winters with completely developed larva inside.
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Most active from 8:30-11:30 AM. Most rest from 11:30 AM - 2:30 PM after which males are seen until past 3:00 PM while females mingle, feeding, laying eggs, and again on the wing around 4:00 PM.; During periods of bad weather, apollo waits until a possible sunny day when it can fly until approx. 6:00 PM, we have seen it as late as 7:00 PM.
Diapause: The egg winters with completely developed larva inside.
Defense.strategies: The fact that apollo can survive sudden temperature changes and snowstorms...is due to the presence of glycerides in its body, also found or easily formed in the larva (possible also in pupa). As in some Lycaenidae fs. apollo has its own "anti-freeze." It has a distinctive intimidation-defense behavior when it is disturbed while resting in that it "blinks" with is hw, eye-spots, which it covers and uncovers using fws. At the same time it produces a hissing snake-like sound by scraping its back legs against to basal area of the wing (stridulation phenomenon).; Employs osmaterium infrequently, the yellow fork appears only after coarse handling.; Full-grown larva is velvety-black, short-haired, and with a row of orange, nearly-luminous spots on its sides and with small, strong blue "warts" on its back: obviously colors of warning.

Book: LuontoPortti [NatureGate]
Common.name: Apollo
Abundance: Endangered, protected in all of Finland, including the Åland Islands.
Flight.characteristics: Males fly around looking for females
Habitat: Rocky terrain with an abundance of flowers.
Oviposition: Females lay their eggs one by one, among lichen and twigs next to the host plant.
Hostplant.larval.food: Orpine (Hylotelephium telephium) and other Stonecrop family plants (Crassulaceae), especially e.g. white stonecrop (Sedum album).
Phenology.and.voltinism: Early July–mid-August.
Diapause: Egg or small caterpillar.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Apollo Parnassius apollo Name also: Mountain Apollo Family: Swallowtail Butterflies – Papilionidae Subfamily: Snow Apollos – Parnassiinae Wing span: Very large, 62–94 mm (2.48–3.76 in.). Finland’s largest butterfly. Wing upper side: White, with black blotches. Hind wing with two red, black-edged eye-blotches. Females darker than males. Tip of forewing transparent. Wing underside: Like upper surface. Habitat: Rocky terrain with an abundance of flowers. Flying time: Early July–mid-August. Overwintering form: Egg or small caterpillar. Larval foodplant: Orpine (Hylotelephium telephium) and other Stonecrop family plants (Crassulaceae), especially e.g. white stonecrop (Sedum album). Endangerment: Endangered, protected in all of Finland, including the Åland Islands. The four species that are members of the Swallowtail family that can be found in Finland belong to two different subfamilies. The Snow Apollo subfamily (Parnassiinae) is home to the apollo and clouded apollo. The Swallowtails(Papilioninae) is home to the swallowtail and the scarce swallowtail.  The apollo is easy to recognise and impossible to confuse with other Finnish species. It can be easily differentiated from the clouded apollo by the red ring patterns on its hind wings.  Males fly around looking for females. Copulated females have at the back of their bodies, a shell-like structure called a sfragis. The male creates it during copulation, and it is assumed that it makes it difficult for the female to copulate again. Females lay their eggs one by one, among lichen and twigs next to the host plant.

Book: A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Vanuatu
Common.name: The Clipper
Distribution.Range: A w idespread species, occurring from Sri Lanka, India, C hina, T hailand, the M alay P eninsula, P hilippines and Indonesia to N ew G uinea, the S olom ons and V anuatu.   R eported from Hiu, Loh, U reparapara, V anua Lava, M ota, E spiritu S anto, A m bae, M aew o, P entecost, A m brym , Epi and Efate.
Abundance: U sually com m on.
Flight.characteristics: Flight is strong and highly characteristic, w ith open w ings depressed below the horizontal, in long glides w ith sporadic w ing beats. It rests on the upper surface o f leaves, basking in the sunshine w ith w in g s held flat
Habitat: F orest clearings, roadsides and open places, including village gardens.
Hostplant.larval.food: Tinospora dissitiflora and T. glabra as likely host-plants in N ew G uinea.
Adult.food: visits flo w e rs often
Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: The Clipper Parthenos sylvia thesaurinus Grose-Smith, 1887 Parthenos sylvia thesaurinus G rose-S m ith, 1897, Annals and Magazine of Natural History, (6 )1 9 :1 7 7 , TL: S olom on Islands, S anta C ruz R ange: A w idespread species, occurring from Sri Lanka, India, C hina, T hailand, the M alay P eninsula, P hilippines and Indonesia to N ew G uinea, the S olom ons and V anuatu. R s. thesaurinus is restricted to the N ew H ebrides A rchipelago. A d u lt c h a ra c te ris tic s : A large, distinctive nym phalid species w ith a series of black and brow n stripes and streaks on both surfaces. The forew ing has a series of conspicuous w hite m edian blotches. O nly the fem ale is illustrated; the m ale is sim ilar, w ith slig h tly m ore pointed forew ings. S im ila r s p e c ie s : None. F lig h t/H a b ita t: F orest clearings, roadsides and open places, including village gardens. Flight is strong and highly characteristic, w ith open w ings depressed below the horizontal, in long glides w ith sporadic w ing beats. It rests on the upper surface o f leaves, basking in the sunshine w ith w in g s held flat, and visits flo w e rs often. Distribution: R eported from Hiu, Loh, U reparapara, V anua Lava, M ota, E spiritu S anto, A m bae, M aew o, P entecost, A m brym , Epi and Efate. U sually com m on. H o s t-p la n ts : P arsons (1998) suggested Tinospora dissitiflora and T. glabra as likely host-plants in N ew G uinea.

Book: Butterflies of the World Part 29: Hesperiidae of the Philippine Islands
Distribution.Range: the nominotypical subspecies occurring in Africa and tropical Asia as far east as Tenimbar
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Pelopidas mathias (Fabricius, 1798) [Hesperia mathias Fabricius, 1798, Entomologica systematica Supplement: 433; rype localiry: Tranquebar, S India] General distribution: Africa (including Madagascar and Comoro Islands), Oriental Region, extending north to Korea and Japan, and east to New Guinea and neighbouring islands. Geographic variation: three subspecies are recognized, with the nominotypical subspecies occurring in Africa and tropical Asia as far east as Tenimbar. Immature stages are very similar to those of P agna; they have been described and figured by Bascombe et al. (1999). In addition to a variety of wild grasses this species also feeds on rice (Oryza sativa) and sugar cane (Saccharum officinarum), and incidental but not very serious damage has been recorded. It also takes maize (Zea mays) which is an introduced plant in the Old World. For parasites, see Kalshoven (1981).

Book: Field Guide: Butterflies of Southern Africa
Common.name: Black Banded Swift
Distribution.Range: This species is found in the Eastern Cape, Natal, Transvaal, Bechuanaland, Rhodesia, and Moҫambique. It inhabits most of Africa north of the Zambezi River and the neighbouring islands.
Abundance: This species is usually common in forest, bush, or grassland.
Habitat: This species inhabits forest, bush, or grassland.
Adult.forms: The forewing has more or less a semi-circular group of hyaline dots which include three minute dots below apex, followed by a curved row of three or four other dots. The brand in the male is black divided by a very fine white line. The female lacks the scent brand. The underside of the hindwing is greyish brown with a curved row of about three to five white dots in the outer part.
Author: anne.lott
Full.Species.Account: Pelopidas mathias (Fabricius, 1798) Black Banded Swift (plates 41, 42) Dark brown with greenish yellow hairs; forewing with more or less semi-circular group of hyaline dots which include three minute dots below apex, followed by a curved row of three or four other dots, ending with two fine dots in the cell. The brand in the male (see above) is black, divided by a very fine white line. Underside of hindwing greyish brown with a curved row of about three to five white dots in outer part and also a more basal dot. The female, of course, lacks the scent brand. Forewing 0.6-0.7". Usually common in forest, bush or grassland. Eastern Cape, Natal, Transvaal, Bechuanaland, Rhodesia, Mozambique; most of Africa north of the Zambezi River and neighbouring islands.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Lesser Millet Skipper
Distribution.Range: The Lesser Millet Skipper is a widespread butterfly recorded from the Gambia, Senegal, Guinea, Burkina Faso, Sierra Leone, Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, Volta, Togo, Bénin, Nigeria, and the Cross River loop. It will be found also in Mali and Niger. The range is practically pan-African, including Madagascar and the Comores, and most of southern Arabia. It is also in much of the Oriental Region (TL India), extending as far east as New Guinea.
Abundance: The Lesser Millet Skipper is a widespread and common butterfly. Gillies (1982) calls it the most common skipper in the Gambia.
Flight.characteristics: This species has a known migratory capacity.
Habitat: Though essentially a savannah butterfly that is adapted to drier conditions than P. thrax, this species occasionally occurs in clearfelled areas of the forest zone, probably aided by its known migratory capacity. On exceptionally hot days they may actively seek shade, resting on walls that are not in direct sunlight.
Hostplant.larval.food: The host-plants of this species are a wide array of Poaceae, including Ehrharta, Panicum, Zea, Imperata cylindrica*, Hyparrhenia diplandra*, Oryza, and Andropogon (*Vuattoux (1999) from Côte d’Ivoire).
Adult.food: I have seen many of this species aggregating on Tridax flowers.
Adult.forms: The hindwing of this species is usually unmarked. On the hindwing underside both sexes usually have a complete row of precise white postdiscal spots, as well as a spot in the cell, but they may be almost absent in the dry season.

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Oviposition: The egg is laid singly on grass.
Hostplant.larval.food: The discarded egg shell is eaten by the larva. The larva feeds on the end of blades of grass.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Eggs hatch after 7 to 10 days. In the 1st instar the larva grows from 2.75 to 5.5 mm in 6 days.  In the 2nd instar the larva grows from 5.5 to 8 mm in 6 days. In the 3rd instar the larva grows from 8 to 13.5 mm in 7 days. In the 4th instar the larva grows from 13.5 to 23 mm in 8 days. In the 5th instar the larva grows from 23 to 38 mm in 10 days. The duration of the instars may be longer and there may be an extra instar. The adult emerges after some 26 days from the pupa. The species is multi-brooded, and appears throughout the year.
Defense.strategies: The entire larval state is spent in a tube constructed by the larva through its spinning together the edges of a blade of grass. When it is too big to occupy a tube, the larva lies along the midrib of a blade, the markings of the dorsum rendering it inconspicuous.

Common.name: Cloudless Sulphur
Distribution.Range: Resident Visitor [to the Carolinas];  Abundant throughout the Southeast, it colonizes much of the Carolinas each year. In favorable years, it survives the winter along coastal parts of southern South Carolina.
Abundance: Abundant throughout the Southeast, it colonizes much of the Carolinas each year. In favorable years, it survives the winter along coastal parts of southern South Carolina.; occasional to abundant
Flight.characteristics: The Cloudless Sulphur is a large yellow but terfly with a fast, powerful flight.
Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, vacant fields, agricultural land, parks and gardens
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves or flower buds
Hostplant.larval.food: various Cassia species including Partridge Pea, Sensitive Pea, Sicklepod Senna, Wild Senna, Maryland Senna and Christmas Senna
Adult.food: Adults have an extremely long proboscis and can feed at many long, tubular flowers inaccessible to other butterflies.
Phenology.and.voltinism: March - November [low contrast chart]; multiple generations
Mobility: Abundant throughout the Southeast, it colonizes much of the Carolinas each year. In favorable years, it survives the winter along coastal parts of southern South Carolina.;  Fall individuals undergo a massive, southward migration into Florida to overwinter.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Cloudless Sulphur Phoebis sennae Family/Subfamily: Whites and Sulphurs (Pieridae)/ Sulphurs (Coliadinae) Wingspan: 2.2-2.8° (5.6-7.1 cm) Above: unmarked bright lemon yellow; female has bro ken black wing borders and black forewing spot Below: male is greenish yellow with virtually no markings; female is yellow with pinkish brown markings and sev eral small silver spots in center of each wing; seasonally variable; winter-form adults more heavily marked Sexes: similar, although female is more heavily marked Egg: white, laid singly on host leaves or flower buds Larva: green or yellow with broad lateral yellow stripe marked with blue spots or transverse bands Larval Host Plants: various Cassia species including Partridge Pea, Sensitive Pea, Sicklepod Senna, Wild Senna, Maryland Senna and Christmas Senna Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, vacant fields, agricultural land, parks and gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: occasional to abundant Compare: Clouded Sulphur (pg. 395) and Orange Sulphur (pg. 335) have a solid black cell spot on the forewing, and broad, solid black wing margins. Comments: The Cloudless Sulphur is a large yellow but terfly with a fast, powerful flight. Abundant throughout the Southeast, it colonizes much of the Carolinas each year. In favorable years, it survives the winter along coastal parts of southern South Carolina. Adults have an extremely long proboscis and can feed at many long, tubular flowers inaccessible to other butterflies. Fall individuals undergo a massive, southward migration into Florida to overwinter. The annual event is one of the Southeast's most impressive natural phenomena.

Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: PHOEBIS SENNAE Linnaeus 1758 Cloudless Sulphur Pl. 17 syn. eubule Linnaeus 1767 Description. Fw [male] 32-35 mm, [female] 30-35 mm. Female usually rather smaller than the male. The clear unmarked yellow upperside of the male is relieved in certain lights by a pale silky wavy-edged marginal border that runs inwards between the veins. The pattern of markings in the female is very constant, with no post discal markings on the forewing below vein 3, but the ground colour varies very considerably, from yellow like the male to orange-yellow, cream or pinkish, or almost pure white ([female]-f. sennalba Brown1929). Underside markings are the same in both sexes, but very much more strongly developed in the female, the two pearly spots at the end of the cell equal in size or almost so. Distribution. A sun-loving open country species much attracted to the nectar of flowers and to moist puddles. Abundant throughout the islands and throughout the year from sea level to at least 5000 ft. RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: Jamaica. Early stages. The full grown caterpillar is pale yellowish green, much speckled with black dots, and with a yellow lateral line on each side and bluish transverse lines. Food plant Cassia, of several species, senna, clover, etc. Note. Similar species. Aphrissa neleis (p. 135) and A. statira (p. 136).

Book: Butterflies through Binoculars: The East- A Field Guide to the Butterflies of Eastern North America
Common.name: Cloudless Sulphur
Distribution.Range: by far the most common and widespread phoebis and the only one likely to be seen north of central Florida or southern Texas. Also south through tropical Americas. Deep South… North Carolina and Oklahoma…  West Virginia… Missouri and Indiana… Atlantic coast… New York... occasionally reaching Maine and probably adjacent Canada. Much less common away from the immediate coast. Similar behavior west of the Appalachians brings rare strays north to Ontario, Minnesota, and South Dakota, tending to follow river valleys.
Abundance: by far the most common and widespread phoebis and the only one likely to be seen north of central Florida or southern Texas. C-A all-year resident in the Deep South: as the season progresses Cloudless Sulphurs move northward in large numbers, usually reaching North Carolina and Oklahoma by mid April, West Virginia by May, Missouri and Indiana by June. Late summer/fall brood moves rapidly up the Atlantic coast, usually reaching New York (where it is R) by Sept. and occasionally reaching Maine and probably adjacent Canada. Much less common away from the immediate coast. Similar behavior west of the Appalachians brings rare strays north to Ontario, Minnesota, and South Dakota, tending to follow river valleys. Numbers fluctuate markedly from year to year. From phenogram NY: uncommon beginning to mid September NC:rare throughout July, uncommon beginning to mid August, common mid August through late October, uncommon at end of October LA abundant March through October
Flight.characteristics: It has a high, directional, sailing flight with characteristic deep, powerful wingbeats.
Habitat: A wide variety of open situations. tending to follow river valleys.
Hostplant.larval.food: Cassias.
Phenology.and.voltinism: C-A all-year resident in the Deep South: as the season progresses Cloudless Sulphurs move northward in large numbers, usually reaching North Carolina and Oklahoma by mid April, West Virginia by May, Missouri and Indiana by June. Late summer/fall brood moves rapidly up the Atlantic coast, usually reaching New York (where it is R) by Sept. and occasionally reaching Maine and probably adjacent Canada. From phenogram NY: uncommon beginning to mid September NC:rare throughout July, uncommon beginning to mid August, common mid August through late October, uncommon at end of October LA abundant March through October
Adult.forms: females vary from orange-yellow to off-white (although white females are scarce in the east).
