Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: various grasses including Purpletop Grass, Whitegrass and lovegrass
Phenology.and.voltinism: April - October; two generations
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Zabulon Skipper Poanes zabulon  Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Banded Skippers (Hesperiinae) Witigspan: 1.0-1.4" (2.5-3.6 cm) Above: male is golden orange with dark brown borders and small brown spot near forewing apex; female is dark brown with band of cream spots across forewing Below: male hindwing yellow with a brown base enclos ing a yellow spot; female is dark brown with small light subapical spots, lavender scaling on wing mar gins, and white bar along leading margin of hindwing Sexes: dissimilar, female brown with little orange color Egg: pale green, laid singly on host leaves Larva: tan with dark dorsal stripe, white lateral stripe and short, light-colored hairs; reddish brown head Larval Host Plants: various grasses including Purpletop Grass, Whitegrass and lovegrass Habitat: open woodlands, forest edges, roadsides, pas tures, wetland edges, stream corridors and old fields Broods: two generations Abundance: occasional Compare: Female "Pocahontas" form of Hobomok Skipper (pg. 195) lacks white bar along the leading margin of the ventral hindwing. Comments: Sexually dimorphic, the Zabulon Skipper is a small butterfly with a bright orange male and a drab brown female. Primarily a butterfly of woodlands and Adjacent open sites, it occasionally wanders into sub urban gardens. Adults have a rapid flight and are strongly attracted to flowers. Males perch on sunlit ranches along trails or clearings and engage passing objects or rival males. Females generally prefer to remain within the confines of nearby shady sites.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Zabulon Skipper
Abundance: Hobomok Skipper (P. hobomok) and Zabulon Skipper (P. zabulon) are generally common, especially the Hobomok Skipper.
Habitat: occur along forest edges, in parks and gardens, along roasides, in open fields, and in pastures
Hostplant.larval.food: Their larvae feed upon various grasses.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Zabulon Skipper, Southern Golden Skipper
Distribution.Range: Statewide Connecticut to Kansas south to Florida, Texas, and through Mexico and Central America to Panama. [images]Jackson County, IL; Putnam County, IL; Champaign County, IL; Piatt County,IL
Abundance: Not uncommon. More common in southern half of thestate.
Flight.characteristics: The males are quite pugnacious, darting out at passing females and other males
Habitat: Damp woods, stream edges, gardens, and old fields.  Males perch a meter or so above ground in sunny spots. The females, when not actively flying, tend to be in more shaded sites.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae are known to feed on the grasses purple-top (Tridens spp.) and love-grass (Eragrostis spp.).
Adult.food: Adults are avid feeders, taking nectar from many different flowers. These are known to include buttonbush (Cephalanthus occidentalis), blackberry (Rubus spp), milkweeds (Asclepias spp.), red clover (Trifolium pratense), purple Joe-pye-weed (Eupatoriadelphus purpureum), thistles (Cirsium spp.), ironweed (Vernonia spp.), and others.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Bivoltine. The first brood flies from May to July, the second brood from July to September Males perch much of the day
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Zabulon Skipper
Abundance: A common species restricted to forests.
Habitat: A common species restricted to forests.
Author: andra.doherty

Common.name: Zabulon Skipper
Distribution.Range: [images] Fairfax Co., Va. E. U.S. from cen. Kans. east through s. Mich. to Mass., south to ne. Texas, s. La., and cen. Fla. Strays to N.M., S.D., and s. Que. Also cen. Mexico south to Panama.
Abundance: [image] Females are found most frequently in shady woods. [image] Males are seen most often in sunlit forest openings or forest edges. Strays to N.M., S.D., and s. Que.
Habitat: [image] Females are found most frequently in shady woods. [image] Males are seen most often in sunlit forest openings or forest edges. Brushy areas and openings near moist woods or streams, city parks.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses
Adult.food: [image] Female nectaring at French Marigold, Fairfax Co., Va.
Phenology.and.voltinism: May-Sept. (2 broods) in North, all year in tropics
Adult.forms: [image] This skipper has only one female form.

Distribution.Range: Also, the mountains of northeastern Mexico south to Panama. RS north to southern Ontario (2 records), Michigan, South Dakota (1 record).
Abundance: U-C. RS north to southern Ontario (2 records), Michigan, South Dakota (1 record). From phenogram NY: rare early to mid May, uncommon mid to end of May, common beginning of June, uncommon early June to early July, rare early through mid July, uncommon late July through early August, common early/mid August to late August, abundant late to end of August, common beginning of September, uncommon early to mid September NC: rare late April, uncommon end of April to early May, common early May to early June, uncommon early  to mid June, rare mid June to early July and late July, uncommon end of July, common throughout August, uncommon beginning to mid September LA: rare from beginning of April to end of October
Flight.characteristics: Unlike most of our grass-skippers, which fly close to the ground, Zabulon Skippers often fly about 3 or four 4 high.
Habitat: Woodland openings, edges, and adjacent fields; suburban habitats. Generally in moist situations. The males sally forth from perches on leaves overhanging woodland trails and edges.
Hostplant.larval.food: Grasses.
Phenology.and.voltinism: 2 broods. Mainly May-June, late July-early Sept. RS north to southern Ontario (2 records), Michigan, South Dakota (1 record). Kosterin (Novosibirsk): Kyzyl, city park, 5 T’43’ N 94°27’ E.; Ulug-Khem river right hank at city Kyzyl, 51°43’ N 94°24’ E.; Erzin and Bulun-Bazhi, Erzin river valley, 50°15’ N 95H10-15’ E.; 5 km S.-W. Erzin, 50lT5’ N 95°06’ E.; 20 km N.-E. Moren, Ular river valley, 50°25’ N 95°32’ E. | Coll. R. Yakovlev (Barnaul): Kosh-Agach distr., Chikhacheva Mts., 10 km N.-E. Kokorya; Sush’; 10 km N. Kyzyl; Shuurmak; Mugur-Aksy; Khondergey pass; Tsagan-Shihetu Mts.; 20 km N. Khol’-Oozhu; Samagaltai; 35 km N.-E. Khandagaity; 15 km S. Erzin; 35 km E. Naryn. Distribution in Altai, Sayans and Tuva. South-East Altai and Central Tuvinian and Ubsu-Nur hollows. Flight. Bivoltine or trivoltine according to locality and altitude; May - September. Habitat. Xerophyte slopes, grassy places up to 1800 m.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Ghost
Distribution.Range: The Ghost is a delightful little butterfly that has been found through most of West Africa, from the level of Conakry in Guinea to Sierra Leone, Liberia, Côte d’Ivoire, Ghana, southern Nigeria, and the Cross River loop (TL Calabar). I found it in Korup as well. It will not be found in Volta, Togo, and Bénin, but in Nigeria it goes as far north as Kagoro and Gashaka-Gumpti. Though widely distributed, the species is scarce and patchily distributed west of the Dahomey Gap. In Ghana I met with it in Ankasa National Park on just three out of many occasions, and Father Maessen collected only a short series from Dixcove and Takoradi. Only in August 1996 did I once find it extremely numerous in the Prah-Suhien Forest; this forest is contiguous with Kakum, some 20 km to the east, where I never saw the species, and where it can hardly have been overlooked. It is local in western Nigeria, more widespread and common in the east, and in the Oban Hills common even in the gloomiest parts of the forest. A resting male from Ankasa is shown on the inset.
Abundance: Though widely distributed, the species is scarce and patchily distributed west of the Dahomey Gap. It is local in western Nigeria, more widespread and common in the east, and in the Oban Hills common even in the gloomiest parts of the forest, flying through the undergrowth with its slow flight, hardly ever settling, except on flowers. During long treks one or two are almost always within sight. The species is besotted with the flowers of Geophila obvallata (Rubiaceae) (E. Obot det.), a low plant growing on forest paths (almost certainly the same plant as mentioned by Schultze (1916)). Dozens may hover above every plant competing for the few flowers that are open at any given time (Okwangwo and Oban).
Flight.characteristics: This is a weak butterfly. It is local in western Nigeria, more widespread and common in the east, and in the Oban Hills common even in the gloomiest parts of the forest, flying through the undergrowth with its slow flight, hardly ever settling, except on flowers. Schultze (1920) said that: “… the small, fragile inhabitants of the semidarkness of the understory fly so slowly and so clumsily [soap-bubbles spring to mind] that they are easily caught in flight with the fingers” [translated from the German by the author].
Habitat: It seems adapted to wetter forests. Schultze (1920) said that: “… the small, fragile inhabitants of the semidarkness of the understory fly so slowly and so clumsily [soap-bubbles spring to mind] that they are easily caught in flight with the fingers” [translated from the German by the author].
Oviposition: A female was seen laying eggs on Pseuderanthemum tunicatum (Acanthaceae) in Sierra Leone (Owen 1971).
Hostplant.larval.food: A female was seen laying eggs on Pseuderanthemum tunicatum (Acanthaceae) in Sierra Leone (Owen 1971). The host-plant in northwestern Zambia was Rhopalopilia marquesii, and R. pallens (Opiliaceae) was recorded in Korup, Cameroun (Lees 1989).
Adult.food: Flowers. The species is besotted with the flowers of Geophila obvallata (Rubiaceae) (E. Obot det.), a low plant growing on forest paths (almost certainly the same plant as mentioned by Schultze (1916)). I never saw them at water.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Only in August 1996 did I once find it extremely numerous in the Prah-Suhien Forest.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Common.name: Common Checkered-Skipper
Distribution.Range: Resident [to the Carolinas];  New data suggests that the once abundant Common Checkered-Skipper has been almost entirely displaced by the White Checkered-Skipper s recent expansion into the Deep South. This trend is continuing northward along the coast into Southern Carolina

Flight.characteristics: Adults have a rapid, darting flight.
Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, old fields, utility easements and fallow agricultural land
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves

Phenology.and.voltinism: April - October; multiple generations
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: ComrrEon/lA/hite Checkered-Skipper Pyrgus communis/Pyrgus albescens Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Spread-wing Skippers (Pyrginae) Wingspan: 0.75-1.25" (1.9-3.2 cm) Above: male is black with numerous small, white spots and some bluish white scaling on base of wings and thorax; female is dark brown with reduced white scaling Below: white with tan to brown irregular bands and spots Sexes: similar, although female has reduced white markings Egg: pale green, laid singly on host leaves Larva: gray-green with dark dorsal stripe, light side stripes and black head Larval Host Plants: various mallow family plants including Indian Hemp. Broomweed, Poppy Mallow and False Mallow Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, old fields, utility easements and fallow agricultural land Broods: multiple generations Abundance: common Compare: Tropical Checkered-Skipper (pg. 369) male has increased bluish white scaling on wings above and both sexes have more diffuse or smudged ventral bands. Comments- New data suggests that the once abundant Common Checkered-Skipper has been almost entirely displaced by the White Checkered-Skipper s recent expansion into the Deep South. This trend is continu ing northward along the coast into Sout^n Carolina Virtually identical m appearance and behavior, the two sibling species can be reliably differentiated only through dissection Adults have a rapid, darting flight. While at rest they generally hold their wings open, allowing a glimpse of the butterfly's distinctive checkerboard pattern.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Common Checkered Skipper
Distribution.Range: Statewide The species ranges from Canada to Argentina. [images]Mason County, IL; Adams County, IL; Iroquois County, IL; Cook County, IL
Abundance: Statewide, sometimes common, some years scarce. Populations are influenced by the severity of winter and the amount of winter kill. The greatest abundance is reached in August and September.
Habitat: Open areas almost anywhere, pastures, brushy fields, roadsides, trails, gardens, meadows, usually where vegetation is low.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on mallows, family Malvaceae, including hollyhock (Alcea spp.), poppy mallow (Callirhoe spp.), rose mallow (Hibiscus spp.), mallow (Malva spp.), sida (Sida spp.), globe mallows (Malvastrum spp.), and others.
Adult.food: Adults nectar on a variety of flowers, often white and in the daisy family. Included are fleabane (Erigeron spp.), asters (Aster spp.), clover (Trifolium spp.), and many others. [image]Common Checkered Skipper nectaring.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Multivoltine, two or three generations per year in Illinois. Overwintering, where temperatures are not too cold, is by mature larvae or pupae. The greatest abundance is reached in August and September. It is one of our latest-flying skippers, on the wing into November in some years.
Diapause: Overwintering, where temperatures are not too cold, is by mature larvae or pupae.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Butterflies of Houston & Southeast Texas
Common.name: Common Checkered Skipper, Checkered Skipper
Distribution.Range: May well be North America's most abundant skipper. Occurs as a permanent resident from the central states through much of tropical America. In summer it strays northward as far as Canada.
Abundance: May well be North America's most abundant skipper. In summer it strays northward as far as Canada, establishing short-lived colonies that do not survive the winter.
Flight.characteristics: Males are extremely pugnacious, darting out at anything that invades their territories.
Habitat: Can occupy almost any open, sunny habitat. Moves readily into yards and gardens as well as fields and weedy roadsides.
Oviposition: Females lay their eggs singly on buds or young leaves of plants in the family Malvaccae.
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae feed on a wide variety of plants in the mallow family, including both wild species and such cultivars as hollyhocks and hibiscus. Females lay their eggs singly on buds or young leaves of plants in the family Malvaccae. Larvae found primarily on globe-mallows in West Texas, on Sida species in the East. Food plants: Sidas, globe-mallows, many other mallows.
Adult.food: Visits a wide variety of flowers for nectar and also flocks to mud puddles and damp places to drink.
Phenology.and.voltinism: One of the first butterflies to appear in spring, P. communis occurs in Housston from late February or early March through November. Season: February - November; occasionally throughout the year.
Diapause: In warm winters without a freeze, it may be on the wing in smaller numbers throughout the year.
Defense.strategies: Males are extremely pugnacious, darting out at anything that invades their territories. Larvae live in nests of rolled leaves.
Adult.forms: Male is dark gray above, with long blue-gray, hairlike scales on the body and wing bases. Numerous white spots checker the wings above, while the fringes of the wings are also checkered. The female is usually somewhat darker, her wings checkered black-and-white.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Checkered Skipper
Distribution.Range: The Checkered Skipper occurs across most of the United States, from the southern prairie provinces and extreme southern British Columbia in the north to Argentina in the south. This skipper is found in prairie grassland, the aspen parkland of southern Alberta and the Peace River valley grasslands.
Habitat: This skipper is found in prairie grassland, the aspen parkland of southern Alberta and the Peace River valley grasslands. There are a few records from sand dune areas of the boreal forest.
Hostplant.larval.food: Many species of mallow are reported as larval hosts including species of Malva and Sphaeralcea, Alberta populations occur in areas where neither plant occurs so other species must also serve as food plants
Adult.food: Adults nectar freely at Aster spp. and fleabane (Erigeron spp.).
Phenology.and.voltinism: There are two broods per year. Adults have been found from May 17 to September 17, with most records occurring in June and August. The prolonged flight period suggests at least two broods, perhaps more in Alberta.
Author: elise.larsen

Author: leslie.ries
Full.Species.Account: This species lives up to its name; it is common and widely distrib uted throughout our area in open, sunny habitats. It is often seen in city parks, gardens, and urban vacant lots, as well as in rural areas. Males are territorial and typically perch well off the ground, up to waist height. They perform spectacular aerial male-male chases, typically returning to their previous perches by executing a wide circle near human eye level. Males flash bluish in flight. Females usually fly close to the ground and lack the bluish sheen. Both sexes visit a great variety of flowers, with mints (Mentha)y including garden lavender (Lrtvandw/nJ, and birdfoot trefoil (Lotus cornicuiatus) among their favorites. The Common Checkered Skipper seems to have benefited from the human transformation of lowland Californian land scapes and vegetation. Our populations are multivoltine. Assum ing they were multivoltine before Europeans came, they had to have been restricted to a handfiil of native host plants whose seasonality would support multiple broods: alkali mallow (Malvella leprosa) in alkaline clay soils in the Central Valley, and various species of checkerbloom (Sidalcea) in tule marshes and moist meadows. These are still used, but the vast majority of eggs can be found today on the introduced weedy mallows (Malva) in dis turbed habitats. It seems certain that the Common Checkered Skipper must be much more abundant now than it could have been 200 years ago. From the Transverse Ranges southward throughout southern California, the Common Checkered Skipper is replaced by an an imal called the White Checkered Skipper (P. albescens). The com mon and scientific names are both deceptive, because the White on average is no whiter than the Common; in fact, the two are re liably distinguishable only by the male genitalia. (See John M. Burns, ''Pyrgus communis and Pyrgus albescens are separate transcontinental species with variable but diagnostic valves," Journal of the I^pidopterists Society 54:52-71,2000.) Their biol ogy is also identical. Only a few individuals with albescens geni talia have been detected north of the Transverse Ranges—aU south of our area. Are these really good species? Molecular studies, still in progress at this writing, present a confusing picture. At the mo lecular level, southern California White Checkered Skippers are consistently different from northern California Common Check ered Skippers—except in the Sierra Nevada. Sierran genitalic Commons (from above 1,200 m [4,000 ft]) are univoltine and feed only on native checkerbloom (Sidalcea), often on the floor of open coniferous forest, sometimes on meadows. Molecularly, these are White Checkered Skippers.'Along the Sierran east slope and in the western Great Basin are multivoltine populations feed ing on weedy mallows, and these are indistinguishable from our Commons. There thus appear to be three entities: multivoltine low-elevation and Great Basin morphological and molecular P. communis; multivoltine southern Californian morphological and molecular P. albescens; and Sierran univoltine, morphological P. communis-molecular P. albescens. Clearly, there is a great deal we do not understand about these critters. We know, thanks to Burns, that the White Checkered Skipper has expanded its range eastward all the way to the Adantic coast in recent decades; it shows up abruptly in collections at specific times. It is possible that it is also moving into lowland northern California! Because the species is considered so ubiquitous, this could easily slip under our radar. No one is seriously suggesting that the genitalia of every male in our area be checked, but users of this book should keep in mind the possibility of a White Checkered Skipper invasion and—if so inclined—take a peek at the form of the valves from time to time (see Burns' article for drawings). DISTRIBUTION: AU counties, everywhere except deep shade. HOST PLANTS: Herbaceous maUows (Malvaceae), including alkali maUow (Malvella leprosaf checkerblooms (Sidalcea), garden hoUyhocks (Akea), and aU species of the weedy mallows (Malvaf for example the cheeseweeds (M. neglecta, M. nicaeensis^ and M. parviflora). The use of velvet leaf (Abutilon theophrasti) also caUed Indian mallow, in our area needs to be confirmed. In the Sacramento area, now using the introduced lawn and golf course weed Modiola caroliniana. Eggs often laid on prostrate maUows in mowed lawns, seemingly in preference to taU, robust speci mens of the same species. Larva in a roUed-leaf nest, resting in a fishhook posture, apple green to purplish brown, with a dark line down the back and a very dark, blackish brown head. Hibernates as part-grown larva, usually pupating in the last larval nest. Pupa buff with brown markings, attached by the cremaster. SEASONS: Continuous broods February to November (rarely December). SIMILAR SPECIES: See discussion for White Checkered Skipper, not known in our area. The Two-banded Skipper (P ruralis), is about 75 percent the size of an average Common Checkered Skipper, with a distinctly grizzled look, no blue sheen, and a complex reddish ventral hindwing pattern; it is very local with the host (Horkelia), in moist habitats near the coast. The Least Checkered Skipper (P. scriptura) is 65 percent (early spring) to only 50 percent the size of the Common; it has more black in the wing pattern, especially in summer broods where white above may be reduced to small dots; the underside hindwing pattern is grayish and different in detail from that of the Common (see pi. 28). It prefers hot inland areas, often alkaline, with aUcaU mal low. Both species may co-occur with the Common Checkered Skipper. The Northern White Skipper (Heliopetes ericetorum) averages 115 percent the size of the Common Checkered Skipper; the male has the upper surface nearly all white except near the margins; the female has a checkered pattern that is incomplete in the middle of the wings; the underside of the hindwing has a wavy brown line in the middle and is not checkered. It is found in sunny, open country, especially chaparral, and is scarce.

In the populations from the Coto Brus area I found that the males are encountered very locally in small groups of two to six individuals between 7:30 and 8 a.m. During this brief window of time, they are found perching along forest edges from 3 to 5 m above the ground only on particular trees.

Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Sarota gamelia Godman and Salvin, 1886 FW length: 10.5-11.5 mm Plate 15 Range: Guatemala to Panama Hostplant: Unknown Early stages: Unknown • Adult: Sexes similar. Upperside dull brown. When viewed from underside many specimens have a bright yellow fringe on distal margins of both wings and a long tuft of black at HW tomus. In other specimens this fringe may be a more subdued yellow, but it is distinct. Un derside red set with pale metallic blue lines, a distinct medial yellow triangle at FW costa, and another submarginal yellow patch near the tomus, medial area on HW with three red chains that have black centers in each link, and distal margin of tomus with a black tuft. The legs are entirely yellow. Note: Populations from the Pacific slope from 1100 to 1600 m associated with premontane wet forest habitats in the Coto Bnis area may represent a different species from gamelia. These individuals are distinguished as follows: upperside dark brown; underside with two elongate metallic green bands near FW apex and two short ones distal to the cell, both parallel to the costa; an indistinct yellowish medial mark at the FW costa; three black spots on FW: one in sub apex, one in tomus, and a third much larger medial one between tomus and posterior mar gin of the cell; distal margins of both wings with a thin band of dull yellow; HW with a dis tinct tuft of long black fringe at tomus and inner margin, another shorter tuft at tomus and distal margin, and often less distinct me dial tufts at distal margin. The legs are dark brown with cream-yellow tibia and tarsi, and the male forelegs are entirely cream-yellow. Compare with myrtea, acantus, psaros, gyas.  Habits: This butterfly has been recorded in our area from 400 to 1600 m on both slopes in association with rain forest, deciduous forest, and premontane wet forest habitats. In populations found below 1000 m, both sexes may be encountered as solitary individuals between 10:00 and 12:30 hrs along forest edges and light gaps where they perch from 2 to 5 m above the ground. In the populations from the Coto Brus area I found that the males are encountered very locally in small groups of two to six individuals between 7:30 and 8 a.m. During this brief window of time, they are found perching along forest edges from 3 to 5 m above the ground only on particular trees. The flight is very fast and erratic, and individuals often engage in whirling aerial dogfights that typically last for a few seconds. After a dogfight, each individual returns abruptly to a particular perch, which may change during the course of the daily activity period. The butterflies may perch either on the upper or underside of leaves, but always in a position that is illuminated by direct sunshine. At Las Alturas, I noted that this species was often in the company of Euselasia hieronymi, E. argentea, and Sarota acantus. Again, it may be that there are two species covered in this account. Uncommon in Costa Rican collections. Localities: [C]: Turrialba (August), Juan Viñas (February, March). [SJ]: El Rodeo (July), Carrillo (February). [H]: la Selva (April, May), Plastico (March). [P]: Carrara (October, November), Buenos Aires (March), Rincon de Osa (February), Las Cruces (June), Las Alturas (August, September). [L]: Guapiles (September), la Florida (March). [G]: Pitilla (October).

Book: The Butterfly Fauna of Sri Lanka
Common.name: Apefly
Distribution.Range: Sri Lanka
Hostplant.larval.food: feeds on mealybugs
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Chapter 6  The Blues: Lycaenidae  Introduction to the Lycaenidae The members of the Lycaenidae (Lycaenids) are widely distributed and the family comprises about 5000 species worldwide. The majority of the species are found in the tropics, and about 30% of all species of butterflies in the world belong to this family. The adults are small to medium-sized butterflies. Most species are some shade of iridescent blue or purple on the uppers idc of the wings, with various patterns and colors on the underside. Despite their common group name, the "Blues", many species have no blue, but are varying shades of red, orange, brown or black.  Distinguishing characters: Members of this family are distinguished by the following characters in the adult: The antennae are set close together on top of the head and the eyes are large and close together. Many species have eyespots on the underside of the hindwing and hair-like tails. In the male, the front legs are reduced in most species. In the forewing, the radial vein has only 3 or 4 of the 5 branches (usually R3 and R4 are missing). The hindwing usually has two anal veins, but no humeral vein. A typical Lycaenid wing venation is illustrated in Fig. 6-1. Adult behavior: The adults are generally moderate to strong fliers despite their small size though some species have a weak, fluttering flight. Most species feed on the nectar of flowers; others feed on fruit, tree sap or decaying matter. Several species mudsip. They are generally found in open sunny places though some species are forest or canopy dwellers. Many species have tornal spots and tails on the hindwing; at rest, they sit head-down and move their hindwings rhythmically so that the tornal spots and tails imitate the head of an adult butterfly when viewed from the side. A predator that is deceived by the false head and attacks it would be rewarded with only a mouthful of wing. Some species have additional lobing on the hindwing, and when these individuals are viewed from behind, they too present a false head with eyes and antennae.  Immature stages: The egg is usually a smooth or a pitted flattened dome though in some species, the egg is almost spherical. The color ranges from white to cream to orange. The larva is usually flattened and slug-like (onisciform), triangular in cross-section, and with a small retractable head. The larvae of many Lycaenids are associated with ants and these have three specialized organs to interact with them: a single dorsal nectar organ (DNO) on segment A7, a pair of tentacle organs (TO) on segment AS and minute pore cupola organs (PCO) distributed over the dorsal surface of the body (Figs. 6-3a, b). The DNO is a complex structure, consisting of four glandular cells below the skin that secrete a mixture of sugars and amino acids into a central sac. When it chooses, the larva releases a drop of this mixture to the surface. These secretions are used as a source of food by the ants associated with the larva. The TO consists of an eversible tentacle with fine filaments at its tip (Fig. 6-5b). 1his structure produces substances that affect the behavior of the associated ants, particularly when the larva is threatened or is on the move. The PCOs are single-celled epidermal glands that secrete substances that are attractive to ants. Two types of ant-larval associations have been recognized among the Lycaenidae. Obligate myrmecophiles ("ant-lovers") are those species in which the larva requires the presence of ants for their survival. In many species that belong to this category, the larva is susceptible to fungal diseases if the sugar secretions are not removed from the DNO by the ants. Further, the female of many species will not lay eggs unless the correct species of ant is present on the larval food plant. Facultative myrmecophiles are butterfly species whose larvae can survive without the presence of ants though they are often attended by ants. The larvae of some species live within an ant nest. The pupa is usually short and rounded with a girdle around the middle and is usually attached to the larval food plant with a pad of silk to which the anal hooks attach; it has no cremaster. In those species without a girdle, the pupa is usually positioned at an angle to the substrate or is suspended with its head down. Many species pupate in crevices or a centimeter or so under the soil or under leaf detritus on the ground. Some pupae, like the larvae, have PCOs and remain attended by ants. The larvae of many species feed on leaves, but some feed on the reproductive parts of flowers, or on fruits or seeds. Many plant families are used including the Leguminosae, Sapindaceae, Oipterocarpaceae, Primulaceae, Zingiberaceae and Rhamnaceae. The larva of one species in Sri Lanka, the Apefly (Spalgis epeus), is carnivorous and feeds on mealybugs (Insecta : Pseudococcidae). The immature stages of 22 species of Lycaenids and their larval food plants were documented in van der Poorten & van der Poorten (20 12b, 20 13b), 18 of them for the first time. Many of the other species have previously been described, though mostly from Indian material. The immature stages and larval food plants of the Tamil Oakblue (Arhopala bazaloides lanka) were described in error in van der Poorten & van der Poorten (2013b) as those of Ormiston's Oakblue (Arhopala ormistoni), whose immature stages are still unknown. As of this writing, the immature stages and larval food plants of several other species are still not known in Sri Lanka: Hampson's Hedge Blue (Acytolepis lilacea moorei), Plain Hedge Blue ( Celastrina lavendularis lavendularis), Pointed Lineblue (Jonolyce helicon viola), White-tipped Lineblue (Prosotas noreia noreia), White Hedge Blue ( Udara akasa mavisa), Singalese Hedge Blue ( Udara singalensis), Clouded Silverline (Spindasis nubilus), Plumbeous Silverline (Spindasis schistacea), Indian Red Flash (Rapala iarbus sorya), Malabar Flash (Rapala lankana), Common Onyx (Horaga onyx cingalensis), Brown Onyx (Horaga albimacula viola), and Ceylon Indigo Royal (Tajuria arida). In this publication, the immature stages and larval food plants of the following species in Sri Lanka are described for the first time from our records unless indicated otherwise: Silver Forgetme-not ( Catochrysops panormus lithargyria); Opaque 6-Lineblue (Nacaduba beroe minima) (T.S. Priyadarshana, pers. comm. and S. Sanjeewa, pers. comm.); Dark Ceylon 6-Lineblue (Nacaduba calauria toxopeusi) (S. Sanjeewa, pers. comm. and H. D. Jayasinghe, pers. comm.); Woodhouse's 4-Lineblue (Nacaduba ollyetti) (in part, H.D. Jayasinghe, pers. comm.); Dingy Lineblue (Petrelaea dana) (T. Ranasinghe, pers. comm.); Long-banded Silverline (Spindasis lohita lazularis) (T. Ranasinghe, pers. comm.); and Indigo Flash (Rapala varuna Lazulina) (T. Ranasinghe, pers. comm.). The immature stages and larval food plants of the following species have been confirmed and are presented in this publication: Transparent 6-Lineblue (Nacaduba kurava prominens) (H.D. Jayasinghe, pers. comm.).  Taxonomy: The Lycaenidae are classified under eight subfamilies of which four are represented in Sri Lanka: Curetinae (1 species), Miletinae (1 species), Polyommatinae (48 species including 6 endemic species and 9 endemic subspecies under 27 genera) and Theclinae (35 species including 4 endemic species and 12 endemic subspecies under 18 genera). These 85 species represent 35% of the butterfly fauna of Sri Lanka. Information about each subfamily is given in the text preceding the accounts of the species in that subfamily.  Conservation issues: In the National Red List 2012, 41 species of Lycaenidae are classified as LC (Least Concern). Twelve species are classified as CR (Critical), while 12 are classified as EN (Endangered), 10 as VU (Vulnerable), 4 as NT (Near Threatened) and 5 as DO (Data Deficient). One species, Arhopala bazaloides Lanka, was not included in the list as its existence in Sri Lanka was not confirmed at the time of the report. [images] Fig. 6·1. Wing venation. Lycaenidae. Theclinae. Thecla. The dark spot near the end of the discal cell on the forewing is a scent patch. D=discal cell. A3=3A. A1+2=A1+A2. From Borror et al. (1989); Fig. 6·2. Plain Hedge Blue (Celastrina l. lavendularis) male in flight; Fig. 6·3. Lycaenidae. a) Ceylon Silverline (Spindasis ictis ceylonica), larva showing TOs with filaments exserted, DNO, and numerous PCOs, dorsolateral view; b) same as a), dorsal view; c) immature stages of Ceylon Cerulean (Jamides coruscans): egg, larva, pupa.

Author: anne.lott
Full.Species.Account: Spialia dromus (Plotz, 1884) Large Grizzled Skipper, Forest Sandman (plate 11) Black, the forewing dotted with white, three of these dots being in the cell. Hindwing with a kidney-shaped white central patch and a few dots before margin. Fringes chequered. Underside of hindwing yellowish ochreous with a complete but irregular white band across the middle and with other white markings. Forewing 0.4-0.45". Bush or forest, often settling on grass or other low plants. Natal, Transvaal, Bechuanaland, Rhodesia, Moҫambique; to tropical Africa, Foodplants: Hermannia (?), Triumfelta.

Book: Butterflies of West Africa: Text Volume
Common.name: Dromus Grizzled Skipper
Distribution.Range: There are records of this butterfly from the Gambia, Senegal (many), northern Sierra Leone, Burkina Faso, northern Guinea, northern Côte d’Ivoire, northern Ghana, Volta, and most of Nigeria. It will eventually be found in Guinea-Bissau, Togo, and Bénin, but is probably genuinely absent from the Cross River loop. It penetrates to the coast along the Accra Plains and near Lagos (Badagry Creek beaches). The species is practically pan-African (TL the DRC), except that it does not occur inside the main equatorial forest zone.
Abundance: The Dromus Grizzled Skipper is considerably scarcer than S. spio, though still not uncommon.
Habitat: The Dromus Grizzled Skipper is a slightly better colonizer of cleared agricultural lands than S. diomus. It does not occur inside the main equatorial forest zone, evidently not being a good colonizer of disturbed areas.
Hostplant.larval.food: The host-plants are Sterculiaceae (Melhania, Waltheria) and Tiliaceae (Triumfetta), specifically T. rhomboidea in Côte d’Ivoire Vuattoux (1999).

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: In the south this Skipper is largely confined to the wooded areas up the coast, from Port St. Johns to Natal, but in the Transvaal it spreads over the eastern mountains into the bushveld and it inhabits the whole of Rhodesia.
Abundance: This Skipper is common, but is largely confined to the wooded areas up the coast in the south, from Port St. Johns to Natal, but in the Transvaal it spreads over the eastern mountains into the bushveld and it inhabits the whole of Rhodesia, where it is abundant.
Habitat: The habitat of this species includes wooded areas, moutains, and bushveld.

QA.Comments: Thursday, November 29, 2018 - 12:48Ghost.ExtractorI had an unusually hard time reading the foodplant names for this record.
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Book: Pennington's Butterflies of Southern Africa (1978)
Distribution.Range: The eggs and larvae were recorded from Durban.
Oviposition: The egg is laid singly among young shoots.
Hostplant.larval.food: The discarded shell of the egg is not eaten. The young larva feeds on the inner surface of a young half-opened leaf. Later it feeds on leaves, where it generally eats the edges.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Eggs hatch after 7 days. In the first instar the larva grows from 1.5 to 3 mm in 8 days. In the 2nd instar the larva grows from 3 to 5 mm in 8 days. In the 3rd instar the larva grows from 5 to 8 mm in 8 days. In the 4th instar the larva grows from 8 to 12 mm in 8 days. In the 5th instar the larva grows from 12 to 20 mm in 12 days. The duration of the instars varies. Emergence of the adult from the pupa takes place after 18 days. There is a succession of broods, and the insect appears all the year round in warmer parts.
Defense.strategies: The young larva hides in the fold of a young half-opened leaf. Later it binds leaves together to form a purse-like shelter in which it lives. It sometimes crawls out to feed on adjacent leaves. Moulting and pupation take place within the \purse\"."
Author: Ghost.Extractor

Full.Species.Account: Tagiades trebellius (Hopffer, 1874) Pterygospidea Trebellius Hopffer, 1874: 41. HT [male] Celebes [Sulawesi, Indonesia] (Dep?). Races Evans (1949) listed 11 ssp., 2 of which occur'in PNG: 1. canonicus Fruhstorfer, 1910. Tagiades canonicus Fruhstorfer, 1910b: 81. HT [male] “D. Neu-Guinea” (BMNH: H. 551). Synonym: Evans (1949) listed persimilis Rothschild, 1916, [male] Utakwa River (BMNH). 2. sheba Evans, 1934. Tagiades trebellius sheba Evans, 1934: 65. HT [male] “Isabel I., 4. VI.—9. VII. 01. (A. S. Meek).” (BMNH: H. 554).Range Japan, northern Borneo, Philippines, Sulawesi, Moluccas and all islands eastwards, including Aru, mainland NG and the Solomons. In PNG, the race canonicus represents trebellius throughout the mainland and on the islands of Karkar (MgP), Umboi (MoP), Goodenough and Fergusson (MBP). The species appears to be absent in the Bismarcks. Ssp. sheba represents trebellius on Bougainville (NSP) and also throughout the Solomons. T trebellius is generally and locally common; 0-1,200 m in areas of open secondary vegetation along roads, foot tracks, creeks, and in old garden regrowth areas. Adults (PI. 2.37-39). [male] Av. 19/37. [female] Av. 23/42. Tagiades japetus is similar to trebellius (see T japetus, Adults). T nestus is harder to distinguish from trebellius. The 2 species are best separated by the distinct differences in the valvae of their male genitalia (compare in PI. II). In trebellius the valva is deeply divided so that its distal end is almost V-shaped, whereas in nestus the valva is shallowly divided and has a more U-shaped distal margin. The apex of the valva in trebellius is long and spine-like, whereas that of nestus is short and broadly serrate. A useful visual guide to the identification of [males], and especially [females], of trebellius and nestus is as follows. In trebellius the 2 HW und subapical black spots, between veins R5 and Mj, and M2, are always more or less traceable on the dark brown costal band. The spot between veins and M2 is rather nearer to the junction of these veins than the termen. In nestus the upper spot, between veins R5 and M1? is generally untraceable and the lower spot, between veins and M2, is always nearer to the termen than to the junction of these veins. Both trebellius and nestus vary throughout PNG in the extent of the HW upp white area (see PI. 2). On Bougainville (NSP), and throughout most of the Solomons, the race sheba is characterised by its much reduced white HW patch, which usually forms a band only 1 -2 mm wide, and the coalescence of the black spots to form a broad border. On the HW und the distal spots connect with the outer dark area. Therefore, this race resembles a number of the darker races (or forms) of nestus which appear to be prevalent throughout the islands of the Bismarcks, Trobriands, D’Entrecasteaux Group and Louisiades in PNG. Early Stages Those of ssp. martinus Plotz, 1884, in Japan were illustrated in colour by Shirozu and Hara (1960-62). In PNG, the early stages are as follows: Egg Pearly-white with 16 vertical ribs, almost spherical, but basally flattened. Larva Final instar (PI. 105.2949 and 2950) similar to that of japetus described above, but body paler turquoise-green. Pupa (PI. 105.2951) similar in shape to japetus but uniform pinkish-yellow or pale transluscent green, lacking markings. Foodplants Dioscorea allata (wild yam, Dioscoreaceae), a twining vine, which is also the foodplant of trebellius in Japan, according to Shirozu and Hara (1960-62). Habits Very similar to those of Tagiades japetus (see T japetus, Habits). Notes Near Bulolo (MoP) trebellius suffers frequent mortality at the pupal stage from the parasitoid wasp Brachymeria lasus (Chalcididae). A characteristic large round exit hole is left in the exuvium by the emerging adult wasp.

Distribution.Range: N.E. Laos (Xam Nua, =Sam Neua)...  C. Vietnam: Mt. Nui Mang (50 km west from Da Nang)...   Song Boung (107°40'E, 16°N)... south-east from massif l’Atuat...  Ngoc Linh N.R... the specimens collected in Ngoc Linh show similarity to the ssp. gillesi
Phenology.and.voltinism: Listed specimens collected on April and March
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Teinopalpus imperialis Hope. 1843 Plate 23, figs. 2a-c Trans. Linn. Soc. Lond. 19 (2): 131 (Teinopalpus) TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - Sylhet; Teinopalpus imperialis f. imperialis (=himalaicus; 1 -parryae): Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921:17. Tonkin (Chapa). Teinopalpus imperialis imperialis: Metaye, 1957: 84. N. Vietnam. Teinopalpus imperialis: Shinkai, 1996: 45. N. Vietnam, (Cao Bang, Pia Oac).  Teinopalpus imperialis imperialis: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 12. N. Vietnam (Lao Cai, Cao Bang). ssp. gillesi - N.E. Laos (Xam Nua, =Sam Neua). Teinopalpus imperialis gillesi Turlin, 1991: 5. N.E. Laos (Sam Neua). Holotype [male] preserved in private coll, by M. Gilles (Paris, France). Teinopalpus imperialis IgiHesi: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2000: 473. c. Vietnam (Ngoe Linh). Teinopalpus imperialis gillesl: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 12. c. Vietnam (Quang Nam, KonTum), P1.14-1. RANGE. The species ranges Nepal, Sikkim, Bhutan and Assam to N. Burma, N. Thailand, N. & N.E. Laos and N. & C. Vietnam; north to C. & W. China (Endo & Ueda, 2004).  DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. Ssp. imperialis: N. Vietnam: Hoang Lien N.P., 1 [male],23.v. 2006, 1,600 m (S R ); Pia Oac N.R., 1 [female], 17.IV.1994, 1900 m (AS); ssp. gillesi: C. Vietnam: Mt. Nui Mang (50 km west from Da Nang) 22.IV.1937; recorded by M. Gilles (Turlin, 1991), Song Boung (107°40'E, 16°N) at 1,500 m, south-east from massif l’Atuat, M. Gilles (Turlin, 1991). Ngoe Linh N.R., 2 [female], 27.III, 1998; 05.IV, 1998; 1 [male], 7.IV.2006 (A LM ). Length of FW: [male] 52 mm; [female] 50 52 mm; TAXONOMIC NOTES. It is possible that the northern populations belong to the nominate subspecies while the specimens collected in Ngoe Linh show similarity to the  ssp. gillesi. However the material so far collected is insufficient for confirmation.  HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The males generally occupy summits or ridges above 2000 m, which they patrol, often choosing the tree tops to rest. In Ngoe Linh N.R. at  2,400 m the butterflies’ activity time is from 8.30-9.00 a.m. to 12.00-13.00 midday. Haribal (1992) notes: the males patrolling their territory have a rest “...they sit with their wings wide open or half open often motionless: they do not even respond to human touch. The males visit damp patches and also suck moisture from leaves. As soon as it becomes cloudy they stop all activity. The females are also seen flying to the summits and these are mostly virgins in search of males. The females fly on cloudy days as well as during showers and they also like sunny spells. Flight is very fast and flitting. They rarely visit flowers or damp patches...” According to Igarashi (1987) females lay eggs on the upper surface of the leaves of Magnolia campbelii (Magnoliaceae). Larvae prefer young leaves. Even though the eggs are laid on mature leaves larvae move and feed on the young  purple leaves. It keeps to the upperside of the leaves and when not feeding it rest on a silk pad spun on the leaf. It avoids direct sun light. The duration of the larval stage is about 50 days. In Ngoe Linh females were collected within montane riverine forest at 1,700 m.  SIMILAR SPECIES. Teinopalpus aureus: in the male the golden discal patch on the UpH covers approximately 1/2 of the cell; in the female the discal line on the HW is  curved inwardly at the basal area. CONSERVATION STATUS. This species is included in Appendix II of CITES and it is also listed by IUCN/SSC as a rare species in need conservation (New & Collins, 1991).

Author: michael.belitz
Full.Species.Account: Orphan data from Teinopalpus aureus account: 26. Teinopalpus aureus Mell, 1923 (Vietnam) [Plate Nos. 36-37] [Foodplants] [Habits] their preference of misty and airy broadleaf forest environment is the same as of T. imperialis. Wheras, the males of T. imperialis have the peak of their activities between 10-12 a.m...; ...eat the entire eggshell...except for the bottom; the preference by T. imperialis of the leaf tips and the soft part in the neighborhood thereof; It has a habit of bending the anterior half of its body sideways at an angle of about 45°...; The silken girth spun in pupation is very long and thin in both T. aureus and T. imperialis.;...By contrast T. imperialis adults exrete the fluid outside the pupal exuvium after emerging out of it.; [Distribution] Whereas the closely related T. imperialis occurs inland the continent of Asia such as in Nepal, Sikkim, Bhutan, N India, Myanmar, Laos, Vietnam, and W China...; [Morphology] In adult morphology, the common traits and differences between T. imperialis and T. aureus are, in short, as follows. T. imperialis: On the head, the frontoclypeus and labial palpus are elongated, and protrude. The antennae are short and brown in color. The proboscis is short. The forewing length is about 47.0-48.0mm in the male, and about 56.0-58.0mm in the female. The apex of the forewing is acutely angled. On the hindwing, the tail and the 6th veins are prominently elongated. The legs are short, and have no scent hair. In the male genitalia, the superuncus covers the uncus, which is distally trilobed. The phallus is curved in the shape of a C.

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Adult.food: T. zoilus females appeared to be more active than males, particularly while feeding on Parsonsia sap,
Mimicry: Tellervo species are also apparently extensively mimicked by other Lepidoptera for the same reason (e.g. as discussed by Ackery, 1987a) (see also Chapter 8). For example, various Neptis species closely resemble T. zoilus and its relatives and, as noted by Waterhouse (1937), N. praslini even has yellow eyes in life, like those of zoilus.
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Subfamily ITHOMIINAE Kirby, 1894 Genus TELLERVO Kirby, 1894 According to the cladistic revision by Ackery (1987a), the Old World section of this nymphalid subfamily contains only 6 tailless species in a single genus, Tellervo Kirby, 1894. D’Abrera (1978) recognised 7 species. Common and Waterhouse (1981) referred to Tellervo as monotypic, containing only the supposedly very variable T zoilus. The genus is centred on the Australian Subregion and ranges from Ambon, Seram, Kai and Aru, eastwards throughout mainland NG, to the Bismarcks, Solomons and the Cape York Peninsula of Queensland in northern Australia. These fairly small butterflies have been popularly included (together with their many South American relatives) in the subfamily Ithomiinae, a taxon accorded the rank of a family by many authors and which was estimated by Ehrlich and Raven (1964) to contain from 300-400 species in 30-40 genera. However, Ehrlich (1958a) nomenclatorially downgraded Fox’s (1956) revision of the Tthomiidae’ to arrive at 2 tribes under the Ithomiinae: Tellervini and Ithomiini. This arrangement is considered here to be correct as the characters of the larvae and pupae of Tellervo, including their larval foodplant relations, clearly demonstrate that this group of nymphalids has very close affinities with the Neotropical Ithomiinae (see especially colour plates in Brown and Freitas, 1994). In addition to this, the treatment of Tellervo within the Ithomiinae is in keeping with the overall ‘balance’ of classification of the Nymphalidae (and other butterfly families) adopted here, as well as nomenclatorially emphasising (rather than obscuring) its closest relatives. The latter is most important in any consideration of the biogeographical origins of Tellervo (see Chapter 4). Noting that the Danainae + Ithomiinae obviously form a monophyletic group, Scott (1985) suggested that they are best treated as a single subfamily. Scott’s suggestion may yet prove to be the most ‘realistic’ level of classification for these nymphalids in comparison with the taxonomic divisions of other butterfly families. In spite of Ehrlich’s and Scott’s above-mentioned findings, Ackery and Vane-Wright (1984: 17, 61) stated that they could not recognise the sister-species group of the Danainae amongst the Ithomiini and Tellervini. They followed several other authors, including Forbes (1939) and Clark (1948), in treating Tellervo in its own subfamily, Tellervinae, equal in rank to Ithomiinae and Danainae. A number of early authors (e.g. van Eecke, 1914) referred to Tellervo under the subfamily name Palaeotropinae Haase, 1891, which is invalid, not being based on a valid included genus. Hamadryadinae Reuter, 1896, as a family-group name, is rendered invalid by Hamadryas Boisduval, 1832, being a junior homonym of Hamadryas Hubner, 1806. On the basis of a careful study of the early stages and larval habits of T zoilus, Okayama (1914) concluded that Tellervo represented a primitive subfamily of the ‘Danaidae’, and that the ‘Satyridae’ must, therefore, be more distantly related than previously indicated from a study of Tellervo adults alone. Forbes (1939) suggested that the Danainae and Satyrinae were “alike” as groups. Fox (1956) maintained that the Tthomiidae’ are closely related to the Satyrinae, and Miller (1968: 131) agreed that they “are not far removed from the satyrid complex”. However, based on a study of the early stages and behavioural ecology of the 2 subfamilies by Gilbert and Ehrlich (1970), Miller’s view of the supposed close relationship of Danainae and Satyrinae was shown to be erroneous. As outlined above, the closest relatives of Tellervo are the Ithomiinae and Danainae and the 3 groups clearly constitute a monophyletic unit. The most recent study of Ithomiinae by Brown and Freitas (1994) also suggests this. They found Tellervo to be phylogenetically 1 of the earliest (and thus most primitive) ithomiines. The work is notable for its colour photographic depiction of most of the mature larvae and pupae of 66 species in 40 out of the 53 genera of the Neotropical Ithomiinae, plus line-drawing figures of their eggs. The type species for Tellervo is zoilus (Fabricius, 1775), designated by author. The species was treated by a number of early authors under the genus Hamadryas Boisduval, 1832, but this name was preoccupied by Hamadryas Hubner, 1806, which applies to a large group of Neotropical nymphalines. In a study of Tellervo, Strand (1911c) treated the 4 species known at the time as races of zoilus. Joicey and Talbot (1922d) later described a distinctive new species, T jurriaansei, from the Menoo River and Mount Kunupi in the Weyland Mountains of Irian Jaya, which has pale yellowish hindwing patches (instead of the usual white of the genus). They also described 4 new subspecies of 2 other species. One of these, T parvipuncta, from Numfoor, Supiori, and Biak (Korrido) in the Schouten Islands group of Irian Jaya, was later treated by D’Abrera (1978) as a distinct species. T jurriaansei and T parvipuncta are the only 2 of the 6 Tellervo species which do not occur in PNG, apparently being endemic to Irian Jaya. Ackery (1987a) found that T jurriaansei was the most distinctive species of its genus in many characters, including its wing colour and pattern, venation, male genitalia and certain abdominal scales. Ackery and Vane-Wright (1984) stated that Tellervo is characterised by the lack of a dorsal hair-pencil (scent tuft) on hindwing vein Rs that is present in the ithomiine males, and by the lack of a pair of eversible abdominal hair-pencils (which are often associated with a hindwing pocket, or scent-pouch), present in Danainae. Instead, some Tellervo males bear a large diffuse (hardly distinguishable) sex-brand of androconial scales that extends across almost half of the forewing, from the inner margin (first described by de Niceville and Kuhn, 1898). Ehrlich (1958a) stated that the apical segment of the labial palpus in Tellervo is much longer than half the length of the second segment, whereas it is much shorter than half the length of the second segment in Ithomiinae. However, Fox (1956) stated that the Tellervo labial palpus is closely appressed to the head, the second segment being longest and curved, and the first segment one-fourth, and the third segment one-fifth, of the length of the second. Thus, Ackery (1987a) cautioned that the character states for Tellervo and the ithomiines were apparently transposed in Ehrlich’s study. Ackery (1987a) pointed out that, according to the 10 Ithomiinae + Tellervinae + Danainae larval tubercle formulae known at that time, only Tellervo bears a pair of dorsolateral tubercles on the metathoracic segment, and that this may be the best character by which Tellervinae may be defined, as Tellervo itself remains barely characterisable in terms of autapomorphies. In Ithomiinae the pair of dorsolateral tubercles, when present, are on the mesothoracic segment. However, Ackery also suggested that the white testes, as yet confirmed only for T zoilus by Emmel et al. (1974), may also eventually prove useful. Harvey (1991) pointed out, however, that an apparently unique apomorphic character that supports the monophyly of this group is the absence of filiform setae on the mature larval meso- and metathorax of Danaus (Danainae) and Tithorea (Ithomiinae), whereas in all other Nymphalidae these setae (of possibly sound-receptive function) are present on both segments (albeit not in full complements, except in Nymphalini and Melitaeni). However, Harvey was not able to study Tellervo and suggested that its filiform setal configuration would help resolve the relationship of Tellervo with the Danainae/Ithomiinae. It is confirmed here that the filiform setal configuration (i.e. pairs present in the normal positions on the prothorax, but absent on the meso- and metathoracic segments) in mature larval Tellervo, as well as in Euploea (pers. obs.), is as Harvey observed in Danaus and Tithorea. This supports Harvey’s suggestion that Danainae/Ithomiinae are a monophyletic group. Okayama (1914) pointed out that the pupa, apart from some black spots, is entirely yellow [or pale green] and lacks any of the metallic gold (or silver) ornamentation typical of danaine pupae, especially those of Euploea. In a study of the chromosomes of T. zoilus Emmel et al. (1974) suggested that its haploid number (n) of n = 32 is particularly interesting because it differs radically from the usual karyotypic numbers for the New World ithomiines, of which the majority fall between n = 11 and n = 27 (with only a few species at n = 31, 41, 45 or 48). Two of the chromosome pairs are notably larger than the remainder and possibly represent the 2 X sex chromosomes present in all male Lepidoptera. As in the New World ithomiines, the Tellervo antenna is scaled, whereas it is unsealed in the Danainae. The eye is smooth and, interestingly, is bright yellow in life. The female forelegs have a 5-segmented tarsus. Forewing vein 3A is present, but anastomoses subbasally with vein 1A+2A. The cells of both wings are closed by tubular discocellular veins. The forewing bears a short recurrent veinlet (vestigial in T. jurriaansei). The male genitalia (PI. XVI) are simple and a gnathos is present, the brachia of which are spiniform. Ackery and Vane-Wright (1984) suggested that, besides their morphological characters, probably a good character to establish the grouping of Ithomiinae + Tellervinae + Danainae will prove to be their use of pyrrolizidine alkaloids (PAs). Males of both the Ithomiinae and Danainae are known to be attracted to PA- containing plants (Pliske et al., 1976). These are necessary in the production of danaidone and similar pheromones used in courtship of their females (e.g. Pliske and Eisner, 1969; Pliske, 1975b). However, Tellervo males are not apparently attracted to any plants in this way (pers. obs. during over 4 years of field studies in NG, and lack of any reports to the contrary in the literature), which might be expected from their.lack of hair- pencils, and the presence of just sex-brands on the wings in males of only certain species. The issue is still open to speculation, however, as R. Smiles (pers. comm., 1985) noted that 1 Tellervo male came to dry (and, therefore, otherwise unattractive) artificial PA bait, placed in a trap under dense primary forest, during field trials in PNG. Also intriguing is the observation by, A. Orr (in Ackery, 1987a) that T zoilus females appeared to be more active than males, particularly while feeding on Parsonsia sap, when they use their antennae to test the stems before probing with their proboscides. In the above-mentioned chromosomal study of zoilus by Emmel et al. (1974) it was suggested from their findings that the species has a “primitive” chromosomal number: “It seems possible that the ancestors of the genus Tellervo reached Australia at a period near the beginning of differentiation within the Ithomiinae, which presumably originated from a nymphaloid ancestral stock with n = 31, the modal number within the Nymphalidae as a family and the Lepidoptera as an order.” Certainly most authors who have specialised in the study of the Ithomiinae and related groups consider Tellervo to be a ‘primitive’ genus. This is probably reflected in such morphological characters as their lack of specialised male androconia, the presence in the male genitalia of an unmodified spiniform gnathos, and an only slightly atrophied 5-segmented foreleg tarsus in the female. Van Eecke (1915b) illustrated a hypothetical wing pattern for the Tellervo ancestor. (The origin and zoogeography of Tellervo is discussed in Chapter 4.) A feature of Tellervo which is similar to that of Danainae is their utilisation of larval foodplants in the families Apocynaceae and Asclepiadaceae (see T. zoilus, Foodplants), particularly Parsonsia (Apocynaceae) which was considered by Edgar (1982, 1984) to be closely related to the ancestral foodplants of the danaines. However, the New World ithomiines are known to feed primarily on the alkaloid-rich Solanaceae (Ehrlich and Raven, 1964), as well as some on Apocynaceae (Young, 1978). For example, the co-evolutionary relationships of Neotropical ithomiine nymphalids with their solanaceous foodplants has been discussed in detail by Drummond (1986). Although correctly treated with scepticism by most, a long-perpetuated error in the literature (e.g. Okayama, 1914; Common and Waterhouse, 1981) is the suggestion that some Tellervo feed as larvae on Aristolochia (Aristolochiaceae). The various toxic secondary substances of apocynaceous and asclepiadaceous plants are known to be sequestered by danaine larvae for the chemical protection of the larva-to-adult stages of the butterflies from predators. Consequently, danaines are frequently mimicked by other Lepidoptera. Tellervo species are also apparently extensively mimicked by other Lepidoptera for the same reason (e.g. as discussed by Ackery, 1987a) (see also Chapter 8). For example, various Neptis species closely resemble T. zoilus and its relatives and, as noted by Waterhouse (1937), N. praslini even has yellow eyes in life, like those of zoilus. Tellervo adults are known to roost gregariously at night in groups of up to 8 (Lindgren, 1975), behaviour mostly associated with distasteful species. The following key to PNG Tellervo species has been modified from Ackery (1987a): 1. a) S with a well-developed FW upp cubital ‘androconial’ patch; the FW und cell basal streak, when present, usually elongate, extending from the extreme base to almost opposite the point of origin of vein CuA1 ....>2 b) 8 usually lacking such a patch; the FW und cell basal streak, when present, is usually shorter: seldom extending right to the cell base, and usually not approaching the point of origin of vein CuA1 .......... >3 2. a) HW und cell CuA1 with a pale basal marking; HW patch usually short and often somewhat rounded, occasionally divided towards the inner margin......................= zoilus b) HW und cell CuA1 uniformly dark basally; HW patch elongate, somewhat parallel-sided and usually continuous to the inner margin .....................= assarica 3. a) HW und with discal bar divided along vein CuA1, forming an isolated discal element in cell CuA1:FW postdiscals usually united to form a band from toward vein CuA1 ...............................................= heiro b) HW bar usually continuous across vein CuAj; when occasionally divided the FW postdiscals do not form a continuous band .............................................= nedusia

Book: Butterflies of Costa Rica Volume 2: Riodinidae
Distribution.Range: Range: Uncertain, but probably Mexico to Panama, Colombia on both slopes During March 1979, I found this butterfly to be especially abundant on Isla del Caño off the coast of the Osa Peninsula Localities: [H]: Chilamate (July). [P]: Cauhita (December), Palmar Norte (September), Isla del Caño (March), Sirena (February). [G]: La Cruz (November).
Habitat: on both slopes
Oviposition: The egg is laid singly on vigorously growing shoots and leaves, always in the presence of Azteca ants.
Hostplant.larval.food: Hostplant: Omphalea diandra (Euphorbiaceae), Inga sp. (Fabaceae)...When not feeding, the later instar caterpillars rest in leaves that may be some distance from the shoots.
Adult.food: Both sexes visit flowers of Casearia, Terminalia, Psychotria, Cordia, Pentaclethra, Inga, and herbaceous Asteraceae.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Localities: [H]: Chilamate (July). [P]: Cauhita (December), Palmar Norte (September), Isla del Caño (March), Sirena (February). [G]: La Cruz (November).
Defense.strategies: Pupation typically takes place inside the edge of a leaf that has been curled over and fixed with silk.
Adult.forms: Sexes dimorphic
Ant.associations: The egg is laid singly on vigorously growing shoots and leaves, always in the presence of Azteca ants....
Author: david.lohman
Full.Species.Account: Theope virgilius (Fabricius, 1793) FW length: 17.5-19 mm Range: Uncertain, but probably Mexico to Panama, Colombia Hostplant: Omphalea diandra (Euphorbiaceae), Inga sp. (Fabaceae) Early stages (Figs. 3e, 55a): Egg—white, rounded, flat lozenge shape that gives the im pression of an overinflated inner tube con tained in a coarse net that has been cut off around the slightly bulging dorsum, leaving a ropelike edge; the micropylar vents appear to be located under the ropy edge; lateral surface smooth, but the bulging dorsal surface is cov ered in a slightly raised pattern of polygons. The egg is laid singly on vigorously growing shoots and leaves, always in the presence of Azteca ants. Caterpillars—all instars have a pale green body; they fold leaf edges and rest in side the folds. Mature caterpillar—pale green with a scattering of small, indistinct white spots over dorsum; conspicuous anal plate with a homy texture, trimmed in black (in cluding the tentacle nectary organ orifices); area between tentacle nectary organs dark brown; major area on dorsal part of anal plate whitish; body trimmed at lateral edges along vent with a skirt of white setae; head capsule shiny black with an inverted, white V-shape along the frontoclypeal sutures; a dense co rona of prominent dark purple and black bal loon setae that does not entirely obscure the head when viewed from above. When not feeding, the later instar caterpillars rest in leaves that may be some distance from the shoots. Pupa—uniformly brown, roundly cylin drical, and in overall form like that of Nymphidium. Pupation typically takes place inside the edge of a leaf that has been curled over and fixed with silk. • Adult: Sexes dimorphic. Male—upperside blue with broadly black FW costa, apex, and distal margin such that the interface of the blue and black creates a straight edge cutting from the cell to the tomus; HW blue except for the distinctly black costal margin. Under side entirely creamy brown with a few, indis tinct blue dots in the HW tomus. Female—up perside similar to male except the blue is paler, the blue and black interface on the FW is not as sharply defined, and one or two blue spots are set in the black FW subapex. The fe male also has more-rounded wings. Note: Sev eral species may currently be placed under this name; in the absence of early stages, they can be separated only by details of the geni talia (D. Harvey, pers. comm.). Compare with T. eupolis, publius, cratylus, speciosa. Habits: Specimens that appear to be of this species have been recorded from sea level to 800 m on both slopes. During March 1979, I found this butterfly to be especially abundant on Isla del Caño off the coast of the Osa Peninsula. Both sexes visit flowers of Casearia, Terminalia, Psychotria, Cordia, Pentaclethra, Inga, and herbaceous Asteraceae. Localities: [H]: Chilamate (July). [P]: Cauhita (December), Palmar Norte (September), Isla del Caño (March), Sirena (February). [G]: La Cruz (November).

Book: The millennium atlas of butterflies in Britain and Ireland
Common.name: Small Skipper
Distribution.Range: The species is widespread and common in much of England and Wales, becoming less so in the north-west. It is absent from Ireland, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man, and the only Scottish records are from the early nineteenth century and may be erroneous. The Small Skipper has undergone a rapid expansion in the north-east and north-west of England since the 1970-82 survey, extending the range of the species by approximately 100 km in both regions. In the north-west the species has expanded through Cheshire, north Derbyshire, Lancashire, and West Yorkshire. In the north-east, where historically its range has always extended further north than on the western side of the Pennines, the recent expansions have seen it spread thronghout Co. Durham and into Northumberland. The nnmber of 10 km squares recorded has increased by 37% since the 1970-82 survey; The species is stable in many countries, but declines have occurred in Austria 50-75% decrease in 25 years and Luxembourg, the Netherlands, Romania, and Slovakia 15-25% decrease. Over a longer period 30-100 years its range has extended northwards perhaps in response to global warming.; Resident, range expanding; Much of Europe, as far north as the Baltic States and Denmark and east to the Urals. Also in North Africa and the Middle East. Its distribution in Europe is general stable with some northward expansion.; widespread in southern Britain and its range has expanded northwards in recent years.
Abundance: The species is widespread and common in much of England and Wales, becoming less so in the north-west. It is absent from Ireland, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man, and the only Scottish records are from the early nineteenth century and may be erroneous. Resident, range expanding; Conservation status UK BAP status: not listed. Butterfly Conservation priority: low. European status: not threatened.; Colonies may be small, both in number of individuals and in the size of habitat patch occupied, but large colonies can occur where there are extensive stands of Yokshire-log, for example in ungrazed meadows. Experiments have demonstrated that Colonies tend to be much larger than indicated by casual recording, as few individuals are active and therefore conspicuous at any one time.; a graph of combined indices [of the Small Skipper and the Essex Skipper] from BMS sites outside the cnrrent range of the Essex Skipper shows an upward trend, although the number of sites involved is small in most years. The coinbined BMS index for the two species across the whole of Britain also shows an increase in abundance over the monitoring period.; The transecct data available for the Small Skipper indicate that numbers increase significantly when the weather preceding and during the flight period is warm and dry.; The Small Skipper remains common and widespread throughout southern Britain and has made significant expansions northwards in recent decades. Its abundance at BMS sites has also increased. Although there is no cause for concern about the long-term future of this species, its overall numbers in the wider countryside have probably declined throughout much of the range due to habitat loss.
Flight.characteristics: They are marvellous flyers, manoeuvring expertly through tall grass stems. Males appear to establish territories and will dart off a favoured perch to investigate any butterflies that approach. Females are more sedentary than males and make slow deliberate egg-laying flights.
Habitat: Small Skipper colonies are found where grasses are allowed to grow tall. Typical habitats are unimproved rough grassland, downs, verges, sunny rides, and woodland clearings. Colonies can occur on small patches of suitable habitat such as roadside verges and field margins.; large colonies can occur where there are extensive stands of Yokshire-log, for example in ungrazed meadows.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid in small batches in the leaf sheaths of foodplants. The female alights on a grass stem and backs downwards, inserting her abdomen into the leaf sheath and depositing several eggs inside
Hostplant.larval.food: The Small Skipper almost exclusively uses Yorkshire-fog (Holcus lanatus), although several other grasses have been recorded as foodplants, for example Timothy (Phleum pratense), Creeping Soft-grass (H. mollis), False BRome (Brachypodium sylvaticum), Meadow Foxtail (Alopecurus pratensis), and Cock's-foot (Dactylis glomerata).; After hatching, the larvae feed on their own eggshells and then immediately enter hibernation, protected by a silken cocoon as well as the enclosing leaf sheath. .; feeding at least in the early stages within protective tubes made from rolled blades of grass held together with silk.
Adult.food: Small Skippers nectar on a wide range of plants (such as thistles, knapweeds, Red Clover, Common Bird's-foot-trefoil, and vetches), but individuals preferentially forage at flowers of the same species as previously visited. However, the butterflies switch to different species if nectar rewards are low or if the abundance of their previously preferred plants is reduced.
Phenology.and.voltinism: The species has a single generation each year and adult emergence appears to be closely synchronized across Britain, although the date varies from year to year. Typically, peak counts of adults occur in July, although individuals are regularly reported from mid-June to mid-September.; After hatching, the larvae feed on their own eggshells and then immediately enter hibernation, protected by a silken cocoon as well as the enclosing leaf sheath.; In spring, the larvae become active, feeding at least in the early stages within protective tubes made from rolled blades of grass held together with silk.; Small Skippers are insects of high summer.; larvae enter hibernation almost immediately after hatching and are not reliant on foodplant quality until the following spring.
Diapause: After hatching, the larvae feed on their own eggshells and then immediately enter hibernation, protected by a silken cocoon as well as the enclosing leaf sheath.; larvae enter hibernation almost immediately after hatching
Defense.strategies: After hatching, the larvae feed on their own eggshells and then immediately enter hibernation, protected by a silken cocoon as well as the enclosing leaf sheath.; In spring, the larvae become active, feeding at least in the early stages within protective tubes made from rolled blades of grass held together with silk.
Mobility: Small Skippers live in colonies and seem not to be particularly mobile. A study in southern England showed that two thirds of the population moved less than 20m per day, the maximum distance recorded was 280m. Elsewhere, however, Small Skippers have colonized site isolated by farmland, woodland, or urban development and the recent expansion in northern England indicated moderate mobility. Colonies may be small, both in number of individuals and in the size of habitat patch occupied, but large colonies can occur where there are extensive stands of Yokshire-log, for example in ungrazed meadows.

Book: The millennium atlas of butterflies in Britain and Ireland
Common.name: Small Skipper
Distribution.Range: The species is widespread and common in much of England and Wales. Absent from Ireland, the Channel Islands, and the Isle of Man.
Flight.characteristics: Males dart off perches. Females are more sedentary than males and make slow, deliberate egg-laying flights.
Habitat: Unimproved rough grassland, downs, verges, sunny rides, and woodland clearings. Colonies can occur on small patches of suitable habitat such as roadside verges and field margins.
Oviposition: Eggs laid in small batches in the leaf sheaths of foodplants.
Hostplant.larval.food: Almost exclusively uses Yorkshire-fog (Holeus lanatus), although several other grasses have been recorded as foodplants, for example Timothy (Phleum pratense), Creeping soft-grass (H. mollis), False Brome (Brachypodium sylvaticum), Meadow Foxtail (Alopecurus pratensis), and Cock's-foot (Dactylis glomerata).
Adult.food: They nectar on a wide range of plants (such as thistles, knapweeds, Red Clover, Common Bird's-foot-trefoil, and vetches).
Phenology.and.voltinism: Single generation each year. Peak counts of adults occur in July, although individuals are reguarly reported from mid-June through to mid-September.
Diapause: Larvae enter hibernation

Book: Butterflies of Bhutan
Common.name: Black-ringed Ochre, Common White-spot Skipper
Distribution.Range: Two generations completed annually in cc. New South Wales, but possibly several generations in north Queensland. Habitat includes elevated ranges on and near the Great Dividing Range. Local. Range extends as far inland as Carnarvon Range in c. Queensland.
Abundance: Common but local. Range extends as far inland as Carnarvon Range in c. Queensland.
Habitat: Savannah woodland and eucalypt open-forest, often with a heath understorey, in low rainfall areas from the coast to elevated ranges on and near the Great Dividing Range, preferring banks of ephemeral streams where the larval food plant grows at the base of eucalypt trees.
Hostplant.larval.food: Usually Lomandra multiflora in n. Queensland and New South Wales; also L. filiformis, L. longifolia.
Phenology.and.voltinism: Two generations completed annually in cc. New South Wales, but possibly several generations in n. Queensland.
Mobility: Males regularly congregate on hilltops where they repeatedly perch in open areas on rocks or bare patches on the ground to establish territories.
Author: minji.ku
Full.Species.Account: Other name: Common White-spot Skipper. Wingspan: male: 28 mm, female: 29 mm. Similar species: Yellow Ochre, Brown Ochre. The Black-ringed Ochre has the HW underside ground colour pale greyish-yellow, with a single white spot enclosed by a broad ring of black. Behaviour: males regularly congregate on hilltops where they repeatedly perch in open areas on rocks or bare patches on the ground to establish territories. Two generations completed annually in cc. NSW, but possibly several generations in n. QLD. Habitat: savannah woodland and eucalypt open-forest, often with a heath understorey, in low rainfall areas from the coast to elevated ranges on and near the Great Dividing Range, preferring banks of ephemeral streams where the larval food plant grows at the base of eucalypt trees. Status: common but local. Range extends as far inland as Carnarvon Range in c. QLD. Larval food plants: usually Lomandra multiflora in n. QLD and NSW; also L. filiformis, L. longifolia.
