(Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Doluduo N.CELEBES  5 [female] hephaestus 1979-May-13 Palopo C.CELEBES 6 [female] V hephaestus 1979-Jul. Palopo C.CELEBES  PLATE 26 3 [male] V hephaestus 1979-Jun. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Assam (Sylhet)... C. Vietnam : Nui Chua N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N. R., Da Teh SFE. S. Vietnam : Dong Sai (ex. Metaye coll., MNHN); Cat Tien N.p. (Cat Loc)
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troidcs Helena (Linnaeus, 1758). Plate 1, figs, a-d Syst. Nat. (ed 10)1: 461 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY : The nominate ssp. - Java; ssp. euthycrates - N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio Helena euthycrates Fruhstorfer, 1913. Neue Indo-Australishe Rhopaloceren. Dt. ent. z. Iris 27:130. N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio helena f. cerberus [male]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. azelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. gypsothelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena cerberus f. cerberus [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. azelia [female]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. gypsothelia [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Kondo & Nishida, 1998: 100. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. Indochina generally, Vietnam. Troides Helena Cerberus: Ikeda et al, 1998 (21): 13. Fig. 3/3-4: [male] Up & [female] Up, Fig. 9/2: [male] genitalia. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Troides Helena euthycrates: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N. Vietnam. ssp. cerberus - Assam (Sylhet). Troides Helena cerberus Felder, 1865. Reise der Oster. Freg. Novarra um die Erde Zool., Lep., Rhop., (1): 19. Syntype [female] preserved in BMNH. Troides Helena cerberus: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. S. Vietnam. Troides helena cerberus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS . Ssp. Cerberus Felder, 1864 has the following synonyms: pompeus Gray (1852); ruficollis Butler, 1877; Hephaestus Distant, 1885 (TL: Celebes), f. male Cerberus Jordan, 1908; f. male eumagos Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female azelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female gypsothelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Tenasserim). RANGE. C. Nepal and N. India through Burma to Indochina and s. China on the continent, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Sumbawa, Sulawesi and Tukangbesi in the archipelago. There are a number of subspecies in Sunda Islands (Haugum & Low, 1982-85). DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. Ssp. euthycrates: N. Vietnam : Cho Moi (ex coll. MNHN), Than Moi; Hanoi; Na Hang N.R., Ba Be N.P.,Tam Dao N.P., Ba Vi N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.P., Bai Tu Long N.p. C . Vietnam : Pu Huong N.R., Ben En N.P., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R. Ssp. Cerberus: c. Vietnam : Nui Chua N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N. R., Da Teh SFE. s. Vietnam : Dong Sai (ex. Metaye coll., MNHN ); Cat Tien N.p. (Cat Loc). The species is variable in size and wing pattern. In particular, the number of submarginal spots on the H W of males varies from a complete series in spaces 2-6 to entirely absent. Length of FW: [male] 65-82 mm; [female] 75-95 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES . Following the concept offered by Haugum & Low (1978-85) type specimens of ssp. euthycrates (N. Vietnam) are rather distinctive and may be distinguished from Cerberus (S. Vietnam): “Male...fairly large, perhaps slightly lager than Cerberus... The abdomen is as in Cerberus but somewhat darker laterally and dorsally. Female... H W with a complete row of black spots, which are notably triangular and also much larger than in Cerberus... Abdomen is as in Cerberus, but darker towards base” . In reality, the females from southern populations have more oval spots while in the specimens from N. and northern part of C. Vietnam spots are more elongated and pointed (Plate l-b,d). The form azelia Jordan, mentioned by Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) from Tonkin is the dark form of the female with an uncompleted series of black submarginal spots (the type from Khasia Hills). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is locally common at low and moderate elevations (e.g. in Ba Vi N.P.; Cat Tien N.P.). The imago feeds on flowering Mussaenda (Rubiaceae), Lantana (Verbenaceae) and Cinnamomum (Lauraceae). The larvae feed on species of Aristolochiaceae, in particular Aristolochia tagala, A. griffithi, A. indica (Chou, 2000; Igarashi & Fukuda, 2000) and Thottea seliquoia in the Malay Peninsula (Corbet & Pendlebury, 1992). The female lays eggs singly on the upper surface of leaves or on the stems (Haribal, 1992). SIMILAR SPECIES. Troides aeacus differs from T. Helena in having the marginal black markings in spaces 2 ,3 and 4 of H W inwardly bordered by a dusting of black scales. CONSERVATION STATUS. All species of this genus are included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (International commercial trade monitored through CITES permits)

Full.Species.Account: Troidcs Helena (Linnaeus, 1758). Plate 1, figs, a-d Syst. Nat. (ed 10)1: 461 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY : The nominate ssp. - Java; ssp. euthycrates - N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio Helena euthycrates Fruhstorfer, 1913. Neue Indo-Australishe Rhopaloceren. Dt. ent. z. Iris 27:130. N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio helena f. cerberus [male]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. azelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. gypsothelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena cerberus f. cerberus [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. azelia [female]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. gypsothelia [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Kondo & Nishida, 1998: 100. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. Indochina generally, Vietnam. Troides Helena Cerberus: Ikeda et al, 1998 (21): 13. Fig. 3/3-4: [male] Up & [female] Up, Fig. 9/2: [male] genitalia. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Troides Helena euthycrates: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N. Vietnam. ssp. cerberus - Assam (Sylhet). Troides Helena cerberus Felder, 1865. Reise der Oster. Freg. Novarra um die Erde Zool., Lep., Rhop., (1): 19. Syntype [female] preserved in BMNH. Troides Helena cerberus: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. S. Vietnam. Troides helena cerberus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS . Ssp. Cerberus Felder, 1864 has the following synonyms: pompeus Gray (1852); ruficollis Butler, 1877; Hephaestus Distant, 1885 (TL: Celebes), f. male Cerberus Jordan, 1908; f. male eumagos Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female azelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female gypsothelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Tenasserim). RANGE. C. Nepal and N. India through Burma to Indochina and s. China on the continent, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Sumbawa, Sulawesi and Tukangbesi in the archipelago. There are a number of subspecies in Sunda Islands (Haugum & Low, 1982-85). DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. Ssp. euthycrates: N. Vietnam : Cho Moi (ex coll. MNHN), Than Moi; Hanoi; Na Hang N.R., Ba Be N.P.,Tam Dao N.P., Ba Vi N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.P., Bai Tu Long N.p. C . Vietnam : Pu Huong N.R., Ben En N.P., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R. Ssp. Cerberus: c. Vietnam : Nui Chua N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N. R., Da Teh SFE. s. Vietnam : Dong Sai (ex. Metaye coll., MNHN ); Cat Tien N.p. (Cat Loc). The species is variable in size and wing pattern. In particular, the number of submarginal spots on the H W of males varies from a complete series in spaces 2-6 to entirely absent. Length of FW: [male] 65-82 mm; [female] 75-95 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES . Following the concept offered by Haugum & Low (1978-85) type specimens of ssp. euthycrates (N. Vietnam) are rather distinctive and may be distinguished from Cerberus (S. Vietnam): “Male...fairly large, perhaps slightly lager than Cerberus... The abdomen is as in Cerberus but somewhat darker laterally and dorsally. Female... H W with a complete row of black spots, which are notably triangular and also much larger than in Cerberus... Abdomen is as in Cerberus, but darker towards base” . In reality, the females from southern populations have more oval spots while in the specimens from N. and northern part of C. Vietnam spots are more elongated and pointed (Plate l-b,d). The form azelia Jordan, mentioned by Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) from Tonkin is the dark form of the female with an uncompleted series of black submarginal spots (the type from Khasia Hills). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is locally common at low and moderate elevations (e.g. in Ba Vi N.P.; Cat Tien N.P.). The imago feeds on flowering Mussaenda (Rubiaceae), Lantana (Verbenaceae) and Cinnamomum (Lauraceae). The larvae feed on species of Aristolochiaceae, in particular Aristolochia tagala, A. griffithi, A. indica (Chou, 2000; Igarashi & Fukuda, 2000) and Thottea seliquoia in the Malay Peninsula (Corbet & Pendlebury, 1992). The female lays eggs singly on the upper surface of leaves or on the stems (Haribal, 1992). SIMILAR SPECIES. Troides aeacus differs from T. Helena in having the marginal black markings in spaces 2 ,3 and 4 of H W inwardly bordered by a dusting of black scales. CONSERVATION STATUS. All species of this genus are included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (International commercial trade monitored through CITES permits)

Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Doluduo N.CELEBES  5 [female] hephaestus 1979-May-13 Palopo C.CELEBES 6 [female] V hephaestus 1979-Jul. Palopo C.CELEBES  PLATE 26 3 [male] V hephaestus 1979-Jun. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: Java
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troidcs Helena (Linnaeus, 1758). Plate 1, figs, a-d Syst. Nat. (ed 10)1: 461 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY : The nominate ssp. - Java; ssp. euthycrates - N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio Helena euthycrates Fruhstorfer, 1913. Neue Indo-Australishe Rhopaloceren. Dt. ent. z. Iris 27:130. N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio helena f. cerberus [male]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. azelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. gypsothelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena cerberus f. cerberus [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. azelia [female]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. gypsothelia [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Kondo & Nishida, 1998: 100. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. Indochina generally, Vietnam. Troides Helena Cerberus: Ikeda et al, 1998 (21): 13. Fig. 3/3-4: [male] Up & [female] Up, Fig. 9/2: [male] genitalia. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Troides Helena euthycrates: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N. Vietnam. ssp. cerberus - Assam (Sylhet). Troides Helena cerberus Felder, 1865. Reise der Oster. Freg. Novarra um die Erde Zool., Lep., Rhop., (1): 19. Syntype [female] preserved in BMNH. Troides Helena cerberus: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. S. Vietnam. Troides helena cerberus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS . Ssp. Cerberus Felder, 1864 has the following synonyms: pompeus Gray (1852); ruficollis Butler, 1877; Hephaestus Distant, 1885 (TL: Celebes), f. male Cerberus Jordan, 1908; f. male eumagos Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female azelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female gypsothelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Tenasserim). RANGE. C. Nepal and N. India through Burma to Indochina and s. China on the continent, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Sumbawa, Sulawesi and Tukangbesi in the archipelago. There are a number of subspecies in Sunda Islands (Haugum & Low, 1982-85). DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. Ssp. euthycrates: N. Vietnam : Cho Moi (ex coll. MNHN), Than Moi; Hanoi; Na Hang N.R., Ba Be N.P.,Tam Dao N.P., Ba Vi N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.P., Bai Tu Long N.p. C . Vietnam : Pu Huong N.R., Ben En N.P., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R. Ssp. Cerberus: c. Vietnam : Nui Chua N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N. R., Da Teh SFE. s. Vietnam : Dong Sai (ex. Metaye coll., MNHN ); Cat Tien N.p. (Cat Loc). The species is variable in size and wing pattern. In particular, the number of submarginal spots on the H W of males varies from a complete series in spaces 2-6 to entirely absent. Length of FW: [male] 65-82 mm; [female] 75-95 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES . Following the concept offered by Haugum & Low (1978-85) type specimens of ssp. euthycrates (N. Vietnam) are rather distinctive and may be distinguished from Cerberus (S. Vietnam): “Male...fairly large, perhaps slightly lager than Cerberus... The abdomen is as in Cerberus but somewhat darker laterally and dorsally. Female... H W with a complete row of black spots, which are notably triangular and also much larger than in Cerberus... Abdomen is as in Cerberus, but darker towards base” . In reality, the females from southern populations have more oval spots while in the specimens from N. and northern part of C. Vietnam spots are more elongated and pointed (Plate l-b,d). The form azelia Jordan, mentioned by Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) from Tonkin is the dark form of the female with an uncompleted series of black submarginal spots (the type from Khasia Hills). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is locally common at low and moderate elevations (e.g. in Ba Vi N.P.; Cat Tien N.P.). The imago feeds on flowering Mussaenda (Rubiaceae), Lantana (Verbenaceae) and Cinnamomum (Lauraceae). The larvae feed on species of Aristolochiaceae, in particular Aristolochia tagala, A. griffithi, A. indica (Chou, 2000; Igarashi & Fukuda, 2000) and Thottea seliquoia in the Malay Peninsula (Corbet & Pendlebury, 1992). The female lays eggs singly on the upper surface of leaves or on the stems (Haribal, 1992). SIMILAR SPECIES. Troides aeacus differs from T. Helena in having the marginal black markings in spaces 2 ,3 and 4 of H W inwardly bordered by a dusting of black scales. CONSERVATION STATUS. All species of this genus are included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (International commercial trade monitored through CITES permits)

Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not.  (Range) cerberus: N.lndia, Burma, Laos, Vietnam, Thailand, Malay Peninsula (=euthycrates) spilotius : Hainan, S. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus
