Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Palopo C.CELEBES 4 [male] ditto How to separate helena ttom amphrysus [Male, Key characters] (1) helena has forewing entirely black, while amphrysus has submarginal series of yellow streaks along veins beyond basal dark area which is angled at space 3. (2) hindwing, vein 7 straight in helena, slightly curved in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area brighter and glossed with gold in amphrysus, while less glossed with metalic sheen in helena. (4) hindwing, black stripe in space 2 sharply extends inward in amphrysus, while the stripe extends inward only slightly in helena. [Female, Key characters] (1) forewing basal dark area extends to submarginal portion of space 3 and angled in the space in amphrysus, while the area does not enter space 3, occupying center of cell and spaces 2-1 with its edge outwardly sloped, and submarginal white streaks in space 1a and posterior portion of space 1b well-developed in helena. (2) hindwing, basal area of cell black in helena, while the area not black in amphrysus. (3) hindwing, yellow area present in the center of space 7 near cell in amphrysus, while the area absent in helena. (4) hindwing, su bmarginal series of black spots large in amphrysus, small in helena. (5) hindwing, yellow area inwardly whitened in amphrysus (applicable only to Java), uniformly yellow in helena. (6) hindwing, tornal portion dusted with greyish white in helena, the portion without such dusting in amphrysus

Book: The Book of Indian Butterflies
Common.name: Common Birdwing
Distribution.Range: India (Orissa, Sikkim to Arunachal Pradesh, Andaman & Nicobar Islands), Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Myanmar
Abundance: Not rare
Habitat: Warmer forests, also visits open areas at forest edges
Hostplant.larval.food: Aristolochia griffithi, A. tagala. Bragantia wallichii (Aristolochiaceae).
Adult.food: Lantana flowers
Phenology.and.voltinism: March to November
Author: erin.leeds
Full.Species.Account: COMMON BIRDWING Troick's helena (Linnaeus) Wingspan: 140-170 mm. Status: Not rare. Distr.: India (Orissa, Sikkim to Arunaehal Pradesh, Andaman & Nicobar Islands), Nepal, Bhutan. Bangladesh, Myanmar. H&H: Usually seen below 900 m in warmer forests from g March to November. Forest dweller, but at times i Z also visits open areas at forest edges. Often seen g on Lantana flowers along forest paths, and Xailless mudpuddling on damp patches. Females more abundant than males. A u • HW rich silky yellow with black veins, t ' black marginal wing border. Black F without distinct vein stripes. Male UPH has dusting of black scales around inner edges marginal spots. UPH dorsum, apical oblique half of space I , triangular markings along terminal margin, base-cell and costal area up to and including basal hall ol space 7 all velvety black; veins narrow, black. One or more postdiscal black spots in spaces 2 or or both. Cream-coloured cottony scent wool in scent told. Female with prominent, broader whitish vein stripes beyond cell on FW. On HW. basal and costal black in onethird of cell, the area above cell along costa black. Series of large oval black submarginal spots on HW, the spots in spaces 2 and ?> often joined to the triangular terminal black marks; dorsum broadh' black. LF: Arisfolochia A. lii^aUh Bra^aniia wallicliii (Aristolochiaceae).

Book: Butterflies of the South East Asian Islands, Vol. I. Papilionidae
Habitat: Mt. Kinabalu... being sometimes captured in Poting Hotspring district
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troides andromache Staudinger (Original Description) [Notes] andromache Staudinger, D_E.Z. Iris, 5, p.393 (1892) marapokensis Fruhstorfer, Bed, Ent, Zeit., 43, p.419 (1898) This species is a member of the Amphrysus group and well known as an endemic species of Borneo. It prefers higher altitude compared with the rest of the congeners, having never been caught in lowland. It may be called an alpine Troides. It has been found from Mt. Kinabalu and its neighbouring mountains. It is rather small and with compact wings as is often the case with mountain species. Its markings are also peculiar, especially the characteristic white streaks on the forewing beneath are quite unique. It is scarce and counted as one of the rarities among the genus Troides. Two subspecies have been described, namely, the nominate subspecies from Mt. Kinabalu and its adjacent mountains, and marapokensis, the type locality of which is said to be Mt. Marapok of Sarawak, the other Mt. Marapokdifferent from the one to the south of Mt. Kinabalu. They are different to each other in that the male of the nominate subspecies has the forewing more pointed and smartly triangle-shaped, and the submarginal white streaks on the underside broader and triangular (pointed toward base) in shape. The mountainous area of Sarawak is difficult to approach, and for this reason the research records of the district by the Japanese are almost lacking except only few of Kuching district. No specimen of marapokensis has been brought to Japan. The sexes of andromache are quite dissimilar, the female having the upperside of forewing covered with pale brownish scale and such a type is not found in any other Troides. It is somewhat similar to the female of Ornithoptera croesus lydius in the colouring of the forewing. Its home range is at the alititude of 1000 to 2000 metres in Mt. Kinabalu, where it flies high above the canopy of the primeval forest. On Mt. Klnabalu few other Troides species occur, only helena and amphrysus being sometimes captured in Poting Hotspring district, where Troides is generally not abundant. Tetsuo Mizunuma observed this species laying eggs at Mamut mine away from Poring, and Shinji Nagai also observed the same behaviour in Headquaters. In both cases the females were laying eggs on climbing Aristolochia on huge trees, and their eggs were not obtained for climbing tree was impossible for them. Butterflies occur all the year round in Kinabalu, but the most favourable season for collecting them is from April to July. Around the end of June 1976, Tetsuo Mizunuma collected as many as forty or more. Most of them were captured at a point in a shifting farm. This ideal collecting site is a block of exposed land surrounded by heavy primeval forests, which can be reached by creeping the steep slope from the road. Tetsuo  Mizunuma, a beetle collector, found the site to collect longhorned beetles. He told us that as he was beating big fell-down timbers he was surprised by a large shadow on the white sheet he used then, and in the next second he found the shadow was that of and romache flying leisurely above. He reported that the males were particularly abundant at the site, they were flying from 10.30 to around noon, then again in the evening, and during the earlier afternoon when they were not found, the females of brookiana flew in turn. No other Troides was found there. At first he was running after them here and there, in the meantime he found that they visited Mussaenda blossom, and on this blossoming tree he collected series of them. The female flies lower than the male and is usually met with on the road or along the forest. Troides species other than andromache is hardly found at the point in Mamut too. The site in Headquaters as well as the point in Mamut is now in devastated surroundings, in fact hardly anyone succesfully collected there after 1977. As this species flies high above the canopy of the primeval forest, the capture of it is difficult unless one finds a proper point on the forest edge where Mussaenda blossoms and the species swoops down. Other species of the genus Troides with purple flush on the forewing above, are amphrysus from java and miranda from Borneo. The larval food plant undoubtedly belongs to Aristolochiaceae, but its specific name is unknown. (Range) andromache: Sabah N.BORNEO marapokensis : Sarawak N.W.BORNEO PLATE 11 1 [male] andromache 1976-Jul.-4 Mt.Kinabalu N.BORNEO 2 [male] V ditto 3 [female] andromache 1977-Jun.-12 Mt.Kinabalu N.BORNEO 4 [female] V ditto  [images] male genitalia, Troides andromache (N.BORNEO); distribution map of Troides andromache

Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troides helena Linne (Original Description) helena Linne, Syst. nat., ed. X, p.461, n.18 (1758) hephaestus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.29 (1864) cerberus C. & R. Felder, Verh. zool-bot. Ges. Wien, p.291, n.31 (1864) (B.M.) heliconoides Moore, Proc. Zool. Soc. Lond., p.529 (1877) nereis Doherty, ]ourn, As. Soc. Beng., p.30, n.47 (1891) sagittatus Fruhstorfer, Soc. Ent., 11, p.123 (1896) (B.M.) nereides Fruhstorfer, insekt-Borse, 23, p.94 (1906) (B.M.) propinquus Rothschild, Nov. Zool., 2, p.218 bis 219 (1908) maurus Fruhstorfer, Int. Ent. Z. (Guben), 2, p.238 (1908) (B.M.) isara Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) mopa Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) antileuca Rothschid, Entom., 41, p.3 (1908) (B.M.) typhaon Rothschild, Entom., 41, p.4 (1908) (B.M.) neoris Rothschild, Entom., 41, (1908) (B.M.) mosychlus Fruhstorfer, D. Ent. Z. Iris, 27, p.134 (1913) (B.M.) Ferrari Tytier, ]ourn. Bomb. Nat. Hist. Soc., 31, p.248 (1926) [Notes] This species is the submontane Troides and the most widely distributed of the birdwings. Both sexes show striking individual variations in various areas, especially in the submarginal black spots on the hindwing. It belongs to the Helena subgroup of the Helena group, being replaced by oblongomaculatus, the sister species, distributed from the Moluccas to New Guinea. Formerly oblongomaculatus was included in helena, but now it is usually treated as the separate species. Its range overlaps with that of aeacus, which also belongs to the Helena group, in the Malay Peninsula and northwards, and the two resemble each other, but their males are easily separable by that the yellow marking of space 7 on the hindwing beneath basally black-striped in the upper half in helena, while the whole space is yellow in aeacus. Their females are separable by that the series of submarginal black spots are large and shifted inwards in aeacus, while they are placed near outer margin in helena. Only aeacus has the yellow marking at the base of space 7 on the hindwing above. Species of Troides are known to be non-hydrotropic by nature, but both helena and aeacus frequently alight to suck water in the districts where the draught in the dry season is so serious as to defoliate trees, for instance, N. Thailand. This species is separated into 17 subspecies, and of which 16 subspecies are known to be distributed in the area here dealt with. As for the four subspecies which are not figured in this book, references be made to D'Abrera's 'Birdwing Butterflies' which illustrates the four subspecies. Its occurence increases in number toward the wet season, but it occurs repeatedly throughout the year. It is abundant in lowland and rarely seen above the altitude of 1000 metres. Most of subspecies are generally common except the Sumbawan subspecies which we have not seen. In S. Celebes the species is not common probably because of its competition with haliphron, but is by no means rare. Butterflies are mainly in evidence in the morning and again in the evening, when they eagerly feed on flowers of tall trees. Their flights are high but slow, sometimes descending to the forest edge. The species is common and the most predominant among the species of Troides which fly together with it in Java, Borneo, N. Celebes, the Malay Peninsula, Bali, lowlands of Sumatra and Nias. The confirmed larval food plant is Aristolochia tagala. Whole individuals figured in PLATE 18 are the males of the nominate subspecies from Java, showing their striking variability. PLATE 19, 1-8 are Javan females with the same variability. PLATE 20 figures the subspecies of Bali, Lombok and Bawean, of which Bali form is hardly separable from thenominate subspecies. The Lombok form is rather long-winged and the female is strongly whitened. The Bawean form is the unique subspecies with conspicuous black spots in the golden yellow spaces on the hindwing above and the shape of the yellow area is peculiar. The female is easily identified by the much whitened ground colour and also by the brown-tinged yellow area. PLATE 21 figures the forms from Nias and Sumatra; the male is similar, while the female is variable in Nias. PLATE 22 figures the subspecies of West Malaysia and the Andamans, where the sexes are also rather variable. 6 figures the peculiar male-like female. PLATE 23 figures the subspecies from Borneo, Engano and Kangean; mosychlus (1, 2) is similar to those from the Malay Peninsula and Sumatra except that it has the rounder wing shape. Nereis from Engano (3,4) is well whitened form with clear white vein stripes on the forewing. Both sexes of antileuca from Kangean (5,6) are larger and dark, and a peculiar subspecies. Hephaestus figured in PLATE 24 is the markedly large and prominent Celebesian subspecies, the variable females ranging from the male-like dark form to the whitened form as of 5,6, but the individual of 4 is the normal one. There will be a controversy about the individual figured in PLATE 26-3, 4. Three S. Celebes ian males of this form are preserved in Tsukada Collection besides the figured ones. They have the longer forewing similar to criton rather than helena, and have the black area along the inner margin well-developed, and thus resemble criton from Halmahera. Instead of the black valva characteristic of the Haliphron group, the figured individuals have the white ones, which clearly indicate that they belong to the Helena group (especially the valva of criton is unusually black). In'this book we name them helena hephaestus and explain as a hybrid between this species and haliphron, but there remains some question as they invariably have the same wing contour and markings, in spite of the fact that several specimens were obtained in different seasons. In view of the faunastic peculiarity of Celebes, where many relics of the older age remain, they might belong to an entirely different species other than helena or criton. At present we have no female corresponding to the males. We are looking forward to checking the sex. Wallace (in Trans, Linn. Soc. Lond. 25,1865, p.39) described celebensis, a new subspecies of criton, together with leda (= hephaestus). D' Abrera treated the subspecies as that of criton in S. Celebes though he did not figure it, regarding it as the same taxon with aphimedon Boisduval and leda Staudinger. A publication of the British Museum (Natural History) relate that the male syntype was designated for the above celebensis. It is not certain whether the type from Macassar (1910), the above mentioned three specimens and the figured individual (PLATE 6-4) belong to the same taxon or not. Book: Butterflies of Vietnam Volume 2: Papilionidae
Distribution.Range: C. Nepal and N. India through Burma to Indochina and s. China on the continent, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Sumbawa, Sulawesi and Tukangbesi in the archipelago. There are a number of subspecies in Sunda Islands (Haugum & Low, 1982-85)
Abundance: locally common at low and moderate elevations
Habitat: The species is locally common at low and moderate elevations (e.g. in Ba Vi N.P.; Cat Tien N.P.)
Oviposition: The female lays eggs singly on the upper surface of leaves or on the stems (Haribal, 1992)
Hostplant.larval.food: The larvae feed on species of Aristolochiaceae, in particular Aristolochia tagala, A. griffithi, A. indica (Chou, 2000; Igarashi & Fukuda, 2000) and Thottea seliquoia in the Malay Peninsula (Corbet & Pendlebury, 1992)
Adult.food: The imago feeds on flowering Mussaenda (Rubiaceae), Lantana (Verbenaceae) and Cinnamomum (Lauraceae)
Adult.forms: Papilio helena f. Cerberus [male]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin; Papilio helena f. azelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkinl Papilio helena f. gypsothelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin
Author: Jomar.Hinolan
Full.Species.Account: Troidcs Helena (Linnaeus, 1758). Plate 1, figs, a-d Syst. Nat. (ed 10)1: 461 (Papilio) TYPE LOCALITY : The nominate ssp. - Java; ssp. euthycrates - N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio Helena euthycrates Fruhstorfer, 1913. Neue Indo-Australishe Rhopaloceren. Dt. ent. z. Iris 27:130. N. Vietnam (Than Moi). Papilio helena f. cerberus [male]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. azelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena f. gypsothelia [female]: Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza, 1921: 7. Tonkin. Papilio helena cerberus f. cerberus [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. azelia [female]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Papilio helena cerberus f. gypsothelia [male]: Metaye, 1957: 80. N. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Kondo & Nishida, 1998: 100. Vietnam. Troides Helena euthycrates: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. Indochina generally, Vietnam. Troides Helena Cerberus: Ikeda et al, 1998 (21): 13. Fig. 3/3-4: [male] Up & [female] Up, Fig. 9/2: [male] genitalia. N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Troides Helena euthycrates: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. N. Vietnam. ssp. cerberus - Assam (Sylhet). Troides Helena cerberus Felder, 1865. Reise der Oster. Freg. Novarra um die Erde Zool., Lep., Rhop., (1): 19. Syntype [female] preserved in BMNH. Troides Helena cerberus: Haugum & Low, 1982-85, V.2: 249. S. Vietnam. Troides helena cerberus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003b: 10. C. & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS . Ssp. Cerberus Felder, 1864 has the following synonyms: pompeus Gray (1852); ruficollis Butler, 1877; Hephaestus Distant, 1885 (TL: Celebes), f. male Cerberus Jordan, 1908; f. male eumagos Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female azelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Assam); f. female gypsothelia Jordan, 1908 (TL: Tenasserim). RANGE. C. Nepal and N. India through Burma to Indochina and s. China on the continent, and from the Andaman and Nicobar Islands to Sumbawa, Sulawesi and Tukangbesi in the archipelago. There are a number of subspecies in Sunda Islands (Haugum & Low, 1982-85). DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. Ssp. euthycrates: N. Vietnam : Cho Moi (ex coll. MNHN), Than Moi; Hanoi; Na Hang N.R., Ba Be N.P.,Tam Dao N.P., Ba Vi N.P., Cue Phuong N.P., Cat Ba N.P., Bai Tu Long N.p. C . Vietnam : Pu Huong N.R., Ben En N.P., Pu Mat N.R., Vu Quang N.R. Ssp. Cerberus: c. Vietnam : Nui Chua N.R., Bi Doup/Nui Ba N. R., Da Teh SFE. s. Vietnam : Dong Sai (ex. Metaye coll., MNHN ); Cat Tien N.p. (Cat Loc). The species is variable in size and wing pattern. In particular, the number of submarginal spots on the H W of males varies from a complete series in spaces 2-6 to entirely absent. Length of FW: [male] 65-82 mm; [female] 75-95 mm. TAXONOMIC NOTES . Following the concept offered by Haugum & Low (1978-85) type specimens of ssp. euthycrates (N. Vietnam) are rather distinctive and may be distinguished from Cerberus (S. Vietnam): “Male...fairly large, perhaps slightly lager than Cerberus... The abdomen is as in Cerberus but somewhat darker laterally and dorsally. Female... H W with a complete row of black spots, which are notably triangular and also much larger than in Cerberus... Abdomen is as in Cerberus, but darker towards base” . In reality, the females from southern populations have more oval spots while in the specimens from N. and northern part of C. Vietnam spots are more elongated and pointed (Plate l-b,d). The form azelia Jordan, mentioned by Dubois & Vitalis de Salvaza (1921) from Tonkin is the dark form of the female with an uncompleted series of black submarginal spots (the type from Khasia Hills). HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. The species is locally common at low and moderate elevations (e.g. in Ba Vi N.P.; Cat Tien N.P.). The imago feeds on flowering Mussaenda (Rubiaceae), Lantana (Verbenaceae) and Cinnamomum (Lauraceae). The larvae feed on species of Aristolochiaceae, in particular Aristolochia tagala, A. griffithi, A. indica (Chou, 2000; Igarashi & Fukuda, 2000) and Thottea seliquoia in the Malay Peninsula (Corbet & Pendlebury, 1992). The female lays eggs singly on the upper surface of leaves or on the stems (Haribal, 1992). SIMILAR SPECIES. Troides aeacus differs from T. Helena in having the marginal black markings in spaces 2 ,3 and 4 of H W inwardly bordered by a dusting of black scales. CONSERVATION STATUS. All species of this genus are included in Appendix II of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES) (International commercial trade monitored through CITES permits)

Book: The Butterflies of Hong Kong
Distribution.Range: Hong Kong
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Tribe TROIDINI Aristolochia Papilios Size large Antennae unsealed, with paired depressions at base of each segment near ventral surface (except in Balt us Scopoli); club gradually formed. Mid and hind tibiae and tarsi unsealed, with shiny black surfaces. Male hindwing dorsum variable Male genitalia with eighth tergite and membrane between eighth and ninth tergites produced posteriorly as a pseuduncus, tegumen poorly developed and strongly attached to eighth tergite uncus absent; socii variable, usually immediately beneath pseuduncus and not strongly sclerotized. valvae variable. In females of Troides helena, Troides aeacus and Pacheopta aristolochiae the hindw ing dorsum is convex and weakly folded downwards. Development of the male hindwing dorsal fold is less constant than in the Graphiini. In the males of T. helena and T. aeacus the hindwing dorsum has a strong upward fold w hich contains large amounts of pale, pinkish brown scent wool but no long bristles. The dorsal margin of the fold has a strongly developed fringe of dark brown hairs. On abdominal segments 3, 4 and 5 there is a middorsal streak of specialized scales which are often abraded, even in only slightly worn specimens. The male hindwing fold of P. aristolochiae is as weak as that of the female and may be upwards or downwards. It contains neither scent wool nor bristles. The dorsal hair fringe is poorly developed and there is no area of specialized scales on the abdom en. The male of Parides alcinous has a well developed hindwing fold that contains black-brown, felt-like scent wool. Apart from Cressida Swainson (represented by one species in Australia) the Old World Troidini fall into two distinct but closely related groups. The Troides group includes the spectacular birdwings of the Papuan subregion and the Troides species with golden-yellow hindwings that range from Sulawesi and the Moluccas to as far north as the Himalayas. Members of the Parides group are smaller and predominantly black; they lack golden-yellow scales but frequently have carmine patches on the hindw ing as well as on the thorax and abdomen. The group includes Pachliopta and Parides. The larval foodplants are almost entirely Aristolochiaceae; these contain aristolochic acids, toxic substances that are selectively stored by the larvae and retained through the pupal stage into adulthood. The adults, with their yellow or carmine markings, are aposematic and act as distasteful models for several Papilionini and a few moths. The immature stages of Troides helena, T. aeacus and Pachliopta aristolochiae are known in Hong Kong. In these the eggs are smooth but thickly covered with a soft substance that appears to be identical to the cement securing the egg. In Troides it is a rich reddish brown and smoothly covers the egg like toffee on a toffee apple. In Pachliopta aristolochiae it is golden yellow and forms 14 vertical beaded ridges ending in an apical cone above the micropylar area. The substance is not water-repellent and does not cover the entire egg, so it possibly acts as either a necessary pabulum for the newly hatched larva, a chemical deterrent against parasitoids and small predators or simply as a means of rendering the otherwise white egg less conspicuous. The larvae have six rows of blunt fleshy tubercles with an extra pair on the mesothorax and metathorax. Their characteristic dark, non-reflective appearance is due to a dense carpet of extremely short hair-like cuticular processes covering all but the head, prothoracic plate and thoracic legs, which are thus shiny. The pale saddle on segments 3 and/or 4 appears in the second or third instar It is interesting to note that the Chalcosiinae (Zyygaenidae) have superficially similar tuberfled larvae and that Gynautocera papilionana (Chalcosnnae), a probable mimic of P. aristolochiae in Hong Kong, has a dull, dark larva with carmine-tipped tubercles like that of its mimetic partner The pupae have variable head horns, a dorsal thoracic hump and well developed dorsolateral abdominal tubercles or plates. Those of T. helena and P. aristolochiae arc* typical of their groups and quite dissimilar in appearance. The three Hong Kong genera are separated as follows: 1. Forewing origin of R, opposite origin of CuA Hindwing partly golden-yellow never with a tail Male hindwing dorsal fold and scent wool strongly developed Female bursa copulatrix with sclerotized areas but without a distinct signum (fig 6 33) Troides Forewing origin of R, well beyond origin of CuA Hindwing never with golden yellow scales may or may not have a tail Male hindwing dorsal fold and scent wool variably developed Female bursa copulatrix with a distinct signum (fig 6 37) 22. Male valva normally developed, socn not hypertrophied Female ductus bursae not heavily sclerotized Parides Male valva much reduced; socn large and heavily sclerotized Female ductus bursae heavily sclerotized Pachliopta [Fig. 6.31 Venation of Troides helena female.] [Fig 6 32 Troicles male genitalia A armature o i l helena minus left valva (eighth tergite and pseuduni us unladed) B right valva of T helena C the same at T aeacus (Seale bars = 1 mm.)] [Fig. 6.33 Bursa copularis of Troides helena x 12]

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Long-tailed Skipper
Distribution.Range: Visitor [to the Carolinas];  The but terfly is migratory, and moves southward each fall to overwinter in warmer portions of Florida
Abundance: Resembling a small swallowtail, the Longtailed Skipper is one of the most common and distinctive skippers in the Carolines.; They are fond of flowers and often abundant in home gardens.; common to abundant
Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, old fields, fallow agricultural land, utility easements, forest edges and gardens; They are fond of flowers and often abundant in home gardens.;
Oviposition: laid singly on the underside of host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: a wide variety of legumes includ ing beggarweeds, wisteria, beans and Kudzu
Adult.food: They are fond of flowers and often abundant in home gardens.
Phenology.and.voltinism: August - November; multiple generations
Defense.strategies: The larvae construct indi vidual shelters on the host by folding over small sections of a leaf with silk. Older larvae may use the entire leaf or connect several leaves together.
Mobility: The but terfly is migratory, and moves southward each fall to overwinter in warmer portions of Florida.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Long-tailed Skipper Urbanus proteus Comments: Resembling a small swallowtail, the Longtailed Skipper is one of the most common and distinctive skippers in the Carolines. Adults have a quick, low flight. They are fond of flowers and often abundant in home gardens. The larvae construct indi vidual shelters on the host by folding over small sections of a leaf with silk. Older larvae may use the entire leaf or connect several leaves together. The but terfly is migratory, and moves southward each fall to overwinter in warmer portions of Florida. Family/Subfamily: Skippers (Hesperiidae)/ Spread-wing Skippers (Pyrginae) Wingspan: 1.5-2.0" (3.8-5.1 cm) Above: brown with iridescent blue-green scaling on wing bases and body; long hindwing tail; forewing has sev eral semltransparent spots Below: brown; hindwing has two crisp dark brown bands; forewing has a continuous brown submarglnal band Sexes: similar Egg: pale yellow, laid singly on the underside of host leaves Larva: yellow-green with a dark dorsal stripe, yellow lat eral stripe and crimson head; body is covered with tiny black spots Larval Host Plants: a wide variety of legumes includ ing beggarweeds, wisteria, beans and Kudzu Habitat: open, disturbed sites including roadsides, old fields, fallow agricultural land, utility easements, forest edges and gardens Broods: multiple generations Abundance: common to abundant Compare: Dorantes Skipper (pg. 209) lacks iridescent blue-green dorsal coloration.

Book: Field Guide to the Skipper Butterflies of Illinois
Common.name: Long-tailed Skipper, Bean Leaf Rollers
Distribution.Range: Illinois is at the northern limit of the Long-tailed Skipper… It is a permanent resident in Florida and along the Gulf Coast to Texas  The Long-tailed Skipper occurs from Connecticut and the Midwest as a vagrant, regularly along the Gulf Coast, south through the Antilles, Mexico, and Central America to Argentina. [images]Champaign County, IL; Alexander County, IL
Abundance: occurs [in Illinois] only as a rare vagrant in the late summer and fall. permanent resident in Florida and along the Gulf Coast to Texas, where the larvae, called Bean Leaf Rollers, are sometimes serious economic pests of beans.
Flight.characteristics: they will dart out at passing insects that may be conspecific females.
Habitat: Open areas, agricultural areas, roadsides, old fields, disturbed sites, forest edges. The Long-tailed Skipper is a perching species, males take stations several feet above ground on plants along forest edges or in brushy areas
Oviposition: Females lay eggs on legumes, especially climbing species, and preferably on beans (Phaseolus spp.).
Hostplant.larval.food: Females lay eggs on legumes, especially climbing species, and preferably on beans (Phaseolus spp.).  Many related species also are larval food plants.
Phenology.and.voltinism: In the south, where the species survives winter conditions, adults are present all year. There, two or more generations occur. Further north the species is a summer and fall resident only. Illinois is at the northern limit of the Long-tailed Skipper and the species occurs here only as a rare vagrant in the late summer and fall.
Defense.strategies: Each larva constructs a shelter formed from a leaf rolled and tied by silken threads.
Author: andra.doherty

Full.Species.Account: Phalanta phalantha (Drury, [1773]) (Plate 36, fig. 8)  Spotted Rustic  • Other common names. Leopard. • Description. Wingspan: male 46 mm; female 46 mm. Upperside: bright orange, with numerous brown-black spot and brown-black subterminal and terminal lines. Underside: ground colour orange-brown, with brown markings, and outer half richly suffused with lilac; fore wing with a prominent dark brown subtornal spot. The sexes are best distinguished by examination of the genitalia and the fore leg. • Variation. A number of subspecies have been recognised. Only P. p. araca (Waterhouse & Lyell, 1914) is found in the Australian subregion, where it is endemic. It is quite variable in the extent of the lilac suffusion on the underside. • Similar species. None. This small northern species is distinguished by the bright orange ground colour on the upperside extensively spotted with dark markings. • Immature stages. Egg: bright yellow; with prominent longitudinal ribs. Larva: body bright green, with branched black spines; head smooth, without prominent spines, brownblack anteriorly and yellow dorsally. Pupa (Fig. 30K): 16 mm long; rich green, with golden markings; anterior end truncate, head with two dorsal golden spots and two lateral golden spots, each edged with red; thorax with two short golden conical dorsal projections edged with red, and a pair of similar dorsal spots, fore wing with a golden dorsal margin edged with red; abdominal segments 3, 5, 7 and 8 each with a golden dorsolateral conical projection tipped with black and basally edged with red. • Larval food plants. Flacourtia territorialis (Flacourtiaceae); introduced plants include Flacourtia inermis, F. rukam (Flacourtiaceae). The natural food plant is Flacourtia territorialis (listed as F. indica) (Common and Waterhouse 1981; Sankowsky 1991; Meyer 1996a), but larvae also commonly feed on ornamental F. inermis (G. Martin) and F. rukam (S. Collins) at Darwin. In captivity, larvae will also accept Scolopia braunii (C. E. Meyer). • Life cycle and behaviour. Eggs are laid singly on the young leaves and stems of the larval food plant (Common and Waterhouse 1981). The larva is very active and grows rapidly, feeding only on new soft growth. The pupa is suspended, head downwards, at an angle of about 30° to the leaf surface, attached by the cremaster beneath a leaf of the food plant. The pupa, as in Vagrans egista and Cupha prosope, is very beautiful, and in its natural surroundings is well camouflaged. Adults usually fly close to the ground near the larval food plant, bur sometimes fly rapidly near the tree tops and settle on the upper parts of the trees. Adults have been recorded during most month of the year. At the Daly River they were very abundant in May, but less oat other time of the year (J. Hutchinson 1978). They are abundant seasonally at Darwin, being most numerous in the late dry season and again after the wet season when the food plant produce copious new growth (C.E. Meyer). The life cycle at Darwin is completed in about two week (egg 2 days, larva 7 days, pupa 4 days) (Common and Waterhouse 1981). • Distribution and habitat. This species ranges widely in tropical Africa and Madagascar, from India and southern Japan, through South-east Asia to northern Australia (Common and Waterhouse 1981). P. p. araca is restricted to the northern NT, where it occurs from near the South Alligator River and Daly River north-west to Cobourg Peninsula (Common and Waterhouse 1981 ). P. phalantha is common seasonally and locally in coastal and riparian monsoon forest (vine thicket) where the natural larval food plant grows. It also breeds in suburban gardens at Darwin if the food plants are present (C.E. Meyer; T.L. Fenner).

Book: The Butterflies of Papua New Guinea: Their Systematics and Biology
Distribution.Range: throughout the Solomons...NG...Australia
Author: Micael.Itliong
Full.Species.Account: Genus VINDULA Hemming, 1934 Vindula contains only 4 (probably 3) fairly large, predominantly lowland species. The genus is distributed throughout the Indo- Australian Region, from Sri Lanka and India to South-east Asia and the Philippines, eastwards throughout Indonesia to the Moluccas, Kai, Am, Waigeo, Biak, mainland NG, various outlying islands in PNG, the Bismarcks, Solomons, and the east coast of north-eastern Australia (as far south as Makay, Queensland). Both Roepke (1938) and Nieuwenhuis (1962) refined the taxonomy of Vindula, initially assumed by Fruhstorfer (1899d), who figured the male genitalia of all species, to represent a single species, but later treated by Fruhstorfer (1912- 15, in Seitz), as 4 species. Thus, according to Fruhstorfer, 2 Vindula species occur in NG, 1 of which (sapor) is endemic to the Solomons, the other (

Full.Species.Account: Ypthima baldus (Fabricius, 1775) Plate 31, figs. 3a-g Syst. Entomologiae, [iv]+[xii]+[xvi]+829 pp. (Papilio). TYPE LOCALITY. The nominate ssp. - India Papilio baldus Fabricius, 1775: 829. India Ypthima baldus f. aest. baldus: Metaye, 1957: 102. N. Vietnam. Ypthima baldus f. marshalli: Metaye, 1957: 102. N. Vietnam. Ypthima baldus: Ikeda et al., 1999: 57, figs. 6-14 [Male] (Up), 6-15 [Male] (Un), 6-16 [Female] (Up), 9-32 ([Male] genitalia). N. Vietnam (Cue Phuong). Ypthima baldus baldus: Monastyrskii & Devyatkin, 2003c: 20. N., C. & S. Vietnam. Ypthima baldus baldus: Uemura & Monastyrskii, 2004: 26, Figs. 2o-r, 6.4, 6.5. N., C & S. Vietnam. SYNONYMS. Y. marshalli Butler, 1882 (TL: Sikkim, Bhutan). RANGE. The species is distributed veiy widely from the N.W. Himalayas to Taiwan and through Burma and Thailand to the Malay Peninsula, Borneo, Natuna, Sumatra, Java and Bawean. DISTRIBUTION AND VARIATION IN VIETNAM. N. Vietnam: Hoang Lien N.P., Van Ban P.N.R., Muong Nhe N. R., Tam Dao N.P, Cue Phuong N. P, Ba Vi N. P, Ba Be N. P, Na Hang N. R., Cat Ba (Is.) N. P. C. Vietnam: Ben En N. P, Pu Hoat N. R., Pu Mat N. R., Vu Quang N. R., Phong Dien N. R., Bach Ma N. P, Ba Na N. R., Ngoc Linh N. R., Kon Cha Rang N. R., Kon Ka Kinh N. R., Dac Lac Province : Ban Me Thuot, Daray Sap Waterfall (500m), Da Lat, Bao Loc, Cat Tien N.P. (Cat Loc), Da Teh SFE. S. Vietnam: La Nga SFE, Nghia Trung SFE, Lo Go Sa Mat N.R., Loc Ninh, Phu Quoc N.R. This species is variable in size and wing pattern depending on season and locality. For example, the length of the FW in specimens from Lao Cai and Bac Can is 16.0-19.0mm, while specimens from Ba Vi are more than 20.0mm  TAXONOMIC NOTES. According to Aoki et al., 1982 and Uemura & Monastyrskii (2004) populations from Indochina belong to the nominate ssp. At the same time it is possible that populations from some sites of N. Vietnam belong to ssp. gallienus Fruhstorfer, 1911 (TL: Hainan). Specimens from Lao Cai and Bac Can provinces of both seasonal forms are small in size and have coarser striation on the Un. This phenotype shows some similarity with ssp. ishigakina Fruhstorfer, 1908 from Taiwan. The genitalia armature and androconia are shown in Figures 35 and 41p, q, r, s. HABITAT AND BIOLOGY. Habitats. Pu Hoat: secondary vegetation, scrub; Pu Mat: secondary vegetation up to 800m. Muong Nhe: secondary vegetation at 300 to 500m; Ngoc Linh: grassland forest paths at 1,000 to 1,600m; Kon Ka Kinh: grassland at 800-1,200m. Most other populations may be easily seen in secondary vegetation and disturbed areas. This species flies all the year round. The larvae feed on Microstegium ciliatum and Pogonatherum crinitum (both Poaceae) (Bascombe et al., 1999). SIMILAR SPECIES. Y. singorensis and Y nebulosa. The former species is smaller in size and much whiter on the Un. Both species have similar genitalia structures and shape of the androconial scales (Figures 36, 37 and 41s, t, u, v)

Distribution.Range: Guatemala to Panama Pacific drainage in Guanacaste Parque Santa Rosa
Abundance: commonest on the Pacific drainage in Guanacaste, it is most abundant in the early rainy season, but is present throughout the year In Parque Santa Rosa, the white form of the female is most common during the dry season
Flight.characteristics: fast flier that stays close to the ground and is very wary when at rest of visiting flowers
Habitat: open areas or second growth
Oviposition: Females oviposit at midday, usually on seedling hostplants
Hostplant.larval.food: Indigofera, Trifolium, Medicago (Fabaceae)
Adult.food: visit flowers of Lantana, Stachytarpheta, Combretum, and Malvaviscus
Phenology.and.voltinism: these individuals (white form of the female in Parque Santa Rosa) are in reproductive diapause until the rains come in May
Diapause: pupa (in the north temperature regions)

Book: Butterflies of the Carolinas
Common.name: Southern Dogface
Distribution.Range: Visitor [to the Carolinas];
Abundance: rare to occasional;
Flight.characteristics: the Dogface is a medium-sized butterfly with a powerful, rapid flight
Habitat: open, dry sites including pastures, pineland, oak scrub, old fields and roadsides
Oviposition: laid singly on host leaves
Hostplant.larval.food: False Indigo, Summer Farewell
Phenology.and.voltinism: June - September [low contrast chart]; multiple generations;  They [adults] overwinter in reproductive diapause.
Diapause: They [adults] overwinter in reproductive diapause.
Author: vaughn.shirey
Full.Species.Account: Southern Dogface Zerene cesonia Family/Subfamily: Whites and Sulphurs (Pieridae)/ Sulphurs {Coliadinae) Wingspan: 1.9-2.5° (4.8-6.4 cm) Above: yellow; forewing pointed with broad, black mar gin highly scalloped to form image of dog's head in profile, single back cell spot and increased black scal ing on basal area; hindwing has narrow black margin Below: hindwings seasonally variable; summer-form is yellow with two small silver spots; winter-form has increased rosy-pink scaling Sexes: similar, although black markings duller and less extensive on female Egg: white, laid singly on host leaves Larva: variable; plain green to green with orange lateral stripe and transverse black and yellow stripes Larval Host Plants: False Indigo, Summer Farewell Habitat: open, dry sites including pastures, pineland, oak scrub, old fields and roadsides Broods: multiple generations Abundance: rare to occasional Compare: All other Carolines sulphurs lack the pointed forewing apex. Comments: The only Carolina sulphur with pointed forewings, the Dogface is a medium-sized butterfly with a powerful, rapid flight. It is named after the unique pattern formed by the black and yellow mark ings on the wings above that resemble (with some imagination) the head of a dog in profile. Adults display considerable seasonal variation. Winter-forms are par ticularly stunning with rich pink scaling on the wings beneath. They overwinter in reproductive diapause.

Distribution.Range: Cuba... Z. cesonia cesonia, the N. American mainland subspecies, occurs freely in open country in western Cuba, e.g. Matanzas, St Cristobal, Holguin, etc. In Hispaniola it is replaced by Z. cesonia cynops Butler 1873... RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: Georgia.

Adult.forms: In the dry (winter) season form, which is rare in Cuba, the hindwing beneath and the apex of the forewing are flushed with rosy pink, f. rosea Roeber 1909.
Author: andra.doherty
Full.Species.Account: ZERENE CESONIA Stoll 1790 Dog Face Butterfly Pl. 13 syn. Meganostoma cesonia Description. Fw [male] 29-33 mm, [female] 25-34 mm. The sexes very similar but the 'dog face' outline rather less sharply defined in the female than in the male. Underside yellow, but with the black pattern of the upperside clearly showing through. In the dry (winter) season form, which is rare in Cuba, the hindwing beneath and the apex of the forewing are flushed with rosy pink, f. rosea Roeber 1909. Distribution. Z. cesonia cesonia, the N. American mainland subspecies, occurs freely in open country in western Cuba, e.g. Matanzas, St Cristobal, Holguin, etc. In Hispaniola it is replaced by Z. cesonia cynops Butler 1873, which is rather more orange-yellow above and below, and has the black dusting at the base of the forewing much reduced in extent and confined to the anterior part of the cell, or, in the female, sometimes absent. RANGE: southern U.S.A. to Argentina. TL: Georgia. Early stages. Caterpillar grey-green above, olive-green below, with numerous small black tubercles, marked with transverse and longitudinal yellow and black lines which vary greatly in intensity. Food plant (in U.S.A.) False Indigo (Amorpha fruticosa) and Clovers (Trifolium); multibrooded.

Book: A Field Guide to Western Butterflies (Peterson Field Guides)
Common.name: SOUTHERN DOGFACE
Distribution.Range: Sonora state, Mex. Resident from S. Amer. north through Cen. Amer. and s. U.S. (s. Tex. and peninsular Fla.). Irregular colonist and temporary resident northward, occasionally reaching Alb., n. Calif., Nev., Utah, se. Wyo., s. Man., s. Ont., and N.J. Sierra Juarez of Baja Calif.
Habitat: Various open places; thorn scrub, deserts, brushy hills, prairie hills, and weedy pastures.
Hostplant.larval.food: [image] Southern Dogface caterpillar feeding on Calliandra, Sonora state, Mex. Many legumes, including leadplant, indigo-bush, prairie-clovers, false indigo, and others.
Phenology.and.voltinism: All months in Deep South and s. Tex., 2 flights during May-Aug. and overwintering adults (Aug.—April). Colonists to north either do not reproduce or bring off only 1  adult generation before winter.
Diapause: overwintering adults
Adult.forms: Two seasonal forms. Underside: Summer form has hindwing yellow, that of winter form has dark and pink mottling.
Author: andra.doherty

Book: Alberta Butterflies
Common.name: Dog Face
Distribution.Range: The permanent range of the Dog Face extends from the southern United States to Argentina, but as the adult flies rapidly, it commonly wanders northward into many of the temperate areas of the United States. Two specimens were collected in Manitoba, both prior to 1942. Our single record from Alberta was collected at Didsbury and represents a major range extension for this species.
Habitat: open, dry prairie habitats
Hostplant.larval.food: Larvae of the Dog Face are reported to feed on members of the pea family (Leguminosae), including clovers (Trifolium spp.), prairie clover (Petalostemon spp.) and Alfalfa (Medicago sativa).
Phenology.and.voltinism: A single adult was collected in Alberta by Art Rupp, sometime in 1944. This species can only survive the winter in the southern United States and must recolonize most of its range each year. should be watched for in late summer.
Author: elise.larsen

Book: THE EARLY STAgES AND NATURAL HISTORY OF Corades medeba HEWITSON, 1850 IN EASTERN ECUADOR (LEPIDOPTERA: NYMPHALIDAE: SATYRINAE: PRONOPHILINA)
Distribution.Range: Venezuelan Cordillera de Me_rida, throughout Colombia and Ecuador to northernmost Peru (Pyrcz 2004)
Elevation: flying generally at elevations from 2000 to 2400 m
Abundance: Corades medeba is one of the most abundant pronophiline butterflies at our study site. aggregating in large numbers at water seeps or dung.
Flight.characteristics: flying rapidly over areas dominated by their food plant or feeding on the ground at mammal feces. They fly out and chase all passing butterflies, and even dragonflies and other large insects. Adults fly on most days, even in light rain, but are most common on sunny days.
Habitat: Adults are most frequently found along roads and open trails feeding on urine- enriched sand or dung. flying rapidly over areas dominated by their food plant or feeding on the ground at mammal feces. aggregating in large numbers at water seeps or dung. Males guard perches near areas of food plant, usually in sunny areas or forest edges.
Oviposition: Eggs are laid singly (n = 2) or in groups of 4 (n = 1), 5 (n = 2), or 8 (n = 2) to 11 (n = 1) on the lower surface of mature leaves. When searching for ovipostion sites the flight of females is fast and erratic. They drop suddenly onto the host plant and oviposit by curling their abdomen under a leaf. They rarely or never appear to test host leaves by rapping their forelegs as seen in other nymphalids (DeVries 1987).
Hostplant.larval.food: Chusquea cf. scandens (Poaceae, Bambusoidea)
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Adults fly on most days, even in light rain, but are most common on sunny days.
Defense.strategies: When disturbed, larvae rear back and try to bite the offending object, usually dropping from the plant if disturbed further.

Book: The life cycle of Oressinoma typhla Doubleday, [1849] (Lepidoptera: Nymphalidae: Satyrinae)

Distribution.Range: Oressinoma typhla is distributed from Costa Rica through Colombia to Venezuela, and south through the Andes to Bolivia (DeVries, 1987; Warren et al., 2017).
Elevation: It occurs between about 600 and 2,200 m in elevation (most frequently between about 1,200 and 1,800m) on mountain slopes
Abundance: it is common and widespread in premontane and cloud forest habitat
Flight.characteristics: The adults have a slow and somewhat bouncy flight,
Habitat: it is common and widespread in premontane and cloud forest habitat, especially along road edges (human-altered spaces which its host plant occupies), naturally disturbed areas such as landslides, and frequently close to water bodies (pers. obs.; pers. comm. from A. Aiello in Panama, M. Costa and F. Romero in Venezuela, Y. Gareca in Bolivia, G. Lamas in Peru, and K. Willmott in Ecuador; DeVries, 1987; Petit, 2017).
Oviposition: Oressinoma typhla females lay individual eggs on the upperside of leaves towards their distal end.
Hostplant.larval.food: DeVries (1987) gives Cyperus luzulae (Linnaeus) Retzius in Costa Rica, Murray (2001) notes Cyperus sp. in Ecuador, while here we report C. involucratus Rottbll from Venezuela (Cyperaceae).
Adult.food: feed on decomposing fruit and fungi, and males are occasionally attracted to dung and rotting fish bait (pers. obs.; K. Willmott, pers. comm.; DeVries, 1987). We have personally not observed or seen reports of feeding on nectar sources; however there are some photographs published on the internet of this species feeding on small flowers in Colombia and Ecuador.

Book: Muyshondt, Alberto. "Notes on the Life Cycle and Natural History of Butterflies of El Salvador II A. Epiphile adrasta adrasta (Nymphalidae-Catonephelinae)."Journal of the New York Entomological Society(1973): 214-223.
Distribution.Range: El Salvador
Flight.characteristics: Males and females of E. adrasta adrasta are swift flyers. The females are seen more often because they fly slowly slowly and at low levels when looking for the foodplant on which to oviposit. The female flights under a mature leaf of the foodplant and deposits one egg on the underside of it.
Habitat: Adults of Epiphile adrasta adrasta Hewitson frequent wooded ravines and creeks where second-growth plant communities are found, usually in the proximity of coffee plantations, which can be considered manmade forests, (about the only forests left in the country).
Oviposition: The eggs of E. adrasta adrasta are deposited singly on the undersides of mature leaves. Several eggs are laid on a single vine, but never more than one egg on the same leaf. Oviposition occurs from late in the morning to early in the afternoon.
Hostplant.larval.food: eggs and larvae have been found on several spe cies of Sapindaceae vines belonging to the genera Paullinia, Serjania, Urvil lea, and Cardiospermum, with a definite predilection for Paullinia fuscescens, H.B.K.
Adult.food: The adults of this species are not flower visitors, but feed greedily on rot ten fruits and animal excrements on the ground and on the sap from tree trunk wounds. When feeding, the adults lose their habitual alertness and are then easily netted.
Phenology.and.voltinism: In early Septembers the adults emerge. Since that time we have reared this species from egg to adult a number of times, from the beginning of the rainy season to mid-dry season (June to March).
Defense.strategies:
Epiphile adrasta adrasta larvae, feeding on plants known to contain nar cotic/poisonous properties, would be expected to be unpalatable to predators and therefore to have the gaudy coloration associated with that condition. In fact the first and second instar larvae of this species seem to rely on crypsis for their defense rather than on the presumable
 protection derived frmo the food plant. The adults also could be expected to be chemically protected by the food plant derivatives, but even if they are so protected, they do not rely solely on that for their survival; they also exploit their fast and erratic flight, combining it with the flash-and-hide effect obtained from the contrast between
 their brilliant dorsal colors and the dull brown color of the hindwings, which almost completely cover the forewings when at rest.
Adult.forms: Wing shape the same in both sexes: forewing with projected angle at apex, then a short concavity followed by a long convexity to tornus; inner margin straight. Hind wing rounded with sinuose outer margin. Drastic difference in dorsal colors between males and females.

Book: Velez, Patricia Duque, Hugo Hernando Vargas Montoya, and Marta Wolff. "Immature stages and natural history of the Andean butterfly Altinote ozomene (Nymphalidae: Heliconiinae: Acraeini)."Zoologia (Curitiba)28.5 (2011): 593-602.
Distribution.Range: Colombia
Abundance: species are abundant in the study area, especially in open areas, scrub and forest edges and along stream margins, paths and tracks (TORO 2000).
Habitat: species are abundant in the study area, especially in open areas, scrub and forest edges and along stream margins, paths and tracks (TORO 2000). Altinote ozomene adults were normally observed in open areas and at forest edges. Males (Fig. 25) fly low, frequently alighting on the ground, and can be caught by hand. Adults form small groups of four or five individuals while feeding on the ground or on avian (duck) excrement on the banks of a reservoir.
Oviposition: Eggs were laid in clusters on the undersides of leaves. Females typically alighted on the underside of the leaf around noon and remained there for over 2.5 hours, laying eggs (Fig. 3). Eggs and/or larvae were often found concentrated on plants within close proximity. Eggs were sometimes laid on plants where eggs or larvae were already present (up to two egg clutches were found on the same plant), generally on different leaves on large plants, and rarely on the same leaf. The number of eggs in each clutch varied from 100 to 380 (n = 39 clutches). Several clutches included four or five infertile eggs (Fig. 6). Larvae from clutches that contained fewer than 30 viable eggs (either because oviposition was interrupted or because most of the eggs died from fungal attack) died within the first three instars.
Hostplant.larval.food: Erato vulcanica(Klatt) H.Rob andMunnozia senecionidisBenth (Asteraceae)
Phenology.and.voltinism: Since 2004, we have foundAl. ozomenefrequently throughout the year, at low densities, except during the second half of 2005, when no adults or immature stages were found.
Defense.strategies: Larvae were gregarious during all instars but rested together only during the day in later instars, either hidden inside dry leaves, on the stem at the base of the host plants, or in the leaf litter.

grass land.  The M. jurtina captured in copula at Hightown were located in areas with vegetation of

Book: Davies, Nicholas B. "Territorial defence in the speckled wood butterfly (Pararge aegeria): the resident always wins."Animal Behaviour26 (1978): 138-147.
Distribution.Range: UK
Habitat: woodland species
Daily.or.circadian.patterns: Speckled woods spent the night high up in the tree tops, 5 to 15 m off the ground . The first signs of activity were seen early in the morning as the warmth of the sun reached the foliage of the woodland canopy. The butterflies opened their wings and orientated towards the sun to warm up. Between 07.00 and 08.00 hours B.S .T. a few could be seen flying about the tree tops and then gradually, over the next hour or two, the males descended to ground level where the sun's rays began to cast pools of sunlight onto the woodland floor . From this time on, throughout the day until early evening, males could be seen fluttering in these sunny pools . It was rare to see any in the shady part of the wood and it seems likely that the sunny spots were preferred because it was here that there was sufficient warmth to enable the butterflies to remain active

Phenology.and.voltinism: Dry season form (DSF) adults appeared in October and formed a small peak in January. Wet season form (WSF) adults appeared in March and showed a first peak in May. After May its number began to decline strikingly and very few number of WSF was found in the month of June to September thereafter population began to rise again and formed second peak in October. The second peak of WSF was higher than first peak of WSF which occurred in May. The peak of the DSF which occurred in January was far lower compared to the first and second peak of WSF adults. The transition period of WSF to DSF was October and the transitions of DSF to WSF were found to occur in March
Adult.forms: dry season morph to wet season morph and reverse in the butterfly species, Appias libythea

Book: Li, Chengzhe, et al. "Role of visual and olfactory cues in sex recognition in butterfly Cethosia cyane cyane."Scientific reports7.1 (2017): 1-9.
Adult.forms: C. cyane cyaneis a medium-sized butterfly and is sexual dimorphic in wing coloration. Males and females showed large differences in the dorsal coloration of both the forewing and hindwing, but little difference in the ventral coloration. The postmedian forewing and discal area of the hindwing is red-orange in males, but faint yellow in females. A single oblique transverse band appears in the subterminal region of the forewing in both sexes (Fig.4A). The UV reflectivity of the white stripes was strong, with no difference between males and females. And the UV reflectivity of the ventral hindwings was also strong, with little difference between males and females. However, there was a large difference in the UV reflectivity of the dorsal hindwings, females reflecting more UV light than males (Fig.4B), indicating that males might distinguish the gender of conspecifics using these UV reflectance differences.

Book: Hojo, Masaru K., et al. "Chemical disguise as particular caste of host ants in the ant inquiline parasite Niphanda fusca (Lepidoptera: Lycaenidae)."Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences276.1656 (2009): 551-558.
Phenology.and.voltinism: univoltine,  they spend approximately 10 months in the host ant nest
Diapause: pupa
Ant.associations:
Caterpillars of the lycaenid butterfly Niphanda fusca develop as parasites inside the nests of host ants (Camponotus japonicus) where they grow by feeding on the worker trophallaxis. d the
newly hatched caterpillars initially feed on excretions of the aphids tended by the Japanese monogynous carpenter ant Camponotus japonicus.  The caterpillars are carried by C. japonicus workers into their nest when they reach the third instar. They are fed by ant worker trophallaxis to grow (figure S1 in the electronic supplementary material) and pupate inside the ant nest after hibernation.

Oviposition:
Jalmenus evagoras are far more likely to lay eggs on plants that contain their attendant ants, Iridomyrmex sp. 25 than on plants without ants, although the clutch sizes of individual
egg masses laid in either situation is the same.  Ovipositing females prefer to lay eggs on plants that contain ant tended homopterans than on plants that contain only a few foraging ants.
Hostplant.larval.food: It has been recorded to feed on at least 16 species of Acacia (Hawkeswood 1981; this study)
Ant.associations: tended by several species of Iridomyrmex ants. This ant is polygynous and polydomous, occurring in vast colonies with nest entrances established at the base of almost every plant bearing larvae of J. evagoras.
